column1: Wal-Mart reports Q4 earnings February 21;2/18/2017;"What's HappeningRetail giant Wal-Mart (WMT) is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter results on February 21. The company will report its quarterly numbers before the market opens
column2: with the consensus calling for earnings of $1.30 per share
column3: on revenue of $130.97 billion. The stock has risen a modest 0.3% on the year.Technical AnalysisWMT was recently trading at $68.87
column4: down $6.32 from its 12-month high and $6.52 above its 12-month low. Technical indicators for WMT are bearish but the stock is showing signs of a possible trend reversal. The stock has recent support above $65.50 and recent resistance below $69.25. Of the 23 analysts who cover the stock
column5: eight rate it a ""strong buy""
column6: 12 rate it a ""hold""
column7: and three rate it a ""strong sell"". The stock receives S&P Capital IQ's 5 STARS ""Strong Buy"" ranking.Analyst's ThoughtsWMT shares have been trending higher over the last month
column8: but in order for the stock to build on its recent gains the company will need to show solid results for its fourth-quarter. Brick and mortar retailers have been punished in recent years by growing e-commerce competition
column9: most notably from Amazon.com (AMZN)
column10: but Wal-Mart has made big strides in recent years to improve its online business. The company has invested a lot of money in its online business
column11: and Wall Street wants to see ongoing improvements in the company's online business. Last quarter the company reported a 21 percent jump in online sales
column12: much stronger growth than the 12 percent gain it enjoyed the previous quarter. Wall Street will pay close attention to the how strongly online sales grew in the most recent quarter. In addition to the company investing heavily in its e-commerce business
column13: it has also been investing a lot in its employees
column14: with additional training and wage hikes
column15: which most analysts agree is starting to result in higher customer satisfaction
column16: but the investments are hurting the company's bottom line in the short term. Earnings are expected to fall by 5.9% this year
column17: before remain relatively flat in 2018. The earnings decline has been priced into the stock
column18: which now trades with a P/E of just 14.9
column19: so as long as the company is able to post results at least in-line with the consensus the stock should continue to make back some of its recent gains.Stock Only TradeIf you're looking to establish a long stock position in WMT
column20: consider buying the stock under $69.00. Sell if it falls below $62.10 or take profits if it gets to $79.25.Bullish TradeIf you want to set up a bullish hedged trade on WMT
column21: consider an April 60/62.50 bull-put credit spread for a 20-cent credit. That's a potential 8.7% return (50.4% annualized*) and the stock would have to fall 9.0% to cause a problem.Bearish TradeIf you want to take a bearish stance on DE at this time
column22: consider a June 75/77.50 bear-call credit spread for a 30-cent credit. That's a potential 13.6% return (41.8% annualized*) and the stock would have to rise 9.3% to cause a problem.Covered Call TradeIf you like the stock
column23: but wish to lower your cost basis on a new position
column24: you may want to consider an April $70.00 covered call. Buy WMT shares (typically 100 shares
column25: scale as appropriate)
column26: while selling the April $70.00 call for a debit of $67.50 per share. The trade has a target assigned return of 3.7%
column27: and a target annualized return of 21.6% (for comparison purposes only)."

column1: The Best Investments for an IRA;2/18/2017;"An IRA is a fantastic way to build long-term wealth
column2: but it   can be tricky knowing which stocks or ETFs are best to own in   one. There are thousands of publicly traded companies and ETFs to   choose from
column3: and they don't all deserve a spot in your portfolio.   How do you separate the good from the bad? It can help to   establish some ground rules. For example
column4: are you a growth   investor
column5: income investor
column6: or value investor? Or are you a little   bit of each? OurIRA centercan help you figure out what approach is best for you
column7: and   then
column8: it's time to get down to picking investments. To help get   you started
column9: here's one growth
column10: one income
column11: and one value   investment I think you ought to consider buying in your IRA.Getting in on growthIf your time horizon is 10 years
column12: 20 years
column13: or longer
column14: investing in companies that are reshaping big and growing   industries can be savvy. Disruptive companies can deliver   significant revenue and profit growth that can fuel   market-beating gains. For example
column15: Alphabettransformed how we search and use information
column16: Pricelineturned the travel market inside out
column17: andNetflixre-envisioned how we consume video entertainment. In each of   these cases
column18: investors savvy enough to tuck these stocks into   their IRAs were rewarded with massive returns: Since 2004
column19: these   three companies are up 745%
column22: and 8
column24: respectively.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();While any one of those stocks could still be worth buying in   IRAs today
column25: I thinkAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) might be an even better bet. Amazon is reshaping   retail
column26: and I think there's plenty of room left for sales to   climb. Why? Because
column27: according to the Census Bureau
column28: e-commerce sales account for just 8.4% of total retail sales
column29: and   that's despite their growing 15% in the past year. I think   e-commerce companies will continue chipping away at traditional   retail
column30: and if I'm right
column31: then perhaps there's no company better   positioned to benefit than Amazon. The company's already the   biggest e-commerce company out there
column32: and in 2016
column33: Amazon's net sales increased 27% to $136 billion. That's   pretty amazing growth for a company its size
column34: but it may only be   the tip of the iceberg. After all
column35: Amazon's revenue is still only   one-third ofWal-Mart'srevenue.Amazon also manages data in the cloud for many of the   country's biggest companies
column36: and its Amazon Prime service is   carving out an important presence in entertainment. If you're   still not convinced
column37: simply consider that Amazon's virtual   assistant -- Alexa -- may only hint at how Amazon thinks it can   transform our lives in the future.Dividend heroesHistorically
column38: stocks that pay dividends outperform their   non-dividend paying peers
column39: and because IRAs are tax-advantaged
column40: those dividend payments can compound over time and potentially   boost your retirement nest egg.As a refresher
column41: traditional IRAs are funded with pre-tax   dollars
column42: and dividends paid to investors on investments held in   traditional IRAs aren't taxed until they're withdrawn in   retirement. Alternatively
column43: a Roth IRA is funded with after-tax   dollars
column44: so dividends paid on investments held in them may never   be subject to income taxes
column45: as long as you follow the rules   regarding withdrawals. Additionally
column46: unlike traditional IRAs
column47: investors don't have to make withdrawals from a Roth IRA during   their lifetime
column48: so owningdividend   stocksin Roth IRAs can really make a lot of sense.If income investing sounds like your cup of tea
column49: one way to go   about owning dividend-paying companies in your IRA is to buy theProshares S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats ETF(NYSEMKT: NOBL) . This ETF owns about 50 mid- and large-sized   companies that have increased their dividend for at least 25   consecutive years. If you buy this ETF
column50: you'll gain exposure to   household names likeClorox
column51: McDonald's
column52: andWalgreens Boots Alliance. You'll also get exposure to many lesser-known top dividend   stocks like steelmakerNucor
column53: Inc.Buying a bargainWhen it comes to buying value stocks
column54: I'm a fan of buying   top-notch companies at fair prices. Thus
column55: it may not be   surprising that I think investors should own top-shelf healthcare   stocks in their IRA
column56: likePfizer
column57: Inc.(NYSE: PFE) .With over $50 billion in sales and about $15 billion in   adjusted income annually
column58: Pfizer is a world-class leader in drug   development and marketing
column59: and since 76 million baby boomers are   getting older and living longer
column60: the demographic argument for   owning Pfizer's shares is compelling.Admittedly
column61: drugmakers have gotten a lot of bad press lately   because of their decisions on drug prices
column62: but that bad press   means investors can get this top stock at a 12% discount to its   price last summer. Importantly
column63: because new drugs and savvy   acquisitions are fueling growth
column64: rising earnings means investors   are only paying about 12 times forward earnings estimates to buy   Pfizer's shares.Pfizer's dividend is another reason why this stock could be a   smart buy for an IRA. Last year
column65: the company returned $12 billion   to investors via share buybacks and dividends
column66: and in December
column67: Pfizer's board of directors declared a $0.32 first-quarter   dividend that's 7% higher than last year. With a healthy dividend   yield of 3.93%
column68: I think this stock makes a lot of sense for IRAs.10 stocks we like better than PfizerWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column69: it can pay to listen. After all
column70: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column71: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column72: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Pfizer wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Does Thinking About Your IRA Give You Heartburn? Let Us Help;2/17/2017;"An IRA is a fantastic retirement saving tool
column2: but many   Americans don't take advantage of it
column3: and when they do
column4: they fail   to make the most of it. If you're among them
column5: don't worry. Here   are some rules to help you build a bigger nest egg with an   IRA.What are IRAs?As a refresher
column6: you can get big tax benefits by saving money   for retirement in a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA.In 2017
column7: you can set aside up to $5
column8: 500 of your earnings in   either a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA or a combination of the   two. If you're 50 years old or older
column9: then you can save up to   $6
column10: 500 of your earnings in an IRA.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.Traditional IRAs can be funded with pre-tax money
column16: which means   that money you put in now isn't taxed at your current tax rate.   Instead
column17: that money
column18: and any future gains
column19: are taxed when its   withdrawn. Because of this feature
column20: traditional IRAs can make   sense if you think your income tax rate in retirement will belowerthan it is today.Alternatively
column21: Roth IRAs are funded with after-tax money
column22: which means you're paying taxes on your contributions now so that   you can withdraw them -- and future gains -- tax-free in   retirement. Because of up-front taxation
column23: a Roth IRA can make   sense if you expect your income tax rate in retirement to behigherthan it is today.Some important IRA withdrawal rulesIn the case of a traditional IRA
column24: if you don't wait until   you're at least 59.5 years old
column25: the IRS will charge you income   taxes on any money that you withdraw
column26: plus a 10% penalty
column27: unless   you qualify for an early withdrawal exemption (more on that in a   minute).In the case of a Roth IRA
column28: you can withdraw your contributions   tax-free at any age without a penalty
column29: as long as the Roth IRA   has been established for at least five years. However
column30: any gains   that you withdraw prior to reaching age 59.5 can be subject to   income tax and penalties.Both traditional IRAs and Roth IRAs do allow penalty free
column31: early withdrawals in specific instances. A full list of these   exemptions can be foundhere
column32: but the big ones to know about include purchasing a first home   (up to $10
column34: or payingcollege tuitionfor you
column35: or an immediate relative
column36: such as a spouse or child. The   rules for taking advantage of these exemptions can be quite   complex
column37: so make sure you consult a tax professional before   taking any early withdrawals. After all
column38: the last thing you want   is a surprise at tax time!Overall
column39: a Roth IRA might be a better option if you think   you'll need to withdraw contributions five or more years from   now
column40: and you won't be 59.5 years old or qualify for an early   withdrawal exemption at that time.Navigating the IRA income capsIn order to qualify for a tax deduction on a traditional IRA   contribution
column41: your modified adjusted gross income has to be below   set limits if you
column42: or your spouse
column43: are covered by a retirement   plan at work. Similarly
column44: in order to contribute to a Roth IRA
column45: your modified adjusted gross income needs to be below set limits   too.Recently
column46: fellow Motley Fool Matthew Frankel did a great job   at explaining adjusted income limits for IRA'shere
column47: but in short
column48: if you're single and you are covered by a   retirement plan at work
column49: you can take the full deduction on a   traditional IRA contribution if your adjusted income is below   $62
column50: 000 in 2017. You can qualify for a partial deduction if your   adjusted income is between $62
column52: 000.If you're single
column53: you can make a contribution to a Roth IRA as   long as your adjusted income is less than $118
column54: 000. You can make   a partial contribution if your adjusted income is between   $118
column56: 000.If you're married filing jointly and covered by a retirement   plan at work
column57: then you can take a tax deduction on your   traditional IRA contribution
column58: as long as your adjusted income is   below $99
column59: 000. A partial deduction is possible if your adjusted   income is between $99
column61: 000.If you're not covered by a plan at work but your spouse is
column62: then you can make a tax deductible contribution to traditional   IRA if your adjusted income is below $186
column63: 000 or a partial   deduction if your adjusted income is between $186
column65: 000.If you're married filing jointly
column66: you can contribute to a Roth   IRA as long as your adjusted income is below $184
column67: 000. A partial   contribution can be made if your income is between $184
column69: 000.If you think you're close to these limits and you're unsure of   how to calculate your modified adjusted gross income
column70: you can   read up on the subjecthere.How to invest in an IRAOnce you've contributed to an IRA
column71: you'll need to pick some   investments. There are a lot of choices
column72: and you'll want to think   carefully about your age
column73: your health
column74: and the number of years   you have until you begin withdrawals.If you're young
column75: in good health
column76: and have plenty of years to   ride out the inevitable recession
column77: then an IRA that includes   stocks
column78: stock ETFs
column79: and stock mutual funds can make sense.   Usually
column80: buying and holding stocks and ETFs for long periods of   time is cheaper than buying an actively managed mutual fund
column81: so   make sure that you balance the potential return
column82: risk
column83: and   expenses associated with these choices.Some investors may prefer owning individual stocks for the   long term
column84: such as disruptive growth companies likeAmazonorAlphabet. Other investors may prefer owning an S&P 500 ETF that   tracks the stock market's returns more closely. If so
column85: a low-cost   S&P 500 ETF that might fit the bill is theVanguardS&P 500 ETF(NYSEMKT: VOO) . It has an annual expense ratio of just   0.05%.It may also pay off to own dividend-paying stocks in an IRA.   Because IRAs offer tax advantages
column86: dividend payments can compound   over time tax-deferred
column87: or in the case of a Roth IRA
column88: potentially   tax-free. Historically
column89: dividend-paying stocks have outperformed   non-dividend-paying stocks. However
column90: the performance ofdividend   stockstends to be lower during periods of rising interest rates
column91: when   they have to compete with bonds for income investors'   attention.Overall
column92: building a diversified IRA that includes exposure to   stocks and stock ETFs can provide financial security in   retirement. For example
column95: 500   per year for 35 years and earn a hypothetical 6% return per year

column98: so make sure that you take advantage of this   powerful savings tool.The $16

column1: VMware
column2: Inc. (VMW) Keeps the Momentum Going;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVMware
column4: Inc.(NYSE:VMW) may not be one of the first companies that comes to mind when you're thinking about cloud services stocks. But
column5: it should be.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrBelieve it or not
column6: VMW is one of the top enterprise cloud services and virtualization companies out there. And
column7: its growth up to now
column8: while impressive
column9: is just the beginning. In the past 12 months
column10: VMW stock has almost doubled.That sounds compelling
column11: but the underlying story is what makes VMW's rise something you should understand
column12: especially if you're looking for exposure in this massively disruptive market.Simply put
column13: cloud computing means that your computer doesn't need to have individual software packages for each specific job you want it to do. In the old days
column14: you ran a word processing program
column15: a spreadsheet program
column16: a design program
column17: etc. And
column18: every machine had to have its individual software suite.The rise of networked computers meant that all of this software could be stored on a network ""library"" and each user could access what they needed.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe next iteration of these networks were housed in the ""cloud
column19: which simply implies a virtual space built into servers. One of the primary advantages is the ability to access your information from the cloud
column20: regardless of where you are or what computer you're using.Cloud computing has been around for a long time
column21: and companies such asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column22: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column23: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) have been using the cloud for many years.Now
column25: companies of all sizes are migrating to the cloud
column26: and within the cloud universe there both public clouds (where many people have access) and private clouds (where only select people have access). VMW provides the ability to develop each of these systems
column27: and also facilitates unique access between public and private clouds.Why Don't We Hear Much About VMware?VMWare is actually owned byDell Technologies Inc(NYSE:DVMT) subsidiary
column28: EMC Corporation(NYSE:EMC). Last April
column29: Dell bought EMC to become the largest privately-held tech company in the world. So
column30: VMWare is a cloud-based
column31: publicly-traded branch of this major tech player now.Part of the reason you don't hear about VMWare as much as its competitors is because the company's relationship to its owners is a bit convoluted
column32: and analysts aren't very confident in figuring out how to value VMW stock. Their loss is your gain.3 Stocks to Buy for Under $10 With 25%-Plus UpsideQ4 and full-year numbers were posted in late January
column33: and they show how strong VMW stock remains. Earnings beat analyst expectations and revenue continued to grow at a solid clip. A new strategic partnership with AMZN's cloud-computing juggernaut
column34: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column35: adds some serious firepower to the VMW arsenal. It also helps the company remain competitive in a very dynamic field.When you have a tech parent like EMC and a tech partner like AWS
column36: you are doing very well. These brands are major players in the enterprise sector and will open even more doors for VMW in the future. VMWare stock is on a significant growth trajectory that should last years
column37: not months.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
column38: Emerging Growth
column39: Ultimate Growth
column40: Family TrustandPlatinum Growth. His most popular service
column41: Blue Chip Growth
column42: has a track record of beating the market 3:1 over the last 14 years. He uses a combination of quantitative and fundamental analysis to identify market-beating stocks. Mr. Navellier has made his proven formula accessible to investors via his free
column43: online stock rating tool
column44: PortfolioGrader.com. Louis Navellier may hold some of the aforementioned securities in one or more of his newsletters.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeWhy Amazon.com

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Charged and Ready to Go;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) andTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) may not be competitors
column3: but you can trade them as if they are. Let me explain.makeArticleAd();I am a fundamentally driven trader. Meaning I like to set my risk based on solid fundamentals. Tesla and Twitter are both perceived as risky bets. This is not a slight against either of them; I am merely saying that their fundamentals have yet to grow into their valuations. Tesla has a few obstacles ahead it. I get the potential but for now it's a speculative play in my book.A few days ago I suggestedclosing TSLA long profits and roll into TWTR longs. I did so because I didn't have room for both speculative trades in my portfolio. The move turned out to be an instant win as that day marked the high in TSLA and a coincided with a spike in TWTR.Click to EnlargeTesla Stock has a cult following. But on Thursday it caught a downgrade that caused a 3.9% drop.It won't be long before TSLA fans start touting great entry points. Personally
column4: I reiterate my skepticism in its fundamentals so I won't be buying the stock.3 Dow Jones Stocks That Are Weighing You DownOn the other hand
column5: I remain a fan of the TSLA stock price action. So
column6: I like selling risk in Tesla options.I am always looking for opportunities to cautiously catch the falling knife. The easiest way I can do it is by repeating what has worked in TSLA
column7: which is to sell risk against extreme opinions. I am not reckless so I always leave plenty of room for error since I never assume that I will pick the perfect time of entry. In this case
column8: I will nibble with a first tranche trade then add to it as price unfolds.The Trade:Sell TSLA Jan 2018 $185 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collected $11.50 to open. The 30% price buffer gives me an 80% theoretical chance of success. My breakeven point is $173.5 per share. Selling naked puts is dangerous and is not suitable for all investors especially on a speculative high-priced stock. So I can modify this trade to carry less overall dollars at risk.The Alternate:Sell TSLA Jan 2018 $185/$180 credit put spread. For this collect $1 to open. If successful
column9: this trade yields more than 25% on money risked. Selling a spread limits my maximum risk to the width of the spread less what I collect to open.Amazon.com
column10: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a BreakoutI am not required to carry these trades through expiration. I can close them at any time for partial gains or losses. Selling naked puts is dangerous especially in markets hovering at all time highs. I only do it if I am willing and able to own the stock at the strike sold.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column11: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold Forever3 Cheap Lithium Stocks to Buy That Will Energize Your PortfolioThe postTesla Inc (TSLA) Stock Is Charged and Ready to Goappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Top Stocks Warren Buffett Is Selling Now;2/17/2017;"Warren Buffett loves buying great stocks at fair prices
column2: but   he doesn't hold onto every stock he buys forever. Sometimes
column3: he'll sell stocks after he's made a healthy profit. Other times
column4: he'll sell because something has changed to make the company less   attractive to him.Knowing what stocks Buffett's selling can be important because   his investment company
column5: Berkshire Hathaway(NYSE: BRK-B) (NYSE: BRK-A)
column6: is so big that when he sells
column7: it   can cause share prices to drop. That's a risk investors might not   want to take!Luckily
column8: Berkshire Hathaway files a 13F report with the SEC   every quarter that shows exactly what he's been selling
column9: and that   can keep you from being unhappily surprised. For   example
column10: Buffett sold shares inWal-Mart Stores(NYSE: WMT)
column11: Deere & Co.(NYSE: DE)  andVerizon(NYSE: VZ)  in Q4. Should you sell those stocks too?makeArticleAd();Bailing on bricks and mortarWarren Buffett has been a longtime owner of Wal-Mart Stores
column12: but he's been selling shares in the retail giant since last   spring
column13: and in Q4
column14: Berkshire Hathaway reduced its position in   Wal-Mart by 89% to 1.4 million shares.Image source: Wal-Mart Stores.One reason Buffett may be selling Wal-Mart is because the   company has been under fire from online retailers
column15: and   maintaining market share against those retailers has been   hard.Wal-Mart is nowhere near as troubled as some other traditional   retailers
column16: but retail sales figures
column17: and Wal-Mart's own   financials suggest Wal-Mart's best days may be behind it.   According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column18: e-commerce industry revenue   jumped 15.7% year over year in Q3
column20: and it now represents   8.4% of total retail sales.Wal-Mart's most recent quarterly earnings report from November   shows investors just how tough its been to compete against online   retailers likeAmazon.com. In Wal-Mart's fiscal third quarter
column21: its sales grew by an anemic   0.7% to $118.2 billion
column22: and through the first nine months of   fiscal 2017
column23: its sales also grew by just 0.7% to $355   billion. For perspective
column24: consider that Amazon.com's net   sales surged 27% to $136.0 billion in 2016. Based on that   comparison alone
column25: it's understandable why Buffett no longer wants   Wal-Mart to be one of his biggest holdings.Farming for profitWarren Buffett was betting that Deere & Co. could   recapture some of luster last year
column26: and it seems the farm   machinery maker lived up to his expectations.Deere & Co.'s shares came into 2016 trading in the $70's.   But
column27: after a big run up
column28: they finished the year trading at over   $100. With Deere's shares rallying to all-time highs
column29: it appears   Buffett decided not to push his luck. In the third quarter
column30: he   sold 874
column31: 185 shares
column32: and in the fourth quarter
column33: he sold his   remaining 21.1 million shares.It's anyone's guess if Warren Buffett will buy shares in Deere   & Co. again
column34: but if he does
column35: it's probably not going to be   for a while
column36: unless of course
column37: Deere's shares sell-off
column38: or farm   income climbs. In 2016
column39: farm income was the lowest since the   recession
column40: and that caused Deere's net revenue to fall 8% to   $26.6 billion.Deere & Co.'s ability to turn a profit despite slowing   equipment demand is impressive
column41: but the outlook for 2017 doesn't   provide a lot of conviction to buy Deere's shares at lofty   levels. The USDA net farm income forecast for this year puts it   at the lowest levels since 2002
column42: and Deere is projecting that   equipment sales will dip by another 1% in 2017. Thus
column43: Deere   & Co. may be worth buying only if share prices retreat    Until then
column44: patience is probably best.Wrong numberVerizon may be the country's biggest wireless carrier
column45: but   that fact alone wasn't enough to keep Warren Buffett a   shareholder. Berkshire Hathaway sold almost all of its stake in   Verizon last quarter.We may never know exactly why Buffett soured on Verizon
column46: but   since Buffett has ownedVerizon sharessince the middle of 2014
column47: it's possible
column48: depending on the exact   timing of his buys and sells
column49: that he was able to book a   double-digit percentage profit on his investment in Verizon
column50: and   if so
column51: then that gain might have been enough to convince him to   sell into growing industry uncertainty.Last year
column52: Verizon decided to buyYahoo!to merge it with its AOL business
column53: but after a high-profile data   breach
column54: pressure has mounted for that deal to be renegotiated to   reflect damage to Yahoo!'s brand. Rumors are that Yahoo! may   agree to a $250 million haircut to appease Verizon

column1: Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock: The Pause That Refreshes;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) is all about visual computing.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe company started as a high-end graphics card maker for users who were interested in having the best display quality you could get. That ranged from online gamers to research scientists.Given that chip and card makers aren't exactly in short supply
column3: few investors gave this niche player much time. The thought was
column4: NVDA may have a great graphics card
column5: but it's a ""nice to have
column6: not a ""need to have"" kind of product.What's more
column7: most chipmakers had perfectly serviceable graphics cards. Why contract out to yet another vendor when you already had a chipmaker that could provide you with a decent graphics card?Those Days Are Gone NowQuality graphics are no longer just a nice add on; they're crucial now that processing speeds have soared and new technologies have been able to thrive. In this visual computing space
column8: Big Data
column9: virtual reality (VR) and the Internet of Things (IoT) are three major disruptive forces that lean heavily on quality rendering and fast processing.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteSimply put
column10: Big Data packages large data sets and then analyzes them to find any discernible patterns or trends. For example
column11: a store can figure out what day and time is best for 30-something women to buy a shirt. Visualizing these data sets is very helpful in analyzing this process.VR and its cousin
column12: augmented reality (AR)
column13: are not only the hottest technologies in gaming
column14: but are already revolutionizing other fields where interaction is highly prized. For example
column15: medical schools are using AR tech to virtually operate on an augmented cadaver
column16: rather than physically operating on one. The possibilities are just being tapped at this point.IoT is another technology in its infancy. As artificial intelligence and bandwidth merge
column17: opportunities are appearing everywhere
column18: for instance in ""smart"" cars
column19: homes
column20: offices
column21: you name it. One of the best examples nowadays isAmazon.com
column22: Inc's(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa orAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home device
column23: where you can do everything from order a pizza to set your thermostat just by talking to the thing. It recognizes your commands and then
column24: through its connectivity
column25: turns your request into reality.NVDA is already working with many major car companies to create the next-generation car dashboard
column26: as well as other interactive possibilities. It is helping scientists manipulate molecules and atoms to build better drugs. And
column27: it's building the chips that are featured in the newest gaming system fromNintendo Co.
column28: Ltd (ADR)(OTCMKTS:NTDOY).These are just a few reasons that NVDA is up 282% in the past 12 months.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeservePart of this big move was because the entire semiconductor industry was weak because demand had slackened. But
column29: this is a cyclical industry and it's ""game on"" once again. Plus
column30: NVDA has shown that it's more than just a graphics card maker at this point. It is on the leading edge of the next generation of visual computing.NVDA numbers for Q4 were recently released
column31: and the stock came down from its 52-week highs on the news.But
column32: this is simply the pause that refreshes. The numbers were still impressive and there is significant untapped growth for NVDA stock. Management's guidance may have been slightly conservative
column33: but it's likely that stellar growth will remain in Nvidia's future for many years to come.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
column34: Emerging Growth
column35: Ultimate Growth
column36: Family TrustandPlatinum Growth. His most popular service
column37: Blue Chip Growth
column38: has a track record of beating the market 3:1 over the last 14 years. He uses a combination of quantitative and fundamental analysis to identify market-beating stocks. Mr. Navellier has made his proven formula accessible to investors via his free
column39: online stock rating tool
column40: PortfolioGrader.com. Louis Navellier may hold some of the aforementioned securities in one or more of his newsletters.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears Strike3 Stocks to Buy for Under $10 With 25%-Plus Upside7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingThe postNvidia Corporation (NVDA) Stock: The Pause That Refreshesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Sorry
column2: Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock Is Not a Short!;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO) stock isn't cheap
column4: to be sure. Even with TWLO more than 50% off late September highs
column5: the stock still trades at over seven times the midpoint of its 2017 revenue guidance. And that multiple excludes the company's $300 million in cash. Meanwhile
column6: the price-earnings ratio for Twilio stock is infinite because the company is unprofitable
column7: and rather sharply so. 2017 guidance implies an operating loss of $13 million to $17 million on a non-GAAP basis.makeArticleAd();Source:Web Summit Via FlickrIn other words
column8: for every dollar of revenue Twilio generates this year
column9: it expects to lose at least 4 cents
column10: plus another 3 to 4 cents in stock-based compensation. (That dilution is excluded from Twilio stock's non-GAAP figures.)So ifAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is overvalued at 62 times earnings
column12: TWLO stock must be even moreso. And that should make Twilio stock a tempting target for short sellers.But it's not that simple. TWLO is a growth stock after all
column13: and growth stocks can stay elevated for a long time. Short sellers indeed have targeted TWLO stock
column14: one reason shares have declined so sharply of late. But as those same short sellers say
column15: ""Valuation is not a catalyst."" And recent history proves them right.Yes
column16: The Numbers MatterValue investors
column17: in particular
column18: often criticize stocks like TWLO
column19: with more than a bit of frustration in their voice. ""I guess
column20: for growth stocks
column21: the numbers don't even matter."" (AMZN shareholders surely are familiar with that sentiment.)The 10 Best Stocks to Buy and Hold ForeverBut that's not the case. A company like Twilio isn'tsupposedto be profitable yet. It's not even a decade old
column22: which isn't a long time in the competitive tech space. It's investing money in attracting new customers to its cloud communications service
column23: which is what it should be doing. There's no need to forego that spend for profits now
column24: when that spend can drive far more profits later.Purely from a valuation standpoint
column25: it's too simplistic
column26: particularly in the PaaS/SaaS space
column27: to look at profits without context. It's better for Twilio to spend a dollar on sales and marketing now - even if that adds to its net losses - if that dollar is worth $3 in sales later. And the reason cloud stocks have been so hyped - and so highly valued - is that $1 upfront doesn't just lead to $3 later … Rather
column28: it leads to $1
column29: or even $2
column30: for years and years and years.So there are investors who are taking the long term - and
column31: dare I say
column32: fundamental - approach toward Twilio stock. TWLO's valuation is based not on what it's doing in 2017
column33: but what it can do in 2020
column34: or 2025. That leads to quite a bit of volatility
column35: as seen in TWLO's short time on the public markets. But that volatility doesn't mean TWLO longs aren't paying attention
column36: and it doesn't mean TWLO is failing. Most notably
column37: for short sellers considering TWLO
column38: it doesn't mean Twilio stock willkeepgoing down.Sentiment MattersOf course
column39: there are fundamental arguments for TWLO stock to continue to tumble. Unlike more well-known cloud plays
column40: Twilio has relatively low gross margins since it still has to pay network providers who transmit calls and text messages. Revenue growth is guided to slow in 2017
column41: to 33%.With similar deceleration
column42: sales wouldn't double again until 2020. $700 million-plus in sales at even 15% operating margin still implies barely $100 million in operating profit. That
column43: in turn
column44: probably puts EPS under $1 - and TWLO stock's 2020 P/E multiple above 35.But investors should look at recent history in the cloud space. Pretty much every high-flying SaaS or PaaS stock has had similar concerns. And pretty much all of them have held up just fine.Workday Inc(NYSE:WDAY) bottomed in early 2016 near $50; it's since rebounded sharply
column45: and now trades at over 10x revenue.Veeva Systems Inc(NYSE:VEEV) was a popular short seller target in 2015; it's at all-time highs
column46: with sales multiples similar to that of TWLO.Splunk Inc(NASDAQ:SPLK) is near a 52-week high - and trades at over 8x revenue on an enterprise basis. A high valuation doesn't mean a bad stock - at least in the short term.Bottom Line on TWLO StockSo there are two concerns when shorting a stock like TWLO. The first is that as long as near-term performance is enough to keep bullish investors happy on the long-term prospects
column47: the stock is unlikely to come down. With Twilio coming out of a strong Q4 that beat expectations
column48: that sentiment seems likely to stay positive for at least the next couple of months.The second is that a short seller on TWLO can be right and still lose badly. ""The market can stay irrational longer than you can stay solvent
column49: the old saw goes. But the market also can berationaland just flat-out wrong. A short seller
column50: however
column51: only profits when the market realizes it's wrong. And that can take a long time.Amazon.com
column52: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a BreakoutTo be sure
column53: short sellers continue to target Twilio stock. But it's a dangerous game. Just ask short sellers of WDAY
column54: VEEV
column55: SPLK or
column56: most notably
column57: AMZN. Timing is key. And right now
column58: the timing does not look right
column59: at all
column60: for a short of Twilio stock.As of this writing
column61: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Dow Jones Stocks That Are Weighing You Down3 Cheap Lithium Stocks to Buy That Will Energize Your PortfolioThe postSorry

column1: WWDC 2017: Here’s What Apple Inc. Might Reveal;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has announced the date for its yearly developer conference. WWDC 2017 will take place in San Jose
column3: starting on June 5. What can you expect the company to announce at the Apple event?makeArticleAd();Source: AppleAs a developer conference
column4: Apple usually focuses on software at its June events and WWDC 2017 will follow the same pattern.The company likes to offer hints at what its upcoming operating system releases hold with demos during the keynote presentation.With the iPhone dominating Apple's bottom line
column5: iOS 11 - the next version of AAPL's mobile operating system - is bound to get the majority of the stage time.Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT) Stock Isn't Coming Back. Just Ask Buffett.You can expect to see the latest versions of Apple's other operating systems to be shown off as well. We'll find out which California geographical feature macOS 10.13 will be named after
column6: along with the latest new features for Mac users. Apple Watch's watchOS and the Apple TV's tvOS will also get mentions.WWDC 2017: What About the Hardware?Software is exciting to app developers. For everyone else
column7: maybe not so much
column8: especially when it's just a teaser or dives into technical details. What really gets people's attention - especially from an Apple event - is new hardware. AAPL doesn't put an emphasis on revealing new products on stage at these developer conferences
column9: but there have been exceptions
column10: including:Mac Pro at WWDC 2006iPhone 3G at WWDC 200813-inch MacBook Pro and iPhone 3GS at WWDC 2009iPhone 4 at WWDC 2010MacBook Pro with Retina Display WWDC 2012New Mac Pro at WWDC 2013Historically speaking
column11: we may be overdue for a hardware announcement and there are two possibilities that come into mind for WWDC 2017.WWDC 2017: iPhone 8?It's been many years since AAPL chose its summer Apple event to take the wraps off a new iPhone. It's a long shot
column12: but there's a possibility the company may choose WWDC 2017 to unveil the iPhone 8. Why?First
column13: there's the significance of the June conference date. 2017 is the 10th anniversary of the iPhone and the very first one first went on sale in June
column14: 2007. Then there are the rumors that Apple is planning toramp up iPhone 8 production in June
column15: which would be earlier than usual.But the most compelling reason why the company might show off the iPhone 8 early is the developers in attendance. We're pretty sure AAPL is going to make sweeping changes to the iPhone 8. Besides design changes
column16: that could mean anything from an optical scanner to a mini version of the new MacBook Pro's Touch Bar replacing the Home button.The company will want apps available at launch that make use of any new hardware and that means bringing developers into the loop early. Apple may decide to let the cat out of the bag at WWDC 2017 so developers have a chance to learn about the new features and capabilities.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingAnother possibility on the hardware front is a revamped Apple TV. AAPL has been struggling with its set-top streamer with sales once again dropping off. It recently hired the former head ofAmazon.com
column17: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV division tohelp turn around the Apple TV's fortunes. One of the big missing pieces from the Apple TV is relatively easy to fix. A new box with 4K support would address the issue of being stuck in the 1080p era when everyone else is doing Ultra HD
column18: and it's possible Apple could have this ready for June.Of course
column19: we have a few months to wait until we find out for sure. Watch InvestorPlace for coverage of WWDC 2017. Once the keynote wraps up on June 5
column20: we'll be posting on all the major Apple event reveals.As of this writing
column21: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceAmazon.com
column22: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a BreakoutDow Jones and Nasdaq Reach New All-Time Intraday HighsThe postWWDC 2017: Here's What Apple Inc. Might Revealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: This Is the Biggest Risk Facing Costco;2/17/2017;"Costco(NASDAQ: COST) has been remarkably steady in a climate where   other retailers have struggled as more consumers move at least   some of their shopping online.That's at least partly because whileAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) and other digital retailers may offer comparable   (or even better pricing) they can't equal the warehouse club's   shopping experience. Certainly many consumers go to Costco   because of price
column2: but others shop there because of the fun of   discovering what deal may be offered that day or what   limited-time seasonal merchandise may be on the chain's no-frill   shelves.Of course
column3: some people also visit the warehouse club because   of the free samples
column4: while others enjoy the ability to get a   cheap meal before or after shopping. It's a mix that has kept the   chain growing despite it having a very limited online   business.makeArticleAd();Costco posted a decent 3% increase in United States comparable   store sales inDecember 2016and a fairly impressive 6% gain inJanuary 2017. Those may not be Amazon-like growth numbers
column5: but they are   increases that the vast majority of retailers would be thrilled   to have.The problem the chain faces -- and it's a big risk going   forward -- is that people are shopping in stores less and less.   Eventually it's possible
column6: maybe even probable
column7: that Costco's   immunity to this trend -- which has impacted so many other   retailers -- will end.Image source:YCharts.com.Where are people shopping?While it may feel like a massive amount of the total retail   sales have moved online
column8: in reality
column9: digital sales only accounted   for 8.4% of all sales in Q3 2016
column10: according to data from the U.S.   Census Bureau. The problem for retailers
column11: as you can see on the   chart above
column12: is that the number has been steadily climbing.The Q3 2016 data represents a full 1% increase year-over-yer   from Q3 2015. Online sales have not made massive gains each year
column13: but consumers are migrating and given the increased ease of   buying things online
column14: there's every reason to believe the trend   will not only continue
column15: but accelerate.Those increases may not impact Costco at first but they are   clearly hurting other retailers. A number of chains including   Sports Authority
column16: Linens-N-Things
column17: Borders Books
column18: Circuit City
column19: and others have gone out of business over the past few years   while a handful of top names are teetering on the edge in   2017.It's possible that some of those losses actually have helped   Costco
column20: but at some point the death of physical retailers will   push more consumers online. With less physical shopping choices   consumers may simply decide that shopping is something they   mostly do online and some
column21: maybe many
column22: could fall out of the   Costco habit.As other retailers close Costco could gain customers or     people could decide to shop online more. Image source: Getty     Images.How can Costco fight this?The warehouse club chain has committed to beefing up its   digital presence and it has shown some strong early results. On a   global basis in Q1 2017
column23: ""total online sales were up 8% in the   quarter and 7% on a comp basis
column24: according to CFO Richard Galanti   in the company's earnings call with investors. The CFO also   pointed out that during the week of Thanksgiving and the two that   followed
column25: digital sales rose by the low-to-mid teens.Galanti reiterated that the company would be investing in   improving the digital experience by doing things like making it   easier to check out and improving the returns process. Growing   digital sales is a small hedge against customers shopping in   stores less
column26: but most consumers are not likely to stay Costco   members
column27: paying $55 or $110 a year
column28: to mostly shop at a   website.For Costco to deal with the risk posed by the declining amount   of money being spent overall in physical stores it must invest in   making sure its warehouses remain destinations. That means   increasing spending on everything from sampling to making sure   its in-house restaurants remain a very cheap way to eat a meal or   snack. The chain has to expand its focus on making people want to   come to its stores because as they buy more and more online it   could become harder to get them to leave the house just to   shop.10 stocks we like better than Costco WholesaleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Costco Wholesale wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column33: 2017Daniel Klinehas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon and Costco Wholesale. The     Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is Ready for a Breakout;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Thursday
column4: Feb. 16
column5: shares ofAmazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) once again got very close to a breakout above their 2016 highs. Thus
column7: Amazon stock caught my eye for a trade setup that could lead traders to topple over each other while chasing the stock higher. Traders and investors would be wise to keep a close eye on AMZN stock again in coming days and weeks.makeArticleAd();Some of the highest probability trades in my eye occur when many market participants are positioned the 'wrong' way and a stock begins to turn
column8: thus quickly forcing traders to reverse their bets. This often leads to explosive moves in stocks higher or lower.This phenomenon often occurs at critical turnaround points in the broader stock indices when they become heavily oversold. When most traders have turned bearish and the market no longer has any sellers left
column9: the path of least resistance goes to the upside
column10: leading short sellers to cover their bets and see the market rocket higher.AMZN Stock ChartsSimilar setups occur in single name stocks at both oversold and overbought conditions as well as around critical breakout or breakdown points. AMZN stock currently finds itself at such a technical juncture where a squeeze higher to fresh all-time highs could soon occur

column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Heading to $160 on Video Capabilities;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMaking excuses to not likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) and avoiding FB stock is just plain dumb. Ahead of the company's fourth-quarter earnings report
column3: I gave FB stock a Strong Buy rating with a 12-monthprice target of $150. With the earnings report now in behind us
column4: I'm inclined to raise that target to $160.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIndeed
column5: FB stock is no bargain when shares are near all-time highs
column6: but the company's revenue growth engines are certain to significantly impact the bottom line. Although management didn't scale back on plans to increase capital spending
column7: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg
column8: who said the social media giant was aiming for shorter-form content
column9: has made clear that FB intends to dominate video
column10: which is where the bulk of its capex will go.And
column11: that spending has already begun.Why Amazon.com
column12: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column13: 000 in 2017Last week Facebook hired Mina Lefevre
column14: former head of scripted development atViacom
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:VIA). This hire can only be for one reason: to increase Facebook's transition toward developing original content. Contrary to popular opinion
column16: Zuckerberg is not pushing Facebook to become a television network
column17: nor does he envision the company competing withNetflix
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX). His drive to become a ""video-first"" company has everything to do with selling more ads.From my vantage point
column19: the reason Facebook must spend money is because it has begun to experience a problem thatTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) craves: It has run out of ad space on its news feeds. But
column20: Facebook doesn't want to sacrifice the user experience without first knowing what sorts of videos users will want to see - and how to make them less intrusive.To that end
column21: Lefevre
column22: whose track record at Viacom-owned MTV Networks includes producing teen-focused content
column23: is a solid hire. To the extent Facebook's shorter-form content can put it into the realm ofAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) advertising juggernaut YouTube
column24: it would have been money well spent.7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeIn that regard
column25: given Zuckerberg's Midas-like qualities
column26: it would be a mistake to avoid FB stock solely on the fears of high capex. It would make more sense to focus on the return Facebook can realize from its investments.Bottom Line for FB StockFacebook - as it promised in the third quarter - has signaled that it will be in a period of transition. Investors
column27: however
column28: are now taking their time to see how the increased spending balances out with management's warning of slow ad growth. While this might put FB stock in limbo
column29: now is also the time to look at the big picture. And my crystal ball says to own FB stock
column30: don't trade it
column31: and wait for $160.As of this writing
column32: Richard Saintvilus did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveWhy Amazon.com

column1: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Labor Issues Could Cause Problems for TSLA Stock;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTesla Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) stock is pulling back after nearing all-time highs
column3: and it's possible that concerns about Tesla's labor force are part of the reason for the modest decline in TSLA stock. Last week
column4: it was reported that TSLA factory workers had contacted the United Auto Workers about creating a union.makeArticleAd();Source:Windell Oskay via Flickr (Modified)One Tesla workerposted an essay online
column5: criticizing working conditions at the company's facility in Fremont
column6: California. Tesla CEO Elon Musk replied angrily
column7: stating that
column8: I find this attack to be morally outrageous.""For its part
column9: the UAW has said that the decision to create a union is up to Tesla workers.Fundamentally
column10: the impact of a potential Tesla union on TSLA stock likely won't be very significant - at least not directly. But
column11: the kerfuffle over unionization highlights the potential political pitfalls that Musk and Tesla must navigate. In an increasingly polarized country
column12: consumers are starting to act like voters - every day
column13: and that implies some potential risks for Tesla stock.The Fundamental Impact of a Tesla Union on Tesla StockIt's tough to parse out what a Tesla union would do to TSLA earnings. Management doesn't break out precise wages
column14: for instance. But
column15: we can get close to a reasonable estimate. In 2014
column16: Tesla told the state of Nevadathat its Gigafactory would employ 6
column17: 500 employees
column18: with annual total wages of $353 million.The company has almost the same number of workers (6
column19: 200) at its Fremont plant
column20: according to a December report
column21: with plans to expand that plant and add another 3
column22: 100 jobs. A rough assumption that wages are relatively similar would imply that (post-expansion) potential Tesla union workers would earn at least $500 million per year in wages.7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveConsidering Tesla's current shipment status
column23: that's a large sum. Trailing 12-month sales are less than $6 billion. But
column24: even with TSLA stock based on where Tesla is going
column25: a wage hike could justify a material change to TSLA's valuation. Even a 20% hike would add $100 million-plus in costs
column26: or approximately $65 million per year after tax. That's roughly 40 cents per TSLA share per year;at a 30x multiple
column27: higher wages could take as much as $12 off the fair value of Tesla stock.However
column28: that's an imperfect estimate for a number of reasons. Tesla's focus on technology likely means the company will require fewer workers over time. Plus
column29: TSLA can find other costs to cut to offset wage pressure
column30: as many companies do.Still
column31: fundamentally
column32: there is reason to believe that a Tesla union could have a modest impact on Tesla stock. It doesn't look like unionization would ruin the company
column33: as some commentators believe happened toFord Motor Company(NYSE:F) andGeneral Motors Company(NYSE:GM) before the financial crisis. But
column34: there is the possibility of a Tesla union having an impact on long-term earnings
column35: and
column36: as such
column37: the long-term price of TSLA stock.The Perception of Tesla and Tesla StockWhere the issue gets dicier for Tesla
column38: in my opinion
column39: is relative to the company's perception. Since last year's presidential election
column40: consumers increasingly vote their politics with their pocketbooks. Liberals against President Donald Trump have boycottedAmazon.com
column41: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column42: Macy's Inc(NYSE:M) (including subsidiary Bloomingdale's
column43: Inc.) and many others.Conservatives have shunnedPepsiCo
column44: Inc.(NYSE:PEP)
column45: Kellogg Company(NYSE:K) and a myriad of other companies
column46: including Amazon. (Evidently
column47: though
column48: the AMZN boycotts aren't holding very strongly.)That leaves Musk
column49: and Tesla
column50: in a tough spot. This isn't the first time TSLA has faced reports of underpaying its labor. Last May
column51: The Mercury Newsreported that the companypaid workers a mere $5 per hourduring a construction project. Management responded by pointing out that it hadpaid its subcontractor $55 per hourfor the labor. And
column52: of course
column53: there was yet another political storm when Musk met with President Trump soon after the inauguration
column54: despite howls of protest from some supporters.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe catch for both Tesla and TSLA stock is that the company can't divorce itself from politics. It's a ""green"" company
column55: which draws admiration from the left. It is emphatic in its intent to be ""Made in America
column56: which likely endears the company to Trump. But
column57: Tesla and Musk need to walk the line very carefully to appeal to both groups.Bottom Line on TSLA StockA Tesla union could put Musk in a bit of a jam. He needs to keep the pro-labor left happy
column58: while also protecting TSLA stock shareholders
column59: and his company's cash as it builds out his infrastructure. Push too hard against the workforce
column60: and liberals will see Musk as another heartless capitalist. Give too much
column61: and investors will see Tesla as a company run for its employees
column62: not its shareholders - and potentially the next 2008-era GM.It's a difficult dance
column63: and if anyone can do it
column64: it's likely Elon Musk. But
column65: he will have to dance very carefully.As of this writing
column66: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears Strike7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingWhy Amazon.com

column1: 3 Beaten-Up Cheap Stocks: Are They Bargains?;2/16/2017;"The market is not a perfect value-weighing machine. Sometimes
column2: stocks trade at dirt-cheap or sky-high valuations for good   reason. In other cases
column3: there's a plot twist just around the   corner and Mr. Market never sees it coming.Today
column4: I'll take a look at three incredibly cheap stocks and   figure out whether their low valuations are reasonable or unfair.   The companies under the lens for examination areFitbit(NYSE: FIT)
column5: First Solar(NASDAQ: FSLR)
column6: andMacy's(NYSE: M) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Fitbit has lost a stepFitbit shares have plunged a massive 57% lower in 52 weeks
column7: includinga 30% drop in a single daytriggered by weak fourth-quarter guidance.The stock is trading at just 14 times trailing earnings and   19% over Fitbit's book value. About 42% of all shares were sold   short a month ago
column8: as if investors are waiting for the other shoe   to drop -- hard.So is this a dramatic overreaction that could lead to a   soaring bounce
column9: or is Fitbit in serious trouble?In the latest earnings call
column10: Fitbit CFO Bill Zarella admitted   that consumer demand for the company's health-monitor tools is   softer than expected. The company is a leader in a once-promising   market
column11: but the market opportunity is turning out to be smaller   than Fitbit thought.In other words
column12: today's step counters and pulse trackers might   just be a fad without staying power. It's quite possible that a   real market for these features won't emerge until the hardware   can be found as a freebie in your next cereal box
column13: or thrown in   as a no-cost bonus in another product. If so
column14: there's no real   value to be found in fitness trackers -- at least none that will   stick around for the long haul.Fitbit's strongest asset is its solid balance sheet. Backing   out $3 of cash per share
column15: the stock would actually be trading at   just 3.9 times trailing earnings. Armed with $672 million in cash   and short-term investments but no long-term debt at all
column16: the   company has a few years' worth of financial support that lets   management take risks and try drastic strategy shifts in order to   relight the growth fires.Personally
column17: I would hardly back up the truck to the Fitbit   window. A small
column18: speculative investment might be appropriate   because the company might be able to find new markets. I could   also be wrong about the faddish nature of fitness trackers.But one-hit wonders never catch a second wind
column19: and I wouldn't   be surprised to see Fitbit falling into that wistful category. If   Fitbit is a bargain
column20: it's a terribly risky one. Keep your buys   small
column21: and be fully prepared to lose it all. This is a gamble
column22: not an investment.First Solar is waiting for a moment in the sunLike Fitbit
column23: First Solar has seen share prices crashing in   recent months. The stock has plunged 43% lower in 52 weeks. Also   like Fitbit
column24: this stock is objectively cheap -- First Solar   trades at just seven times trailing earnings
column25: or 2.7 if you back   out $20 of net cash per share from the share price. Furthermore
column26: both companies used to sport rambunctious sales growth figures
column27: but have slowed down considerably in recent years.But that's where the similarities end.Rather than a potential fad
column28: First Solar works in a field of   explosive growth opportunities. Solar production and installation   costshave fallen 90% in a decade
column29: making the technology a serious alternative to oil
column30: coal
column31: and   natural gas. First Solar's stalled sales growth will continue in   2017
column32: or maybe even turn negative for a variety of political and   operational reasons. But the long-term value here is undeniable
column33: and First Solar is a proven leader in this industry.Solar stocks in general are primed for a rebound today -- andFirst Solar more so than most.Yes
column34: this is a genuine bargain. You can quote me on that.Macy's bricks-and-mortar messRetail veteran Macy's can't quite match First Solar's or   Fitbit's extreme one-year market drops
column35: but share prices have   indeed plunged 55% lower in about 18 months. The fall of 2015 was   not kind to Macy's investors.Mind you
column36: 2016 really should have roughed the stock up even   further. Here's why:M Revenue (TTM)data byYCharts.Macy's has seen its revenue sliding south over the last four   quarters
column37: which wouldn't be a huge problem if profit margin was   on the rise. Instead
column38: the store chain's profitability is   plunging. Managementrecently closed down 100 locations
column39: even in profitable markets. Same-store sales fell over the   holidays. There isn't much good to say about Macy's these days.   Like most of its bricks-and-mortar peers
column40: the retailer is   fighting for its life against online retailers led byAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .This company does seem open to trying new ideas
column41: such as the   Backstage discount-store-within-a-store concept or the   smaller-sized BlueMercury beauty outlets. But the age of big-box   retailers is drawing to a close
column42: and none of these admirable   moves will do much to delay the inevitable.Macy's had better embrace the online retail market   wholeheartedly
column43: before it's too late. A handful of old-line   department stores will make it
column44: but most will die defending the   outdated business models they hold too dear to kill.Sadly
column45: Macy's seems destined for the great outlet store in the   sky unless management makes some drastic attitude changes.   Management still insists that the in-store experience always will   form an effective weapon against online sellers. The company's   financial reports don't even break out online sales so they can   be discussed or analyzed.It's not too late to turn the sinking ship around
column46: but it'd be   an unlikely and difficult turnaround battle -- and Macy's isn't   even thinking about the core problem in the right terms yet.   Until further notice
column47: then
column48: Macy's low share price is more of a   falling knife than an inviting bargain.10 stocks we like better than First SolarWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor

column1: What's in Store for Wal-Mart (WMT) This Earnings Season?;2/16/2017;"Retail giantWal-Mart Stores Inc.WMT
column2: is set to report fourth-quarter fiscal 2017 results on Feb 21. The question lingering in investors' minds is
column3: whether the company will be able to maintain its positive earnings surprise streak in the to-be-reported quarter. In fact
column4: the company has outpaced the Zacks Consensus Estimate in each of the trailing four quarters
column5: with an average of 5.1%.Wal-Mart forms part of the Retail-Wholesale sector. Per the latest ZacksEarnings Preview
column6: we note that the above mentioned sector's earnings growth looks disappointing. Total earnings for the sector are estimated to decline 1.0%
column7: while revenues are projected to improve 4.8%.Wal-Mart Stores

QuoteLet's delve deeper how things are shaping up for this announcement.Which Way Are Estimates Treading?Let's look at earnings estimate revisions in order to get a clear picture of what analysts are thinking about the company right before the earnings release. The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter under review has remained unchanged over the past 30 days and is currently pegged at $1.30
column13: down 12.8% from $1.49 delivered in the year-ago quarter. Analysts polled by Zacks expect revenues of $130.9 billion
column14: up 1% from the prior-year period.What the Zacks Model Unveils?Our proven model does not conclusively show that Wal-Mart is likely to beat earnings estimates this quarter. This is because a stock needs to have both a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)
column15: 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold) and a positiveEarnings ESPfor this to happen. You may uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they're reported with ourEarnings ESP Filter.Wal-Mart has an Earnings ESP of 0.77% as both the Most Accurate estimate of $1.31 is higher than the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.30. The company has a positive ESP
column16: which increases the predictive power of earnings beating estimates. However
column17: it carries a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). However
column18: it is to be noted that we caution against Sell-rated stocks (#4 or 5) going into the earnings announcement
column19: especially when the company is seeing negative estimate revisions.Factors Influencing the QuarterWal-Mart has been striving to understand the evolving needs of its customers to regain their confidence and boost sales. It has delivered positive comps in the U.S. in the last nine quarters. Moreover
column20: traffic improved for the eighth consecutive quarter
column21: owing to the company's efforts to modernize stores for higher footfall and improvement in consumer spending. The company continues to expect positive comps year over year at Wal-Mart U.S. in fiscal 2017 results.Wal-Mart expects U.S. comp sales growth in the range of 1−1.5% for the 13-week period ending Jan 27. Sam's Club comp sales
column22: without the impact of fuel sales
column23: are expected in the range of 1−1.5% for the fourth quarter.Coming to the share price movement
column24: Wal-Mart's shares have increased 4.2% in the past one year
column25: little higher than the Zacks categorizedRetail-Supermarketsindustry's growth of 2.6%.While Wal-Mart posted positive earnings streak for the fifth consecutive quarter
column26: top line remains sluggish due to the deflationary pressure the industry is grappling with.Wal-Mart is also making huge investments in e-commerce initiatives to compete with the biggest online retailer
column27: Amazon.comAMZN. The company is also making efforts to improve its customer service. In this regard
column28: on Jan 31
column29: the company started offering free two-day shipping to U.S. shoppers on a minimum order of $35 on over 2 million items and that too
column30: without any membership fee.The company competes with Amazon's Prime shipping program
column31: which charges customers $99 a year for two-day shipping with additional features like a streaming video service. This project will replace Wal-Mart's existing shipping program named 'Shipping Pass' that charge shoppers an annual membership fee of $49.In addition to offering two-day shipping to stores
column32: Wal-Mart continues to offer same-day store Pickup on many items and Online Grocery Pickup at more than 600 locations across the country. The company intends to expand this service in the coming year.Wal-Mart is also expanding in e-commerce business through acquisitions. Earlier in Feb 2017

column34: JD.com Inc.
column36: up from the 10.8% stake it had in Oct 2016
column37: and its 5.9% stake in Jun 2016.After the acquisition of Jet.com

column39: Flipkart Online Services Pvt.
column40: in order to expand in the fast-growing online retail market. Recently on Dec 30
column41: Jet.com acquired Boston-based footwear-shopping website ShoeBuy
column42: which will give Jet.com access to expand in the footwear industry.Moreover
column43: the Bentonville
column44: AR-based company is paying higher wages to its workers and training them to improve its stores performance. However
column45: these initiatives have increased expenses for the company. This
column46: along with unfavorable currency
