column1: Groupon's Stock Soars As Q4 Earnings Beat Estimates On Solid North America Performance;2/16/2017;"Groupon's (GRPN) stock rose over 20% on Thursday
column2: after the company reported better than expected fourth quarter earnings
column3: with both revenue and adjusted profits beating market expectations. The company also revealed inits annual reportthat it had paid nothing for the acquisition of its competitor LivingSocial last quarter
column4: a company which was once valued at $6 billion.In terms of financial results
column5: Groupon reported 2% year-over-year (y-o-y) growth in revenue to $935 million
column6: against market estimates of about $913 million
column7: driven by solid growth in North America. Its adjusted earnings were 7 cents per share against consensus estimates of 2 cents per share. In terms of geographies
column8: the company's gross billings
column9: revenues and profits declined in international markets
column10: owing to its strategy to focus on the North American market and move away from certain low-margin goods businesses.Groupon has already shut operations in 23 countries in the last 24 months
column11: bringing down its international presence from 47 countries in January 2015 to 24 countries by the end of December 2016. By the end of the second quarter this year
column12: Groupon aims to bring this down to 15 countries primarily in North America and Europe to further streamline its operations.makeArticleAd();North America ResultsNorth America
column13: which has been the primary area of focus for the company
column14: reported revenues of about $651 million for the quarter
column15: an increase of 4.5% on a y-o-y basis. Gross billings for the region improved by 6% over the prior year quarter to over $1.1 billion while operating margin improved dramatically from (-0.4)% in Q4 2015 to 5.3% in Q4 2016. The renewed focus on North America led to an addition of 2 million unique customers during the quarter
column16: including 1 million customers added from LivingSocial.Outlook for 2017Groupon provided its 2017 full year guidance in the recent earnings call in light of the acquisition of LivingSocial
column17: exit from several more international markets
column18: and cost benefits associated with the company's streamlining initiatives. Groupon expects gross profit of $1.3-1.35 billion in 2017 compared to $1.36 billion in full year 2016. It also expects adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $20o million and $240 million
column19: against $178 million in full year 2016.View Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis Research"

column1: Fidelity Investments' Revenue And Profit Rose In 2016;2/16/2017;"Known for managing millions of retirement accounts
column2: college   savings plans and regular taxable-investment accounts
column3: Fidelity   Investments on Thursday said 2016 revenue rose 3.4% to $15.9   billion
column4: a record for the privately held company.The combination of revenue growth and slightly lower expenses   produced a record profit of $3.5 billion. That was an increase of   19.5% over 2015's $3 billion in operating income.""All businesses contributed to our strong results
column5: a Fidelity   spokesman said.makeAd('4'
column7: 'mktsnews'
column8: 'vanguard'
column10: '');The 2016 profit increase reversed a profit decline in   2015
column11: when profit fell $325 million
column13: from 2014's $3.282   billion.""Fidelity is profitable
column14: strong
column15: innovative and driven to   growth
column16: said Jim Lowell
column17: editor-in-chief of Fidelity   Investor
column18: an independent newsletter. ""That's not true for many   financial services companies.""The 2015 profit erosion was caused by spending on staffing and   technology to compete with tough rivals.Operating expenses fell slightly to $12.35 billion in 2016   from $12.4 billion the year before.""The slowdown in expenses is because Fidelity is starting to   see the benefit in Abigail's (Johnson) leadership
column19: Lowell said.   One way she has cut spending is by centralizing functions
column20: eliminating redundancies in information technology and   compliance. ""There's more efficiency
column21: Lowell said.Across all of its stock mutual funds
column22: technology was   Fidelity's largest sector as of Jan. 31 with a 20.3%
column23: according   to Morningstar Inc.Fidelity's top U.S. holdings wereApple(AAPL)
column24: Facebook(FB)
column25: Amazon(AMZN)
column26: Alphabet(GOOGL) andMicrosoft(MSFT).Apple's stock has surged 22% since shortly after the election.   It has a so-so 76 Composite Rating from IBD. Facebook has a 90   Comp Rating and is trading near its all-time high after breaking   out of a cup-with-handle base in late January. Amazon has risen   12% this year
column27: has a 76 Comp Rating
column28: and has formed a   cup-with-handle base with a buy point of 843.94. Alphabet's Comp   Rating is 69. Microsoft has a weak 60 Comp Rating. It has   uptrended since June.99 is the highest possible Comp Rating
column29: which is on a scale   from 1-99.Fidelity also reported a record $5.7 trillion in investor   assets under administration (AUA)
column30: up 10.6% from year-end   2015.Total discretionary and nondiscretionary asset flow for the   year was $218.9 billion
column31: up 15% from 2015 flow.Discretionary flow includes flow to and from managed accounts
column32: mutual funds
column33: exchange traded funds and collective investment   trusts.Nondiscretionary flow goes to and from investments not managed   by Fidelity
column34: such as other firms' mutual funds and individual   securities.At year-end
column35: Fidelity serviced 27.5 million members of   workplace retirement plans. It serviced another 8.9 million   retail households
column36: plus 8.7 million institutional accounts.Those totals were 6%
column37: 6.8% and 4.1% higher
column38: respectively
column39: than   at year-end 2015.Fidelity mutual fund managers found it harder to beat their   peers in 2016. Fidelity mutual funds beat 58%
column40: 68% and 70% of   their peers for the trailing one-
column41: three- and five-year periods   that ended Dec. 31. They outperformed 72% of their peers in   the one- and three-year periods and 71% of their peers in   the five-year span.Still
column42: the outperformance rate was high. ""To beat 58% of your   peers and have that as a bad year - most fund companies   would kill for that number
column43: said newsletter editor   Lowell. ""The falloff reflects the difficult time active   managers had during the six-week Trump (inspired) market run-up.   Odds are they'll be back to outperforming 70% or more in 2017.   That is excellent.""The annual report is a must-read mainly for Fidelity   employees
column44: who control 51% of the voting stock
column45: while the Johnson   family controls the other 49%.Abigail Johnson is chairwoman of parent company   FMR. She succeeded her father
column46: ""Ned"" Edward C. Johnson III
column47: late   last year
column48: shortly before her 55th birthday. Ned Johnson had been   chairman since 1977.Fidelity was founded by Abigail's grandfather
column49: Edward C.   Johnson II
column50: in 1946. His father
column51: Samuel Johnson
column52: worked in the   family dry goods business at the C.F. Hovey department store.Abigail's brother
column53: 52-year-old Edward C. Johnson IV
column54: is   president of Fidelity's Pembroke Real Estate division.Going forward

column1: Amazon.com Is Giving Us a Closer Glimpse of Its Prime Subscriber Numbers;2/16/2017;"Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) doesn't like to give Wall Street more information   than it has to. It took a long time for the company to show   investors the financials of Amazon Web Services
column2: its cloud   computing platform
column3: and it was already a $4.6 billion business by   the time Amazon did. But Amazon's reporting a new revenue   category for its retail operations that gives us a small glimpse   into how big Amazon Prime is.In its latest 10-K filing
column4: Amazon reported a line item called   ""retail subscription services."" The segment includes ""annual and   monthly fees associated with Amazon Prime membership
column5: as well as   audiobook
column6: e-book
column7: digital video
column8: digital music
column9: and other   subscription services
column10: according to the SEC filing. Those   services brought in $6.4 billion in revenue last year.The number could give us a hint as to how many Prime members   Amazon has.makeArticleAd();Image source: Amazon.com.The minimum number of Prime membersOver the past few years
column11: management has given us some hints as   to how many Prime members Amazon has. Here's what management   said
column12: and what it implies for Amazon's membership numbers.YearWhat Management SaidMinimum Number of Prime Members Implied2013""We now have tens of millions of members             worldwide.""20 million2014""Worldwide paid membership grew 53% last year.""30.6 million2015""Worldwide paid Prime memberships increased 51%""46.2 million2016""Tens of millions of new paid members joined the             program in just this past year.""66.2 millionHow do those numbers compare with subscription revenue?What's interesting about these implied numbers is that   subscription revenue grew at the same rate as Prime members last   year -- 43%. Subscription revenue grew 62% in 2015
column13: faster than   the 51% growth in Prime membership. So while Prime is definitely   the biggest factor
column14: it's not the only thing contributing   revenue.Audible
column15: with its ""millions of subscribers"" paying at least   $14.95 per month
column16: is a sizable factor as well
column17: at least 5%. Add   in a few Kindle Unlimited subscribers and some Amazon Music   subscribers
column18: and it's possible Prime accounts for as much as 90%   of Amazon's subscription revenue
column19: asMorgan Stanley's Brian Nowack estimates.That implies the average global Prime member pays at most   $86.93 per year
column20: if we presume Amazon has at least 66.2 million   of them.That number seems a bit high
column21: considering two-thirds of   Amazon's sales come from outside the U.S.
column22: where Prime is usually   less expensive. For example
column23: over 10% of total sales came from   Germany last year
column24: where Amazon charged just 49 euros ($52) per   year for Prime last year. Japan accounts for about 8% of sales
column25: and Prime costs just 3
column26: 900 yen ($34) per year. Prime in Canada is   just 79 Canadian dollars ($60.50).Considering the impact of lower-priced Prime subscriptions   around the world and regular promotions in the U.S.
column27: it's likely   the average Prime member pays closer to $80 per month. At that   rate
column28: there are as many as 72 million total Prime members around   the world. A more conservative estimate might be the midpoint --   69 million.But the number could be even higherAmazon doesn't count all the cash it receives from Prime   members as revenue when they sign up for the service. Instead
column29: it   amortizes the yearly fee over the 12-month membership length.   Each month it transfers a certain amount fromunearned revenueto its revenue.As such
column30: estimates using revenue from all of 2016 can only   provide an average number of Prime members for the full year. And   since the number is going up
column31: Amazon's current Prime membership   numbers are certainly higher than its average membership numbers   from last year.Considering the holiday season is prime time to sign up for   Prime (pun intended)
column32: sign-ups are likely backloaded in Amazon's   fiscal year. The result is Amazon has significantly more Prime   members than what its numbers can tell us. While Amazon gave us a   glimpse at how much revenue its Prime members are producing
column33: it's   still obfuscating the actual number of members itself.Regardless
column34: it's a very big number
column35: and it's still growing   rapidly. That's as much as Amazon investors can ask for
column36: and it   should make them very happy.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRoughly half of American homes no longer have an old-school telephone

column6: home phones could become even more of a rarity.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonA report inTheWall Street Journalsuggests the companies are working on adding voice-calling capabilities to the Amazon Echo and Google Home smart speakers.The Plan to Make Amazon Echo Your New TelephoneTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Google and Amazon are looking at an all-new use for their smart speakers:replacing the home telephone.The idea makes sense. Telephones increasingly seem like outdated technology. Between smartphones and PC-based calling services likeMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Skype
column7: the days of the dedicated home phone seem numbered. In 2015
column8: a survey by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (which
column9: apparently
column10: cares about these things) found thatnearly half of American homes had given up their dedicated landline.But
column11: that still leaves a lot of telephones in operation.Apparently
column12: it's occurred to both Amazon and Google that smart speakers such as the Amazon Echo and Google Home may be the right device in the right place at the right time. Smart speakers get the name because they leverage an AI-powered personal digital assistant.Why Amazon.com
column13: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column14: 000 in 2017Amazon's Echo is home to Alexa
column15: withover 5
column16: 000 skills. These devices have the smarts to take on telephone functionality. They could incorporate Skype
column17: for example. And
column18: Google has a slew of its own telephony applications it could leverage
column19: including Google Voice and Duo.The Amazon Echo and Google Home are equipped with excellent microphones
column20: they have speakers
column21: they are always connected (to the internet) and they respond instantly to voice commands
column22: even from across a room.So
column23: as long as privacy isn't an issue (since using one would be like using a speakerphone)
column24: a smart speaker could replace a telephoneandsave consumers money by eliminating the monthly cost of a landline. While this would be a potentially useful trick for existing smart speaker owners
column25: it's the kind of practical capability that could drive sales among those consumers who wouldn't otherwise consider a high-tech device like the Amazon Echo.The Challenges of Turning a Smart Speaker Into a TelephoneWhile the technology and built-in smarts may be there
column26: in reality turning that Amazon Echo on your kitchen counter into your home phone may not be quite that simple.TheWall Street Journalarticle lays out some of the challenges. For example
column27: there are potential privacy issues
column28: not only in speaking out loud to the Echo (it lacks an AUX input
column29: so you couldn't physically connect a handset)
column30: but the fact that now your telephone would always be listening to you and recording key data like phone numbers and call durations.Amazon and Google would also have to implement a feature to prevent voice commands from being triggered during a phone conversation.It's also been pointed out that switching from a cell phone or landline to an internet-based telephone service has implications for emergency services. For example
column31: theFCC lists a series of limitations to 911 servicewhen home owners rely on internet-based (or VoIP) services.Calls may not be routed directly to an emergency center
column32: locational information may not be available to emergency responders and
column33: in a power outage
column34: internet telephones go offline without battery backups.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteDespite the challenges
column35: The Wall Street Journalsays its sources are convinced Amazon and Google will move forward
column36: calling the move to telephone capability ""the logical next step for the artificial intelligence-powered speakers."" And
column37: that move could happen later this year.The question is
column38: knowing that there are some privacy concerns and potential safety issues in doing so
column39: would you ditch your landline and use an Amazon Echo as your home's new telephone?As of this writing

column1: Amazon Plans to Drop Packages With Parachutes From Drones;2/16/2017;"Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) has long teased consumers with the idea that it   would someday deliver packages via drones.The company has pursued the idea even though it's not   currently legal to use unmanned flying vehicles for most   commercial activities (including package delivery) in the United   States. And while that could eventually change
column2: the Federal   Aviation Administration (FAA) has so far been wary of the   retailer's vision that someday the sky could be filled with   package-bearing drones.Those significant implementation hurdles however have not   stopped the online retailer from advancing the development of   what it calls Prime Air. The goal of that effort
column3: according to   the company
column4: is ""to safely get packages to customers in 30   minutes or less using unmanned aerial vehicles
column5: also called   drones
column6: according to Amazon'sweb pagefor the service. The company sees drones as having the potential   to allow it to improve its service and delivery times while also   increasing ""the overall safety and efficiency of the   transportation system.""makeArticleAd();Exactly how the retailer intends to do that has remained a bit   of a mystery. Would drones fly up and knock on your door? Would   they bring packages to windows or drop them from the sky? Now
column7: a   newpatent filingfrom Amazon shows at least one method the company could use --   dropping packages on parachutes from drones.Amazon plans to use drones like this one to deliver     packages. Image source: Amazon.What is Amazon doing?In its patent filing the online leader explains that it plans   a package delivery system that would launch a package from a   drone or unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) while it's in motion. The   drone would be able to control the descent of the package in a   number of ways which the company laid out in its filing.The package delivery system can apply the force onto the     package in a number of different ways. For example
column8: pneumatic     actuators
column9: electromagnets
column10: spring coils
column11: and parachutes can     generate the force that establishes the vertical descent path     of the package. Further
column12: the package delivery system can also     monitor the package during its vertical descent.Essentially a parachute and/or other control mechanisms would   help guide the package to Earth. It/they would also be able to   steer the package around obstructions or help it regain stability   if something disrupted its flight.Why does Amazon want this?The online retailer has built warehouses all around the U.S.   and setup shipping operations which allow it to offer two-day   delivery across the country. In some markets it has improved on   that with same-day delivery
column13: but using trucks
column14: people
column15: and even   couriers to make deliveries is expensive. Using drones would
column16: at   least with some deliveries in some markets
column17: make getting packages   to consumers cheaper and more efficient.Amazon explained in its patent filing that the use of UAVs can   overcome some of the inefficiencies of traditional delivery   methods ""by leveraging more flexible aerial transportation paths   between destinations
column18: rather than relying on rigid road   infrastructure."" In theory drones can travel more direct routes   and deliver more packages than traditional methods. The online   retailer does acknowledge that drones come with their own   problems because at some point they have to drop off the   package.""Traditionally
column19: this involves the UAV landing at the   destination
column20: releasing the package
column21: and then taking off to its   next destination
column22: wrote the company.  ""The sequence of   landing and taking off for each package delivery creates time and   energy resource inefficiencies
column23: which negate at least a portion   of the benefit of adopting a network system of UAVs.""Using parachutes solves that problem. It's likely that a   parachute-based solution would only work with certain products
column24: in select areas (it's hard to picture parachutes falling in   Manhattan) and this patent is only one possible way Amazon would   use drones for deliveries.Is this going to happen?It's easy to see the business reasons Amazon wants to use   drones. If it can offer near-immediate delivery in broad coverage   areas the online retailer takes away the last advantage   brick-and-mortar stores have. The challenge in doing that remains   solving the problem of the last mile -- getting items from a   nearby warehouse to the consumer.Drones may be part of that solution
column25: but it still may be a   long time before broad use of UAVs becomes legal or even   practical. There's a point where using UAVs with parachutes may   make sense
column26: but the process would have to be efficient enough to   make financial sense for Amazon. That's something the company   needs to work on and it's a challenge that's equally as daunting   as the significant legal hurdles that currently keep drone   delivery from being a reality.Someday drone delivery will be a real thing
column27: at least in   certain situations. That day however remains in the distant   future. These plans are clever
column28: and it makes sense for Amazon to   take a long view to developing its business
column29: but drones will have   no impact on the company's sales for the foreseeable future.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column30: the newsletter     they run

column32: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for     investors to buy right now. Amazonis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full       list!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Groupon (GRPN) Q4 Earnings and Revenues Beat Estimates;2/16/2017;"Shares ofGroupon Inc.GRPNwere up 22.75% on Feb 15 following  impressive fourth-quarter 2016 results. The company reported earnings of 3 cents per share as against the Zacks Consensus Estimate of a loss of 2 cents.However
column2: we note that
column3: shares of Groupon have underperformed the broader ZacksInternet Commerceindustry over the last one year. While the industry registered growth of 46.3%

Direct revenues (63.5% of total revenue) increased 3.8% while Third Party & other (36.5% of total revenue) declined 1.2% from the year-ago quarter.Region-wise
column5: revenues from North America increased 4.5% from the year-ago quarter while that from EMEA and the Rest of World (Asia-Pacific and Latin America) declined 2% and 11.7% year over year
column6: respectively.On a constant currency basis
column7: Rest of World (Asia-Pacific and Latin America) revenues declined 8% on a year-over-year basis
column8: while EMEA increased 1%.Gross billings dipped 0.4% year over year to $1.67 billion in the quarter. Region-wise
column9: billings from North America jumped 5.9% year over year. However
column10: billings from EMEA and the Rest of World declined 8.9% and 15.4% year over year
column11: respectively.On a same-country basis
column12: gross billings grew 2% year over year excluding the unfavorable impact of foreign exchange rates.North America local gross billings of $1.1 billion grew 5.9% and North America local revenues of $650.8 million grew 4.5% in the reported quarter primarily attributable to new customer additions as well as the acquisition of LivingSocial.During the quarter
column13: Groupon reduced its country presence to 24 from 47. The company plans to finally operate in 15 countries in Europe and North America.As of Dec 31
column15: Groupon had approximately 31.1 million active customers in North America. The company added nearly 5.2 million new customers in the quarter. Active customers were 52.7 million.Operating DetailsGross margin contracted 100 basis points (bps) on a year-over-year basis to 39.6% in the quarter. The year-over-year decline was primarily attributed to lower Third Party & other gross margin
column16: which fell 120 bps
column17: partially offset by 380 bps increase in Direct gross margin.North America gross profit increased 14%
column18: EMEA declined 25% and Rest of World slumped 10%. Local gross margins stood at 31.4% as compared to 30.1% in the year ago quarter. On the other hand
column19: Goods margins expanded by 140 bps to 11.7% on the back of improved pricing algorithms.Adjusted EBITDA margin expanded 130 bps to 8.6% reflecting successful implementations of the company's streamlining initiatives.Groupon's operating expenses dropped 6.3% year over year to $347.8 million due to lower selling
column20: general & administrative expense (SG&A)
column21: which was down 11.6%
column22: reflecting the benefits of streamlined operations and lower headcount.Marketing expenses increased 12.2% from the year-ago quarter due to investments on customer acquisition both online and off-line.Nevertheless
column23: Groupon reported operating loss of $362.4 million as compared with a loss of $377.2 million reported in the year-ago quarter.Balance Sheet and Cash FlowAs of Dec 31
column25: Groupon had cash and cash equivalents worth $891.8 million as compared with $853.3 million as on Sep 30
column26: 2016.Free cash flow was $268.9 million up a 14.5% when compared to the year ago quarter.During the fourth quarter
column27: Groupon repurchased 12
column29: 795  shares of its common stock for an aggregate purchase price of $49.9 million.OutlookFor first-quarter 2017
column30: Groupon intends to bring its country count to 15 with respect to its strategy of streamlining its business.Seasonally
column31: the first quarter is the lightest. Groupon expects to report lowest billings and adjusted EBITDA. However
column32: management expects adjusted EBITDA to be slightly better that the year-ago quarter.For full-year 2017
column33: Groupon projects gross profit to remain in a range of $1.30 billion to $1.35 billion (for the 15 countries)
column34: a jump of $40 million to $90 million from full year 2016 on an FX neutral basis.Also
column35: adjusted EBITDA is expected to remain in a range of $200 million to $240 million (for the 15 countries)
column36: a jump of $16 million to $56 million compared with full year 2016 on an FX neutral basis.Our TakeGroupon's new business strategy (with core focus on marketing
column37: international and shopping) appears to be working. Its performance has started to improve since the past few quarters after CEO Rich Williams took the helm.The company continues to see strength in its customer acquisition and shopping endeavors
column38: aimed at developing its local core business. Notably
column39: its North American business returned to growth during 2016 after hitting a patch of stagnation.Further
column40: the company has been taking a number of strategic initiatives to streamline its operations. Additionally
column41: it has increased its marketing spend
column42: which should boost its business to a great extent in the long run.Although softness in the business was observed during the run up to the elections and a few weeks after it
column43: the company is again back on a strong footing. This indicates growing demand for the company's platforms
column44: which augurs well in the long run.However
column45: Groupon is investing quite a bit in the transition
column46: which is expected to affect its near-term financials. Competition from giants like eBayEBAYand Amazon.comAMZNand impending lawsuits are the other headwinds investors need to watch out for.Groupon

column1: 3 Scorching Hot Internet of Things Stocks -- Are They Buys?;2/16/2017;"The Internet of Things (IoT) is on track to become a $7.1   trillion market with nearly 50 billion connected things over the   next few years
column2: all collecting data or automating systems. The   sectors that are already undergoing IoT upheavals range from   automotive to agricultural
column3: and energy to personal   electronics.If you're looking for IoT stocks that are making huge gains --   and still have lots of room for more growth -- than look no   further thanAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column4: NVIDIA Corporation(NASDAQ: NVDA)
column5: andSkyworks Solutions(NASDAQ: SWKS) .Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Amazon's growing IoT playAmazon's stock is up more than 60% over the past 12 months
column6: and the company just hit another quarterly earnings home run in   Q4 2016. Sales were up 22% year-over-year and net income   popped 55%.The company's Amazon Web Services (AWS) is almost always one   of its bright spots -- it brought in $3.53 billion in Q4 2016 --   and it's also turning into one Amazon's biggest IoT assets.Part of AWS' future growth potential comes from its AWS IoT   service
column7: which allows developers to manage their data and track   analytics from connected devices. Amazon's robust cloud-based   server system is quickly becoming a staple for many companies
column8: and as those same companies further embed themselves into   Amazon's AWS system it'll be a logical step for them to use AWS   IoT for their connected devices.If all that weren't enough
column9: Amazon is leading in the   home-automation space as well with its Echo devices and Alexa   virtual assistant. Amazon has opened up Alexa to third party   developers and other companies so that they can implement the   assistant into their products
column10: further tying companies and   consumers into its ecosystem.NVIDIA's burning IoT opportunityNVIDIA's stock has been on a tear since the beginning of 2016
column11: and is up 300% over the past year. The company's leading position   in the GPU chip market has morphed into astrong lead in self-driving technologies.The company's Drive PX 2 supercomputer is helping dozens of   automakers and automotive parts suppliers create driverless car   technologies by using GPUs to quickly process and identify images   captured by self-driving vehicles.The company also has big plans to use its new DGX-1   supercomputer to help offload some of a self-driving car's   on-board processing to the cloud
column12: which would allow driverless   cars to process even more information faster than they do   now.NVIDIA has managed to grow revenue to a record high of $6.91   billion in fiscal 2017
column13: up 38% from a year ago. Additionally
column14: net   income skyrocketed by 171% and diluted earnings per share were up   138% year over year.With the stock's spike in 2016
column15: some investors may be worried   that the company has no more room to grow
column16: but keep in mind that   NVIDIA has only just begun to tap into the $42 billion (by 2025)   driverless car market
column17: and only brought in $127 million in   automotive revenue in fiscal Q4 2017.An IoT tinderboxSkyworks is in the middle of shifting its mobile   prospects to the Internet of Things
column18: and its stock is up   about 50% over the past 12 months.Skyworks earns the majority of its revenue -- about 40% -- by   providing chips forApple's devices
column19: but that should't be a deterrent for investors   looking for solid IoT investment.The company's current mobile business is shifting to IoT   connections
column20: primarily through connected cars. Skyworks'   management said on its fiscal first-quarter 2017 earnings call   that the ""connected car is yet another catalyst that offers   significant opportunity"" for the company. Many of the company's   car connectivity chips are used for collision avoidance right   now
column21: and Skyworks anticipates demand for its chips to increase as   semi-autonomous and fully autonomous vehicles hit the market.Skyworks' CEO
column22: Liam Griffin
column23: said on the earnings call
column24: ""By   2020 a single autonomous car is expected to consume 4
column25: 000   gigabits of data per day in realtime diagnostics
column26: positioning
column27: vehicle-to-vehicle communications
column28: and that's equivalent to the   daily data consumed by more than 2
column29: 000 smartphone users in   2017.""The massive opportunity of connecting cars to the Internet   should give Skyworks any easy transition from mobile to the IoT.   And the company is already in a good position for more growth.   Revenues were up more than 9% year over year in the current   quarter
column30: and the company forecasts 10% sales growth for the rest   of the fiscal year.There will be a estimated 250 million connected cars on   the road by 2020
column31: and the overall autonomous driving market will   be worth $77 billion by 2035. With its chips
column32: Skyworks is   perfectly positioned to benefit from the expanding market.We're still at the beginning stages of the Internet of Things
column33: but these companies are already building out their own   niches in the space. As the market expands
column34: NVIDIA
column35: Amazon
column36: and   Skyworks should all make the short list for investors considering   adding IoT positions to their portfolios.10 stocks we like better than Skyworks     SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column37: it can pay to listen. After all
column38: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column39: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column40: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Skyworks Solutions wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column41: 2017Chris Neigerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon
column42: Nvidia
column43: and Skyworks     Solutions. The Motley Fool has the following options: short     August 2017 $87 calls on Skyworks Solutions and short August     2017 $85 puts on Skyworks Solutions. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Walmart Splurges $51 Million on Outdoor Retailer Moosejaw;2/15/2017;"On Wednesday
column2: retail giantWalmartWMTannouncedits acquisition of Moosejaw
column3: a popular and fast-growing outdoor retailer
column4: for $51 million. The all-cash deal closed on February 13.Moosejaw is headquartered in Madison Heights
column5: Michigan
column6: and is a fairly small retailer
column7: with only 10 physical stores across the Midwest. Its online presence
column8: however
column9: is huge
column10: and a popular choice for people who lead an active outdoor lifestyle. Moosejaw carries over 400 brands
column11: including Patagonia
column12: The North Face
column13: Canada Goose
column14: Marmot
column15: Arc'teryx
column16: and more.Walmart wants to continue to operate the Moosejaw website and stores as a standalone business
column17: as well as a complementary one. With Walmart's firepower and commitment to online growth
column18: Moosejaw.com will definitely benefit.Moosejaw's success comes at a time when other outdoor and athletic retailers have struggled. Eastern Mountain Sports filed for bankruptcy just last week
column19: while Gander Mountain
column20: a stalwart in hunting
column21: fishing
column22: and camping

column1: Attunity Ltd. - Big Data Enabler With 84% Upside;2/15/2017;"ByCobiaman:Share Price - $8.00Market Cap - $140 millionEnterprise Value - $131 million2016 Revenue - $54.5 million2017E Revenue - $66.9 million (23% growth)2018E Revenue - $82.5 million (23% growth)EV/2016 Revenue - 2.4xEV/2017E Revenue - 1.9xEV/2018E Revenue - 1.6xAttunity Ltd. (ATTU) provides software to enterprises used to replicate and integrate heterogeneous data sources into a single data lake
column2: which provides the basis for creating data warehouses used for Big Data analysis. The company has been in existence for 20 years
column3: first providing software used to integrate mainframe data and then adding more data sources as they became available in the market. Current data sources include Oracle (Oracle)
column4: Microsoft (MSFT)
column5: SAP (SAP)
column6: Amazon Redshift (AMZN)
column7: Teradata (TDC)
column8: Hadoop
column9: and modern streaming data sources. The company has OEM relationships with Microsoft and Amazon where the companies embed Attunity's solution into their own when data replication is called for.Attunity's revenue grew quickly in the 2014-2015 time frame
column10: with 43% growth in 2014 and 36% growth in 2015. This growth was driven by the need to gather data from various corporate sources and assemble it into data warehouses for analysis. Attunity has a simple but powerful solution that enables a much faster time to analysis for its customers. Attunity is admittedly a smaller player in the market facing bigger competition in Informatica (INFA) and IBM (IBM)
column11: but its solution is robust and has proven successful for its customer base. In 2014 and 2015
column12: Attunity mostly sold into smaller opportunities of $1 million or less with six to nine month sales cycles. By 2016
column13: Attunity's success and increasing name recognition began to attract larger deals with longer sales cycles and different sales team requirements. The company found that some of its sales force was not up to the task and revenue only grew 11% as some large deals slipped during the year.makeArticleAd();Attunity management acknowledged the problem and swapped out 15 of its weaker sales hands and replaced them with more experienced enterprise software sales people. Our work suggests that the company's problem in 2016 was indeed company-specific as the market for its type of software remained robust. Management is convinced that the worst of its sales issues are behind it and this was borne out by a beat and raise December quarter. The company notched sales of $15.6 million versus expectations of $14.3 million. Guidance for 2017 was set at $62-65 million
column14: above consensus of $60 million.We believe that after the company's tough 2016
column15: management is guiding more conservatively for 2017 than it did last year. The market seems to be supportive of growth rates seen in 2014 and 2015
column16: yet neither the management team nor the analysts want to get ahead of themselves at this point. Given the very high gross margins in this business (90%)
column17: there is a ton of operating leverage once revenue gets moving. Management guided to 5-8% operating margins in 2017 but these could go much higher
column18: especially in 2018
column19: if revenue ramps ahead of plan.We value ATTU on an enterprise value to revenue basis based on 2018 numbers. Based on our current 2018 revenue forecast
column20: ATTU trades at 1.6x revenue. We believe it should trade at a substantially higher multiple of 3x. The closest public comp
column21: Talend SA (TLND) trades at 4x 2018 numbers and operates in essentially the same market. At 3x
column22: ATTU would be worth $14.72
column23: or 84% higher than its current trading price.In terms of an endgame
column24: Attunity could grow organically for an extended period in this large market
column25: but it could also present an interesting acquisition target for a larger strategic or financial player. The CEO
column26: Shimon Alon
column27: is the largest shareholder with 8% of the stock
column28: so he has a considerable financial interest in the company's future. Interestingly Microsoft
column29: as an OEM partner
column30: has right of first refusal for any acquisition proposed by another party. This demonstrates the importance of ATTU to Microsoft and presumably to its other OEM partner.Attunity is a bit of a relic in its perpetual license revenue model. While most software companies today are in the Software-as-a-Service ((SAAS)) model
column31: Attunity's customer base demands ownership of its software products
column32: so it sells to them in a perpetual fashion. This business model is a two-edged sword as revenue above/below forecast drops to the bottom line and causes large EPS beats/misses. The main risk for Attunity is that some deals slip out of a quarter causing a revenue and earnings shortfall.See alsoBuffett Fleeing Wal-Mart: Beginning Of The End For The Giant Retailer?on seekingalpha.com"

column1: Here's How to Find the Best Dividend Stocks;2/15/2017;"When I first started investing
column2: I judged dividend-paying   stocks solely on their yield. In my mind
column3: the higher the yield
column4: the better.Thankfully
column5: I quickly learned that investing in income stocks   based on their yield alone is a huge mistake. In fact
column6: a   super-high yield can often be a sign ofdanger. That's why I've been refining my process for dividend stock   selection for years
column7: and I now focus on several other factors   before making a buy or sell decision.So what are those factors? Below
column8: you'll find the checklist I   use to put a dividend-paying stock to the test.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Test No. 1: Predictable revenueI'm convinced that the bestdividend   stockshave control over their top line. After all
column9: companies that   depend on factors outside of their control for revenue can see   their profits evaporate when the markets take a downturn.A shining example of a company with predictable revenue isBroadridge Financial Solutions(NYSE: BR) . Broadridge helps other companies with record   keeping and investor communications by handling boring but   mission-critical financial paperwork such as proxy   statements and prospectuses. The business was spun offADPin 2007 and it truly dominates its industry
column10: boasting a   market share of roughly 80%. Since companies need to remain in   contact with their investors through all market conditions
column11: Broadridge's financial statements arehighlypredictable.By contrast
column12: consider the office supply retailerStaples(NASDAQ: SPLS) . With a massive yield of 5.2% (more than twice   the S&P 500's average dividend yield of 2.2%!)
column13: the old me   would have been foaming at the mouth to buy the stock. However
column14: Staples' revenue has been declining for years due to the   significant pressure from e-commerce companies such asAmazon.com.Have a look at what has happened to these two companies   top-lines over the past five years.BR Revenue (TTM)data byYChartsWhile Staples' managementhas a planto help reverse the trend
column15: I don't have any confidence in   this company's ability to generate predictable top-line results   from here
column16: so I would urge investors to look elsewhere for   opportunity.Test No. 2: A sustainable payout ratioThe next must-know metric for any dividend stock is itspayout ratio. This figure is calculated by dividing the company's dividend   payment per share by its earnings per share. For example
column17: if   a company's annual dividend payment is $1 per share and its   earnings are $4 per share
column18: then its payout ratio is 25%   ($1/$4).In general
column19: a low payout ratio suggests that a dividend   is sustainable since it provides the company with financial   flexibility in case something bad happens. Thus
column20: any stock with a   very high payout ratio -- say
column21: above 80% -- should be approached   with caution
column22: even if it passes the first test.For that reason
column23: I've taken a pass on the cigarette and real   estate companyVector Group(NYSE: VGR) . That might come as a surprise since this company's   top line is highly predictable and has been growing for years.   With a dividend yield of 7.1%
column24: what's not to like?VGR Revenue (TTM)data byYCharts.That's all great
column25: but Vector Group has sported a payout ratio   above 100% for several years
column26: meaning that its dividend payment   exceeds its net income. The company has pulled off this trick by   turning to the debt markets to fund the difference. While this   strategy has worked for some time
column27: its current payout   ratio of 262% is a big cause for concern.By contrast
column28: Broadridge offers up a much smaller dividend   yield of 1.9%. However
column29: Broadridge's payout ratio is only 48% of   trailing earning
column30: which suggests that its dividend is far more   stable than Vector Group's.Test No. 3: Strong growth prospectsThebest dividend   stocksnot only sustain their current payouts but canincreasethem over time
column31: too. That why I exclude companies that pass the   first two tests but are not expected to grow much over the coming   years.ConsiderFirstEnergy(NYSE: FE) . As a utility
column32: its revenue is highly   predictable. In addition
column33: its low payout ratio of 51% suggests   that its dividend yield of 4.6% is quite sustainable.However
column34: FirstEnergy's aging power plants run primarily on   coal
column35: so its expenses have been on the rise as it works to reduce   its carbon emissions. When mixed with slow but steady declines in   revenue
column36: its profits have taken a big hit over the last few   years.FE Revenue (TTM)data byYCharts.Worse yet
column37: market watchers believe this trend will continue   for the foreseeable future. Analysts project that the company's   profits will decline by more than 5% annually over the next few   years. While the Trump administration has taken a pro-coal   stance
column38: the long-term outlook for the industry istoo toughto ignore. That leads me to believe that this is a stock to   avoid.Yet again
column39: this is a test that Broadridge Financial passes   with flying colors. The combination of organic growth and   acquisitions should allow the company to grow its top-line by   single digits over the next five years. Better yet
column40: modest margin   improvements and share buybacks are expected to fuel 12% earnings   growth over this time frame.Given all of the above
column41: perhaps it isn't surprising to learn   that I think that Broadridge Financial is a top-notch dividend   stock. With a predictable revenue stream
column42: a sustainable payout   ratio
column43: and solid growth prospects
column44: this company passes my test   with flying colors. That makes Broadridge a strong   dividend stock that any income investor could learn to love.10 stocks we like better than Broadridge Financial   SolutionsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column45: it can pay to listen. After all
column46: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column47: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column48: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Broadridge Financial   Solutions wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10   stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Holders Shouldn’t Worry About Oracle;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAll too much like James Cameron's 2009 sci-fi flickAvatar
column3: just when you think the feud betweenAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column4: NASDAQ:GOOGL) andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) is over
column5: you find out it's not.* Last week
column6: the iconic database company told the iconic search engine company it was appealing a ruling made against Oracle - in favor of Alphabet - in May of last year.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFor better or worse
column7: GOOGL stock owners either didn't hear
column8: or didn't care. If it's the latter
column9: it's not terribly surprising. The company formerly known as Google is sued on a regular basis
column10: often by parties with weak cases just looking for a payday.GOOGL shareholders may want to take a closer look this time around though. While successful appeal cases are tough
column11: Oracle's argument holds slightly more water than the typical long-shot caselike the one Vringo levied (and ultimately lost) back in 2014. Moreover
column12: the case itself could have significant repercussions for other outfits in the heat of similar arguments about open source software.GOOGL: Here We Go AgainWarning: You may need to read through the intricacies of this case twice to fully understand what's going on
column13: and even then
column14: there's no guarantee it will make complete sense. Here's the crux of the argument though … Oracle says Alphabet used a little too much of its Java software - which is free
column15: open-source software - in its Android operating system.The suit largely hinges on what constitutes ""fair use"" of open-source and freely-available software.7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TVWhile Oracle offers Java for any consumer to download and any developer to utilize pieces of
column16: the company contends it was never intended for wide swaths of the code to be cut and pasted and utilized as part of a commercial
column17: revenue-bearing system.The complaint specifically read:""The undisputed evidence showed that Google verbatim copied the heart of Oracle's creative work for an entirely commercial purpose without any change to Oracle's expressive content or message
column18: took far more than necessary to program in the Java language
column19: and
column20: in so doing
column21: harmed the market for Java.""The strength of Oracle's copyrights on its application programming interfaces
column22: or APIs
column23: was particularlyemphasizedby the company in the prior jury trial.Alphabet's counterargument is simpler -CEO Larry Page said
column24: ""We didn't pay for the free and open things.""If all of this rings a bell with GOOGL stock owners
column25: there's a reason. This argument has been waged in a courtroom a few times
column26: going back as far as 2010. The current stage for this battle of the titans is an appeal of last year's loss suffered by Oracle. That case's loss likely saved Alphabet Inc from being forced to pay the $9 billion in damages Oracle was seeking.Bottom Line for GOOGL Stock
column27: and OthersOwners of GOOGL stock don't have a great deal to worry about here. The courts sided with the company in the most recent case
column28: and appeals - a reversal of a prior judgment - are very difficult win.The case
column29: though
column30: will have far-reaching consequences beyond the Alphabet/Oracle tiff. In essence
column31: this contest could largely help affirm just how ""open"" open source code really is even if its user ends up commercializing it as Alphabet did with Java via Android. Perhaps in a bigger sense though
column32: this trial will once again serve as an indictment on decency (or lack thereof) and common sense (or
column33: again
column34: lack thereof).Why Amazon.com
column35: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column36: 000 in 2017While not a legal matter raised during any of the lawsuits' arguments
column37: all juror's minds were apt to be asking themselves why Oracle would offer Java in part or in whole for free - even for commercial uses - if it didn't want it to be used this extensively.Another relevant but unasked question is why Java's original developer
column38: Sun Microsystems
column39: supported Android's use of the platform before Oracle acquired Sun
column40: but Oracle switched gears on the stance after buying Sun Microsystems. And
column41: perhaps if Oracle had been more clear about how its rampant use of it in the Android OS had ""harmed the market for Java"" when it's not really otherwise monetized
column42: a judge and jury could have been a little more sympathetic.As it stands though
column43: the Oracle argument looks to be founded more on regret and frustration and less on merits. The courts so far seem to be picking up on that.Broadly speaking
column44: it all bodes well for other entities that have somehow commercialized open source software and APIs.* Avatar
column45: while a stunningly successful film
column46: was a three hour epic
column47: and could have easily ended at two points in the film before the third (and actual) ending.As of this writing
column48: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy Today10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe postAlphabet Inc (GOOGL) Stock Holders Shouldn't Worry About Oracleappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: How Amazon Payments Could Be The Next Big Thing;2/15/2017;"While retail seems like an old-school business
column2: Amazon has integrated it with innovative and advanced technology
column3: creating a company that challenges players across industries. Amazon.com (AMZN) doesn't just dominate the U.S. e-commerce marketplace - it’s among the top cloud computing platforms
column4: and is well known for its cargo planes and drones too.To further expand and strengthen its ecosystem of products and services
column5: Amazonlaunchedits payment gateway – ‘Pay with Amazon’ in October 2013 with an aim to provide an uninterrupted shopping experience to its customers and affiliate online merchants. However
column6: number of customers engaging with ‘Pay with Amazon’ trails behind its e-commerce users.As per a surveyreportby Channel Advisor
column7: when comparing marketplaces
column8: “more than 60% of respondents said Amazon is generating the greatest sales volume for their products.” However
column9: when it comes to payments
column10: about 70% of respondents named PayPal as the most commonly used payment method by customers after only debit/credit cards. 15% go with Amazon Payments.makeArticleAd();While this is reflective of Amazon’s struggle in a highly competitive payments market
column11: it is also indicative of the huge opportunity that lies ahead for Amazon Payments. Here’s why Amazon Payments could become a significant revenue generator for Amazon changing its ‘underappreciated’ status going forward.Growing E-Commerce MarketWhile the e-commerce marketplace is expanding fast
column12: it continues to be a small segment of the total retail market. In the U.S.
column13: the retail e-commerce sales for the third quarter of 2016 were just 8.35% of the total retail sales that were estimated at $1.21 trillion as per areportby the U.S. Census Bureau of the Department of Commerce. eMarketer estimates that the worldwide retail e-commerce sales will increase to $4.05 trillion in 2020
column14: making up 14.6% of total retail spending that year.The scope to penetrate further into the e-commerce segment provides Amazon with a big opportunity and gives a fair chance for hundreds of merchants to join the online bandwagon. This indirectly opens a vast ground for its affiliate payment service which nearly doubled the payment volume in 2016.Beyond The Top MerchantsAmazon’s payment service enables customers visiting websites of partner companies to pay using their Amazon account (shipment address
column15: card information
column16: etc.). However
column17: due to fear of revealing customer data to Amazon
column18: many e-commerce entities have avoided the adoption of ‘Pay with Amazon’. This trend has benefited PayPal
column19: ApplePay
column20: Google Wallet and other payment providers.Interestingly
column21: there is enough room for Amazon to grow beyond the top e-retailers by roping in second and third-tier online merchants in the U.S. and worldwide who aren’t intimidated by Amazon (with many selling goods through Amazon) and value the trust provided by Amazon payment gateway.Such partnerships need not be limited to e-retailers but any service provider using digital payment (such as airlines
column22: hotels
column23: restaurants
column24: taxi services). By adding the ‘Pay with Amazon’ button
column25: these merchants make spending much simpler for the 300 million plus user base of Amazon on their portals. During 2016
column26: more than 33 million customersusedAmazon Payments to make a purchase.Connected CarsAmazon is making its way into the connected car space by teaming up with automobile companies to integrate its cloud-based voice service Alexa to enable customers to play audiobooks
column27: check weather
column28: control Alexa-enabled smart homes and even shop. Amazon’s current tie-ups include brands such asFord
column29: Hyundai
column30: Volkswagen
column31: BMW
column32: GenesisandINRIX.While this is just the beginning and most of the features are limited to remote commands to car from home and vice versa
column33: such collaborations would add new customers by offering them a new way to interact with their cars and shop at Amazon.com especially for regularly bought items. This could strengthen its clientele for Prime and ‘Pay with Amazon’ to build a strong sense of trust and service.Final WordAmazon is by far the largest e-commerce company in the U.S. and the 8thbiggest retailerby revenue (was 15th in 2012) and is rapidly spreading its wings in Europe and Asia. With Amazon’s expansion into newer segments such as connected cars
column34: increasing number of Prime members which constitute half of its ‘Pay with Amazon’ users
column35: and more and more businesses going online
column36: there’s high probability that Amazon Payments will steadily garner a bigger market share and emerge as a strong revenue driver for the company in the future."

column1: iShares Core S&P 500 ETF Experiences Big Inflow;2/15/2017;"Looking today at week-over-week shares outstanding changes among the universe of ETFs covered atETF Channel

column9: and Amazon.com Inc. (Symbol: AMZN) is up by about 0.3%.For a complete list of holdings

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column14: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column15: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column16: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column17: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column18: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows »"

column1: New Facebook Inc (FB) Video App Is Part of a Greater Plan;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVideo is becoming increasingly important toFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB). Social media users are big on watching video

Not any longer. The company announced it's releasing a new Facebook video app for TV. The app will soon roll out to two of the most popular set-top streaming boxes.makeArticleAd();Source: FacebookYesterday

column3: 2017makeArticleAd();New economic data relevant to a possible Fed interest rate decision next month has hit the tape prior to today's opening bell. Retail Sales

column7: that number jumps to +0.8%. Year over year
column8: Retail Sales are up 2.3%; you'd have to go back to 2008 to see a higher read than that. Even though retailers overall struggled during the 2016 holiday season
column9: at least some of this rests on headwinds from competition from AmazonAMZN. What we instead see through reports like this is actual inflation creeping into the retail space.Speaking of Retail
column10: President Trump meets with top executives from retail majors such as TargetTGT
column11: GapGPS
column12: Best BuyBBYand J.C. PenneyJCP. Based on how much of these companies' inventory is manufactured outside the U.S.

Meaning a March rate hike looks firmly on the table at this point.The market has not yet priced in the possibility of a new quarter-point hike (to 75-100 basis points)
column19: but market futures are down slightly ahead of the bell. Then again

column23: and more than double the expectations from analysts of 7.5% growth in the manufacturing economy of New York State. New orders and shipments both spiked up in this latest read; this is a rather volatile survey month over month
column24: but it also represents strong economic growth for the second straight report.Mark VickerySenior EditorClick here to follow this author>>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today

column1: Evaluating Counter-Trend Opportunities In Retail ETFs;2/15/2017;"Retail stocks have become a highly-publicized area of the market in recent years as the continued struggle for brick and mortar relevance battle the efficiency of online sales.  The trend has been exacerbated with the steady expansion of retail juggernautAmazon Inc(AMZN) into more and more households.  The strength of Amazon has unavoidably weighed on the share prices of more traditional retailers that find themselves strung with slowing sales and inescapable costs.There is no doubt that consumerism is alive and well in the heart of the American economy.  Which is why it’s worth considering if the pendulum of momentum will eventually swing back in the direction of numerous stalwart retail competitors.One way to gauge and potentially invest in this trend is through diversified exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that track a basket of retail stocks.  TheSPDR S&P Retail ETF(XRT) is by far the largest and most widely followed ETF in this space.  XRT owns approximately 100 shares of publicly-traded retail companies that are primarily domiciled in the United States.  This includes industry sub-sectors such as apparel
column2: automotive
column3: food
column4: department stores
column5: drug stores
column6: specialty retail
column7: and electronics.  The fund currently has $850 million in total assets and charges a net expense ratio of 0.35%.makeArticleAd();The most interesting feature of XRT may be its equal-weighted composition.  Each stock within the index is given an equally proportionate share of the asset allocation to provide smaller companies the opportunity of making a meaningful impact on performance.  Companies like AMZN are given the same weighting asCostco Wholesale Corp(COST)
column8: Ulta Beauty Inc(ULTA) andWalgreens Boots Alliance Inc(WBA) at each rebalancing period.It’s worth noting that the price trend of XRT has been quite volatile over the last several years with little net gain overall.  This tug-of-war among the underlying holdings demonstrates a lack of definable trend for the group amid a roller coaster of peaks and valleys.Perhaps the more important issue with the performance of retail stocks is how strong the rest of the market has been in their absence.  The ratio of momentum between XRT and theSPDR S&P 500 ETF(SPY) just recently hit a new three year low to start off 2017.Investors who are seeking contrarian or deep value plays may be intrigued by the potential for a turnaround in the retail sector.  However
column9: the greatest challenges will be in timing this momentum swing and selecting an appropriate way to play it.XRT is the obvious investor favorite based on its size and longevity.  Nevertheless
column10: there remain alternative options in the ETF category that make compelling cases as well.The next largest competitor is theVanEck Vectors Retail ETF(RTH)
column11: which has $72 million in assets and charges a similar 0.35% expense ratio.  RTH varies its approach by honing in on just the 25 largest retail names in a more traditional market-cap weighted structure.  Because of its index construction criteria
column12: AMZN accounts for 17% of the underlying exposure
column13: withHome Depot Inc(HD) andWal-Mart Stores Inc(WMT) rounding out the top holdings.The newly launchedAmplify Online Retail ETF(IBUY) is another intriguing option as well.  This fund focuses on 40 publicly traded stocks that derive more than 70% of their revenue from online sales. IBUY follows a modified equal weight index methodology to create a level playing field across all its underlying holdings.This ETF also captures multiple market cap segments and contains some modest international exposure as well.  IBUY is truly designed for those investors who believe in the continued trend of online retail sales growth and profitability.  Nevertheless
column14: investors should be aware that the unique strategy charges an expense ratio of 0.65%
column15: which is on the high side for its peer group.The Bottom LineSector investing is often a hit-or-miss endeavor that can be fraught with missteps in timing or execution.  ETFs of this nature are generally more appropriate as smaller tactical holdings to supplement core
column16: broad-market exposure.  This allows you to participate in the returns of the sector without significantly overweighting your allocation towards a single industry trend.Furthermore
column17: those who are considering using a retail ETF should carefully evaluate the underlying index construction criteria as there are many varying methods within this group.  The allocation of capital to stocks within each unique fund will play a meaningful role in its overall performance."

column27: in line with company targets. All told
