column1: How Safe Is Wal-Mart Stock and Its Dividend?;2/15/2017;"Retail giantWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) has long enjoyed a significant competitive advantage   thanks to its massive scale. Wal-Mart is able to get the best   prices from its suppliers and pass those savings onto its   customers
column2: making it next to impossible for traditional retailers   to compete on price.But the continued rise of e-commerce has changed the equation
column3: putting Wal-Mart in a position where it's playing catch-up withAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) . Wal-Mart has gotten far more serious about   e-commerce in recent years
column4: acquiring Jet.com in 2016 for $3.3   billion
column5: rolling out an online grocery pick-up and delivery   service
column6: and just recently launching free two-day shipping in an   effort to undercut Amazon Prime. But it remains well behind the   e-commerce leader.Image source: Wal-Mart.makeArticleAd();Wal-Mart's U.S. store business is still performing well
column7: producing a long streak of positive comparable-sales growth   thanks in part to initiatives like higher wages and better   training for employees. But that business will no doubt begin to   feel pressure as online sales grow as a percentage of total   retail sales. Profits have taken a dive as Wal-Mart invests in   e-commerce and in-store initiatives
column8: and an earnings recovery   will require these investments to pay off in the long run.With the retail business changing rapidly
column9: is Wal-Mart stock a   safe bet? And what about the dividend? With slumping profits
column10: is   the quarterly payout at risk?A solid dividendWal-Mart has not historically been a great dividend stock
column11: in   part because the stock price was soaring right along with the   dividend prior to 2000. The yield was consistently below 1% until   the mid-2000s
column12: when the stock price began to stagnate. The yield   has steadily risen since then
column13: currently sitting right around   3%.WMT Dividend Yield (TTM)data byYCharts.Wal-Mart is a Dividend Aristocrat
column14: meaning that it has raised   its dividend annually for at least 25 years. In Wal-Mart's case
column15: the dividend has been increased annually since the very first   payment in 1974. This long track record doesn't guarantee that   the dividend will continue to increase going forward
column16: but it   shows that the company has been disciplined over the years in   regards to capital allocation.Wal-Mart's current quarterly dividend is $0.50 per share
column17: with   a total annual payout of $2 per share. Based on its adjusted   earnings guidance for fiscal 2017
column18: results for which the company   will report on Feb. 21
column19: the payout ratio is currently around 47%.   This gives Wal-Mart some breathing room
column20: even though earnings   will be down compared to previous years.Wal-Mart's dividend growth will likely be slow as the company   diverts its resources to building out its e-commerce business.   But I suspect that it will remain a dividend aristocrat for the   foreseeable future.Elevated risksThe risk of future profit declines is certainly higher today   than it was before the company needed to care very much about   e-commerce. Not only is there the threat of declining in-store   sales as consumers shift online
column21: but Wal-Mart is competing in   e-commerce against a company that has been operating with   razor-thin margins
column22: and sometimes no margins at all
column23: since its   founding.Amazon generates lower margins than Wal-Mart
column24: but Amazon also   spends prodigiously on everything from content for its streaming   service to a $1.5 billion air hub to help shuttle around   merchandise. Wal-Mart will almost certainly be more focused and   disciplined with its e-commerce investments
column25: which should help   keep the bottom line intact.The worst-case scenario for Wal-Mart would be a failure to   grow e-commerce sales rapidly despite its major investments   coupled with declining in-store sales. That scenario would almost   certainly lead to earnings stagnation or decline
column26: eventually   putting the dividend at risk. The best-case scenario
column27: strong   e-commerce sales growth and solid store performance
column28: would   eventually lead to earnings growth.Wal-Mart stock trades for around 16 times the company's   guidance for full-year adjusted earnings. That's not bargain   territory
column29: but it does represent a discount to the overall   market. Any company going through a major transition is   inherently risky
column30: but it looks like the steps Wal-Mart is taking   are the right ones. Wal-Mart stock comes with risks
column31: but not   nearly as many as most other retailers.10 stocks we like better than Wal-Mart StoresWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column34: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Wal-Mart Stores wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column36: 2017Timothy Greenhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Breakout Alert: Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) Stock;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBanking stocks and the rest of the financial sector led the market higher on Tuesday for a second straight day. This resulted in plenty of chart breakouts in important bank stocks such asWells Fargo & Co(NYSE:WFC). One day does not make a new trend
column3: but the widespread rally in financial stocks - which follows a two-month sideways march - looks promising for higher prices in WFC stock.makeArticleAd();Classic textbook technical analysis teaches that price action is all that matters. It's undeniable: Price is what gets market participants paid. However
column4: over the course of my career
column5: I have come to respect that the news
column6: market structure and some fundamental analysis significantly improves the probabilities of profitable trading and investing.The rally thus far this week in WFC stock and other bank stocks has marked several charts with clear breakouts from a two-month consolidation phase. But we must be able to contextualize this move
column7: which came on the back of hawkish commentary out of the Federal Reserve and Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen.Being able to decipher context in any stock move based on the news is important for any sector or industry group. However
column8: I constantly see investors fail to do so in the financial sector
column9: which naturally is sensitive interest-rate levels. In other words
column10: when the Fed sounds hawkish
column11: bank stocks (especially in this environment) tend to pop. A dovish Fed has a tendency to lead to lower interest rates
column12: and thus weighs on financials.And that brings me to our analysis of Wells Fargo.WFC Stock ChartsLooking at the multiyear weekly chart of Wells Fargo shares
column13: we see that the post-election rally this past November cleanly broke the stock back above its 50-week (yellow) and 200-week (red) moving averages.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThis also coincided with a breakout of the big bull flag-like pattern that I marked with the two purple-dotted parallels.Click to EnlargeWFC stock then slipped into a sideways pattern (marked by the blue box)
column14: which thus far this week it has marginally broken out of to the upside.From this angle
column15: WFC stock now looks poised to overtake its 2015 highs and push toward $60 as a next upside target (barring any quick bearish reversal
column16: of course).On the daily chart
column17: we see that during the two-month consolidation phase
column18: Wells Fargo in mid- to late January and through early February continuously found support at its rising 50-day moving average (yellow).Click to EnlargeThis support ultimately helped WFC stock attempt a breakout of the consolidation phase on Monday. The stock finally broke higher on Tuesday on a daily closing basis.Why Amazon.com
column19: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column20: 000 in 2017Active investors and traders could look to try Wells Fargo stock from the long side. The $60 area is your next upside target. Meanwhile
column21: respect any bearish reversal that closes the stock back below $56.80 as a potential ""pop-and-drop"" move.Like what you see? Sign up for our dailyBeat the Belle-letter and get Serge's investment advice delivered to your inbox every morning!You can also download his6 Keys for Successful Trading and Investing.More From InvestorPlace9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the Dividends3 Marijuana Stocks That Don't Need U.S. LegalizationHow Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Turns Lemons Into ProfitsThe postBreakout Alert: Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column3: 000 in 2017;2/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI've said it before
column5: and I'll say it again:Amazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) will take over the world. While the general public obsesses over bad hair and the color orange
column7: I think we face a bigger threat. Amazon's drones and their uncanny way of doing business will fundamentally alter commerce as we know it. Note that I didn't say ""e-commerce."" When you dominate as much as AMZN stock has
column8: your industry no longer requires a qualifying prefix.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAnybody that doubts that AMZN stock could hit the$1
column9: 000 marksimply needs to peruse theircustomer serviceoptions.If you ever encounter an issue using Amazon
column10: the company will take care of you promptly. Should you need immediate
column11: on the spot assistance
column12: AMZN will take you to a special menu screen. From there
column13: you enter your phone number
column14: and literally within seconds
column15: you will be directed to a company representative.We all know firsthand how frustrating most customer service experiences are. I wouldn't be surprised if some companies deliberately promote poor service just so you won't call them. This of course is just another reason why Amazon stock is so special. They could rest on their laurels. They could kick back and relax
column16: knowing that their status as king is unchallenged. Yet they still have the same hunger that they did back in the late 1990s.Maybe that's why AMZN stock is one of the greatest investments in history
column17: while generational internet peersNetscapeandLycosarehistory.AMZN Stock Teeing Up for An Explosive 2017I can go on a full-blown rant listing all the reasons why every investor should at least consider Amazon stock
column18: but a recent development in the markets really solidified the bullish argument. As you know
column19: AMZN stock didn't do so well when Donald Trump won the general election on Nov. 8. Within a few days
column20: shares had fallen by as much as 9%. This is understandable considering the bitter and contentious political campaign season.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayEven by the end of 2016
column21: AMZN stock was conspicuously lower than its pre-election result close. However
column22: that changed dramatically at the start of the new year. Amazon stock gained some much-needed traction
column23: and shot above the $800-mark. Since breaching that psychological barrier
column24: AMZN has yet to fall back below it. And for January
column25: Amazon saw a robust 9% return.This is important because January is typically not a good time for Amazon stock. Of all the opening months going back to 1998
column26: shares average an extremely pedestrian 0.6%. However
column27: annual returns from 1998 through 2016 average 84%.Such huge discrepancies made me wonder - are there indicators in January that predict how AMZN stock will do later?Click to EnlargeThe answer is a resounding yes.This past January's performance for AMZN stock was the fourth best overall. Of the three other times that Amazon stock posted better opening months
column28: investors later saw average annual returns of 120%. Inclusive of every positive January
column29: AMZN still nets an amazing average annual return of 100%.That's not all. Of the seven years in which Amazon took a loss
column30: six had Januarys that also incurred red ink. The one exception occurred in 2001
column31: during the immediate aftermath of the tech bubble bursting. As long as January holds up
column32: it's highly unlikely to be on the losing end.Amazon's Fundamentals Look Great Too!I don't recommend making a decision on an opportunity on the basis of a sole metric or indicator. The same can be said about statistical data. Even the best-reasoned and logical calculations can't account for every variable. Just like the election of President Trump
column33: there are certain elements of unpredictability that can and will bite you.Another Take - Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN): Is It Time to Start Worrying?However
column34: with AMZN stock
column35: I think investors have a little more buffer to play with thanks to its solid fundamentals. Primarily
column36: Amazon is still innovating. We saw a bit of that during the Super Bowl commercial featuring Amazon Prime Air. It's also a dominant player in cloud computing
column37: frustrating companies likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column38: SAP SE (ADR)(NYSE:SAP)
column39: International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL).And while I acknowledge it's risky for AMZN stock if it doesn't work out
column40: I like Amazon's venture into groceries. Granted
column41: I'm not crazy on possible rumors that the company is thinking about rolling out2
column42: 000 stores. But if they do this right - particularly in trendy places like their Seattle hometown - AMZN could have another winner on its hands.These underlying drivers provide the confidence for investors willing to bet that Amazon stock will hit quadruple digits. However
column43: what can't be denied is the momentum. When AMZN gets hot
column44: it almost always stays hot. For many
column45: that will be the nudge they need to make their final decision.As of this writing
column46: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any Minute12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThe postWhy Amazon.com
column47: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1

column1: Move Over China: India's the Best Place to Invest Right Now;2/14/2017;"(1:30) - Apple to begin iPhone manufacturing in India(6:15) - Tesla speculates opening the doors into India's   Market(9:15) - Internet Expansion   in India(13:35) - Amazon's Big Investment into India(21:30) - India's influencing infrastructure(25:25) - Stock Re-capWelcome to Episode #70 of the Zacks Market Edge Podcast.Every week
column2: host and Zacks stock strategist
column3: Tracey Ryniec
column4: will be joined by guests to discuss the hottest investing topics in stocks
column5: bonds and ETFs and how it impacts your life.In this episode
column6: Tracey is joined by Neena Mishra
column7: Zacks Director of ETF Research and also the editor ofZacks Income Investor.But she's not on the show this week to talk about ETFs or income stocks. No
column8: she's joining Tracey to discuss a far more important topic: the investing opportunities in India.Neena just returned from a trip to India where she noticed that there was a lot more optimism about the economy.Prime Minister Modi has been trying to institute economic reforms to open up India's economy
column9: which has been notoriously closed off to foreign investment. Given the developments over the last few years
column10: it looks like he is succeeding.While many American technology and social media companies are shut out of China for various reasons
column11: India has seemingly opened its doors. With 1.2 billion people
column12: and growing
column13: many companies would love to tap that consumer base.With one of the largest populations of Millennials in the world
column14: and a growing middle class
column15: 2017 could be the year of India.Tracey and Neena discuss 5 ways in which investors can invest in India's rising economic power
column16: without even leaving the shores of the United States.5 Stocks to Play the Indian Growth Story1.AppleAAPLonly has 2% of India's smartphone market. Estimated at 300 million
column17: and growing
column18: that's just a small sliver of the market. But until 2017
column19: it hasn't been able to open Apple retail stores in the country. Thanks to a deal to manufacture the phones in India
column20: which will bring costs of the phones down for consumers
column21: Apple could soon be tapping India's growing elite.2.TeslaTSLAappears to be poised to enter the India market after CEO Elon Musk tweeted out in February 2017 that it is looking to enter India in mid-2017. There are also rumors that a long-awaited Tesla Asia manufacturing plant may get the green light in India
column22: instead of China. Stay tuned.3.FacebookFBhas long been shut out of the massive Chinese market
column23: but that's not the case in India. One problem in India
column24: however
column25: has been the poor Internet infrastructure. There are just 250 million data subscribers
column26: although that number is growing quickly. In 2016
column27: Facebook tried to give away the Internet in India but was shot down by the government. However
column28: data companies have been quickly expanding which is helping Facebook's reach. In the fourth quarter of last year
column29: India was Facebook's fastest growing market.4.AmazonAMZNhas put the most on the line in India as it has already spent about $5 billion to expand its fulfillment centers and delivery service in the country. Amazon Prime has launched in 100 cities. 10% of India's population speaks English
column30: which makes it the second largest English speaking country
column31: after the United States
column32: in the world. It's facing competition
column33: however
column34: from Alibaba and homegrown FlipKart and Snapdeal. But it has launched Amazon Video and a recent 3-day Great Indian Sale saw sales growth surge over 200% compared to a regular shopping day.5.NetflixNFLXhas an aggressive international expansion plan
column35: and it includes India. In December 2016
column36: just as Amazon Video launched
column37: Netflix announced a partnership with Bollywood movie star and producer
column38: Shah Rukh Khan. Right now
column39: Neena says Netflix is charging around $10 a month for its streaming service. That is high for India. But
column40: again
column41: companies are looking at the growth potential.What else should you know about India and investing in its hot growth story in 2017?Find out the answers to this and more on this week's podcast.Zacks' Best Investment Ideas for Long-Term ProfitmakeArticleAd();Today you can gain access to long-term trades with double and triple-digit profit potential rarely available to the public. Starting now

column1: Amazon.com Gives a New Clue About Prime Member Numbers;2/14/2017;"One ofAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) most closely guarded metrics is how many Amazon   Prime members there are. For years
column2: Amazon has merely referred to   its Prime member base as being in the ""tens of millions."" The   company has used that language since 2013
column3: leaving investors to   speculate where in the 20 million to 90 million range the figure   actually sits.But third-party research firms are always happy to suggest   some estimates. Consumer Intelligence Research Partners (CIRP)   regularly puts out estimates
column4: with the most recent being from   October 2016
column5: pegging Amazon's Prime member base at 65 million.   Meanwhile
column6: we know that Amazon should have at least66 millionPrime members by now
column7: based on the growth rates and figures that   Amazon has disclosed over the years.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();Well
column8: the company has finally started to give clearer clues as   to its Prime member base.Saying more while still saying nothingAmazon recently filed its 2016 10-K
column9: and for the first time it   has started disclosing a new category of sales called ""retail   subscription services
column10: which includes ""annual and monthly fees   associated with Amazon Prime membership
column11: as well as audiobook
column12: e-book
column13: digital video
column14: digital music
column15: and other subscription   services."" This metric totaled $6.4 billion last year
column16: and has   grown significantly over the past three years.Data source: Amazon 10-K. Chart by author.If we were to take the figure at face value and do the   super-complicated math of dividing sales by Prime's cost of $99   per year
column17: that would imply about 64.5 million Prime members. But   it's not so clear-cut for a few reasons.For starters
column18: theaveragemembership fee is impossible to calculate. Amazon offers   discounted memberships for students; Prime receives regular   promotions that reduce the fee
column19: like a Black Friday deal in 2016   that knocked off $20; Prime is available in many countries
column20: each   with varying (and often lower) fees that are subject to volatile   currency translation; some members may pay monthly instead of   yearly
column21: which costs more ($132 instead of $99).Additionally
column22: Amazon sells all sorts of subscriptions that   likely fall into this category
column23: from digital content to dog   food.Amazon also accounts for the Prime membership fees it collects   in different ways
column24: allocating portions to product sales and   service sales while amortizing those amounts over the   subscription term; some of the revenue remains deferred
column25: while   the new metric only includes recognized revenue. Another portion   of the fee is even allocated as shipping revenue.In other words
column26: while Amazon's new disclosure around retail   subscription revenue provides yet another data point for   investors to scrutinize and analyze
column27: the company has done a good   job of splitting up the allocation of Prime fees for accounting   purposes in a way that still obfuscates how many Prime members   there are. It's safe to say that memberships are in the ballpark   of 65 million to 70 million at this point
column28: and at the rate that   Amazon is adding Prime members
column29: it'll be less than two years   until it changes its language from a vague ""tens of millions"" to   a still-vague ""over a hundred million.""Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more     than a decade beating the market. column1: Better Buy: Baidu Inc. vs. Amazon.com Inc.;2/14/2017;"Baidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) have both beenveryprofitable plays for long-term shareholders. Shares of Baidu have   risen 1
column2: 480% over the past ten years
column3: while shares of Amazon have   surged 2
column4: 050%.Baidu and Amazon probably won't repeat those massive gains   over the next decade
column5: but both tech giants remain solid   investments -- Baidu is the top search engine in China
column6: and   Amazon is the biggest e-commerce site and cloud platform provider   in the world. Let's compare both company growth trajectories and   valuations to see which is a better buy at current prices.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();How fast are Baidu and Amazon growing?Baidu's revenue grew 35% in fiscal 2015
column7: but it's only   expected to rise 6% in fiscal 2016 when it reports its full-year   earnings on Feb. 23. That slowdown was mainly caused by a   government crackdown on misleading ads (especially for healthcare   products) across its sites
column8: aswap of its stakein online travel agencyQunarwith its rivalCtrip
column9: and the overall slowdown of the Chinese economy.But once those headwinds fade
column10: Baidu's top line is expected to    grow 20% in fiscal 2017. That growth will likely be fueled   by its investments in new and adjacent markets
column11: like O2O   (online-to-offline) services which integrate new services into   its core mobile app
column12: driverless vehicles
column13: and artificial   intelligence.Amazon's revenue rose 20% in fiscal 2015
column14: 27% in fiscal 2016
column15: and is expected to rise another 22% this year. That consistent   growth can be attributed to the rapid growth of its core   marketplace businesses and the growth of AWS (Amazon Web   Services)
column16: the biggest cloud platform in the world. During fiscal   2016
column17: AWS revenues surged 55% and accounted for 9% of its top   line -- compared to 7% in 2015.How profitable are Baidu and Amazon?Most of Baidu's revenues come from ads
column18: which have much higher   margins than Amazon's main marketplace business. However
column19: Baidu's   operating margins have gradually declined over the past few   years
column20: due to the ramp up in its spending on O2O services and   other businesses. Meanwhile
column21: Amazon's operating margins have   gradually improved due to the growth of AWS
column22: which has much   higher margins than its marketplace business.Source:YCharts.Baidu's net income rose 155% in fiscal 2015
column23: but much of that   gain came from the aforementioned share swap with Qunar and   Ctrip. For fiscal 2016
column24: analysts expect Baidu's net earnings to   fall nearly 10% on higher O2O investments in letting users order   meals
column25: hail cabs
column26: make payments
column27: and perform other tasks within   its core app. Baidu needs these features to widen its moat   againstTencent(NASDAQOTH: TCEHY)
column28: which squeezes similar features into its   monolithic WeChat app. But looking forward
column29: analysts expect   Baidu's earnings to rebound 33% in 2018 as those ecosystem   investments bear fruit.Amazon's rising operating margins lifted its net income by   125% in 2015 and 298% in 2016. Analysts expect AWS' top line   growth and its steady operating margins to boost its net earnings   by 49% this year and 75% in fiscal 2018. That impressive bottom   line growth will give Amazon more freedom to use loss leading and   low-margin strategies (like additional Prime services
column30: Echo
column31: Fire   TV
column32: Dash buttons) to expand its e-commerce ecosystem. However
column33: investors should be aware that an ongoing price battle in the   cloud platform market has forced AWS to repeatedly lower its   prices -- so the unit's bottom line growth could still hit a few   speed bumps in the near future.What the valuations tell usBaidu trades at 14 times trailing earnings
column34: which is much   lower than the industry average of 50 for internet information   providers. But its forward P/E of 32 is higher due to its   expected slowdown in earnings growth.Amazon has a trailing P/E of 192
column35: which initially looks lofty   but isn't terribly high relative to its earnings growth in 2016.   Its forward P/E of 65 also looks reasonable compared to earnings   growth expectations for 2017 and 2018.With high-growth internet companies like Baidu and Amazon
column36: it's also important to check their enterprise value to free cash   flow (EV/FCF) ratios. A lower figure indicates that the company   is ""cheaper"" relative to its free cash flow -- which can be used   to further expand their businesses. As seen in the following   chart
column37: Amazon looksmuchcheaper than Baidu by that key metric.Source:YCharts.The winner: AmazonI own shares of both Baidu and Amazon
column38: and I still recommend   buying both stocks as long-term tech investments. But if I can   only buy one at current prices
column39: I'd buy Amazon because it   exhibits steadier top and bottom line growth with reasonable   valuations. As for Baidu
column40: investors should see if short-term   concerns about its rising expenses punish the stock -- which   could reveal better buying opportunities.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. The connection gives Shopify store   owners seamless access to the millions of customers searching for   products to buy on Amazon.""Our work with Amazon is an important step in   strengthening our robust multi­channel commerce strategy and the   ability of our merchants to sell anywhere their customers buy

Winners of Shopify's 2017 Build a Bigger Business competition --   this year's version of the company's long-running entrepreneurial   contest -- will get to embark on a learning retreat with Robbins   and other Shopify coaches

column1: Don’t Buy Into Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Until You Consider All Angles;2/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhen I look at the analysis of my fellow InvestorPlace colleagues
column3: I see a recurring pattern. They're bullish onAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA)
column4: and exceedingly so. Dana Blankenhorn is on record saying that BABA stock willhit all-time highs. James Brumley believes that Alibaba stock willdo the impossible- outperformAmazon.com
column5: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN). I
column6: on the other hand
column7: am not too convinced.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThis isn't to say that I don't think those metrics can't come true. For example
column8: I can easily see a case where the Alibaba stock price hits an all-time high. The markets are in a carefully optimistic mood right now. President Donald Trump
column9: while still being the self-anointed king ofTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR)
column10: is saying just the right words. Plus
column11: theiShares FTSE/Xinhua China 25 Index (ETF)(NYSEARCA:FXI) is near double-digits year-to-date.Therefore
column12: don't be surprised if BABA stock outduels AMZN for a few cycles.So what is my issue with Alibaba stock? There are two concerns that I have: the first
column13: a broader perspective that is rarely discussed
column14: and the second
column15: the lack of technical enthusiasm.BABA stock Can Turn on a DimeLet's tackle the broader concerns
column16: but to do that
column17: I will need to wade into a politically sensitive area. Since our kindergarten and elementary school years
column18: we've been taught that we are all the same. As we become adults
column19: we find that such platitudes - while well-meaning - are not very helpful. People are different. And Asian markets are a lot different than American or western markets. Because of this
column20: comparing BABA stock to an American counterpart is also not helpful.7 High-Risk
column21: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowThe reason for this is that the gambling culture is so integrated in Asian cultures that it's not really defined as a social problem. Only when Asian immigrants come to the U.S.
column22: for example
column23: dogambling behaviorsbecome quantified as problems. According to numerous Asian-American researchers interviewed byPsychology Today
column24: individual cultures throughout Asia actively promote a gambling ethos.What does this have to do with Alibaba stock? Investors need to be aware that BABA can make you rich
column25: or it can make you poor in a hurry. This is especially true because we just saw a massive collapse in the underlying Chinese markets. Sure
column26: the benchmark FXI is up over 10% this year. However
column27: it's also down more than 23% from its 2015 highs.Plus
column28: we've alreadyseen this showbefore. Back in the late 1980s
column29: many feared Japan would take over the world. This was one of the subtle themes of Hollywood blockbusters likeBlack Rain.Then the collapse happened
column30: and Japanese markets have never looked the same. True
column31: China and Japan have different fundamentals
column32: but it's worth considering when looking at BABA stock.Alibaba Stock Isn'tThatImpressiveI will further argue that a correlation exists between the Asian gambling culture and Alibaba stock's technical performance.Consider the average annual return of BABA. On paper
column33: it's really not that impressive. Between 2014 (which was not a complete year) and 2016
column34: the average is a mere 1.2%. People love BABA stock for its surges in momentum
column35: but that's about it. As a prime example
column36: shares are up 15.5% YTD
column37: but only after dropping 12% between Nov. 8 and the end of December.Click to EnlargeOverall
column38: the history of Alibaba stock isn't that favorable. On the day of its initial public offering
column39: BABA stock closed at $93.89. Presently
column40: shares are trading slightly over $101. That's just an 8% net profit after all this time. The math is pretty clear - BABA is one choppy mess.In China and other Asian markets
column41: they live for this kind of volatility. In America and the West? Not so much.And if we're in the business of comparing Chinese stocks to American stocks
column42: consider Amazon's performance relative to where BABA is now. On its 605th day of trading
column43: AMZN was up almost 4
column44: 400% since its first closing price. Of course
column45: that was smack dab in the middle of the tech bubble. But even during the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11
column47: AMZN was up more than 216% from its opening drive.Know the Risks Before Buying BABAThis leads me to ask an unavoidable question. If Chinese consumers are truly ringing up the cash registers for discretionary items
column48: why isn't BABA doing better? They've already beaten their regional rivals likeJD.Com Inc(ADR)(NASDAQ:JD). Plus
column49: everybody has presented otherwise excellent arguments for its imminent rise higher.Why Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Still Needs to Prove ItselfIf you were to hold BABA stock long-term
column50: it really didn't do you any good. If you traded it
column51: and traded it well
column52: however
column53: it's a different story.This brings me to a sensitive conclusion. When you talk about Alibaba stock
column54: you have to look at it from all angles
column55: especially the cultural one. BABA can work for you
column56: but boy
column57: you have to know what you're getting yourself into.As of this writing
column58: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace9 Top Pharmaceutical Stocks to Buy for the Dividends7 Dividend Stocks for the Retirement You DeserveThe postDon't Buy Into Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Until You Consider All Anglesappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Bitcoin Meets Starbucks: iPayYou's Bold Bet Goes Live;2/14/2017;"By Michael ScottWith 2017 in full motion
column2: Bitcoin’s price climb to the mid-$900 range and beyond continues to raise eyebrows. For many
column3: this milestone is just one signal of cryptocurrency’s growing repute as a legitimate store of investment value.Little attention
column4: however
column5: has been given to Bitcoin’s utility as a day-to-day method of payment. Practical use cases involving consumer adoption
column6: in fact
column7: are rarely talked about. This is despite the well-documented cost
column8: efficiency and security advantages of the Bitcoin payment network for both consumers and businesses alike.makeArticleAd();A new U.S.-based startup company aims to change this through an effort to accelerate the everyday use of Bitcoin for consumers worldwide. Launched in May of 2016
column9: iPayYouis an online platform and digital wallet that promotes the viability of Bitcoin as a method of payment. It immediately saw early success through a unique feature known as Pay-by-Twitter — the first online platform site for peer-to-peer payments over Twitter (TWTR).Now in a bold bet sure to deliver a caffeine jolt to the retail sector
column10: iPayYou this past December introduced Bitcoin Direct to Starbucks (SBUX)
column11: a new way for coffee aficionados to pay for those espressos and other drinks through the use of Bitcoin.This feature allows users to seamlessly transfer bitcoins from their existing iPayYou Bitcoin wallet to their Starbucks mobile app. They select how much (in USD) they wish to transfer before prompting Bitcoin Direct to Starbucks to automatically withdraw that amount from their iPayYou account. Once deposited into that person’s Starbucks account
column12: purchases can be made via the mobile app at any Starbucks location.This latest addition to the iPayYou platform comes on the heels of iPayYou’s recent gift card integration
column13: allowing Bitcoin to be used for instant gift card purchases from retailers like Amazon (AMZN)
column14: Best Buy (BBY) and iTunes (AAPL).These creative payment applications are the mastermind of founder and CEO Gene Kavner
column15: former Worldwide Director of Amazon Associates. With extensive experience in the world of commerce
column16: including prominent positions at Microsoft (MSFT) and Expedia (EXPE)
column17: Kavner developed iPayYou with the intention of establishing a easy-to-use Bitcoin wallet with simple features and low costs.Regarding the strategic collaboration with Starbucks
column18: Kavner remarks: “The broader significance of this move is that iPayYou is able to encourage Bitcoins to be spent in ways that its creators intended — for everyday purchases from popular merchants without needing a bank account to do so. This arrangement with Starbucks allows coffee lovers to replenish their primary Starbucks account with their Bitcoin holdings.  We’ve accomplished this feat without Starbucks having to directly accept Bitcoin. Our hope is that through this demonstration Starbucks will soon begin accepting Bitcoin directly
column19: sooner rather than later.”In terms of advantages for Starbucks regulars
column20: Kavner continues: “We intend to show that Bitcoin is not only a great investment but is also becoming quite useful in everyday life. Because so many of us are addicted to coffee
column21: being able to use Bitcoin to purchase anything at Starbucks is an enormous win for everyday consumers. And Starbucks will benefit too due to the amount of Bitcoin users who will now become customers.”Over time
column22: Kavner believes that initiatives like this will encourage merchant acceptance of Bitcoin. “Probably the most important metric that every merchant looks at when deciding what methods of payment to accept is how many new customers will it help attract. A key reason for the slow merchant adoption of Bitcoin has been the relatively limited amount of people who wanted to use Bitcoin for POS transactions. Now
column23: I believe that more and more will.”In terms of what’s next for Bitcoin Direct for 2017 and beyond
column24: Kavner is optimistic: “We’re going to continue to make Bitcoin easier
column25: safer and more useful over 2017 and beyond. We are planning on expanding to enable more merchant adoption as well as adding many features that every Bitcoin wallet should have. At the same time
column26: we’ll make Bitcoin simple to understand
column27: not just to those of us who know and love Bitcoin already but for the everyday consumer who may not even know what Bitcoin is. We’ll continue to innovate to make Bitcoin easier and more useful for everyone.”"

column1: Is Netflix Inc. Falling Behind in the World's Fastest Growing Internet Market?;2/14/2017;"Netflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) launched in India with a lot of fanfare roughly a   year ago as part of its global expansion efforts. Since India is   the world's fastest growing internet and smartphone market
column2: it is   important for Netflix to establish itself in the region. However
column3: the lure of India's internet growth and entertainment consumption   mean Netflix won't have a free hand in this market for long.In fact
column4: Netflix's brand has failed to strike a chord with   Indian customers. The launch ofAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) Prime Video service and the growth of the   Hotstar streaming service
column5: owned byTwenty-First Century Fox(NASDAQ: FOX) (NASDAQ: FOXA)
column6: have posed big challenges for the   company.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Netflix's pricing is a big problemNetflix's biggest problem in India is pricing. In a country   where consumption of pirated content is rampant
column7: Netflix needed   to get its pricing right before anyone else in order to drive   adoption of its service. According to a survey by Irdeto
column8: 66% of   polled customers watch pirated content in India
column9: though 56% of   them could be convinced to pay for content.Image source: Netflix.However
column10: whoever designed Netflix's strategy seems to have   forgotten the gap in the GDP per capita between India and the   company's home market. Netflix priced its basic monthly plan at   INR 500 (roughly $7.50) -- almost equivalent to the price of the   basic plan it charges in the U.S. The premium plan costs INR 800
column11: almost $11.99 at the current exchange rate
column12: which is identical to   what Netflix charges in the U.S. However
column13: India's GDP per capita   was just $1
column15: whereas the U.S. stands at about 30   times that. Netflix should have taken this gap into consideration   as its current subscription plans limit its reach to wealthier   audiences only.Then
column16: there's the problem of slow internet speeds and data   costs. According toAkamai
column17: India has the slowest average internet speed in Asia-Pacific at   3.5 Mbps. Additionally
column18: consulting firm Analysys Mason points out   that an average Indian customer spends 2.6% of her annual income   to pay for 1 GB of data a month. This is more than the 0.2% to   0.4% of annual income customers in developed countries spend to   get the same service.High internet costs and sluggish data speeds make Netflix's   subscription plans especially costly as customers will need to   also spend money on a bigger data package. Most content   consumption in the country will take place on smartphones
column19: but an   average smartphone in India generated just 559 MB of data each   month in 2016
column20: which a Netflix stream would consume in just 90   minutes. Therefore
column21: to consume more Netflix content
column22: a user will   have to buy more data and shell out more money above and beyond   subscription costs.Amazon and Hotstar are eating Netflix's lunchNetflix needs to think about India from a longer-term   perspective
column23: as mobile data consumption in the country is   expected to grow at a rapid pace. TheEricssonMobility Report indicates that India's mobile data consumption   will grow to 7 GB per smartphone in 2021 thanks to a drop in data   costs and the growth of high-speed networks.The company needs to keep its subscription costs low until   data costs in India go down. Unfortunately
column24: Netflix failed to do   so and is now losing the market to the likes of Amazon and   Hotstar
column25: who have kept their prices significantly lower.Amazon launched Prime Video in India in Dec. 2016
column26: and the   company sells it as a part of the Prime package
column27: which costs INR   499 (approximately $7.46) annually. Therefore
column28: Amazon's annual   subscription can be had for the same amount a customer would pay   for a month of Netflix. Even if Amazon raises its Prime   membership to INR 999 a year (approximately $15)
column29: as expected
column30: it   would still be much cheaper than Netflix's annual cost.What's more
column31: Amazon does not discriminate in the video quality   it provides to customers. Users can enjoy both HD and ultra HD   for a flat subscription fee at Amazon
column32: while Netflix charges a   premium for each category. Amazon also provides expedited   delivery and early access to deals as a part of the Prime   package
column33: giving customers good value for their money.While Amazon is beating Netflix on pricing
column34: Twenty-First   Century Fox's Hotstar is beating Netflix on content -- especially   sports. Hotstar's premium subscription is priced at just INR   199 (just under $3) a month
column35: though there is a free model as well   that gives delayed access to content and also carries   advertisements.In fact
column36: Hotstar is the top video streaming app in India   according to App Annie
column37: with Amazon Prime and Netflix occupying   fifth and ninth positions
column38: respectively. There are two key   factors working in Hotstar's favor: strong local content and   sports. Since Hotstar is under the umbrella of India's biggest   television house -- Star TV -- it has good access to local   content such as popular TV shows from local channels.More importantly
column39: Hotstar gives users access to live sports as   a part of its subscription plan
column40: which is a key differentiator   for it compared to Amazon and Netflix. The app gives users access   to a wide range of sports from cricket to football to tennis
column41: along with HBO shows such asSilicon ValleyandGame of Thrones.This diverse content
column42: along with reasonable pricing
column43: is one of   the major reasons for Hotstar's success in the region
column44: while   Netflix is lacking on both of those fronts. This is why a new   entrant such as Amazon
column45: which launched almost a year after   Netflix
column46: is already in a better position.Unless Netflix adapts its business model for the Indian   market
column47: it won't find as much success in the country as it has in   so many other markets. The competition will continue to leave it   behind
column48: which should be cause for concern since India's online   video subscribers are expected to exceed 100 million by 2020   (from just 12 million in 2014).10 stocks we like better than NetflixWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column49: it can pay to listen. After all
column50: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column51: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column52: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Netflix wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column53: 2017.Harsh Chauhanhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon and Netflix. The Motley Fool     has adisclosure policy."

column15: Kohl's and Macy's shareholders' best hope may be a   sale to aprivate equity firmoranother retailer. J.C. Penney has an eventougher road ahead
column16: and if the heavily indebted retailer doesn't significantly   improve its profitability and cash-flow generation
column17: it could head   down a path similar to that of Sears Holdings.All told
column18: the department-store industry appears to be in a   state of secular decline
column19: and these retailers' ongoing struggles   will be a major storyline to watch in 2017.No reprieve for discountersEven discount chains such asTarget(NYSE: TGT) and the mightyWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) have seen their sales and margins dented by   intensifying competition. For decades
column20: these discount chains were   the disruptors; with their wide selection of goods and low   prices
column21: they steadily claimed market share from their   higher-priced and often smaller rivals.Now
column22: however
column23: it's these massive retailers that are losing   share to an even more disruptive threat: the relentless rise of   e-commerce. And this global megatrend is being spearheaded by the   juggernaut that isAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .Can anyone challenge Amazon?Without the cost burdens and physical limitations of a store   base
column24: Amazon -- along with itsarmy of third-party sellers-- is able to offer an even wider selection of goods and often   lower prices than its still primarily brick-and-mortar   rivals.Even more worrisome for traditional retailers is that Amazon   dominates consumer mindshare when it comes to shopping online. In   fact
column25: areportby marketing firm BloomReach shows that 55% of consumers   begin their searches on the e-commerce titan's website when   shopping online
column26: up from 44% in 2015. During that time
column27: the   percentage of shoppers whose searches originated at all other   retailers' sites combined fell from 21% to only 16%
column28: with search   engines holding the remaining share. It appears that ""Amazon"" is   increasingly becoming synonymous with shopping in the minds of   consumers.To combat this trend
column29: Wal-Mart and Target are investing   aggressively in their e-commerce operations. Target islargely focusedon improving its website
column30: strengthening its supply chain
column31: and   utilizing more of its stores to fulfill online orders. Wal-Mart's   efforts are highlighted by its$3.3 billion acquisitionof e-commerce start-up Jet.com
column32: which the company hopes will help   it gain ground on Amazon.Yet even with these heavy investments
column33: Wal-Mart and Target's   e-commerce businesses are still only a fraction of the size of   Amazon's online retail operations. Still
column34: investors shouldn't   completely dismiss Wal-Mart and Target as threats to Amazon's   dominance
column35: and the battle between these giants will be   interesting to watch in the year
column36: and years
column37: ahead.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column38: the newsletter they   run

column1: Shopify Earnings: What Investors Should Expect;2/13/2017;"Shopify(NYSE: SHOP) will look to extend its flawless record of earnings   beats on Wednesday morning before the market opens.Shopify provides the backbone for some 325
column2: 000 online stores
column3: offering an easy way to set up an online store. It charges a   monthly fee for its core service. On top of that
column4: it offers   additional services such as payment processing and shipping
column5: for   which it takes a cut of each sale.Shares of Shopify are up about 27% since the company reported   its third-quarter earnings results. The share price is now   trading around its all-time high. Investors are expecting strong   results from the company
column6: whose revenue growth has been huge
column7: but   which has yet to turn a profit. Here's what investors should   expect from Shopify's fourth-quarter earnings.makeArticleAd();Data source: YCharts.Analysts expectations and Shopify's outlookThe consensus on the Street is that Shopify brought in around   $121.69 million in revenue for the fourth quarter. That's on the   high end of management's range of $120 million to $122   million.Analysts expect that revenue to translate into a $0.02 loss   per share. That's also in line with management's outlook for an   adjusted operating loss of $1 million to $3 million. Shopify also   provided a GAAP outlook of $10 million to $12 million in   operating losses for the quarter.But Shopify has consistently outperformed its revenue outlook   over the past year.QuarterOutlookActualQ4 2015$59 million-$61 million$70.2 millionQ1 2016$65 million-$67 million$72.7 millionQ2 2016$79 million-$81 million$86.6 millionQ3 2016$93 million-$95 million$99.6 millionQ4 2016$120 million-$122 million?Data source: Shopify quarterly reportsGiven Shopify's history of conservative outlooks
column8: the Street   may be underestimating the company's fourth-quarter results. It   wouldn't be a huge surprise if Shopify once again beats analysts'   expectations.Image source: ShopifyKey metrics to watchThere are several important operating metrics for investors to   pay attention to. First and foremost is the company's total   merchants. The number passed 325
column9: 000 in the third quarter
column10: up   from 200
column11: 000 the year before.In the fourth quarter last year
column12: Shopify added around 43
column13: 000   new merchants
column14: an extremely strong quarter. Management said this   year's fourth quarter will be strong once again
column15: but it tempered   expectations
column16: noting that it reports milestones throughout the   year (e.g.
column18: 000) instead of exact numbers. Depending on when   it passes those milestones within the quarter
column19: it could make   fourth-quarter additions look smaller.Another factor to pay attention to is the split between   subscription solutions revenue and merchant solutions revenue.   Subscription revenue is driven by the growing number of merchants   on the platform
column20: and it's growing more slowly than merchant   solutions revenue. Merchant solutions (payment processing
column21: shipping
column22: and the like) should surpass subscription revenue in   the fourth quarter
column23: especially considering retail sales tend to   increase during the holidays.It's worth noting that merchant solutions revenue carries a   lower margin than subscription revenue
column24: so Shopify may experience   some margin pressure. Ultimately
column25: however
column26: wide adoption of   merchant solutions from its merchants should support subscription   solutions as it makes the product stickier for Shopify's   customers.One last metric to consider is gross merchandise volume and   what percentage of that volume is processed through Shopify   Payments. During the third quarter
column27: GMV reached $3.8 billion and   Shopify Payments processed $1.5 billion
column28: or 39%. Before that
column29: Shopify didn't provide exact details but noted on its   second-quarter report that ""the percentage of GMV processed   through Shopify Payments continues to grow
column30: Qualitative updates from managementIn addition to those key metrics
column31: investors should watch for   management's commentary on its recent deal to integrate withAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) marketplace
column32: further strengthening Shopify's   partnership with the retail giant. The new deal makes it easier   for Shopify merchants to list their products on Amazon. Amazon   previously shut down its Amazon Webstore service and sent its   users to Shopify.Image source: ShopifyInvestors should also look for comments on the continued   growth of Shopify Plus
column33: its enterprise-level e-commerce solution.   Any updates on the progress of Shopify Shipping and Shopify   Capital -- two high-margin products -- could be valuable as   well.Overall
column34: Shopify looks set to produce yet another earnings   beat

column1: Nordstrom and Others Dump Trump: Here's Who Still Sells the Trump Brand;2/13/2017;"Ivanka Trump's fashion line has come under fire recently as the political turmoil surrounding President Donald Trump and his administration rages on. And now
column2: some retailers have stopped carrying Ivanka Trump's brand.Over the last several weeks
column3: corporate America has responded to President Trump's travel ban and other initiatives of the new Trump administration
column4: in a variety of manners. The biggest display came when nearly 130 companies
column5: including AppleAAPL
column6: FacebookFBand MicrosoftMSFT
column7: took to the courts to fight against the controversial travel ban from seven Muslim-majority nations.The Trump Brand BattleMacy'sMstopped selling Donald Trump's line of menswear in Summer 2015
column8: after the then presidential candidate made inflammatory remarks regarding Mexican immigrants. NBC Universal
column9: owned by ComcastCMCSAended its business relationship with Trump for the same reason when it opted to no longer air his Miss USA and Miss Universe pageants.Donald Trump's critics have urged consumers to stop shopping at retailers that sell Trump family brands
column10: including Ivanka Trump's line of women's clothing and accessories. At the same time
column11: Trump supporters have threatened to stop shopping at businesses that cut ties with any Trump brands.On February 2
column12: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick stepped down from Trump's economic advisory board amid the travel ban fight. The move leaves Tesla'sTSLAElon Musk as the only remaining big-time tech executive still sitting on the board.The battle between corporate America
column13: consumers
column14: the Trump administration and Trump brands is likely just heating up.Grab Your Wallet CampaignShannon Coulter
column15: a San Francisco-based political activist
column16: began the hashtag #GrabYourWallet campaign on social media in November. Since then
column17: the campaign has spawned into awebsitethat constantly updates its lists of companies that still carry or no longer carry Trump family brands and products.The website lists the ""Top Ten Companies We're Boycotting
column18: Other Companies We're Boycotting and Companies NOT Being Boycotted At This Time.""NordstromJWNofficially announced on February 2 it will not buy Ivanka Trump's brand for the upcoming season. The company first came under pressure to cut ties with all thingsTrump in Oct. 2016. The company cited her brand's declining performance as the reason it would no longer be carried
column19: not external political pressure.Nordstrom's stock went upafter the formal announcement.Neiman Marcus dropped Ivanka Trump's high-end jewelry line from its website nearly the same time Nordstrom made the move. Neiman representatives took a similar stance
column20: citing the brand's recent poor performance.Belk
column21: a Charlotte
column22: North Carolina-based store no longer sells Ivanka Trump's brand online. The company cited performance metrics for making the change. But
column23: the company still carries her brand in stores.WayfairW
column24: which sells furniture and home décor
column25: dropped Trump Home products in November. Fellow home design retailer Bellacor also dropped Trump Home.WalmartWMT-acquired e-commerce power Jet.com began to drop Donald Trump and Ivanka Trump-branded apparel and perfume
column26: according to aMicreport. ShopStyle
column27: another e-commerce site
column28: pulled Ivanka Trump products.St. Petersburg-based Home Shopping Network dropped some Trump Home offerings. But HSN stated the company did not have to cut ties with Ivanka Trump's brand
column29: amid reports it had dropped her brand as well. HSN stated it has never sold any Ivanka Trump products.Sears HoldingsSHLDremoved 31 Trump Home items from online stores.But the company pushed back Mondayamid reports it had stopped carrying Trump brands.Company's Still Selling Trump BrandDespite the turmoil
column30: many brands have not dropped the Trump brand. Macy's stopped selling Donald Trump's line of menswear
column31: but it still sells Ivanka Trump's line. This has placed the company firmly at the top of the grabyourwallet.org boycott list.AmazonAMZN
column32: Zappos
column33: Bloomingdale's
column34: Dillard's
column35: Bed Bath & BeyondBBBYand LL Bean are also all listed in the top ten of #grabyourwallet's Trump-based boycott rankings.Long-Term Buys You Won't See in the NewsThe stocks you see in today's headlines may not be in the news tomorrow or next week. column1: Netflix is My Biggest Stock Holding -- and That Isn't Changing Any Time Soon;2/13/2017;"Netflix
column2: Inc.(NASDAQ: NFLX) is by far my largest holding. Not because it's the   one I invested the most in -- far from it. I only invested 1.5%   of my original invested funds in Netflix. It has since grown to   an astounding 20% of my portfolio thanks to 3
column3: 000% gains. Some   might argue that is too much to have riding on a single company   and would've sold off some of the position to lock-in those   gains.Not me. Even after the massive run the stock has gone on
column4: I   see a business with several big growth opportunities that can   meaningfully move the needle.makeArticleAd();Netflix available across all your devices. Image source:     Netflix
column5: Inc.Netflix was my first investment back in 2007
column6: just as the   company was introducing its online streaming. I was one of the   disillusioned customers of Blockbuster -- now owned byDISH-- that found Netflix a couple of years earlier
column7: when I was   charged $40 in late fees for a movie that I could have purchased   for $20. I cut up my Blockbuster card
column8: joined Netflix and never   looked back. I saw then what I see now: a company that is   providing an unbeatable service at a reasonable price. I love the   programming
column9: my personal dealings with its customer service have   been seamless
column10: and these experiences as a consumer (plus some big   business levers) have made me a more confident investor.Ready to take on the worldIn addition to providing a great customer experience
column11: Netflix   has a large un-tapped pool of potential customers. Its total   addressable market
column12: based on fixed-line broadband subscribers is   estimated at 765 million homes worldwide. This number is   expected to grow to 925 million by 2020. Even excluding an   estimated 300 million potential customers in China
column13: a country   Netflix itself admits would be difficult to enter
column14: the company's   addressable market could exceed 625 million potential customers   within three years.Netflix available in 200 countries -and in Portuguese! Image     source: Netflix
column15: Inc.Within its US market
column16: the number of households is estimated at   125 million
column17: of which Netflix counts 49 million subscribers
column18: for   a penetration rate of about 40%. If it were to achieve that level   of penetration in the rest of the world -- even excluding China   -- paid subscribers could grow more than 2.5 times from its   current level of 94 million to 240 million worldwide. This   excludes potential market increases from population gains and   further broadband penetration.Economies of scale at playLet's not forget decreasing incremental costs
column19: which is the   cost of adding each additional subscriber. Once Netflix has built   out its library of streaming content
column20: a greater portion of the   revenue from each additional subscriber will drop to the bottom   line. Netflix has been hard at work growing its portfolio of   self-produced original programs. It plans to spend $6 billion in   2017 up from $5 billion in 2016. In its most recent shareholder   letter
column21: it stated ""it is clear to us that high quality content   travels well across borders."" The ability to spread the cost of   its content across an ever-growing base of global customers   produces economies of scale not available to traditional linear   TV broadcasters.Amazing original contentNetflix plans to have its self-produced originals eventually   account for half of the platform's content. At Goldman Sachs 25th   Annual Communacopia Conference on September 20
column22: 2016 CFO David   Wells indicated that the company was still a couple of years away   from that goal
column23: estimating that it is one-third to halfway there.   Netflix first began debuting exclusive original content in 2013   as a way to differentiate its offerings. Many of those shows have   become wildly popular. New seasons of some of its earliest   releases are still enthralling viewers includingHouse of CardsandOrange is the New Black. It's partnership's withThe Walt Disney Company's(NYSE: DIS) Marvel has produced such hits asDaredevil
column24: Jessica Jones
column25: The Punisher
column26: andLuke Cage-- my personal favorites. Other offerings includingStranger ThingsandMaking A Murdererhave become cultural phenomenons. The caliber of these offerings   has put the industry on notice that Netflix is a force to be   reckoned with and bolstered the strength of the platform.Netflix has plans for half its library to be self-produced     original content. Image source: Netflix
column27: Inc.It could still all go sidewaysWhat could go wrong? Plenty. Cash burn could overwhelm the   video purveyor. Even by its own estimates
column28: it will produce   negative cash flow of $2 billion in 2017
column29: up from $1.7 billion in   2016. Additionally
column30: competition is heating up in the space.Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) announced in December that it had expanded its   competing streaming service to 200 countries. The e-commerce   giant is one of the few companies with the resources to compete   with Netflix on a global level. Finally
column31: worldwide growth   estimates may be too aggressive. Netflix virtuous cycle only   works as it continues to add new members. If that growth stalls   before the build-out is complete
column32: it could come crashing   down.My money is where my mouth isEven in the face of those potential challenges
column33: my money is   still on Netflix. I think Netflix has executed its plan nearly   flawlessly
column34: itsQwikster debaclenotwithstanding. The worldwide expansion is on track and the   company very rarely misses its own internal financial and   subscriber growth estimates. That
column35: plus the success of its   original content
column36: proves to me that Netflix is company that is   connected to its customers.So long as the results keep proving that
column37: I don't plan on   selling any time soon.Find out why Netflixis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column38: the newsletter     they run

column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Can Always Brush Things Off;2/13/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI won't sit here and tell you that I have any idea what a reasonable valuation forAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) should be. I mean
column5: I have SOME idea
column6: but seeing how nobody else really has any idea
column7: I may as well throw darts. AMZN stock tends to move in big chunks based on big news
column8: such as an earnings report.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockEven though Amazon stock missed estimates when it reported last week
column9: and the stock got whacked
column10: I say it means nothing because there is no hard-and-fast way to value AMZN stock. Without that centralized
column11: normalized metric as a baseline
column12: it is difficult to interpret what the earnings report actually means except in a general sense.Nevertheless
column13: I'll try.First
column14: the market got tied in knots over Amazon missing revenue estimates. Revenue was $43.74 billion
column15: which fell short of the $44.68 billion total. Gasp. Web Services revenue fell $64 million short
column16: coming in at $3.536 billion. Double gasp. Q1 guidance was for $33.25 billion to $35.75 billion
column17: short of $35.95 billion expected.The sky is falling.Why AMZN Stock Isn't Really in Any TroubleOf course
column18: nobody mentioned that AMZN actually turned in a $749 million profit
column19: up 55% from the previous year. Web Services had operating income of $926 million compared to $580 million last year and that accounted for almost three-fourths of Amazon's total operating income. Mind you
column20: the loss in its international e-commerce unit blew up to $487 million from a loss of $108 million the year before.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenSee
column21: AMZN stock really is different from any other stock because it is basically taking huge chunks of cash and free cash flow and investing in a very-long-term infrastructure and services plan.Amazon is constantly investing in and beefing up its Prime service
column22: which various sources put at 65 million subscribers (Bezos won't say). This doesn't mean just the techy stuff like Price Reading
column23: Audible Channels and Twitch
column24: but the hub of Prime: free 2-day delivery.That's where the rub is from an expense standpoint. AMZN stock added 18 more cities to Prime service
column25: which means more infrastructure to support those cities
column26: like warehouses and labor and transport. The company needs fulfillment centers. That's why it's building a $1.5 billion new airport hub in Cincinnati.Then we can add in the investments in Amazon Fresh
column27: which also requires tons of infrastructure to support
column28: and its expansion into India.Spend
column29: spend
column30: spend in order to grow
column31: grow
column32: grow.What's so bizarre and different is that most companies would - after more than 20 years in business - have predictable earnings and growth. Except Amazon is trying to take over the world
column33: and Bezos isn't worried about profit because he has tons of cash flow. This is very John Malone of him
column34: and we know how successful Malone has been
column35: even as predicting earnings-per-share for any of his zillion tracking stocks is equally impossible.Thus
column36: a revenue miss means nothing to me. We're in the top of the third inning.Bottom Line on Amazon StockStill
column37: can we value Amazon stock at all? Well
column38: yes … sort of.Take Enterprise Value-to-EBITDA ratio: AMZN stock trades at about 30.Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) trades at 24.Wal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) trades at 7.7.Liberty Interactive Corp(NASDAQ:QVCA
column39: NASDAQ:QVCB) trades at 8.4. So on this basis
column40: AMZN stock is crazy expensive.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkOn a price-to-sales basis
column41: Amazon stock trades at 2.9. The other stocks above trade at 14
column43: respectively. So AMZN stock is arguably expensive by this metric as well.How about return on equity? This is the amount of net income that is returned as a percentage of shareholder equity. Amazon is at 14.52%. For FB
column44: WMT
column45: and QVCA
column46: return on equity is 19.76%
column47: 18.46% and 11.67%. In this case
column48: AMZN falls in the middle.Ultimately
column49: that's why I prefer to sell naked puts on Amazon stock that are far out of the money and expire months down the line. I make a little money with much less risk.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column50: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column51: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column52: and has written more than 1
column53: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.More From InvestorPlace10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe postWhy Amazon.com

column1: The Simple Concept Underlying U.S. Bancorp's Dominance;2/13/2017;"Even if you compareU.S. Bancorp(NYSE: USB) to the best in the banking business
column2: it still   dominates the competition. For seven consecutive years
column3: it has   ranked first among big banks in terms of return on equity
column4: the   preeminent profitability metric in the industry.I've studied U.S. Bancorp over the years in an effort to   figure out how it does this -- especially how it does so year in   and year out. The short answer is that the Minneapolis-based bank   is highly efficient
column5: spending a smaller share of its revenue on   operating expenses each year than even the notoriously efficientWells Fargo.Data source: Quarterly earnings reports. Chart by     author.makeArticleAd();But there's more to U.S. Bancorp's perennial outperformance   than just this. Efficiency is a necessary but not sufficient   condition of dominance in the bank industry. A bank must be   efficient to outperform its peers
column6: in other words
column7: but efficiency   alone doesn't capture the whole picture. It instead merely   ignites and accelerates what may best be described of as a force   of nature
column8: akin to the law of compounding returns.Jim Collins in his bookGood to Greatanalogizes this force of nature to a flywheel. It takes effort to   get the wheel spinning
column9: and more effort to make it go faster
column10: but   at a certain point
column11: Collins notes
column12: there's a breakthrough when   the laws of physics take over:The momentum of the thing kicks in in your favor
column13: hurling     the flywheel forward
column14: turn after turn . . . whoosh! . . . its     own heavy weight working for you. You're pushing no harder than     during the first rotation
column15: but the flywheel goes faster and     faster. Each turn of the flywheel builds upon the work done     earlier
column16: compounding your investment of effort. A thousand     times faster
column17: then ten thousand
column18: than a hundred thousand. The     huge heavy disk flies forward
column19: with almost unstoppable     momentum.No company illustrates the power of this concept better thanAmazon.com
column20: which
column21: as Brad Stone writes inThe Everything Store
column22: incorporated Collins' flywheel into its operating philosophy   more than a decade and a half ago.In Amazon's version
column23: a low-cost structure enables the   e-commerce giant to offer lower prices than its competitors.   Lower prices lead to happier customers
column24: which leads to higher   traffic on its website. Higher traffic encourages new sellers to   join Amazon's marketplace
column25: which increases selection. And a   better selection improves the customer experience
column26: which powers a   new revolution of the flywheel.The Virtuous Cycle
column27: as drawn by Amazon. Image source:     Amazon.Although Amazon and U.S. Bancorp are very different companies
column28: the flywheel concept works in a similar way for the $446 billion   bank. In fact
column29: given the unique dynamics of banking
column30: it may be an   even more powerful force in the financial services arena.By operating more efficiently than its peers
column31: U.S. Bancorp can   underprice them in the credit space. This attracts high-quality   borrowers
column32: boosting loan volumes and reducing loan losses. The   latter keeps a lid on credit costs and thereby enables U.S.   Bancorp to be even more competitive with respect to loan terms on   the next revolution of the flywheel. It also buttresses the   bank's debt rating
column33: which keeps its interest expenses low and   thus acts as added accelerant. Holding all else equal
column34: then
column35: with   each turn of the flywheel
column36: U.S. Bancorp should widen its   competitive advantage over its peers.This chain of events isn't just theoretical. Here's U.S.   Bancorp Chairman and CEO Richard Davis connecting the dots   between its low-cost debt and heightened pricing power on a   conference call with analysts in 2015:[Our best in class debt ratings] allow us to benefit from     pricing. And again
column37: this is an audience that understands this
column38: but if we're going to the markets and we can receive five-year     money at a 40 to 60 basis point benefit from our peer group
column39: that's five years we get to price things better by 40% to 60%     -- basis points and/or at least take half of it and put it into     price. We only deal with high-quality customers
column40: so we're not     using it for subprime or near-prime purposes. We're using it     for the best customers to win them and keep them
column41: but we're     unabashed about saying that we'll use pricing as a tool at this     moment in time.As I've demonstratedin the past
column42: moreover
column43: there's a clear correlation between efficiency ratios   and loan losses among the nation's biggest banks. This follows   from the fact that less efficient banks must stretch for yield in   their loan portfolios in order to generate the double-digit   returns on equity earned by more efficient banks. And because   higher yields reflect higher risk
column44: less efficient banks tend to   write off a larger share of their loan portfolios during   recessions such as the one following the financial crisis eight   years ago.Data source: S&P Global Market Intelligence. Chart by       author.The irregular but not infrequent undulations of the credit   cycle further accelerate this
column45: as banks that play fast and loose   with credit risk are more likely to fail when the economy takes a   turn for the worse. And even short of insolvency
column46: a bank that   takes large loan losses in a downturn is in no position to pick   up its less prudent peers for pennies on the dollar when they run   into trouble
column47: which is one of the most effective ways to grow a   bank and maximize returns over the long run.What all of this means is that U.S. Bancorp should continue to   outperform its peers in the years ahead. Its stock isn't cheap
column48: and Davis is retiring later this year
column49: but I don't believe that   either of these alter the investment thesis underlying its stock.10 stocks we like better than US BancorpWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
