column1: Google's Biggest Cloud Customer Just Signed a $1 Billion Deal With Amazon;2/12/2017;"It didn't take long for Google's biggest cloud customer to   split its allegiances. Just a week afterSnap(NYSE: SNAP) announced it signed a $2 billion five-year contract   with theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) company
column2: it signed a $1 billion   contract with Google's biggest cloud competitor --Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) .Snap will continue to use Google Cloud for the core Snapchat   functionality. The Amazon Web Services contract is for ""redundant   infrastructure support of our business operations
column3: according to   Snap'samended S-1filing.The new filing also revealed Snap has been using Amazon for   nearly a year
column4: so not much will change in the near term. But the   way Snap's contract is structured with Amazon
column5: it could be   spending nearly as much on AWS five years from now as it is on   Google Cloud.makeArticleAd();It's worth taking a closer look at Snap's cloud contracts.     Image Source: Snap.A quick look at Snap's cloud contractsYearAmazon spendingGoogle spending2017$50 million$400 million*2018$125 million$400 million*2019$200 million$400 million*2020$275 million$400 million*2021$350 million$400 millionSource: Snap S-1. *Snap has the option to defer up to 15% of   the amount to the subsequent year.Snap uses Google for most of its heavy lifting today. That   might change in five years. While Amazon just provides redundancy   for Snapchat to ensure the app doesn't suffer significant   downtime right now
column6: it could grow into a much bigger partner for   Snap. That's evident by the ramp in minimum obligations.Google still has a big advantage over Amazon. Snap built   Snapchat on Google's Cloud Platform. Transition to another cloud   provider ""would be difficult to implement
column7: and may cause us to   incur significant time and expense
column8: it said in its S-1. What's   more
column9: Snap built Snapchat using the tools available on Google
column10: some of which do not have an alternative in the market
column11: according to its prospectus.But if Snap wants to expand to China
column12: where Google doesn't   operate
column13: it'll have to rework things on another cloud provider
column14: anyway. Considering the growing size of Snap's cloud spending
column15: Amazon may be able to offer tools comparable to what it uses on   Google to help facilitate a transition.Google's cloud business is minuscule in comparison to   Amazon's. Snap's $400 million per year contract very likely made   it Google's biggest cloud customer
column16: and now Amazon's going to   steal away a good chunk of its business. That doesn't mean much   for Amazon -- its cloud business brought in $12 billion last year   -- but it means a whole lot to Google.What this means for SnapSnap is now committing $3 billion to cloud services over the   next five years. That's a lot for a company with only $405   million in annual revenue
column17: even one growing as quickly as   Snap.At some point
column18: it would make more sense for Snap to build out   its own infrastructure like other popular internet services.   Building infrastructure is capital intensive
column19: but once it's   built
column20: the company would no longer be as reliant on third parties   to support its flagship app. With Snap locked into contracts for   the next five years
column21: it's unlikely we'll see it go that way   anytime soon
column22: which means continued pressure on its gross   margin.Last year
column23: Snap's cost of revenue exceeded sales. The bulk of   its cost of revenue was attributed to its cloud infrastructure   expenses
column24: which climbed $192 million last year. As such
column25: Snap   posted a negative gross margin
column26: which is crazy for a company that   primarily produces software.By 2021
column27: Snap will be paying at least $750 million for cloud   services. That will make it one of the largest cloud-computing   customers in the world. With that much committed to Google and   Amazon
column28: Snap better get to work on growing its revenue.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: How Wal-Mart Can Take On Amazon Beyond Free 2-Day Shipping;2/12/2017;"Wal-Mart Stores
column2: Inc.(NYSE: WMT) has taken another step forward in its quest to challengeAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) for e-commerce supremacy.The world's largest retailer ditched its Amazon Prime-wannabe
column3: Shipping Pass
column4: which offered free three-day shipping for an annual fee of $49
column5: and is instead offering free two-day shipping on all orders of $35 or more.makeArticleAd();It's a better deal for customers
column6: as a majority of orders on the company's website are for more than $35
column7: and Wal-Mart's success has historically come from offering rock-bottom prices without hurdles such as a membership fee
column8: offering a different kind of value from Amazon Prime. Wal-Mart's own warehouse chain
column9: Sam's Club
column10: has always lagged behindCostco Wholesale.Image source: Wal-Mart.Wal-Mart is making more than 2 million items eligible for free two-day shipping
column11: but that's much less than Amazon
column12: which has over 50 million items available for free two-day shipping to Prime members. Wal-Mart's $35 minimum
column13: however
column14: is lower than Amazon's $50 minimum for non-Prime members
column15: which does not promise two-day delivery -- though deliveries now often come in two days anyway
column16: as the company's distribution network has vastly expanded in recent years.Wal-Mart's U.S. e-commerce CEO
column17: Marc Lore
column18: who came to the company with the Jet.com acquisition last year
column19: touted the move
column20: saying in a press release: ""I couldn't be more excited. We are moving at the speed of a start-up. Two-day free shipping is the first of many moves we will be making to enhance the customer experience and accelerate growth."" With a nod to Amazon
column21: Lore added
column22: ""In today's world of e-commerce
column23: two-day free shipping is table stakes. It no longer makes sense to charge for it.""Will it be enough?Wal-Mart's free two-day shipping offer is certainly a step in the right direction
column24: as was its acquisition last summer of Jet.com
column25: the company Lore founded. But there's also evidence that Amazon is stretching its lead over the retail giant.Amazon's North American e-commerce sales jumped 22% in the fourth quarter
column26: reaching $80 billion for the full year
column27: and the company grabbed 53% of all e-commerce sales growth in the country last year
column28: according to Slice Intelligence.That figure shows how dominant Amazon has become
column29: taking more than half of new e-commerce sales in the country
column30: which added $16 billion to its revenue last year. Retail giants like Wal-Mart and its competitors
column31: as well as smaller e-commerce providers
column32: are left to fight over the remaining growth.Amazon continues to tighten the screws on its rivals
column33: adding more members to Prime
column34: and spreading Prime Now and Fresh to new cities.According to Consumer Intelligence Research Partners
column35: Amazon now has 65 million Prime members
column36: or slightly more than half of total U.S. households. Wal-Mart's new two-day free shipping offer is unlikely to appeal to current Prime members
column37: who have already coughed up the $99 annual fee to get free shipping and benefits including video streaming and access to the Kindle Lending Library.But Wal-Mart can start by making a bid for non-Prime shoppers
column38: who may currently be even more profitable to Amazon -- the company is running a wide shipping deficit
column39: with net shipping costs totaling $7.2 billion last year. Shipping costs are growing faster than shipping revenue
column40: evidence that membership fees from Prime are not keeping up with shipping costs.Price vs. convenienceWal-Mart can start by pressing its price advantage over Amazon. After all
column41: the world's largest retailer reached the top of the food chain by promising everyday low prices that drove the mom-and-pop stores that couldn't compete out of business. Amazon stole some of that thunder as it also focused on rock-bottom prices during its early days
column42: but the company has increasingly pivoted to competing on convenience over price

column1: Amazon's Shipping Costs Are Soaring. Should Investors Be Worried?;2/12/2017;"E-commerce was supposed to be cheaper than operating a retail   store
column2: the traditional thinking went. Online sellers can save   money by avoiding pricey commercial rents and a staff devoted to   assisting customers.Despite the conventional wisdom
column3: that hasn't always been the   case
column4: and shipping costs are a primary reason why.Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) spends billions more on shipping than it brings in   in charges and fees
column5: and many brick-and-mortar retailers have   complained that e-commerce sales
column6: though accretive to overall   revenue
column7: come with a lower margin than in-store sales. With   networks of stores across the country
column8: incremental sales in   stores cost those retailers almost nothing in operating costs
column9: but each e-commerce sale needs to be picked
column10: packed
column11: and   shipped.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty ImagesFor Amazon
column12: shipping costs have long been a concern for the   company. In recent years
column13: Amazon has made efforts to diversify   its logistics capabilities
column14: entering into a contract to lease 20   cargo planes last year
column15: recently handling its own ocean freight
column16: and also building a $1.5 billion airport hub in Cincinnati. The   company sees those investments as necessary to handle spikes in   demands that can overwhelm its shipping partners likeFedEx
column17: UPS
column18: and the US Postal Service
column19: especially after thousands after   deliveries arrived late for Christmas in 2013. As its retail   sales grow by more than 20% a year
column20: it seems logical that the   company will have to take more of its logistics under its   control.However
column21: as Amazon's sales have skyrocketed so too have its   shipping costs. Those expenses reached $16.2 billion last year
column22: a   40% increase from the year before and accounted for nearly all of   the company's $17.6 billion in fulfillment expenses
column23: its biggest   line item after cost of sales
column24: or what Amazon pays for the goods   it sells. During the same time
column25: net shipping costs
column26: which   subtract revenue from shipping fees along with a portion of Prime   membership fees
column27: surged 43% to $7.2 billion
column28: outpacing overall   e-commerce sales growth of 24.9% last year. That was the fastest   growth in net shipping costs since 2011.Let's take a closer at Amazon's shipping costs to see what   investors can expect in the coming years.Shipping ain't easyAmazon has stepped up efforts to make shipping even faster and   more convenient for its customers. It now offers its Prime Now   service with delivery in as short as an hour in 40 cities   worldwide
column29: and has more than 60 million Prime members in the U.S.   according to some estimates.And the recent expenditures are evident based on the explosion   in shipping costs last year.Source: Amazon 10-K Filings. Note: 2011 and 2012 revenue growth   figures include AWS.As the charts above show
column30: shipping costs have grown   substantially in recent years as net shipping costs jumped more   than fivefold from 2010-2016 to $7.2 billion. However
column31: the second   chart shows that e-commerce sales growth mostly kept pace with   net shipping costs between 2012 and 2015
column32: and even last year's   spike in net shipping costs came with an acceleration in   e-commerce growth
column33: a sign that the increase in shipping costs was   the result of increased demand and not poor management.The charts below may offer a clearer picture of how shipping   costs are affecting Amazon's bottom line.Source: Amazon FilingsSource: Amazon Filings.Note: Figures do not include expense for stock-based   compensation. 2010-2012 figures include AWS.As the charts above show
column34: shipping costs as a percentage of   revenue have been relatively steady in recent years
column35: although   there was an uptick last year. The second chart also shows that   operating income has surged in the last two years despite rising   shipping costs. That seems to indicate that Amazon is executing   its business objectives effectively -- and that rising shipping   costs are one consequence of that growth
column36: even if they have not   been substantial enough to derail its overall profit growth.For investors
column37: the lesson is clear. While net shipping costs   demand some attention
column38: especially as they are set to top $10   billion this year
column39: they are only one part of the larger business   story here. Amazon
column40: after all
column41: is not a shipping company but an   e-commerce business
column42: and absorbing shipping costs is a necessary   component of growing its business as it meets surging demand.As the recent profit growth shows
column43: there's no need for   investors to worry about rising shipping costs for the time   being
column44: and as long as e-commerce profits are growing
column45: rising   shipping costs should be seen as simply a necessary function of   that profit growth.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column1: Why Amazon.com Inc. Is Investing Billions in India;2/11/2017;"India is the world's second most populous country
column2: its biggest   democracy
column3: and its sixth-biggest economy. And now
column4: it appears to   be the next big prize forAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .When Amazon spots a market opportunity

column7: e-books
column8: video streaming
column9: and cloud computing. Its   ability to recognize opportunities and take advantage of them is   one of the biggest drivers of its success.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Now

column12: and CEO Jeff Bezos has   ordered his deputies to ""do what it takes"" to win the Indian   market
column13: where the company faces stiff competition from China'sAlibabaand native players Snapdeal and FlipKart.What makes India so specialIndia presents a unique e-commerce opportunity for several   reasons. The country currently has 1.3 billion people
column14: about four   times the population of the U.S.
column15: and is on track to surpass   China as the world's most populous country in just five years
column16: according to the U.N.Its economy is growing 5% annually. Much of the population is   tech-savvy
column17: with smartphone penetration reaching more than 30%
column18: making it the world's second-biggest smartphone market after   China. About 10% of Indians speak English
column19: giving it the   second-largest English-speaking population after the U.S.
column20: and   thus making it an ideal market for Amazon Video
column21: which the   company launched internationally at the end of 2016. Finally
column22: India is densely populated
column23: with 1
column24: 033 people per square mile
column25: compared to the U.S.
column26: which has just 85 people per square
column27: and   its retail industry is highly fragmented
column28: without dominant   entrenched brands occupying positions similar to whatWal-Mart
column29: for example
column30: holds in the U.S.Those two factors make the country an ideal market for an   e-commerce operator like Amazon. The high population density   means shipping would be much easier and cheaper than in the U.S.
column31: especially if the company can master drone delivery

column35: selling goods through third-party vendors
column36: but it handles the technology infrastructure and most of its   vendors' deliveries. Building out its own delivery network
column37: as   opposed to relying onUPSor the Postal Service as it does domestically

column40: for an annual fee of just $15. Amazon is offering a   one-year trial for half that price
column41: just $7.50

column44: as it says   it's targeting elites rather than offering a mass-market product.   Amazon

column48: and it's increasingly   touting its growth in India on its earnings calls -- smartphone   shipments grew 18% in the country in 2016
column49: and it sold 2.5   million iPhones there.Amazon has always been willing to play the long game

column51: and he   promised his first shareholders as much. The Indian e-commerce   market is still small

column53: where it controls   about one quarter of e-commerce sales
column54: its Indian operations   could be huge in just a few years.The company does not break out results by country

column1: 7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBack when I was a kid
column3: a half-century ago
column4: most people saw only three TV networks - CBS
column5: NBC and ABC.makeArticleAd();Source:Flash.pro via Flickr (modified)If you're old enough to remember the DuMont network
column6: please check outmy recent gallery on dividend stocksthat provide solid retirement income. If you think ofTwenty-First Century Fox Inc(NASDAQ:FOXA) as the fourth network
column7: read on.A quarter-century ago
column8: when my children were small
column9: a host of cable networks rose to challenge the broadcast networks for viewers. It was the age of""57 channels and nothing on""with ESPN
column10: the USA Network
column11: CNN
column12: the Weather Channel and the Food Network all having their heyday.Over time
column13: the broadcasters bought out most of the new operators
column14: sometimes after being bought themselves.CBS Corporation(NYSE:CBS) now owns Showtime and the Smithsonian Network.Comcast Corporation(NASDAQ:CMCSA)
column15: the parent of NBC
column16: owns all or part of a dozen networks
column17: including CNBC
column18: Syfy and USA.Walt Disney Co(NYSE:DIS)
column19: the parent of ABC
column20: owns ESPN
column21: the biggest franchise of all
column22: and the Disney networks. And Fox
column23: which grew up in this era
column24: has clones for nearly all of them.But in the 2010s

column27: which deliver their shows to your TV
column28: over the internet through plug-in dongles rather than set-top boxes - unless you prefer viewing on a PC
column29: tablet or phone. These offer all the entertainment a TV zombie might ever need
column30: and the services can cost less than $10 per month
column31: much less than a cable service. They don't have schedules
column32: so you watch what you want to watch
column33: when you want to watch it.Streaming through the internet is the future of TV
column34: and we are just at its dawn. It's still unclear how we will discover shows
column35: how we will interface with what we want to watch or how much we'll eventually pay for the privilege of watching. But cable
column36: at least as we knew it
column37: is drifting away
column38: as broadcast television previously drifted away. It will continue to exist
column39: as broadcasting does
column40: just in a smaller
column41: truncated form.What is the future of live events in the new world? Is TV even going to remain a one-way
column42: passive medium? We don't know.In addition to being better
column43: and cheaper
column44: for viewers
column45: the new TV environment right now looks great for entertainers and show producers
column46: who suddenly have a host of new options on where and how to sell their wares
column47: which they're using to gain new creative freedom if not new wealth.But the new media landscape is a lot less stable than the old one and
column48: given the wealth of choices available
column49: it may prove much less lucrative for stars
column50: writers and producers.Just a few years into the new era
column51: moreover
column52: it's apparent that the new streaming companies are big enough to regard the cable networks' owners as minnows. This is not a problem the networks can buy their way out of
column53: as they bought out of cable.7 High-Risk
column54: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowYour mission
column55: as an investor
column56: is to examine the new TV stocks and decide whether to invest your money in them. And along the way
column57: you will be buying a lot more than TV.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Netflix (NFLX)Source:Via NetflixThe business model of the new TV era was created byNetflix
column58: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX).A decade ago
column59: Netflix was a relatively small but interesting company that mailed DVDs. You paid a monthly fee to hold a few
column60: then got more when you sent them back. It was a relatively simple business based on physical media
column61: but it had potential.By simply moving that business model online
column62: using cloud services and open-source technology
column63: Netflix now delivers unlimited amounts of content to viewers as a stream
column64: rather than on a disk.Cofounder Reed Hastings has transformed TV as no one has since Ted Turner. If you bought Netflix when it went public in 2002
column65: your $1 investment is now worth $137.Hasting's second big innovation
column66: which came on the heels of the streaming business model
column67: was tostart funding his own programmingrather than just reselling existing movies and TV shows. His string of hits began withHouse of Cards
column68: based on a British mini-series
column69: which by itself made his monthly $8 per month subscription fee seem a bargain.Netflix offers its shareholders low profit margins
column70: but great growth. Between 2013 and 2016
column71: revenue doubled
column72: from $4.37 billion to $8.83 billion
column73: and profits nearly followed
column74: from 26 cents per share to 43 cents. Along the way
column75: the company has increased its debt dramatically - it now represents about one-fourth of assets - to pay for its delivery infrastructure and to obtain new programming assets
column76: which it is assumed will retain their value over time. (Your grandkids will watchHouse of Cardsthe way your kids now watchM*A*S*H.)With a market cap of $62 billion
column77: Netflix could now buy other TV stocks
column78: like CBS. Its value exceeds that of Fox. ABC and NBC are protected from a Netflix acquisition by deep-pocketed parents
column79: Disney and Comcast. HBO
column80: a subscription service based on cable
column81: will be protected in the same way once parentTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX) is bought byAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T).NFLX retains its value as an investment because ofits international operations
column82: which by the fourth quarter of 2016 represented around 40% of the total and continue to grow. In the last three months of 2016 alone the company added 7.05 million new members
column83: after forecasting it would add just 5.2 million. Netflix' growth is accelerating
column84: and its ability to buy must-see programming is growing with it.The problem for Netflix is that the cloud providers on which its success rests have seen what it has done. They're on to the trick. A network today isn't necessarily just a provider of content
column85: but the scaled infrastructure necessary to provide that content. The owners of cloud networks and vast internet networks are copying what Netflix does.These challengers have more zeroes in their asset bases than those NFLX has faced before. Once more
column86: Reed Hastings is a minnow in a sea of sharks.Everything about the industry has changed

column88: or whether it will eventually be bought out as Turner was

column99: and supports a host of other services including Netflix) that I don't need anything else. Were it not for live sports
column100: I would kill my cable in a heartbeat
column101: and as my favorite sports signstreaming contracts
column102: that motivation is disappearing as well.And it's not just TV either. I'm fortunate enough to have a wife who hates TV. She reads instead. Amazon's Kindle Unlimited
column104: became fantastic over the last year as more authors have signed up and Amazon's algorithms have gotten better at anticipating what people might want to borrow next from its vast library.My son doesn't watch TV either. He's a gamer
column105: and has been for years. He is constantly talking aboutTwitch
column106: which offers live streams of people playing video games. I don't get it
column107: but Amazon does. They paid $970 million for Twitchlast March
column108: making them partners with characters such as Bunnyfufu
column109: who stream their gamingon Twitch.Like most people
column110: I watch very few cable channels. Cancel cable and there is $100-150 per month I can pay for whatever programming I want. There are only so many hours in a day - who needs hundreds of channels with nothing on when a streaming service (or maybe two) can meet my needs?If I sound like an Amazon fanboy
column111: it's because I am. As previously noted
column112: my TV has an Amazon Fire Stick plugged into it
column113: and I use a Fire tablet for reading. I also started accumulating Amazon shares in 2014
column114: at an average price of $330. They're now worth about $800
column115: and they're a bargain at that price.For the fourth quarter of 2016 Amazon earned $749 million
column117: on revenues of$43.741 billion. It is making the turn from a company investing in front of growth to one that starts earning profits regularly. Its cloud operation
column119: now brings one-quarter of its $3.5 billion in quarterly revenue to the bottom line - and one of its customers is Netflix.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayImagine. Amazon creates infrastructure that lets other companies make money
column120: then competes with its customers to make even more money with the same infrastructure. I recently dumped shares before earnings
column122: because they had become such a huge portion of my retirement account.I may have to buy them back.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Alphabet (GOOG
column123: GOOGL)Source: ShutterstockNetflix may have created the new business model and Amazon may have perfected it
column124: but the technology began atAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column126: with Google and YouTube.One of YouTube's co-founders says the idea started afterthe Janet Jackson ""wardobe malfunction""at the 2004 Super Bowl. They just couldn't find any video of it
column127: and so asked others to upload it so they could see it. The service was an immediate sensation
column128: and Google's purchase of the site for $1.65 billion was just the beginning.The business model was simple. People upload videos
column129: people watch videos. Google places ads in front of the videos
column130: and shares some of the revenue with those who uploaded the videos. Like Google itself
column132: although it now has a paid version called YouTube Red.YouTubedid not make a profit for its parentuntil after Amazon and Netflix got going. It is now estimated to be bringing in$10 billion per year
column134: with 80% of views outside the U.S. By 2020 that will mean$27 billionin revenue per year. Its audience is tilted toward young people
column137: and a growing percentage access it via phones or tablets.An analysis from STL Partners indicates YouTube's profit contribution is mainly indirect. Its traffic helps Google get the best prices for internet bandwidth. Its meta data is contributed to other Google services. It gives Google a place at the tablewhenever video copyright issuesare discussed.Veteran TV producer Susanne Daniels joined Google in 2015
column138: and is charged withgrowing the YouTube Red service. She is not onlybuying TV showsand makinga splash at movie festivalsbut aiming to take veteran TV hosts likeConan O'Brien online. (Chelsea Handler has already moved to Netflix.) Daniels is helped by continuing sales ofChromecast
column139: a TV streaming device which competes with the Apple Fire StickYouTube has created its own stars
column140: most of whom are unknown to their parents' generation. The most popular YouTube celebrity
column142: drew $15 million in income last year and hadalmost 50 million viewers.By taking advantage of Google's low-cost infrastructure
column143: YouTube has carved out a unique niche for itself in the new TV universe
column144: one that is subsidizing its entrance into more ""traditional"" areas like YouTube Red subscriptions.Thanks to Amazon's purchase of Twitch
column145: TV stocks Google and Amazon are now on a collision course in the world of streaming video. Customers of both will be the big winners
column147: too.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Apple (AAPL)Source:via AppleApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) was a latecomer to TV streaming in the cloud.Apple began ramping up spending for its own cloud only a few years ago
column148: investing $15 billion in 2016 aloneto build a global network of cloud data centers and
column150: a place for itself in the new industry.The money was spent mainly to serve existing paid Apple services
column153: which are nowbigger profit drivers than the Macintosh or iPad. CEO Tim Cook said in his most recent earnings call that Apple Services brought in$7.17 billionin the December quarter alone
column154: which he expects will double by 2020.Apple's streaming business is distinguished from that of Google because it consists of paid subscribers
column155: and distinguished from Amazon and Netflix by being primarily fee-for-service rather than subscription revenue.While iPhone sales are stagnating
column156: Apple has found a new growth engine in services
column157: and built a platform to challenge the other streaming players. Apple Music now has about21%of the music streaming market
column159: but Spotify is not profitable and struggling to justify a $8 billion valuation
column160: which at One Infinite Loop is considered seat cushion money.Apple's push into TV streaming will be through a new app called
column163: which aims to solve one of the most vexing problems for a streaming user - deciding what to watch next. The Apple TV streaming service itself has yet to launch
column164: butrumors about it abound. Apple wants to get the same 30% revenue cut on TV streaming it gets on apps
column165: producing a service that will cost $20-30 per month.The most persistent rumors about Apple's intent regarding streaming involveHBO Now
column166: a Time Warner service that costs $15 per month
column167: and which was Apple exclusive for a few months in 2015. Apple has the financial wherewithal to buy HBO as part of Time Warner's merger with AT&T
column168: or to buy a broadcasting company like CBS for cash. Apple TV hardware isused by an estimated 11.9%of TV streaming customers.Thanks to its existing service businesses
column169: global reach and over $200 billion in cash
column170: Apple has the freedom to be patient and negotiate with rights holders before launching a TV streaming service. But it is far more concerned with maintaining its high margins than with driving traffic
column171: which hurts it in competition with services whose prices start at virtually free
column172: like Google's YouTube and Amazon Prime.It is hard for me to see how Apple can win in streaming when it's unwilling to bend on margins to win market share
column173: and willing to dither aimlessly with existing TV rights holders while rivals are creating their own shows and even new types of experiences.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendBut that's just my opinion. I bought Apple shares before its 7:1 split in 2014
column175: but retain them in my retirement account. It's going to be a nice retirement.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: AT&T (T)Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrI got my first glimpse of the future several years ago
column176: when rights to English Premier League games came up for bids.The winners weren't the traditional networks
column177: public or private. They wereSky TV
column180: the state phone company.This was years before AT&T said it would buy Time Warnerfor a reported $85.4 billion. It was even years before AT&T agreed to spend$48.5 billion forDirecTV
column181: the direct broadcast satellite business.The two deals will combine to transform AT&T from a phone company into a streaming player. It will be able to bundle wireless
column183: and let its customers stream shows from DirecTV to their mobile deviceswithout cost.Its new streaming service
column185: carried an introductory price of $35 per month for 60 channels and attractedover 200
column186: 000 customers during the fourth quarterwhich helped offset a loss of customers from its more traditional cable service
column187: U-Verse. It competes ina cord-cutting nichealongsideSling TV
column188: owned by DirecTV rivalDISH Network Corp(NASDAQ:DISH)
column190: owned bySony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)For the fourth quarter
column191: AT&T reported net income of $2.44 billion
column193: on revenue of $41.84 billion. While this didn't clear the company's 49-cent-per-share dividend payment during the quarter
column194: for the year the company did earn $2.10 per share
column195: beating the $1.93 annual dividend. It's the dividend
column196: a 4.7% yield to today's stock buyer
column197: that you're buying when you buy AT&T stock. The shares themselves are worth little more than they were in 2007.I switched from Comcast to AT&T for my own TV and internet service last year
column198: combining it with my existing mobile phone subscription. I now pay the company about $400 per month for various services. That's a lot of cash flow. I should probably buy the stock.AT&T is the most traditional of the new streaming players. It earns a place in this gallery for its sheer size
column200: and its control of key internet infrastructure in the core of the network and at the edge.AT&T has moved into streaming for defensive reasons. Internet advocates have criticized it for DirecTV Now
column201: which gives its own customers free bits that others are charged for
column202: ignoring the concept of network neutrality
column203: but the Donald Trump Administration isgiving it a free pass on that.When the acquisition of Time Warner is finalized - and that looks like a better bet with Trump in charge - AT&T will own a big hunk of the traditional cable universe
column205: CNN and Cartoon Network.Time Warner agreed to be bought
column207: because it needs cash to compete for programming against deep-pocketed rivals like Netflix
column209: Google and possibly Apple. AT&T bought Time Warner because the vertical integration - owning the programming as well as the network so you write rights checks to yourself - should allow it to maintain that dividend.Comcast made the marriage of network infrastructure and content work with NBC Universal
column210: mainly by keeping its hands off its creative people. It is still unclear to me whether AT&T will be willing to do the same
column211: or whether it will focus on milking a dying industry for profits
column212: which has been its way of doing business since I began covering them over three decades ago.That's the only thing keeping me from buying the shares. That and the lack of capital gains.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Facebook (FB)Source:SilverIsdead Via FlickrFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is the newest and
column214: the second-smallest of the new streaming players
column215: behind only Netflix.During the December quarter Facebookearned $1.41 per shareon $8.81 billion in revenue. This makes it four times bigger than Netflix by revenue. With a market cap of about $390 billion
column216: it isthe sixth most valuable company in the country
column217: less than five years after first going public.Facebook got into streaming withFacebook Live
column218: a sort of YouTube for streaming
column219: which has already made news with House Democrats streaming a sit-in when Republicans turned off their cameras and with Donald Trump announcing a Supreme Court pick on the service.Facebook Live is already getting Facebook into trouble with rights holders
column220: like the TV network which saw sales of a recent pay-per-view fight in Australia impacted when one subscribersimply held his phone up to his TV and streamed it. There is even a name for this kind of thing -""stream ripping.""Facebook is reportedlyworking on an app for streaming
column221: which would put it into more direct competition with Apple TV and Google's YouTube. This would be a software solution that lets it piggyback on others' hardware
column223: Amazon's Fire Stick and Apple TV. In addition to supporting its streaming
column224: the app would also support 10-minute TV shows with commercials inserted into them
column225: like broadcast TV in the 1940s.What makes Facebook powerful in streaming is the sheer number of people using the service - nearly 2 billion - and the amount of time they spend with it. The average global user spends 20 minutes per day on the service
column226: andthe average American spends twice that amount of time.Analysts are divided on analogiesfor Facebook's strategy here. Is it Netflix? Is it YouTube?In fact
column227: neither analogy is correct. Facebook mainly wants to integrate video into its existing offering. It is backing away frompaying publishers for streams
column228: and may be backing away in the near term as people use its unmoderated do-it-yourself streaming to show themselvescommitting violent crimesandeven committing suicide.All this reminds me of something I wrote 20 years ago
column229: about telephony. Telephony is simply an internet service. Today
column231: an internet service. The difference is that video is far more intimate than a phone call
column232: easier to make money from and subject to discussion of rights
column233: or right and wrong.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenIntegrating video
column235: as just one part of a broader computer experience is the road not being taken by anyone but Facebook.Stocks to Buy for the Future of TV: Alibaba (BABA)Source: ShutterstockAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NASDAQ:BABA) got into streaming in 2015 by buyingYouku Tudou
column237: for $4 billion-plus.Alibaba was late to this business
column238: but is working hard to make up for lost time. It launched a paid streaming service calledTmall Box Officein September
column239: 2015. It has a TV operating systemcalled YunOS
column240: which is getting its streaming services into homes throughout East and South Asia.In 2016
column241: Alibaba launchedpartnerships with a host of global producers
column242: the most important being with Steven Spielberg'sAmblin Entertainment
column243: which is aiming to bring Chinese stories to American audiences and vice versa. Alibaba also took a stakein China'sHeHe Picturesand signed a deal withHarry Potterproducer David Heyman to produce a series of movies aroundWarriors
column244: a children's book series about warring cats. Already in 2017 Alibaba has signed to becomea major sponsor of the Olympic Games
column245: responsible for streaming events and back-end cloud computing.Thanks to deals like this
column246: Alibaba's digital media revenues grew 270% year-over-year
column247: inits most recent quarterly report.The segment produced $585 million in revenue.Despite all this
column248: Alibaba is still a relative minnow in the streaming TV stocks waters. Its streaming revenue is just one-quarter that of Netflix. What makes it powerful
column249: and a threat to the giants
column251: not just in China; its willingness to buy its way into businesses like movie production; and its highly profitable growth trajectory
column252: which gives it a cash hoard worth $15 billion
column253: which it is far more aggressive about investing than Apple.Because Alibaba enables commerce
column254: rather than buying inventory as Amazon does
column255: it brings over 25% of its revenue to the net income line
column256: with operating cash flow that has grown four-fold in the last four years. It has enormous advantages in China
column257: the world's second-largest and one of its fastest-growing markets. This has given it a springboard into other markets like India
column259: where it is also growing a range of services.It is just a matter of time before Alibaba becomes a major factor in the U.S. market
column260: through its ownership of content and cloud operations if nothing else. Any innovation a U.S. company can come up with
column262: can be jumped on by Alibaba in a flash
column263: grown in China as a captive market
column264: and then sprung on the world quickly.It may be the most important story of the next four years
column265: but it won't be televised. It will definitely be streamed. I'm a buyer.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column266: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AAPL
column269: BABA and FB.The post7 Stocks to Buy for the Future of TVappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Amazon's U.S. Online Sales Growth Last Year Was More Than Everyone Else's Combined;2/10/2017;"It's no secret thatAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) is a dominant force in online retail. But it's   still astounding just how dominant it's been in recent years. New   data fromSlice Intelligenceshows Amazon took 53% of all the sales growth of online retailers   in the US last year.Amazon's North American sales increased 25.2% in 2016.   Meanwhile
column2: the U.S. Census Bureau has been tracking e-commerce   sales growth around 15.5% through the first three quarters of the   year.Put another way
column3: despite its size
column4: Amazon continues to take   share of the growing e-commerce market
column5: and competitors such asWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) are struggling to keep up.makeArticleAd();Image source: Amazon.com.$53 billion in retail sales up for grabsWhile the U.S. Census Bureau hasn't released its estimates for   the fourth quarter of 2016 yet
column6: extrapolating out the steady   growth rate of the first three quarters results in $53 billion in   online sales for 2016. In addition
column7: the majority of retail growth   in the United States comes from e-commerce. In 2015
column8: 62% of total   growth came from online sales.Slice's numbers may be a bit off
column9: considering Amazon saw an   increase of ""just"" $16 billion in sales across all of North   America. Still
column10: the company is undoubtedly taking market share as   its sales growth outpaces the overall industry.With e-commerce accounting for such a significant share of   retail growth in the United States
column11: Amazon's biggest competitors
column12: like Wal-Mart
column13: are really feeling the hurt. While Amazon's North   American sales increased 25.2% last year
column14: Wal-Mart's overall U.S.   sales increased just 3.3% through the first three quarters of the   year.Wal-Mart's e-commerce sales fared a bit better
column15: increasing 7%
column17: and 20.6% in the first
column18: second
column19: and third quarters
column20: respectively. The third quarter was boosted by the acquisition of   Jet.com. Overall
column21: Wal-Mart's organic e-commerce sales still   appear to lag the industry.How is Amazon dominating retail?Even if you're skeptical of Slice's claim that Amazon took 53%   of online sales growth last year
column22: it's clear that Amazon accounts   for a huge share of the retail growth in the United States. Not   just e-commerce growth
column23: but overall retail sales.Slice had a few thoughts to share on why Amazon has been able   to stay ahead of the competition:Faster shipping.Amazon's average ship time fell about 1.5 days over the past       two years
column24: and it remains more than two days faster than the       average competitor
column25: according to Slice's data. Wal-Mart       recently started offeringfree two-day shippingon about 2 million select items
column26: but its selection pales in       comparison with the 50 million Prime-eligible items on       Amazon.Subscriptions.Amazon's subscribe-and-save feature allows customers to       automatically reorder a product
column27: receive free shipping
column28: and       get a discount to boot. That's quite an incentive to become a       repeat customer.Ease of ordering.Products such as Amazon's Echo smart speaker or its Dash       buttons make ordering products from Amazon easier than       putting on pants -- the very pants I ordered from Amazon.Undoubtedly
column29: however
column30: the biggest factor fueling Amazon's   continued dominance of retail in the United States is its Prime   program. Prime makes customers extremely loyal. It's what fuels   55% of online shoppers to check Amazon.com first (and maybe   last). And it causes shoppers to spend more on Amazon than their   non-Prime counterparts.Last year
column31: Amazon added ""tens of millions"" of new Prime   members
column32: according to its fourth-quarter earnings release. Unlike   the previous two years
column33: when Amazon experienced around 50% annual   growth in membership
column34: the company didn't provide a growth   rate.That may be because Prime membership is nearing saturation in   markets such as the United States. Estimates show more than half   of U.S. households are already Prime members. Still
column35: with a   growing majority of households subscribed to Prime (even if that   growth is slowing) and going to Amazon as their first online   shopping destination
column36: it looks as if Amazon will continue to take   share of the U.S. retail market for the foreseeable future.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column37: the newsletter they   run
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for   investors to buy right now. Amazonis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full list!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column40: 2017Adam Levyowns shares of Amazon. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Amazon. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: The 2 Best
column2: and 2 Worst
column3: Dow Dividend Stocks Today;2/10/2017;"The classic ""Dogs of the Dow"" strategy advises buying the 10 highest-yielding Dow Jones Industrial Average stocks
column4: then holding onto them for a year. The idea is that higher yields are a signal of a beaten-up share price - and that because we're buying a stable blue-chip with a stable customer base
column5: investors will eventually bid the stock back up when the business cycle turns up again.But we can further improve on this effective yet somewhat ""dumb"" strategy with a bit of second-level analysis. After all
column6: some of these companies have business models that are actually aging in dog years! And they should be avoided.Today we're going to discuss four high paying Dow components. Two are compelling buys
column7: while two should be sold immediately (or even shorted).makeArticleAd();WINNER: Exxon Mobil (XOM)Dividend Yield:3.6%Exxon Mobil (XOM)is emerging from what easily has been one of the most trying points in the company's history
column8: the roots of which stretch all the way back to 1870.From about mid-2014 through the start of 2016
column9: oil pricesplunged from near $110 down to below $30 - a collapse that caused energy stocks across the sector to careen into the ground
column10: and forced numerous companies to shut their doors.Even Exxon Mobil - America's biggest energy company by market capitalization
column11: and one of the world's largest and most diversified oil and gas operations - wasn't immune. Shares dipped from around $105 to around $72 or so - a 30%-plus dip in just more than a year's time
column12: which is virtually unheard of in blue chips as well-established as XOM. Pundits thought that Exxon's streak of dividend increases
column13: which spanned more than three decades
column14: was in jeopardy.However
column15: former CEO Rex Tillerson himself managed the company in such a way that he knew its operations could survive with oil prices as low as $40 per barrel. April 2016 came around
column16: and XOM maintained its status as a Dividend Aristocrat with a small but symbolic payout hike. Meanwhile
column17: XOM shares have clawed back at least some of their losses.Speaking of Tillerson ...The former Exxon CEO is a ""former"" chief because he's now America's Secretary of State. That's no doubt a boon to XOM
column18: especially considering the Trump administration's seemingly favorable and cooperative view with Russia - where Exxon has huge energy interests and projects
column19: and where Tillerson himself has deep ties.Moreover
column20: President Donald Trump and a GOP-controlled Congress are proving extremely friendly to the energy sector as a whole right now
column21: most recently with a Senate vote to knock down a rule governing transparency on energy firms' payments to foreign governments.Exxon was already set up well to benefit from an eventual return to high oil prices
column22: and now it's seemingly in the driver's seat. While investors wait for those gains to take hold
column23: they can enjoy 3.6% in dividends from this relentless oil titan.Exxon (XOM): This Long-Time Winner Is in Recovery ModeLOSER: Walmart (WMT)Dividend Yield:3%Walmart (WMT)is one of the perfect examples of how a big
column24: solid blue-chip can still be a big
column25: solid dud.Walmart is the largest retailer in the world
column26: and in fact Earth's biggest company by revenue
column27: boasting more than 11
column28: 000 stores across 28 countries. BeforeAmazon.com (AMZN)came around
column29: Walmart was considered one of the biggest disruptors to traditional brick-and-mortar retail. Its bargain-basement prices and enormous product offerings upended countless mom n' pop shops
column30: but also put the hurt to larger specialty retailers such asBest Buy (BBY)andH.H.Gregg (HGG).But Amazondidcome along
column31: and that - along with Walmart's ubiquity and lack of options for expansion - are at the very least keeping Walmart from being the investment powerhouse it once was.While WMT does produce world-class revenues
column32: top-line growth has been thinning for years
column33: and in 2016
column34: Walmart's sales actually dropped year-over-year:Walmart has been spending for years trying to bring its online offerings up to par to battle Amazon's unstoppable e-commerce machine - yet it just keeps falling farther behind. Dividend growth is lagging too - last year management upped its payout by a meager 2%. WMT has lagged the total returns of the S&P 500 for the last 15 years - it's time to cut this dead weight loose.WINNER: Boeing (BA)Dividend Yield:3.5%Boeing (BA)just boosted its dividend by 30% to $1.42 per share - more than double its quarterly payout from 2013! And Boeing's generosity to shareholders didn't stop there. The company also upgraded its old stock repurchase program by implementing a new $14 billion buyback plan.Future business prospects are looking good. Boeing said it expects 2017 commercial aircraft deliveries to reach between 760 and 765
column35: up from last year's 748. Core earnings are expected to surge from $7.24 per share to a range of $9.10 to $9.30 per share. And Boeing sees cash flow ticking up from $10.5 billion last year to $10.75 billion in 2017 - plenty of cash to dish back to shareholders.Boeing's (BA) Dividend Takes OffLOSER: IBM (IBM)Dividend Yield:3.2%Nineteen straight quarters of year-over-year revenue declines - nuff said.IBM's (IBM)core businesses
column36: such as services and software licenses
column37: have declined on a year-over-year basis for 19 straight quarters. And it's a bad sign that the company still won't break out its Watson revenues
column38: despite the fact IBM says its promising artificial intelligence unit is growing briskly.IBM's 2016 dividend hike dipped into single digits after years of double-digit improvements. Cash and short-term investments have dipped from about $11 billion in 2013 to $8.5 billion as of its last report ... and long-term debt has climbed from $32.9 billion to $34.7 billion in that same time.And that streak of consecutive revenue declines? If Wall Street is right
column39: it'll be extended at least by a couple more quarters
column40: and both 2017 and 2018 revenues are seen eroding
column41: not recovering.IBM might survive for an eternity

column1: Nvidia Shows Artificial Intelligence Revolution Is Biggest Trend Of Our Time;2/10/2017;"Nvidia (Shutterstock photo)It's no secret that Nvidia (NVDA) was the best performing stock in the S&P 500 in 2016
column2: gaining more than 370%. But while the company's graphics processor unit (GPU) chips are being used in everything from gaming PCs to autonomous cars to virtual reality to data centers
column3: the reinvigoration of Nvidia is built by one thing: artificial intelligence.AI is increasingly being used in everything and everywhere
column4: most notably data centers for machine learning
column5: where Nvidia's GPUs have a tremendous lead over the competition
column6: including anything from AMD (AMD) and Intel (INTC). Data center revenue was up 67% year-over-year in the quarter at $296 million and more impressive
column7: up 23% from the impressive fiscal third-quarter 2017 results that helped send the stock soaring more than 30% in November 2016.makeArticleAd();The technology is touching everything and anyone
column8: be it on your smartphone or when you shop on Amazon (AMZN) or using software. In fact
column9: Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang toldBarron'sthat AI is just the future of software.If you read Nvidia's conference call transcript and itsearnings press release
column10: AI is mentioned everywhere and with good reason: deep learning is only made possible by the advancements in AI being made by university researchers and big companies such as Google (GOOG)
column11: Apple (AAPL)
column12: Facebook (FB)
column13: Amazon and others.In reacting to the blow-out earnings results
column14: Jefferies analyst Mark Lipacis called Nvidia essentially the only publicly traded company solely focused on AI. ""[Nvidia] posted its 7th consecutive beat
column15: and while YoY rev growth of 55% likely marks 2nd derivative peak
column16: the 200% growth in its Datacenter business and improving GM reinforce our thesis that NVDA is emerging as the de facto standard in AI - one of the most exciting growth drivers in tech
column17: Lipacis wrote
column18: while raising his price target to $140 from $125.Of the aforementioned areas
column19: perhaps the one that is most tangible to show consumers the AI revolution is autonomous driving.Tesla (TSLA) and CEO Elon Musk have pioneered autonomous driving in the Model S (though to which extent is up for debate)
column20: but Tesla has chosen to use Nvidia's chipsets to not only help it with its infotainment unit
column21: but more importantly
column22: the software that helps withautonomy
column23: using the NVIDIA DRIVE™ PX 2 AI computing platform.Society is a little bit away from true autonomy in a car (Level 5)
column24: in which a human does not need to do anything
column25: but Tesla is working on getting towards Level 4/5 faster than anyone else
column26: thanks to Nvidia. (For a good primer on what each level means
column27: clickhere.)Nvidia has several other automotive partnerships
column28: including recently announced ones with Bosch andAudi.All of this highlights that self-driving cars is not just a science fiction fantasy
column29: it's real and it's coming. And it's being powered by AI. The societal impact AI will have is up for debate
column30: whether it will be a net positive or a net negative
column31: but there is no stopping it.AI is continuing to become more prevalent in everything we do
column32: but we are nowhere near general AI
column33: in which computers can make decisions just as a human can. What we're experiencing right now is soft (weak) AI
column34: in which humans tell a computer to do a task and it does it better than any human can. But thanks to deep/machine learning
column35: we're getting closer to general AI
column36: even if it's still decades away. That means the AI revolution is only just getting started and it has years and years on which to run.All thanks to Nvidia."

column1: Why Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock Will Hit $15 Soon;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere is nothing more painful for investors than watching a stock that once traded at $1.81 soaring six-fold in the last year. The higher shares ofAdvanced Micro Devices
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) goes
column5: the riskier it gets for investors. AMD stock still has $1.44 billion in debt against $1.26 billion in cash and equivalents. In early March
column6: the chip supplier is about to make its biggest launch its his history with Ryzen
column7: and that's bound to make a lot of noise.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrFor the time being
column8: details of AMD's Ryzen are limited. Although the company recently demoed the chip in a gameplay demonstration
column9: it gave no details on the chip's pricing.Without knowing what Ryzen offers at a price-to-performance ratio compared toIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC)
column10: the harder it is to predict Ryzen's sales when it launches.AMD's (Leaked) Ryzen RoadmapIf theleaked rumorsare true
column11: AMD will launch three classes of PC chips: high-range
column12: medium-range and entry-level. Denoted R7 (8 core
column13: 16 threads)
column14: R5 (4-6 core
column15: 8-12 threads) and R3 (4 core
column16: 4 threads)
column17: respectively
column18: the CPUs will differ by core
column19: thread and clock speed. The mid- and high-range chips will compete with Intel's mainstream processors
column20: the i5 and i7.Click to EnlargeRyzen's processor speed does not aim to out-clock that of Intel chips. Rather
column21: AMD's strategy primarily targets the enthusiast PC game community. Ryzen will pair with the next-generation GPU (graphics processing unit) Vega chips.After Ryzen's launch in March
column22: AMD will release Vega sometime in the second quarter. Mentions of Ryzen picked up again on Feb 9.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendRyzen's Processor SizeAlthough Advanced Micro Devices ismanufacturingZen on 14nm
column23: its an area of 44 square millimeters implies that the chip will at least match or beat Intel's chips. Before Lisa Su's leadership
column24: AMD did not talk about manufacturing at 14nm.Prior to Ryzen
column25: Advanced Micro Devices embraced x86 chips at 28nm. The engineering achievement will lead to lower manufacturing costs and higher profit margins for AMD stock. On its conference call
column26: the company revealed that it aimed to achieve gross margin of around 33% in the first quarter. In the quarters before that
column27: its gross margin hovered in the 31%-range due to the product mix. With Ryzen on the list
column28: expect that profitability number to improve quarter after quarter.Manufacturing of the processor will only get better andgo all the way down to 7nm:""They are not just buying a point product and we have a multi-generational roadmap that we are working on
column29: including sort of the Zen 2 and the Zen 3 follow on. From our standpoint process technology
column30: we ramped 16nm and 14nm really well last year and into this year. We are actually in the process of developing now in 7nm and we think the 7nm foundry roadmaps that are available are very competitive and will ensure that we have a strong multi-generational roadmap.""AMD stock's valuations may scare investors ahead of the Ryzen launch. But since the Polaris GPU launch last year
column31: CEO Lisa Su proved her technical skills in leading product launches. Advanced Micro Devices gained market share when it priced Polaris competitively againstNvidia Corporation's(NASDAQ:NVDA) more expensive GTX cards.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkChances are good that AMD will price Ryzen to win market share from Intel. The i5 and i7 Kaby Lake processors did not win rave reviews from the technology community.Bottom Line for AMD StockAdvanced Micro Devices is hovering at near yearly highs
column32: while Intel stock is showing a ""double top"" at around $38 a share. The marketplace is right in embracing Ryzen's release next month. Its chip performance
column33: lower energy consumption compared to past chips and
column34: hopefully
column35: a competitive price could lift the AMD stock price to at least $15 a share. That implies a forward price-to-earnings ratio of around 50
column36: compared to 43 with Nvidia.As of this writing
column37: Chris Lau did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's Pen7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsThe postWhy Advanced Micro Devices

column1: 3 Big Bets Cisco Systems
column2: Inc. Is Making -- Will They Be Enough?;2/10/2017;"Cisco Systems Inc.(NASDAQ: CSCO) has been best known in the past for its enterprise   network hardware
column3: but the company continues to build out and grow   its other segments with some interesting recent innovations and   acquisitions. Here are some of the areas of growth Cisco is   betting on
column4: the pressure it's getting from new competitors likeAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column5: and why the stock looks like a fine holding as   the company transitions for the future.1: Building smart
column6: connected citiesIn a recent blog post
column7: Cisco management said that cloud   computing is ""the fourth industrial revolution."" The company   estimates that by 2020
column8: over 90% of total data center traffic   will be via cloud networks. While there are many companies   working to provide services for individuals' and companies' cloud   needs
column9: Cisco is gearing up to offer its services to cities around   the world.Cisco launched the ""Smart+Connected City Platform"" at   the Smart City Expo World Congress 2016 in Barcelona in   November
column10: and the company says this service is ""a centralized   layer for addressing the infrastructural need to connect cameras
column11: water meters
column12: traffic meters
column13: and so on in a reliable
column14: secure
column15: robust and seamless manner."" This initiative was recently   implemented in Jaipur
column16: India
column17: which joins Hamburg
column18: Germany;   Barcelona
column19: Spain; Kansas City
column20: Missouri; and Adelaide
column21: Australia   as test smart cities. The video below shows the CIO of Adelaide   explaining the importance Cisco has played in his city.makeArticleAd();2: Becoming an all-encompassing IoT platform""Internet of Things"" has become a buzzword in 2016
column22: but really   it just describes the growing trend of consumer or otherwise   low-tech items that are being connected to the internet and to   each other
column23: usually through a wireless cloud network. In fact
column24: the smart cities initiative is mostly about IoT on city level.   Estimates on just how big this market could be vary widely
column25: but   most analysts predict it could continue growing by tens ofbillionsof devices in the next few years.Cisco is increasingly making itself the bedrock for various   parts of this ecosystem
column26: including the actual hardware that makes   these consumer products connectivity possible
column27: the connectivity   through cloud networks
column28: and the security to make sure the IoT   connectivity isn't easily compromised. Cisco acquired a   cloud-based IoT company called Jasper Technologies last March for   $1.4 billion
column29: which
column30: among other things
column31: enables more   data-tracking and IoT management. This acquisition and others   like it
column32: along with Cisco's own innovation in this space
column33: have   helped the company to launch various new products and bundles   into this space recently.Similar to Cisco's smart+connected cities push
column34: the company   believes it has the breadth of expertise and support to be the   IoT platform for enterprise and governmental accounts. Remember   that Cisco already has a large footprint in these spaces
column35: so it   might be easier for them to win over these big clients as they   seek an IoT solution.Image source: Cisco Systems.3: CybersecurityWhile the first two areas above are incredibly exciting in   terms of what they could mean for the future of the digital   world
column36: they also open up the world to many more risks in the form   of cyber-threats. A recently intensified focus on hacking threats   and the need to build secure solutions throughout cloud networks
column37: IoT platforms
column38: and all other connected technology creates an   opportunity Cisco is taking advantage of.In February
column39: the company launched Cisco Firepower
column40: a new   firewall series
column41: and the company says its advanced security   systems have been proven to help customers ""dramatically reduce   time to detection of attacks."" Throughout the year
column42: the company   also launched new tools such as Cisco Umbrella and Umbrella   Roaming
column43: which are increased defenses on routers and VPN devices   to block suspicious activity. In September
column44: Cisco   acquired CloudLock
column45: a company that helps provide integrated   security solutions for cloud-based networks.Cisco's security revenue in its fiscal Q1 ended Oct. 29 rose   11% from the year-earlier quarter to about $540 million. Even   though that makes up less than 5% of Cisco's total revenue
column46: management believes that having the focus and expertise in this   area will help them win over more business within its other   segments as consumers and businesses start to consider the need   for the most secure network possible a top priority.Can Cisco fend off competition?Cisco's traditional markets
column47: which still make up the bulk of   sales
column48: have declined in recent quarters. Switching
column49: which still   makes up nearly a third of total sales
column50: slumped 7% in the most   recent quarter year over year. Overall
column51: even with the growth   above
column52: total sales in the quarter gained a paltry 1%.   Additionally
column53: management gave less-than-exciting guidance for   early fiscal 2017.More concerning is that in the company's new growth areas
column54: it   faces some serious competition. The biggest of them   is Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column55: which offers both public and   private cloud hosting solutions
column56: as well as IoT solutions
column57: usually for a lower cost than traditional options. The service   has success stories from some big names likeNetflixandComcast
column58: just to name a few
column59: which has helped raise its prestige. In   terms of security
column60: Amazon provides cloud services to U.S.   intelligence agencies
column61: so clearly
column62: security is important to them   as well. AWS is growing quickly -- up nearly 50% year over year   in the most recent quarter to over $3.5 billion.The early successes of the segments above are encouraging.   Additionally
column63: Cisco has been able to gain a lot of expertise and   value from acquiring smaller tech companies in these high-growth   segments
column64: and Cisco is in a great position to continue that   strategy with around $70 billion in cash that it's likely to   start deploying more heavily in the quarters and years to come.   While Cisco will certainly face increased growth pressure ahead
column65: especially with AWS disrupting this space
column66: it looks to be making   some smart moves to transition its focus. Finally
column67: Cisco is   trading at just 15 times earnings
column68: just 2.5 times book value   (compared with Amazon's P/B at 21.7 times)
column69: and has a 3.3%   dividend yield that continues to grow. It looks like there's   plenty of reason to hold Cisco to see how these markets transform   in the years ahead -- and how this behemoth tech company will   play a part in them.10 stocks we like better than Cisco SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Should Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn late December
column3: I made apredictionthatMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) stock would hit $80 in 2017. In reality
column4: it was less a prediction than my agreement with Piper Jaffray analyst Alex Zukin's 12-month price target for MSFT stock of $80.makeArticleAd();Source:Via MicrosoftMore than one month into the year and the Microsoft stock price has a long way to go to reach this lofty goal.It's fair to say that if MSFT stock is going to hit $80
column5: Microsoft's burgeoning cloud business - an annualized revenue run rate of $14.0 billion as of Q2 2017 - needs to deliver more growth over the next three quarters (April
column6: July and October earnings announcements) to justify to investors a forward2018price-to-earnings ratio of 24.5.As I said in my earlier article
column7: I think MSFT can deliver on this front.But it got me thinking about Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates
column8: the world's richest person at $85 billion and the owner of approximately 179 million shares of MSFT stock
column9: a number that's been dwindling by approximately80 millionper year over the past decade or so; the proceeds going to fund the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.If this pace continues Bill Gates will have reduced his Microsoft stake to zero by sometime in 2019.Should Bill Gates Sell His MSFT Stock?No
column10: I'm not talking about whether he should continue to fund his foundation - of course
column11: he should -I'm merely wondering if there wasn't a better stock to sell to fund the foundation's good works.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayA quicklookat the financial statements for the foundation's 2015 and 2014 fiscal years shows that $11.3 billion was spent over the course of two years to fund its programs around the world
column12: an average of $5.65 billion per year
column13: about the same amount that Gates would currently generate from the sale of 80 million shares of Microsoft stock.So
column14: from a financial planning standpoint
column15: the 80 million figure makes a whole lot of sense.The holdings of the trust that oversees the investments and cash donated by the Gates's along with Warren Buffett for use by the foundation had a value of $18.5 billion as of September 30
column16: 2016; more than half (57.8%) of the portfolio invested inBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column17: NYSE:BRK.B) Class B stock.Since August 24
column18: 2006 through July 2015
column19: Buffett has donated 200.6 million shares of Class B Berkshire Hathaway shares to the foundation; this past year
column20: Buffett donated roughly15 millionshares. The remaining 285 million shares he agreed to donate back in June 2006 will be doled out at a rate of 5% per year until all 500 million shares are in the hands of the foundation sometime around 2036.So
column21: the choice comes down to whether it makes sense to sell the shares of Microsoft for cash to fund the foundation's work and continue to hold the Berkshire Hathaway shares as an investment or the other way around.The Gates have chosen the former rather than the latter.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkOn the surface
column22: that would seem to be a mistake given MSFT stock has outperformed Berkshire Hathaway Class B stock by 269 basis points on annuallized basis over the last five years through Feb. 6.So
column23: with that in mind
column24: does it make sense for Bill Gates to sell his MSFT stock?I don't think he should as some of its best growth lies in the immediate future. But
column25: I also don't think the trust should sell Berkshire Hathaway stock because it provides such good diversification and protection of capital.Both of these stocks are worth owning for the long haul.If it were up to me
column26: I'd probably look at cashing in some of the trust's other holdings first
column27: but thankfully for all those around the world deserving of the good education and healthcare the foundation looks to fund
column28: it's not up to me.As of this writing
column29: Will Ashworth did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendThe postShould Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alphabet Inc. Takes Another Shot at Amazon With Home Control;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlphabet Inc.'s(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Home connected speaker takes onAmazon.com
column3: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa on its home turf. But what about Google's big advantage over Amazon in the smart home war - all those smartphones?makeArticleAd();Source: GoogleThe company has just begun rolling out Home Control
column4: a new feature that lets Google Assistant control smart home devices by voice.However
column5: at this point
column6: Home Control - like Google Assistant - remains a feature that's exclusive to Google's own Pixel Phones.The Battle for the Smart HomeGoogle Home is a connected speaker with Google Assistant baked in. Owners can use Google Assistant on the speaker to answer questions
column7: find music and control a growing number of smart home devices using their voice only.The device is GOOGL's answer to the Amazon Echo. Amazon's Alexa-enabled speaker has been a surprise hit and allowed Amazon to take a big lead in the race to become the smart home hub - despite the distinct disadvantage of lacking a smartphone platform to host its digital assistant.Google has Google Now and the new Google Assistant
column8: whileApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has Siri. Between them
column9: the two companies have billions of mobile devices in consumers' hands
column10: yet Amazon still managed to leapfrog them with its personal assistant hosted in a speaker
column11: to build an impressive smart home lead.Apple's Siri can control HomeKit-compatible smart home devices using voice commands
column12: and now GOOGL is rolling out asimilar feature for its Google Assistant
column13: Home Control.Home ControlGoogle's new feature for voice control of smart devices isn't actually new. Anyone who owns both a Pixel Phone and a Google Home speaker already had a Home Control setting on their smartphone.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayHowever
column14: as of yesterday
column15: GOOGL has begun to roll out Home Control to all Google Assistant users. This amounts to all Pixel Phone owners
column16: since Google Assistant remains an exclusive that third-party Android smartphones don't get.With Home Control
column17: someone with a Pixel Phone gets the same voice control ability for smart devices they would have if they owned a Google Home speaker. They can use voice commands on their phone to change the temperature on their Nest Learning Thermostat or turn off the smart lighting in the room they just left.The Battle for the Smart Home Enters a New Phase (Sort of)At the start of this fight to be the company that becomes the hub of the smart home - the one who controls all those smart devices - the smartphone was it.Smartphones ran all the apps that controlled each of the devices and everyone owned one. With smartphones
column18: the battle came down to iOS and Android
column19: Apple and Google.Then Amazon disrupted everything with the Echo and Alexa. With thousands of compatible products and services
column20: consumers have been snapping them up. Amazon sold out of the Echo at Christmas
column21: afterselling nine times moreof the smart speaker than the previous year.Voice control is in. Having to poke buttons on a smartphone is out.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Finally Fires Back at Apple With Android Wear 2.0However
column22: Apple and Google are not about to cede the smart home to Amazon. GOOGL began its assault on Amazon with the Google Home smart speaker to directly take on the Echo and Alexa. With Home Control
column23: it's bringing voice control of smart devices to the smartphone
column24: leveraging its massive lead over Amazon when it comes to numbers. There may be millions of Alexa-powered homes
column25: but there are billions of people already carrying an Android smartphone.Except
column26: most of those people still won't be able to use Home Control. GOOGL has baked Home Control into Google Assistant
column27: a feature that's been exclusive to its Pixel Phones since they were released last fall. With Google Home and now Home Control
column28: Alphabet clearly has Amazon's number. The question will be whether Amazon gets Alexa into more third-party devices before Google decides to let third-party Android smartphone makers have access to Google Assistant.For GOOGL
column29: the decision comes down to which is more valuable: maintaining a key competitive advantage for its own Pixel Phones
column30: or giving up that Google Assistant and Home Control exclusivity to take a real shot at unseating Amazon in the smart home.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceNo
