column1: Nvidia (NVDA) Earnings: Why This Q4 Beat Was Really Important;2/10/2017;"Nvidia earnings (Shutterstock photo)It appears the only thing now strong enough to stop Nvidia (NVDA) stock from climbing higher are investors’ expectations. Thanks to the company’s advancements in cutting-edge technologies such as deep learning and artificial intelligence (AI)
column2: NVDA shares have soared some 340% over the past year
column3: crushing every important index.As such
column4: the California-based semiconductor giant had lot to prove Thursday. And with top- and bottom-line numbers that cruised by even the most bullish forecasts
column5: Nvidia answered the call. But the shares appear muted
column6: falling as much as 3% in the after-hour session. From my vantage point
column7: this decline
column8: which I consider inconsequential
column9: is victory for Nvidia and its investors. I’ll get back to that in a moment.makeArticleAd();Let’s go though the numbers.In the three months that ended December
column10: Nvidia reported net a income of $655 million
column11: or 99 cents per share. On an adjusted basis
column12: when taking out one-time gains and costs
column13: earnings came to $1.30 per share
column14: which beat consensus estimates by a whopping 30 cents. Fourth quarter revenue also beat
column15: coming in 55% higher year over year to $2.17 billion. The Street was looking for revenue of $2.11 billion.The strong bottom-line beat was driven by record quarterly GAAP gross margin at 60.0%
column16: the company said
column17: while non-GAAP gross margin at 60.2%. When looking back at fiscal 2016
column18: the company broke several of its own records
column19: including full-year revenue of $6.91 billion
column20: which grew 38% from a year ago.""We had a great finish to a record year
column21: with continued strong growth across all our businesses
column22: said CEO Jen-Hsun Huang in a statement. ""Our GPU computing platform is enjoying rapid adoption in artificial intelligence
column23: cloud computing
column24: gaming
column25: and autonomous vehicles. Huang also added that Nvidia’s deep learning GPUs (graphical processing units) has made a breakthrough approach to AI
column26: which can now help in early cancer detection
column27: weather prediction and is helping to tackle challenges such as self-driving cars.All told
column28: it is these breakthrough areas that continue to drive interest in NVDA stock. Admittedly
column29: I wasn’t a believer until now. And while the tech battle has always been between Apple (AAPL) Alphabet (GOOGL)
column30: Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB)
column31: those guys are not alone anymore.In terms of the 3% decline on these solid numbers? Nvidia is being shown the respect it now deserves. Even if the stock were to decline 5% to 10% — after a 340% one-year rise — it would still imply the momentum story is still in place. And Nvidia’s Q1 outlook for revenue to be $1.9 billion
column32: which surpass Wall Street estimates of $1.88 billion
column33: suggests it sees no signs of slowing down."

column1: Why I’m Raising My Price Target On Microsoft Corporation Stock (MSFT);2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you thinkMicrosoft Corporation(MSFT) shares are expensive now
column3: they are about to get even more so.makeArticleAd();Back in December
column4: I issueda 12-month piece target of $72 per share. But following the company's breathtaking fiscal second-quarter earnings results
column5: I am now confident is too cheap.As such I'm raising my price target by $8 per share to $80 per share.Why the price increase? For starters
column6: Microsoft stock is currently priced at a forward P/E of just 21 based on fiscal 2017 estimates of $2.97 per share. And while that P/E is two points above the average stock in the S&P 500 index
column7: Microsoft's recent moves suggests it deserves a much higher multiple.With growth opportunities emerging in the realm of the cloud
column8: Internet-of-Things
column9: smart home and a host of other areas thanks to its recent acquisitions
column10: Microsoft stock still looks like a bargain. I'll get back to this in a moment. But let's first assess its recent earnings.The main question heading into 2017 was to what extent Microsoft could sustain the strong cloud momentum it used in 2016 to surpassAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(AMZN).Microsoft answered that question with authority. In three months that ended December
column12: the company earned $5.2 billion
column13: or 66 cents per share
column14: rising from $5.02 billion a year earlier. On an adjusted basis
column15: when taking out one-time gains and costs
column16: earnings came to 84 cents per share
column17: which beat the consensus estimate of 79 cents per share. Second-quarter revenue came in at $24.1 billion
column18: while adjusted revenue was $26.1 billion
column19: also topping Wall Street estimates.The company's aggressive move towards the cloud was the main driver of the strong top- and bottom-line beat. Not only does this lessen Microsoft's reliance on declining PC sales
column20: but cloud businesses also generate higher margins. Revenue from the Office 365 business grew almost 50% year-over-year
column21: while gross margins in its commercial cloud business
column22: which includes Azure and Office 365 products sold to businesses
column23: reached 48% during the quarter - up two percentage points year-over-year.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth Potential""Our customers are seeing greater value and opportunity as we partner with them through their digital transformation
column24: said CEO Satya Nadella in a statement. ""Accelerating advancements in AI across our platforms and services will provide further opportunity to drive growth in the Microsoft Cloud.""Azure revenue surged 93% year-over-year (up 95% in constant currency) during the quarter. Though Microsoft provided no specific dollar amount to help break down the cloud revenue
column25: Bernstein analysts Mark Mordler estimates Azure now generates some 20% of commercial cloud revenue
column26: which Microsoft said was generating an ""annualized run rate"" just north of $14 billion
column27: according to Barron's. This means Azure now generates quarterly revenue at around $3 billion.Between now and 2020
column28: worldwide spending on public cloud services is expected to soar to more than $195 billion. This is double the revenue the industry is expected to generate by the end of 2016
column29: according to a research firm IDC.""Cloud software will significantly outpace traditional software product delivery over the next five years
column30: growing nearly three times faster than the software market as a whole and becoming the significant growth driver to all functional software markets
column31: said Benjamin McGrath
column32: senior research analyst
column33: SaaS and Business Models. ""By 2020
column34: about half of all new business software purchases will be of service-enabled software
column35: and cloud software will constitute more than a quarter of all software sold.""IDC is not alone in this prediction. Pacific Crest analyst Brent Bracelin forecasts public cloud spending
column36: currently around $58 billion annually
column37: will triple to $205 billion in the next three years. During that span
column38: Bracelin sees spending on SaaS services to surge 20% annually
column39: reaching $129 billion by 2020.As Microsoft's cloud business takes up greater portions of its total revenue
column40: Microsoft stands to secure larger pieces of the cloud pie. And Microsoft
column41: which during the second quarter completed its blockbuster $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn
column42: now has even more ways to attract businesses to Azure. To that end
column43: Microsoft stock should command a higher P/E of 4 to 6 points above its current valuation.When applying a P/E of just 25 to fiscal 2018 estimates of $3.26 per share
column44: this puts the stock's fair value at around $80. That valuation is still more than half that of Amazon
column45: which relies on its AWS cloud platform for the bulk of its profits. And with almost $121 billion in cash on its balance sheet make more deals for growth in key areas
column46: Microsoft
column47: which also pays a 2.45% annual dividend yield
column48: is a stock to own and forget about.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkRisks To Consider:Much of my optimism is based on the assumption that Microsoft can continue to increase cloud market share and successfully integrate LinkedIn.Action To Take:Microsoft should be kept on the watchlist of investors who are looking for a company with upside potential that pays a reliable dividend.Editor's Note:All Wall Street firms closely-guard theirblack box trading systemsto gain an edge over their competition. column1: Reinventing Retail: What if GoPro
column2: Garmin
column3: and Fitbit Rethought Everything?;2/9/2017;"One of the realities of business today is that retail in 2017   little resembles retail of a decade ago. Product companies used   to succeed or fail based on their distribution power and the   shelf space retailers gave them
column4: and retailers succeeded or   failed by having the right product at the best price for   consumers. Scale in retail mattered and that's how retailers   became power brokers in the product world.Retail today has been completely flipped on its head. A great   product from a small business can be a hit because its customers   share their experience online. Going viral can be more important   than being in the right retailers in 2017. Today
column5: anyone can open   a store online or onAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column6: Etsy
column7: eBay
column8: or any number of other platforms.The product development landscape that used to rely on large   companies to succeed has been flattened in a way that allows   someone in a garage to create a great product and get it out to   the world. All of this seems logical today
column9: but so many companies   are still built as if the old retail model still exists. Product   companies likeGoPro(NASDAQ: GPRO)
column10: Fitbit(NYSE: FIT)
column11: andGarmin(NASDAQ: GRMN) are a great example of this -- and if they're   going to succeed
column12: they may have to rethink their business models   to incorporate the retail realities of 2017.makeArticleAd();Drones are growing in popularity
column13: but are they really a     retail impulse purchase in 2017? Image source: GoPro.The old retail model is ancient historyThe old retail model for a product company essentially had   three to four layers
column14: depending on the channel. There was   manufacturing
column15: the product company would then have inventory on   hand to fill orders
column16: there may be a distributor who sells   multiple product lines
column17: and then there's the retailer themselves.   Manufacturing has to line up with end user demand
column18: but in between   is two to three layers of channel inventory that's incredibly   complex to get exactly right
column19: particularly if you're a   holiday-based business.This model creates two challenges for companies like GoPro
column20: Fitbit
column21: and Garmin. First is that they have to get their product   inventory build right so they don't miss the critical holiday   season
column22: but can't build too much or there's excess inventory. The   second problem is that retailers have to make money
column23: so they're   cutting into margin compared to if products were directly sold to   customers. Why not cut out the middleman?The inventory problemI don't think I can overstate how much of a problem inventory   is for product companies or how quickly it can erase years' worth   of profits. Companies have to try to guess what demand will be   months in advance
column24: build product to ship to stores
column25: and then if   demand isn't as strong as they predicted
column26: they usually have to   take product back from retailers.Image source: Garmin.In the fourth quarter of 2016
column27: Fitbit says it will take a   one-time writedown of $68 million for ""tooling equipment and   component inventory
column28: increase return reserves by $41 million   because of ""greater channel inventory
column29: and take another $37   million charge for ""increased rebates and channel pricing   promotions"". That's $146 million in charges during a single   quarter that was driven by too much inventory in the retail   channel. That quickly erased most of the $176 million in net   income from 2015
column30: which was a record for the company.Something similar happened at GoPro in 2015. Fourth-quarter   2015 results included $21 million in lost revenue from ""price   protection related charges"" and $57 million in costs associated   with ""excess purchase order commitments
column31: excess inventory and   obsolete tooling."" The $78 million in charges didn't quite offset   2014's full-year net income of $128 million
column32: but it took a big   chunk out of past success.Building the right amount of inventory is tough for companies   like this
column33: especially when they're selling into a channel with   multiple layers of distribution inventory. Maybe it would be   better to do a 100% direct business model
column34: especially when you   consider the value retailers are taking out of potential   profits.Direct sales are the product cash cowRetailers can bring products to millions of potential   customers
column35: but they need to make money to do so. And that makes   retail sales far less profitable for product companies than going   direct to consumers. Here's an example of how the trade-off   looks.Let's assume a retailer has a gross margin of 30%. So
column36: GoPro   would only make $279 on a Hero 5 Black that retails for $399. And   that's before any promotion or volume discounts a retailer may be   given that are then passed on to customers (think Black Friday   deals on GoPro cameras this year).If we assume that it costs $200 to make a Hero 5 Black (based   on margins for the company)
column37: then GoPro makes about $79 per   product sold at retail. But if GoPro sold the exact same camera   directly to a customer on its website it would get the entire   $399 and have a $199 margin. On the bottom line
column38: a direct sale is   worth 2.5 times that of each retail camera sale.GoPro sold 2.28 million GoPro units last quarter and a little   over half went through a distribution channel. But if GoPro would   have sold every camera directly to customers
column39: it could have sold   at least 25% fewer units and actually made more money. And this   is before we even consider the sales staff and inventory that   could be eliminated if a company only sold directly to   customers.This is a hypothetical example
column40: but it should be directionally   accurate for product companies. Selling in retail isn't the   highest-margin business any of these companies have
column41: and it may   not be worth the effort at all when you consider the charges a   company has to take if they get their inventory buildout   wrong.Less risk
column42: more profitWhen I look at companies like GoPro
column43: Fitbit
column44: and Garmin
column45: I see   a businesses that could survive very easily without any retail   presence at all. A $400 action camera or $500 triathlon watch   isn't exactly an impulse purchase
column46: so customers will find your   products if they're the very best. And if these companies went   with a more direct model
column47: they may generate significantly higher   profits even if sales fall. On top of that
column48: a simpler   distribution model means they could take less inventory risk.Changing business models may be hard
column49: but the retail business   isn't what it once was
column50: and if it's not a huge benefit to a   business
column51: then why pursue it at all? As traditional retail slowly   dies
column52: I think it's time for product companies to look for better   strategic alternatives. GoPro
column53: Fitbit
column54: and Garmin may be better   off building on top of their brands with a direct model rather   than trying to reach everyone in retail.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip

column1: 3 Stocks You Can Buy and Hold Forever;2/9/2017;"The ""simple"" method of buying and holding a stock really isn't   all that simple. Some companies might post stable growth for   years
column2: but suddenly be crushed by technological shifts or new   competitors.Therefore
column3: stocks that you can buy and hold ""forever"" should   have well-diversified businesses
column4: wide competitive moats
column5: and   solid plans for future growth. Let's take a look at three   companies that clearly fit those criteria --Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column6: Disney(NYSE: DIS)
column7: andFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) .AmazonAmazon is one of my top ""forever"" holdings for three reasons.   First
column8: it owns the most visited e-commerce website in  the   world. Second
column9: its ""prisoner-taking"" Prime ecosystem continues   expanding with new features and perks that brick-and-mortar   rivals are struggling to match. Last June
column10: research firm CIRP   estimated that Amazon's Prime member base in the U.S. had grown   43% annually to 63 million
column11: and that Prime shoppers spend an   average of $1
column12: 200 per year -- compared to $500 for   non-members.makeArticleAd();Amazon's Prime Air. Image source: Amazon.Lastly
column13: AWS (Amazon Web Services) is the biggest cloud   platform in the world
column14: and its higher operating margin (26% last   quarter) supports the company's other lower margin and   loss-leading efforts. AWS has an annual run rate of $14 billion
column15: and its revenue and operating profit respectively rose 47% and   60% annually last quarter.The combination of the growing Prime ecosystem
column16: connected   hardware devices like the Kindle
column17: Fire TV
column18: and Echo speakers
column19: and   the AWS backbone make Amazon the 800-pound gorilla in both retail   and cloud computing -- and I believe that it can continue   dominating both markets (and other adjacent ones) for decades to   come.DisneyIf you believe that Disney's theme parks and movie franchises   will still be making money hand over fist decades from now
column20: then   the House of Mouse is the ideal stock to hold forever. In theme   parks and resorts
column21: Disney's footprint continues to grow with its   new Shanghai Disney Resort
column22: new extensions (like Star Wars Land)   for its existing parks
column23: and a growing fleet of cruise ships. In   movies
column24: Disney continues generating billions of dollars in box   office revenues per year with its carefully crafted Marvel
column25: Star   Wars
column26: and Pixar franchises -- which are all built to last for   decades.Disney's only soft spot is its media business
column27: which has been   hurt by consumers ""cutting the cord"" in favor of streaming-only   platforms. A key concern is that ESPN
column28: the crown jewel of the   business
column29: has been losing subscribers
column30: disproving the notion that   live sports were insulated from cord cutters. However
column31: Disney hasbeen expandingits core cable brands
column32: like ESPN
column33: away from traditional pay TV   platforms and toward websites
column34: apps
column35: and stand-alone streaming   platforms.Over time
column36: I believe that the media business' dependence on   pay TV platforms will decline
column37: and that the weight of its theme   park and film businesses will increase. That gradual evolution   should make Disney a safe stock to own for generations to   come.FacebookFacebook finished last quarter with  1.86 billion monthly   active users -- about a quarter of the entire world population.   That's a moat that's nearly impossible for any competitor to   cross
column38: and makes the company the 800-pound gorilla of social   networking and a formidable rival toAlphabet's Google in the internet advertising space.In addition to its flagship site
column39: Facebook owns Instagram
column40: which hit 600 million active users last  December
column41: and   WhatsApp
column42: which hit  1.2 billion active users last month.   It's also been turning Messenger
column43: which has over a billion users
column44: into a gigantic platform for reaching businesses
column45: making mobile   payments
column46: and playing games.The Oculus Rift. Image source: Oculus VR.Lastly
column47: Facebook owns Oculus VR
column48: the maker of the seminal Rift   headset. Facebook also launched its own VR platform with Oculus   Home
column49: a VR launcher for Rift and Gear VR headsets. Users can   already chat and play games with each other in that VR   environment
column50: so it's likely only a matter of time before users   will visit each other's Facebook or Instagram profiles in a VR   environment. Facebook's growth will inevitably slow down over the   next few decades
column51: but it will likely keep generating billions of   dollars in advertising revenue as it expands its ecosystem into   adjacent markets.Think in decades
column52: not quarters...Many analysts are currently focused on Amazon
column53: Disney
column54: and   Facebook's near-term challenges. They're worried about Amazon's   rising logistics expenses and the perceived slowdown in AWS' top   line growth. They think that Disney's streaming efforts might not   offset its losses in pay TV subscribers
column55: and they probably think   Facebook is running out of room to grow.But as a long-term investor
column56: you should ask yourself if   Amazon
column57: Disney

column59: then you should consider buying and holding   these stocks for several decades instead of a few quarters.10 stocks we like better than Walt DisneyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Don't Overlook These 6 Incredible Amazon.com Numbers;2/9/2017;"Shares ofAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) fell more than 3% on Feb. 3 after the tech giant   posted mixed fourth quarter earnings and  soft guidance for   the first quarter. Revenue rose 22% annually to $43.7 billion
column2: but that  missed expectations by $980 million. The company   was hit hard by currency headwinds
column3: which reduced its top line by   about $558 million. Amazon's closely watched AWS (Amazon Web   Services) revenue rose 47% annually to $3.54 billion
column4: but that   also missed expectations of $3.6 billion and represented a   slowdown from 55% growth in the third quarter.For the first quarter
column5: Amazon expects 14.1% to 22.7%   year-over-year sales growth
column6: which missed analyst forecasts for   23.4% growth. But on a currency neutral basis
column7: which excludes an   expected currency impact of $730 million
column8: Amazon expects its   revenue to rise 17% to 25%.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();Some negative reports about Amazon focused on those headline   numbers
column9: but they glossed over many of the positive growth   figures. Let's take a look at six incredible numbers from that   report that investors shouldn't overlook.1. $749 million in net incomeDuring the fourth quarter
column10: Amazon's net income rose 55%   annually to $749 million
column11: or $1.54 per share -- which beat   expectations by $0.19. For the full year
column12: its net income surged   over 300% to $2.4 billion.That incredible growth was mostly attributed to the rapid   growth of AWS' high-margin business
column13: which gives Amazon much more   freedom to expand its e-commerce ecosystem with low-margin   hardware like its Echo speakers
column14: loss-leading services like   Amazon Video and Prime Now
column15: and logistics solutions like new   fulfillment centers and drones.2. AWS' operating margin of 26%AWS finished last quarter with an operating margin of 26%
column16: compared to 24% in the year-ago quarter. That margin expansion   indicates that AWS' massive scale is offsetting tough price   competition across the cloud platform market
column17: which caused Amazon   and its rivals to reduce their prices throughout the year.3. AWS' annual run rate of $14 billionAmazon announced that AWS had achieved an annual run rate of   $14 billion
column18: indicating that it maintains a commanding lead overMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure in the cloud platform race.Microsoft claimed that its ""commercial cloud"" had achieved an   annual run rate of over $14 billion last quarter
column19: but most of   that total came from SaaS platforms like Office 365 and Dynamics   CRM. Azure -- which competes directly against AWS in the   IaaS/PaaS ""cloud platform"" markets -- accounts for a much smaller   percentage.Microsoft doesn't disclose how much revenue Azure generates
column20: but  combining earlier industry estimates and its reported   growth rate  over the past few quarters indicates that its   annual run rate could be around $3 billion.4. Over 1

column23: andNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) with AWS

column27: bringing AWS' total coverage to 42   Availability Zones across 16 regions globally. That massive data   center expansion will help AWS reach more companies and   developers
column28: all while supporting the expansion of its e-commerce   and digital ecosystem into new markets.5. Prime Video in over 200 countriesA big part of that digital ecosystem expansion is Prime Video
column29: the company's streaming answer to Netflix. Amazon has made the   platform a ""free"" perk for Prime subscribers and a stand-alone   subscription service that costs slightly less than Netflix.Like Netflix

column31: and popular shows likeTransparentandMan in the High Castlehelped it become the third largest video streaming platform in   the U.S. after YouTube and  Netflix last year

column33: which could help  expand its   Prime user base worldwide.6. 4

column2: Inc. Is Also Spending $1 Billion With Amazon AWS;2/9/2017;"Earlier today
column3: Snap(NYSE: SNAP) filed its first amended S-1 with the Securities and   Exchange Commission. Companies often modify their initial   registration statements leading up to their IPOs
column4: prior to   issuing a formal prospectus. Prospective investors already knew   that Snap is a big spender atAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google Cloud
column5: which it relies on   for its cloud infrastructure needs.Snap is unique in its continued use of third-party   infrastructure vendorsat the scale at which it is operating; most companies invest in their own infrastructure once they   grow to a point where it's warranted. To a lesser extent
column6: Snap   also purchases infrastructure services fromAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();In the amended filing
column7: Snap provided some additional detail on   its relationship with the e-commerce giant.Always have a contingency planTo be clear
column8: Google Cloud is still Snap's main flame
column9: but it   never hurts to have backup. In fact
column10: contingency planning is   absolutely critical when your entire service relies on   third-party infrastructure partners
column11: and this is the role that   AWS will play. The deal was inked just yesterday
column12: which is what's   triggering the S-1 amendment.In last week's version
column13: Snap said: ""We are currently   negotiating an agreement with another cloud provider for   redundant infrastructure support of our business operations.""   That line was replaced in this week's version with: ""We have also   committed to spend $1 billion with Amazon Web Services over the   next five years for redundant infrastructure support of our   business operations."" Snap says an existing agreement with AWS   that was originally entered into in March 2016 was amended on   Feb. 8
column14: 2017.That $1 billion commitment will slowly ramp up
column15: starting with   $50 million in spending this year. That's a tiny drop in the   bucket compared to the $12.2 billion in sales that AWS did in   2016. Snap is on the hook to spend $350 million with AWS in 2021.   In contrast
column16: the agreement with Google Cloud that was finalized   on Jan. 30
column17: 2017 calls for a flat $400 million per year for five   years
column18: with a little bit of leeway in shifting spending to   subsequent years (up to 15% in each of the first four years).Data source: Snapchat amended S-1. Chart by author.Combined with its $2 billion commitment with Google Cloud
column19: we're looking at $3 billion pledged between Google Cloud and AWS   over the next five years. Snap's cloud strategy of relying   entirely on third-party partners is risky for many operational   reasons
column20: but that's an awful lot of financial pressure for the   start-up. In 2016
column21: cost of revenue exceeded revenue
column22: resulting in   a negative gross profit of nearly $50 million
column23: and infrastructure   costs are the largest component of cost of revenue.Snap only recently rolled out its automated ad sales API in   October

column1: Voice Control Platforms a Key Technology Trend in 2017;2/9/2017;"Technology companies have spent years on computational linguistics to solve the basic problem of making machines more efficient in an era where they would have to deal with bigger data loads and more complex queries. One of the products of this research is voice driven artificial intelligence that can connect and drive everyday devices to understand human speech and react accordingly.The most basic form of voice technology is a person directing a machine to do routine tasks such as play a track

column4: Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle Now or Microsoft'sMSFTCortana took care of. Home automation is a more recent trend and wouldn't it be cool if most of the smart devices/appliances used in the home can also take voice commands? And sync with each other to decide the desirable activity and then get it done?Amazon AheadWhile Microsoft has many years of research behind it

column10: cars

But all this works simply because everything is connected with AWS

column1: Are These 3 Dividend Stocks Too Cheap to Buy?;2/9/2017;"Income seekers get paid to invest when they buy into   dividend-paying stocks. Who wouldn't want that? Getting a good   deal on a stock's price simply adds to the value that accrues   from searching out cheap stocks that reward shareholders with   healthy payouts.But there might be times when there's too much of a good thing   -- a dividend stock that's so cheap it may be a trap. Consider
column2: for example
column3: Barnes & Noble(NYSE: BKS)
column4: Bed Bath & Beyond(NASDAQ: BBBY)
column5: andGameStop(NYSE: GME) . They all pay dividends
column6: and the market is broadly   discounting them
column7: but investors might want to think twice before   buying in. Read on to see why.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Barnes & NobleOn the surface
column8: picking up shares of Barnes & Noble   doesn't seem like such a bad idea. Trading at around $10 a share
column9: the bookseller's $0.60 annual dividend currently yields a hefty   6%
column10: and though its payout ratio stands at an astronomical 300%   based on earnings
column11: viewed through the lens of the free cash flow   it produces
column12: it's a much more reasonable 49%. Yet anyone who   knows even the slightest thing about the book market understands   that Barnes & Noble is operating on unstable ground.In its fiscal second quarter
column13: the bookseller said sales fell   4% to $858.8 million
column14: as comparable-store sales fell 3.2% because   of lower customer traffic
column15: which pretty much explains the   industry as a whole.Even though the book industry is growing (surprise!)
column16: the   buying of books continues to move online
column17: which remains the top   sales channel for publishers' revenue in the trade category.   According to the Association of American Publishers
column18: online   holds a 37.4% share of the market. It also says there is a   return to hardcover books as consumers move away from e-books
column19: which peaked in 2013 but have since fallen away and now comprise   around 17% of the market.Barnes & Noble was famously upended byAmazon.com
column20: which also caused the demise of Borders
column21: and its enterprise   value now trades at just 9.8 times its free cash flow
column22: a   bargain-basement price. But with a business model standing on   shaky ground that may be risky for its earnings growth
column23: such a   high payout for the dividend it pays makes it a risky read.Image source: Bed Bath & Beyond.Bed Bath & BeyondHome-goods retailer Bed Bath & Beyond has an even more   heavily discounted EV/FCF ratio of just 7.8
column24: but like the book   business
column25: its home-furnishings business is also being displaced   by the online market. And where Barnes & Noble at least had   tried to respond by getting into the e-reader business
column26: Bed Bath   & Beyond largely neglected e-commerce until relatively   recently. Now it's in hurry-up mode to make up for lost time
column27: plowing significant resources into the effort and going on a   shopping spree.Last June
column28: it purchased dying flash-sale site One Kings Lane
column29: and in November it bought PersonalizationMall.com
column30: a seller of   individually personalized gift items. These aren't particularly   material purchases
column31: but they're not big sales winners
column32: either.   And though its digital customer-facing channels grew 20% in the   third quarter
column33: the gains weren't nearly enough to offset the   declines in its brick-and-mortar locations.Management says its earnings have been trapped in a moribund   range of around $4.50 to $5.00 per share for several years now   because of investments made in the business
column34: and cash balances   that routinely ran north of $1 billion now total less than half   of that amount.It's also having trouble luring customers into its stores
column35: as   itsprodigious couponing effortsno longer generate the same response they once did. Instead
column36: they   only weigh on earnings. It is still able to generate significant   amounts of free cash flow
column37: but an investor might have to wait a   long time before the business turns around
column38: if ever. Its dividend   payment is new
column39: having just been initiated last year
column40: and it   yields just 0.3% -- suggesting it might not be worth the effort   to invest in the stock simply for its payout.GameStopVideo-game retailer GameStop suffered a disappointing   Christmas season
column41: as sales tumbled 16% from the year-ago period   while comparable sales plunged almost 19% on weak sales of once   strong titles such asCall of DutyandTitanfall. As with everyone else on this list
column42: its in-store traffic   fell.The gaming console market is in a state of flux as it   transitions to a digital distribution format. The transition is   obviously hurting sales of physical games
column43: but it's also   affecting the trade-in market. GameStop's response has been to   enter into the mobile-phone and collectibles market
column44: and though   revenue in the segment grew better than 37% in the last quarter
column45: it still accounts for less than 6% of revenue. And so many   troubled retailers -- RadioShack
column46: anyone? -- have placed their   hopes on having cell phones save them
column47: only to be sorely   disappointed.GameStop is another retailer that's still able to produce   handfuls of free cash flow
column48: generating $451 million worth over   the last 12 months
column49: which means its enterprise value is at a   minuscule 6.5. A $1.48 annual dividend yielding 6.1%
column50: and an   earnings-based payout ratio of 39% (34% based on free cash flow)
column51: make it tempting to take a bite here just to play along.However
column52: with GameStop's main game business moving away from   it even as it operates a large footprint of 7
column53: 600 stores
column54: all   while it's betting on new revenue streams that have nothing to do   with its area of expertise
column55: investors would do better looking   elsewhere for a dividend-paying stock.10 stocks we like better than Bed Bath and   BeyondWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column56: it can pay to listen. After all
column57: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column58: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column59: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Bed Bath and Beyond wasn't   one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

The Motley Fool has the     following options: short April 2017 $28 puts on GameStop. The     Motley Fool recommends Bed Bath and Beyond. The Motley Fool has     adisclosure policy."

column3: Inc. (DRI) and Agilent Technologies Inc (A);2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTheDow Jones Industrial Averageand other benchmarks are breaking out this morning on relatively strong trading. A check of our breakout stocks list brought some familiar names to our attention that deserve a closer look.makeArticleAd();Shares ofAgilent Technologies Inc(NYSE:A)
column5: Darden Restaurants
column6: Inc.(NYSE:DRI) andCostco Wholesale Corporation(NASDAQ:COST) are among the names helping to drive the strong performance today as each of these companies are making moves above key trendline or consolidation levels. These breaks suggest that higher prices await as traders begin to chase these trends higher.Agilent Technologies Inc (A)The healthcare sector has been quiet as traders await any ideas on how the regulatory environment and Obamacare may change with the new Trump administration. Agilent set itself outside of the crowd today as the stock broke through technical resistance and into a volatility rally.A shares are moving above $50 today as the company's earnings announcement approaches next week. It appears that the market is ""buying the rumor on Agilent beating expectations. Something it has done each quarter since May 2015.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenEven better
column7: A has been showing revenue growth as the rest of the market has been seeing flagging sales. This puts Agilent in a better light than its peers.The break above $50 is key as it marks the first time A shares have been above this price since 2001.Today's move breaks Agilent above its top Bollinger Band ahead of next week's earnings
column8: something that is likely to continue as volatility rallies higher right up to the announcement. A shares are heading into a slightly overbought condition
column9: which makes the ""trade"" relatively clear.The charts should take Agilent shares higher through mid-week trading after the announcement
column10: then traders should watch for a ""sell the news"" rally to follow and likely end shares back down at $50
column11: where they will find consolidation support before continuing higher.Costco Wholesale Corporation (COST)Another company seeing a breakout today is Costco. The retailer pulled back prior to the holiday season and traded range-bound; however
column12: COST shares have been leading the retail sector since December as they continue a climb.Today
column13: Costco broke above $170 on no news. In addition
column14: the COST's earnings aren't expected until the beginning of March. This means the breakout for Costco is trading driven - something we love to see.The break above $170 is coming with volatility as COST shares have now broken above their top Bollinger Band. This indicates that we should expect volume and volatility to increase as Costco stock makes its way higher.How much higher is hard to say as COST shares are now breaking into new all-time high territory. What will help Costco is the fact that the stock saw a 6% increase in short interest in the last reporting period. This indicates that there were traders expecting to see COST stock get rejected at its highs.  Now
column15: these traders must correct their short bets by buying the stock back
column16: helping to drive prices higher.For now
column17: keep eyes on round-numbers as these will be the first targets that traders will act on. Based on that
column18: $180 (a 6% move) is a clear upside target for Costco.Darden Restaurants
column19: Inc. (DRI)One final breakout for the day is Darden Restaurants. DRI
column20: the proprietor of Olive Garden
column21: among other eateries
column22: is making a technical move above its 50-day moving average for the first time since breaking below this key trendline on Jan. 6.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkThe break above the 50-day moving average comes during
column23: you guessed it
column24: a break above Darden stock's Bollinger Band. This suggests that we are likely to see an increase in the upside volatility of DRI Stock.The last time that we saw a similar combination of Darden breaking above the 50-day and a top Bollinger Band was in November 2016. This pattern was ahead of a strong rally in DRI shares that took them from $62 to above $75.For now
column25: watch for some resistance to come in on Darden shares as they trade to $80
column26: as this marks the stock's all-time highs.As of this writing

column1: Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You Think;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAs I write this
column3: Amazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) stock trades at about $824 per share. For 2017
column5: analyst consensus estimates are that AMZN stock will earn $7.25 per share for the full year. That gives Amazon stock an astronomical forward price-to-earnings ratio of nearly 62x. In comparison
column6: theS&P 500as a whole trades at about 17x next year's earnings.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIn other words
column7: AMZN stock trades at a multiplenearly six timesthat of the average large-cap U.S. stock.Of course
column8: this isn't a new phenomenon: For years
column9: investors have considered Amazon stock overvalued based on a P/E ratio that has often been in the triple digits - and
column10: not all that long ago
column11: negative.Yet AMZN stock seems to defy gravity: Shares are up 50% over the past year
column12: 110% over the past three years and a stunning 340% over the past five years. The reason is that Amazon isn't a stock that should be valued solely on next year's earnings
column13: or the price investors are paying for those earnings. That's not because the market is crazy when it comes to AMZN stock and it's not because the fundamentals ""don't matter"". It's because Amazon is investing now for growth later - and that's exactly what itshouldbe doing.AMZN's Earnings Aren't the Only ThingIt's tempting to think that a stock with a lower P/E ratio is by definition ""cheaper"" than other stocks. Why would an investor pay 50x
column14: or 100x
column15: a year's earnings when he or she could pay 15x
column16: or 10x? Growth certainly matters.7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendIntuitively
column17: an investor understands that 18x earnings for a bad business isn't obviously better than
column18: say
column19: 22x earnings for a good business. In fact
column20: it may be worse. But the P/E ratio for Amazon stock seems ridiculous on its face. AMZN is already the biggest retailer in the world; is it really going to show so much growth that it's worth paying a 100x P/E? It would have to grow its profits by a factor of five just to get the multiple to 20x
column21: which doesn't sound cheap itself.However
column22: that type of analysis is generally too simplistic. A stock is valued based on the sum ofallits future cash flows - not just next year's. That's true for AMZN stock
column23: and it's true forMacy's Inc(NYSE:M) stock as well.The fact that AMZN trades at 62x 2017 earnings and M trades at 10x doesn't
column24: in and of itself
column25: prove anything. It seems almost certain that the earnings and cash flow attributed to AMZN stock will continue to rise; it seems highly likely that Macy's earnings will
column26: in contrast
column27: fall. The rates at which those earnings rise or decline matters
column28: of course
column29: and those rates inform how investors value AMZN stock or M stock.But whether a stock is valued at 100x P/E or 3x P/E
column30: investors need to take a long-term outlook. And while it may not appear like it at first glance
column31: that's exactly what many AMZN stock holders are doing.The Two Ways For Amazon Stock to Grow EarningsEven those investors who are mostly bearish on Amazon stock would likely admit that Amazon's earnings will continue to grow going forward. But the bearish argument - one that has been made for the better part of a decade - is that it's almost impossible for AMZN earnings to growthat much. After all
column32: as a company gets bigger
column33: its growth rate fades
column34: simply due to its size. (SeeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) for a perfect example.)At some point
column35: the optimism that keeps Amazon stock at nosebleed levels will fade - and AMZN stock will come back to Earth.But that argument assumes that Amazon is at nosebleed levels
column36: which may not be the case. The heavy-handed P/E ratio sounds highly stretched; however
column37: according to AMZN's most recent 10-Q
column38: it generated $8.6 billion in free cash flow over the last four quarters. That implies a sub-50x multiple to free cash flow ona trailing basis -a slightly less intimidating multiple. And the focus on P/E ratio also ignores that there are two ways for Amazon to grow earnings.The first is the standard way that companies grow earnings: higher sales and better margins. There's little reason
column39: barring an economic recession
column40: to see AMZN's sales declining. Even then
column41: increased market share could allow Amazon to post revenue growth
column42: if not at the 29% pace seen through the first three quarters of 2016.There's also reason to see AMZN's margins expand considerably. Somewhat incredibly
column43: on a GAAP basis
column44: Amazon's operating margin year-to-date is just 3.2%. Yet the company has built out an incredible distribution platform and it has invested billions of dollars in its Amazon Web Services business. Incremental sales thus should boost margins considerably; it takes very little in the way of investment to sell a few more items
column45: or add another cloud customer.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column46: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingAMZN still has years of benefits from the scale it has built out
column47: and those benefits will continue to expand margins for some time
column48: allowing for steady
column49: and even explosive earnings and cash flow growth.The second issue relative to current and 2017 earnings is that Amazon isn't currently maximizing its profits. Rather

column51: offering everything from restaurant delivery to photo printing to Prime Video and Prime Music subscriptions.Some of those efforts will work; many likely will fail. But looking at 2016 and 2017 earnings and not considering the impact of that spending is as short-term as buying AMZN stock in 2017 simply because it rose in 2016. Amazon's operating expenses are on pace to increase almost $10 billion year-over-year in 2016. A good chunk of that is coming from hiring employees

Ignoring that new spend ignores the 'true' earnings power of AMZN stock.Bottom Line on AMZN Stock: It's ComplicatedThis is not to say that Amazon stock is necessarily a buy. column57: difficult
column58: detailed endeavor. The Amazon Web Services business is vastly different from the price-sensitive
column59: low-margin

column63: toward AMZN stock

column1: Snap Just Became One of Google's Most Important Cloud Customers;2/9/2017;"One of the many interesting details revealed inSnap's S-1 filing with the SEC is that it agreed to a $2 billion   contract with Google Cloud in January. The agreement with theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary spans five years with   relatively equal payments scheduled for every year.Snap has used Google Cloud since its creation
column2: but had been   spending considerably less than the $400 million per year it's   slated to spend through 2021. For the first few years of its   existence
column3: it spent less than $30 million per year on Google   Cloud. Last year
column4: however
column5: it started seeing its hosting costs   increase considerably
column6: up $192 million for the year.Image Source: GettymakeArticleAd();Google's cloud service competes against the largerAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) Web Services andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure. A $2 billion infusion could help it catch   up to the competition.What does $2 billion mean to Google Cloud?Alphabet isn't exactly forthright with its cloud revenue. It   lumps Google Cloud in with Google's other revenue line item
column7: which also includes Google Play and hardware sales. In 2016
column8: the   three categories produced $10.1 billion in revenue. Google Play   likely accounts for the bulk of revenue.The cloud unit had an estimated run rate of just $1 billion as   of the end of 2015
column9: according to RBC Capital. Snap's new contract   likely makes it Google's biggest cloud customer.While Google has made several advancements in its cloud   services over the past year
column10: so have its competitors. Microsoft   boasted that its Azure revenue increased 93% last quarter
column11: but   Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss estimates the unit brought in   just $1.6 billion. Bernstein's Mark Mordler estimates Azure's run   rate at $3 billion as of last quarter.Meanwhile
column12: Amazon just reported AWS sales topped $12 billion   in 2016. Sales surpassed $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter   alone
column13: although that fell short of analysts expectations.Google still needs to diversifyThe growth of Snapchat has been a major boon to Google's cloud   services
column14: but it's still actively seeking to pull customers away   from its competitors and take market share. The hiring of   cloud-computing veteran Diane Greene to lead the division has   helped the company attract numerous high-profile customers
column15: but   there's still more work to do.On Alphabet's fourth-quarter earnings call
column16: Google CEO Sundar   Pichai said
column17: ""We have truly differentiated offerings in four key   areas: data analytics and machine learning
column18: security and privacy
column19: tools for application development
column20: and the ability to create   connected business platforms."" Snap can take advantage of at   least three of those four factors
column21: so it's clear why it was   willing to lock down a long-term contract.At the same time
column22: the contract is not exclusive. If Snap wants   to enter China
column23: for example
column24: where Google doesn't operate
column25: it   could tap one of Google's competitors. Or it could build its   own servers.Snap recently hired Jerry Hunter from AWS
column26: who ran global data   centers for the cloud-computing giant. In Snap's S-1 filing
column27: management notes
column28: ""In the future
column29: we may invest in building our   own infrastructure to better serve our customers.""If Snap continues to grow at the pace it has been for the last   few years
column30: it may make economic sense for it to switch to its own   cloud infrastructure
column31: which would be a huge blow for Google.What this means for SnapSnap is now on the hook for $400 million per year in cloud   costs. There is some wiggle room: The contract says it can   postpone up to 15% of expenses for a year
column32: so it only has to   spend $340 million this first year. Still
column33: that's a huge amount   for a company that generated just $404.5 million in revenue last   year.It also means that switching service providers will be   difficult
column34: considering it would either have to eat the contract   as a loss
column35: or leave at least some of its operations on Google   Cloud in order not to waste the money. That makes the economics   of building out its own infrastructure within the next five years   even costlier.On the flip side
column36: analysts expect Snap's revenue to continue   growing at a rapid pace
column37: approaching $1 billion this year fueled   by continued user growth and product expansion that will surely   put additional demands on Google's servers. It has plenty of   capital to cover the expense
column38: and if last year's growth is any   indication of what to expect
column39: it will need to spend at least $340   million on cloud infrastructure this year. The deal with Google   ensures that it gets the lowest rates possible
column40: so it can to make   the most of its spend.Overall
column41: it's not a bad deal for Snap
column42: but it does tie the   company to Google for a long time.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(AAPL) stock enjoyed healthy gains in the days following the company's earnings reports
column3: and analystscrooned over the results.makeArticleAd();But not everyone was so thrilled
column4: with some pointing out the fact that the December quarter had an extra week and others focusing on the challenges being seen in the smartphone market.Nonetheless
column5: analysts are as happy as can be and continue to try to sell investors on the iPhone 8 cycle. At least one analyst has boosted his price target for AAPL stock based on the record iPhone unit number in the December quarter.AAPL Stock Target: $154 Per ShareCanaccord Genuityanalyst T. Michael Walkley raised his price target for Apple stock by more than $10 per share
column6: from $142 to $154 per share in a research note dated Feb. 6. He feels the company took a ""strong share"" of the premium end of the world's smartphone market during the December quarter
column7: as it generated 92% of profits.That is a decline from 106% of the profits in the September quarter
column8: however
column9: becauseSAMSUNG ELECTRONIC's (SSNLF) profits improved after the Galaxy Note 7 recall.Apple sold 78.3 million iPhones with an average selling price of $695 during its first fiscal quarter as consumers preferred the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus models. Walkley also believes the iPhone maker benefited from the Note 7 recall-although there was some debate about that before the results were released. Apple management said the quarter had the highest quarterly number of switchers from Android
column10: something that third-party data indicated just before the release.The analyst also expects the iPhone 7 lineup to continue doing well
column11: bridging the gap until the iPhone 8 is released
column12: probably in September.Despite Walkley's (and almost everyone else's) enthusiasm about Apple stock
column13: Neil George
column14: a contributor forThe Street
column15: feels investors are doing nothing more but attending the ""church of Apple.""Here's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200InvestorsdumpedAmazon.con
column16: Inc.(AMZN) stock immediately following the retailer's earnings results (although the shares are up today)
column17: but they have been happily slurping up Apple stock.He said the iPhone maker ""is faced with a dwindling market share and shrinking margins
column18: which means it just doesn't make sense to be so enamored with the company.Meanwhile
column19: Amazon recorded soaring revenues and the seventh consecutive profitable quarter. There's also new data from Slice Intelligence indicating that the company hoards 53% of all growth in U.S. online sales.Did Apple Take Investors For a Ride?George argues that Apple ""pulled off a sleight of hand"" by adding the extra week in the December quarter-an argument also made by Thomas H. Kee Jr. onMarketWatch. According to Kee
column20: to make up for that extra week
column21: the company would have had to report about $3.53 per share in earnings rather than the $3.38 per share it reported.He also estimates that revenue should have been about $81 billion rather than the $78.4 billion that was reported. Based on his weekly calculations
column22: the company grew at a 4.11% slower rate in the most recent December quarter than it did in the same quarter in 2015. Kee argued that Apple's growth rate contracted rather than grew in the most recently completed quarter and that it only looks like it did because of that extra week.George highlighted other ""problems"" he sees at Apple as well
column23: like the contracted gross margin
column24: which fell to 38.5% from 40.1% in the year-ago period. The iPhone maker also saw its sales in China
column25: the world's biggest market
column26: fall 12% in the December quarter
column27: reducing its market share there to 9.6%. He said the company's global market share has fallen as well
column28: down to 11.5%.Apple  is widely expected to launch the tenth anniversary edition of its smartphone under the iPhone 8 moniker
column29: and most firms have been calling this cycle a ""supercycle"" because they're expecting tremendous growth.However
column30: one analyst that's been calling for a supercycle is starting to back off from that theory and suggests now that the next cycle will be one of ""smooth"" growth rather than anything of the ""super"" variety.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialUBSanalyst Steven Milunovich said in a research note dated Feb. 7 that he's now ""smoothing"" out his assumptions for iPhone growth over the next couple of years and adopting ""less of asupercycleview"" for fiscal 2018."" He noted that it should be expected for product cycles in a maturing market to become muted
column31: so he's cutting his iPhone unit growth estimate from 16% to 12% for fiscal 2018 and boosting his fiscal 2019 estimate from a 2% decline to a 7% increase.Despite this smoothing out
column32: he's still expecting the iPhone 8 cycle to bring greater growth than the fiscal 2019 cycle.He feels that it could be more beneficial for Apple stock's multiple if the company experiences more gradual growth because investors might be encouraged to see the company's hardware and services revenue combined as an annuity.Shares of AAPLstock rose by as much as 0.19% to $131.78 during regular trading hours on Wednesday and are trading slightly higher in early morning trading Thursday.The postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Target Upped By Another Firm For Earningsappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market

column1: What Is Unearned Revenue
column2: and Why Should Amazon Investors Care About It?;2/9/2017;"A small line item onAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) balance sheet has been growing rapidly over the   past couple years. Since the end of 2014
column3: Amazon's unearned   revenue liability increased from $1.8 billion to $4.8   billion. Some investors might see a growing liability and   think that's bad news
column4: but in fact this is very good news.Unearned revenue is simply cash customers have paid to Amazon   in advance for services it has yet to render. For example
column5: Prime   members typically pay $99 up front for a full year of the two-day   shipping program. Amazon immediately takes the cash and puts it   on its balance sheet
column6: but it amortizes the $99 of revenue over   the 12 months of the membership. So it accounts for only $8.25   per month in revenue per month for each Prime member. The rest of   the cash received for Prime is held in the unearned-revenue   balance.Prime growth has been very good over the past few years.   Amazon says it added ""tens of millions"" of new members last year.   But Prime isn't the biggest driver of unearned revenue. More   likely
column7: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the biggest factor pushing   the balance higher.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty Images.Maybe last quarter wasn't so disappointingFor the first time since Amazon started breaking out AWS   revenue and income
column8: the cloud-computing segment missed analysts'   expectations. Sales totaled $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter
column9: where analysts were expecting $3.6 billion on average.But unearned revenue climbed $568 million from the previous   quarter. That's unusual for Amazon's fourth quarter. Usually
column10: unearned revenue spikes in the first quarter as cloud customers   presumably re-up short-term contracts for the year.Most of Amazon's AWS customers are small businesses using its   pay-as-you-go pricing
column11: which allows them to quickly scale their   use. The solution works well for companies with small or   unpredictable user bases.But a lot of AWS's money comes from the big enterprises that   spend hundreds of millions every year on cloud computing. For   those companies
column12: with more predictable usage needs
column13: Amazon offers   ""reserved instances
column14: which offers a discount if customers pay up   front. Growth in reserved instances
column15: or other long-term   contracts
column16: may have resulted in lower revenue in the short term
column17: but it nearly guaranteed revenue in the future.Locking in customersAs the competition for cloud-computing infrastructure   continues to heat up
column18: long-term contracts may prove invaluable.   Locking in customers for a relatively long term means those   enterprises will start optimizing their code so that it runs more   efficiently on the specific hardware and platform they're   using.Such is the case withSnap(NYSE: SNAP)
column19: which uses Google's cloud. In its S-1 filing
column20: Snap   says it built its app to use ""services provided by Google
column21: some   of which do not have an alternative in the market
column22: asRe/Code'sPeter Guagenti points out. Not only did Snap just agree to a $2   billion five-year contract with Google
column23: but it's also going to be   hard for it to leave Google even after the five years is up.   That's excellent news forAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) investors.
column24: and not as excellent   for Snap investors.Ultimately
column25: signing long-term contracts provides a moat   against the growing competition. Not only does it lock in   customers for the length of the contract
column26: but it could also lock   them in longer if they become dependent on certain features of a   cloud platform. In that light
column27: Amazon's fourth-quarter AWS   results look quite strong.Find out why Amazonis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column3: Dow Dividend Stocks Today;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe classic ""Dogs of the Dow"" strategy advises buying the 10 highest-yieldingDow Jones Industrial Averagestocks
column5: then holding onto them for a year. The idea is that higher yields are a signal of a beaten-up share price - and that because we're buying a stable blue-chip with a stable customer base
column6: investors will eventually bid the stock back up when the business cycle turns up again.makeArticleAd();But we can further improve on this effective yet somewhat ""dumb"" strategy with a bit of second-level analysis.After all
column7: some of these companies have business models that are actually aging in dog years!And they should be avoided.Today we're going to discuss four high paying Dow dividend stock components. Two are compelling buys
column8: while two should be sold immediately (or even shorted).12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenLet's get started…WINNER: Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM)Dividend Yield:3.6%Exxon Mobil Corporation(XOM) is emerging from what easily has been one of the most trying points in the company's history
column9: the roots of which stretch all the way back to 1870.From about mid-2014 through the start of 2016
column10: oil prices plunged from near $110 down to below $30 - a collapse that caused energy stocks across the sector to careen into the ground
column11: and forced numerous companies to shut their doors.Even Exxon Mobil - America's biggest energy company by market capitalization
column12: and one of the world's largest and most diversified oil and gas operations - wasn't immune. Shares dipped from around $105 to around $72 or so - a 30%-plus dip in just more than a year's time
column13: which is virtually unheard of in blue chips as well-established as XOM. Pundits thought that Exxon's streak of dividend increases
column14: which spanned more than three decades
column15: was in jeopardy.However
column16: former CEO Rex Tillerson himself managed the company in such a way that he knew its operations could survive with oil prices as low as $40 per barrel. April 2016 came around
column17: and XOM maintained its status as a Dividend Aristocrat with a small but symbolic payout hike. Meanwhile
column18: XOM shares have clawed back at least some of their losses.Speaking of Tillerson …The former Exxon CEO is a ""former"" chief because he's now America's Secretary of State. That's no doubt a boon to XOM
column19: especially considering the Trump administration's seemingly favorable and cooperative view with Russia - where Exxon has huge energy interests and projects
column20: and where Tillerson himself has deep ties.Moreover
column21: President Donald Trump and a GOP-controlled Congress are proving extremely friendly to the energy sector as a whole right now
column22: most recently with a Senate vote to knock down a rule governing transparency on energy firms' payments to foreign governments.Exxon was already set up well to benefit from an eventual return to high oil prices
column23: and now it's seemingly in the driver's seat. While investors wait for those gains to take hold
column24: they can enjoy 3.6% in dividends from this relentless oil titan.Exxon (XOM): This Long-Time Winner Is in Recovery ModeLOSER: Wal-Mart Stores Inc (WMT)Dividend Yield:3%Wal-Mart Stores Inc(WMT) is one of the perfect examples of how a big
column25: solid blue-chip can still be a big
column26: solid dud.Walmart is the largest retailer in the world
column27: and in fact Earth's biggest company by revenue
column28: boasting more than 11
column29: 000 stores across 28 countries. BeforeAmazon.com
column30: Inc.(AMZN) came around
column31: Walmart was considered one of the biggest disruptors to traditional brick-and-mortar retail. Its bargain-basement prices and enormous product offerings upended countless mom 'n' pop shops
column32: but also put the hurt to larger specialty retailers such asBest Buy Co Inc(BBY) andhhgregg
column33: Inc.(HGG).But Amazondidcome along
column34: and that - along with Walmart's ubiquity and lack of options for expansion - are at the very least keeping Walmart from being the investment powerhouse it once was.While WMT does produce world-class revenues
column35: top-line growth has been thinning for years
column36: and in 2016
column37: Walmart's sales actually dropped year-over-year:Walmart has been spending for years trying to bring its online offerings up to par to battle Amazon's unstoppable e-commerce machine - yet it just keeps falling farther behind. Dividend growth is lagging too - last year management upped its payout by a meager 2%.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in FebruaryWMT has lagged the total returns of the S&P 500 for the last 15 years - it's time to cut this dead weight loose.WINNER: Boeing Co (BA)Dividend Yield:3.5%Boeing Co(BA) just boosted its dividend by 30% to $1.42 per share - more than double its quarterly payout from 2013! And Boeing's generosity to shareholders didn't stop there.The company also upgraded its old stock repurchase program by implementing a new $14 billion buyback plan.Future business prospects are looking good. Boeing said it expects 2017 commercial aircraft deliveries to reach between 760 and 765
column38: up from last year's 748.Core earnings are expected to surge from $7.24 per share to a range of $9.10 to $9.30 per share.And Boeing sees cash flow ticking up from $10.5 billion last year to $10.75 billion in 2017 - plenty of cash to dish back to shareholders.Boeing's (BA) Dividend Takes OffLOSER: International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)Dividend Yield:3.2%Nineteen straight quarters of year-over-year revenue declines - 'nuff said.International Business Machines Corp.'s (IBM) core businesses
column39: such as services and software licenses
column40: have declined on a year-over-year basis for 19 straight quarters. And it's a bad sign that the company still won't break out its Watson revenues
column41: despite the fact IBM says its promising artificial intelligence unit is growing briskly.IBM's 2016 dividend hike dipped into single digits after years of double-digit improvements. Cash and short-term investments have dipped from about $11 billion in 2013 to $8.5 billion as of its last report … and long-term debt has climbed from $32.9 billion to $34.7 billion in that same time.And that streak of consecutive revenue declines?If Wall Street is right
column42: it'll be extended at least by a couple more quarters
column43: and both 2017 and 2018 revenues are seen eroding
column44: not recovering.IBM might survive for an eternity
column45: but it won't grow your money for you.IBM (IBM) Revenues Just Keep SinkingThe Best 7% Dividends for 2017Every portfolio has room for Dow Jones stalwarts like Boeing and Exxon Mobil that will throw off serious dividends and actually help grow your nest egg in the process.But Boeing and especially Exxon Mobil could see some significant moves in either direction depending on how the winds in Washington blow over the next few years. And I don't know about you
column46: but I don't want to have to check CNN headlines and Donald Trump's Twitter account every single day just to make sure my retirement holdings are still in the clear.That's why my latest stock research has been focused on a 1-2 punch of high yields and all-weather performance.I've just put together a newFREEreport
column47: ""The Best 7% Dividends for 2017
column48: that features bulletproof yields of 7%
column49: 8% … even double digits. Yes
column50: we need big yields to make it to the retirement finish line comfortably intact
column51: but we also need stocks that can go on the offensive when bull markets take hold
column52: yet also won't shiver at the first sniff of macroeconomic uncertainty.The Federal Reserve could throw three interest-rate hikes at us this year
column53: or it could do what it did the past two years and deliver just one rate hike. Donald Trump could justify the big sector moves from the past couple of months by delivering on his campaign promises … or Washington could deliver a bunch of compromises that temper the bulls' expectations. China could rattle more sabers in the South China Sea. The Brexit could take a more definite shape and send international investors into a panic once more.10 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print MoneyWith these top dividend picks
