column1: Why Fitbit Inc (FIT) Needs to Wise Up Before It Can Win Again;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) may be great to improve your health
column3: but as for Fitbit stock
column4: it has been lethal for investors. During the last 12 months
column5: FIT stock is off a horrendous 60%. This is certainly another case study of how high-profile IPOs can quickly come undone.makeArticleAd();Source:Via FitbitBut what about the future? Is there hope for Fitbit stock? Might there be a value play here?As I've written various times for InvestorPlace
column6: it's probably not a good idea to be hopeful. For example
column7: FIT is a company that develops a product that really is not a must-have. According to a recent study fromGartner
column8: the abandonment rate on fitness trackers is 30%. The most common reasons for this include: users either get bored or the device breaks!The conclusion from the report: ""Dropout from device usage is a serious problem for the industry. The abandonment rate is quite high relative to the usage rate. To offer a compelling enough value proposition
column9: the uses for wearable devices need to be distinct from what smartphones typically provide. Wearables makers need to engage users with incentives and gamification.""The Other Problems for FIT StockBut this is definitely not the only major issue with Fitbit stock. Let's face it
column10: the competitive environment remains intense. The company must fight against tough rivals likeGarmin Ltd.(NASDAQ:GRMN)
column11: Samsung(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). Although
column12: the biggest threat isApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL) Apple Watch
column13: which is still in the early phases.7 Stocks That Will Drop by 10% or More This QuarterIn light of all this
column14: is it any wonder that Wall Street is concerned with FIT stock? Of course not.More importantly
column15: the company is already reporting major problems
column16: as seen with the latest warning on fourth-quarter earnings. Fitbit's guidance calls for a loss of 51 cents to 56 cents a share on revenues of $572 million to $580 million. By comparison
column17: the prior forecast was for earnings of 14 cents to 18 cents a share and revenues of $725 million to $750 million. Overall
column18: it looks like the holiday season turned out to be a disaster for the company.Unfortunately
column19: the bad situation isexpected to continue. The full-year prediction is for revenues of $1.5 billion to $1.7 billion and a loss of 22 cents to 44 cents a share on FIT stock. Wall Street
column20: on the other hand
column21: was looking for a much more robust $2.38 billion on the top-line and profits of 64 cents a share.Bottom Line on Fitbit StockTo deal with the challenges
column22: FIT has a plan that looks weak. The company expects to reduce the workforce by mere 6% and to take other vague efforts to reduce operating costs
column23: leverage data and launch products into new categories. Interesting enough
column24: Fitbit wants to focus more on the smartwatch market
column25: but this will likely mean more expenses.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column26: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingEven worse
column27: CEO James Parksaidthat the issues with the company were ""temporary"" and the ""performance is not reflective of the value of our brand
column28: market-leading platform
column29: and company's long-term potential.""Huh? Well
column30: this really does seem like the talk of someone who is out-of-touch. And this should definitely be ominous for holders of FIT stock.Granted
column31: perhaps there may be a buyout. But when it comes to broken hardware companies
column32: this may be wishful thinking. For example
column33: think about how long the rumors for a purchase of the beleagueredBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) have existed.For the most part
column34: Fitbit stock may not be very interesting to a suitor. And this is not because the products are sub-par. Instead
column35: it could be as simple as that the market has hit maturation levels and that big players like AAPL stand to capture a big part of what's available.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbook. He is also the author ofHigh-Profit IPO Strategies
column36: All About Commodities
column37: andAll About Short Selling. Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column38: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's Pen7 Gold Stocks That Will Shine Under TrumpThe postWhy Fitbit Inc (FIT) Needs to Wise Up Before It Can Win Againappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Zacks Podcast Highlights: Wide Moat Investing: The Best Way to Find Great Long Term Stocks?;2/9/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column2: IL - In this edition of the Dutram Report
column3: we investigate the world of wide moat companies. These firms have durable competitive advantages which may make them top notch picks for investors over the long haul. To learn more about this concept
column4: we speak with Brandon Rakszawski
column5: a product manager at VanEck
column6: who gives us his insights on the topic. To listen to the podcast
column7: click here: (https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/243925/how-to-find-the-best-stocks-for-long-term-investments )When you are looking for a great selection for your long term portfolio
column8: you want a stock that is in a great competitive position
column9: and one that looks to see these advantages hold over years
column10: if not decades. But how do you find a company that is going to stand the test of time?One way to find these companies is by looking at those with 'wide moats'. This concept seeks companies that have a long term
column11: durable competitive advantage that can protect a firm's position over the coming years. Think of a castle with a wide moat surrounding it. The wider the moat
column12: the tougher it will be to break into the castle
column13: and that is exactly what this approach is looking for in the corporate world too.Where Are These Companies?To find these companies
column14: I spoke with Brandon Rakszawski of VanEck for some insights. Brandon is the product manager at VanEck
column15: an ETF provider that has the VanEck Vectors Morningstar Wide Moat ETFMOATand the VanEck Vectors Morningstar International Moat ETFMOTIin its lineup
column16: so he is definitely familiar with the concept.We discuss the idea of wide moats in a bit more detail
column17: and we also talk about the index construction of these products which focus on wide moat ratings from Morningstar
column18: in addition to trading at big discounts to fair value.We also talk about some of the major types of wide moats out there and how these can help give companies durable competitive advantages over time
column19: and what investors need to look for when analyzing a stock's prospects.I also asked Brandon for a few examples of how this in terms of the funds' holdings
column20: and he noted how Tiffany & CoTIFwith its excellent brand name is a great case
column21: as well as MastercardMAwith its incredible network. Additionally
column22: investors should note a few other top-notch examples from the current holdings list
column23: including AmazonAMZNwhich is well-known for its ultra-low cost model
column24: as well as Grupo Aeroportuario Centro Norte
column25: which is a Mexican company that owns more than a dozen airports
column26: giving it basically a monopoly over air travel in many areas of that country.We also discuss how this approach might result in some sector biases
column27: and some key factors that investors need to know about this approach. I also talk to Brandon about some of the companies out there that have no moat at all-and thus little to no competitive advantage-and what investors can take away from these companies too.Bottom LineThis was a great chat on what makes a 'wide moat' company
column28: and it could give investors something to look for in terms of 2017 picks too. So
column29: make sure to listen to this edition of the Dutram Report for a closer look at this often-overlooked
column30: but potentially lucrative
column31: segment of the equity world. And for more news and insights into the world of ETFs
column32: make sure to be on the lookout for the next edition ofthe Dutram Reporteach and every Thursday

column1: Snap
column2: Inc. Is Pioneering a New Cloud Strategy. Will It Work?;2/8/2017;"Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) may be leading the growing market for cloud   infrastructure
column3: butAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is still putting up a fight.Cloud infrastructure vendors have been crucial in enabling   smaller start-ups
column4: particularly those that are building mobile   apps
column5: to get up and running without having to worry as much about   the back end. It's an appealing model since it allows smaller   companies to simply pay for what they need without having to   invest in building the infrastructure themselves. In other words
column6: it's an OpEx model versus a CapEx model
column7: andGoogle is betting bigthat the market is going to shift to the OpEx model in a major   way in the years ahead.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();But as companies grow
column8: they often choose to invest in their   own cloud infrastructure. This gives them much more control over   their own destinies
column9: reduces risk
column10: and over time the cost   efficiencies improve after the large upfront investment.Social media peersFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) andTwitterboth operate their own data centers; Facebook announced itsseventh data centera few months back
column11: while Twitter's infrastructure operations are   expanding more slowly
column12: as it operates in co-located facilities.   Data centers are so strategically important to Facebook that it   helped create the Open Compute Project back in 2011
column13: publicly   sharing Facebook's infrastructure innovations for the greater   good.But notSnap(NYSE: SNAP) .Hey
column14: big spenderSnap primarily relies on Google Cloud for its infrastructure   needs. While this is entirely par for the course for mobile app   start-ups
column15: Snap has grown to a size (nearly 160 million daily   active users) that would typically warrant investing in   infrastructure. The sheer scale of Snap's use of Google Cloud is   what's unprecedented here. The Information reports that Google   landed Snap with numerous discounts and other benefits
column16: and Snap   very much relies on Google Cloud at this point
column17: although it also   uses Amazon's AWS to a lesser degree.Back in 2014
column18: Snap CTO Bobby Murphy said the company picked   Google Cloud over AWS because the company could scale better on   Google Cloud. Snap poached AWS' head of data centers in October   of last year
column19: which is a peculiar move as it may imply that Snap   has longer-term ambitions to build out its own   infrastructure.But for now
column20: Snap is firmly in bed with Google Cloud
column21: and   spends quite a bit of money. Infrastructure costs comprise the   bulk of Snap's cost of revenue. From the S-1: ""Cost of revenue   consists primarily of payments to third-party infrastructure   partners for hosting our products. Hosting costs primarily   include expenses related to bandwidth
column22: computing
column23: and storage   costs."" Cost of revenue in 2016 was $452 million
column24: and Snap has   committed to spending $2 billion with Google Cloud over the next   five years.But at what cost?In discussing its operating leverage
column25: Snap believes that using   a capital-light business model will translate into ""lower costs   for us in both the short and long term."" That's definitely true   in the short term
column26: but much more debatable in the long term.Having a larger proportion of fixed costs actually helps with   operating leverage as the business grows
column27: since those fixed costs   get spread out over an increasing revenue base over time
column28: reducing total average costs. In contrast
column29: if a company's cost   structure has a larger proportion of variable costs
column30: those costs   will scale commensurately with revenue
column31: so you don't get as much   margin expansion. It's already telling that Snap's cost of   revenueexceededrevenue in 2016 ($405 million)
column32: resulting in negative gross   margin.We saw this all play out years ago in the semiconductor   industry
column33: with the rise of the ""fab-less"" and ""fab-lite"" models   that are dominant today. Building a chip fab costs billions of   dollars
column34: which was a significant barrier to entry. Then contract   chip manufacturers came around and allowed companies to focus   more on designing the chips while the manufacturing partners   would produce them. By outsourcing production to a few large chip   manufacturers
column35: the industry collectively saved billions and   innovation flourished. Semiconductors mostly shifted to the OpEx   model long ago
column36: and there are only a handful of companies that   currently manufacture their own chips these days.Snap is wading into uncharted territory by relying on   third-party infrastructure partners at this scale. Whether or not   this proves right or wrong will also depend on how Snap grows   from here. One thing is for sure
column37: though: Both aspiring start-ups   and infrastructure vendors will be watching closely to see how   this experiment unfolds.10 stocks we like better than SnapWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Snap wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Can FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Salvage Some Value Through a Sale?;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt has been a rough ride forFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) stock. FEYE stock went public in September 2013
column3: priced at $20 per share. FireEye doubled on its first day of trading; it cleared $90 by March. A quick plunge followed
column4: and after a modest rebound
column5: shares have been in a consistent downtrend
column6: falling from above $50 in June 2015 to a current price around $11.makeArticleAd();Source:David via Flickr (Modified)With FEYE stock now near an all-time low
column7: investors are looking to see if there's a way to salvage some value.FireEye itself has been in the middle of a turnaround
column8: to be sure. The company has cut costs
column9: and worked to shift from legacy hardware products to a more cloud-based model. But the departure of the chairman and CFO after last week's Q4 earnings report could hamper those plans. Already
column10: restructuring has left several key positions open and affected FireEye's sales and marketing efforts.There is a case for the company to be a takeover target
column11: which almost certainly would value FEYE stock above current levels. But investors expecting a deal in the near-term seem likely to be disappointed. FireEye could be of interest to a larger player
column12: but it still has a lot of work to do.What FireEye Needs To DoIt's always tempting to see a M&A opportunity in a growth stock that has fallen on hard times. According to aBloombergreport last year
column13: FireEye already has turned down several buyout offers. Those deals almost certainly would have been struck at a price much higher than $11. Surely
column14: the rumored buyers - among themInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) andCisco Systems
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) - would still be interested at a lower price?12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThe problem
column16: however
column17: is that FEYE's business looks much worse than it did even six months ago. 2016 as a whole doesn't look that bad
column18: to be sure: Revenue increased 15% over 2015
column19: and the company managed to cut non-GAAP operating expenses by 3% at the same time. That combination moved FireEye closer to profitability: The non-GAAP loss narrowed from $1.61 per share to $0.99 per share.Those numbers don't show the real issue
column20: however. Billings
column21: which reflect revenue added in the quarter - not necessarily recognized sales - increased just 3% for the year. More concerning: That figure became progressively worse as the year went on. In Q1
column22: billings growth was over 20%; in Q3
column23: the figure increased just 4%. Q4 billings then declined 14% and the midpoint of Q1 guidance implies a 25% decrease next quarter.Nothing good will happen for FEYE stock until that trend is reversed. Acquirers don't want to buy a declining business. FireEye is already both unprofitable and burning cash. Declining billings will only worsen its losses. And FEYE can't blame its market. PeerFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT) announced 22% billings growth in its first quarter on the same day FEYE stock was plunging after its report. To be even considered as an M&A target with a market cap still over $2 billion
column24: FireEye has to fix its sales problems.Can FEYE Stock Rebound Through M&A?For its part
column25: FireEye management believes those issues will be fixed. After Q4
column26: outgoing CFO Mike Berry said the company would return to growth in the second half of 2017. New cloud-based offerings and the recently rolled out Helix platform are projected to start boosting sales by then.The huge decline in product billings - down 50% in Q4
column27: and guided the same in Q1 - will start to be lapped. And CEO Kevin Mandia pointed out on the Q4 call that FireEye for months had no head of sales
column28: either worldwide or in Europe.Combined with easy comparisons
column29: FEYE expects to get back to billings growth toward the end of this year
column30: which likely would translate into revenue growth in early 2018. But until that happens
column31: it's hard to expect much in the way of M&A interest.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column32: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingWhile FireEye seems confident in its prospects
column33: the price of FEYE stock shows that many observers remain skeptical. The company is shifting from products to clouds
column34: but there's a real concern that it's ""too little
column35: too late
column36: with rivals like Fortinet andPalo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW) having beaten FireEye to market.Any sale of FEYE is going to depend on that top-line rebound taking place. Lower spend is nice in the near-term
column37: but isn't going to be the primary consideration of a strategic acquirer like IBM or Cisco. A larger company looking to enter the cybersecurity market through a takeout of FireEye stock is going to plan for substantial cost cuts regardless. Whether FEYE makes those cuts in 2017 or IBM does so in 2019 doesn't much change the possibility of a takeover - or the price to be paid for FireEye stock.Simply put
column38: it's revenue that will drive FEYE's attractiveness as an M&A target. Thus
column39: it's revenue that will drive the performance of FireEye stock this year. Sales performance seems to hinge on whether the company succeeds in pivoting away from its legacy appliance business. That puts a lot of pressure on Helix
column40: in particular. The platform may rise to the challenge
column41: to be sure. But any investors expecting a takeout of FEYE stock should at the least
column42: be patient. FireEye has a lot to prove before bigger companies come calling.As of this writing
column43: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Dividend Growth Stocks on Sale TodayThe postCan FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Salvage Some Value Through a Sale?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Amazon and Samsung Offerings Could Eat Into Google Search;2/8/2017;"Let me start by stating the obvious:Alphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google is the undisputed   champion of search. With over 60% of the US market and more than   90% of worldwide of worldwide search
column2: Google is ubiquitous   and is not going anywhere any time soon. But even 800-pound   gorillas need to look around the room every now and then and see   what might be coming their way. From the looks of it
column3: two fellow   titans are pushing products that might test Google's   strength.Google is the undisputed king of search. Image source:     Google.makeArticleAd();Bixby to bypass Google?Samsung acquires Viv virtual personal assistant. Image     source :VivLate last year
column4: Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) acquired Viv
column5: an artificial intelligence   company whose founders were the original developers ofApple'sSiri. With this purchase
column6: Samsung joined the fray of thevirtual personal assistant. With several more years of development under its belt
column7: Viv was   being billed as Siri's smarter sister that would work and play   well with others. In addition to the standard assistant chores   fare of language search
column8: map directions
column9: and weather
column10: Viv was   able to respond successfully respond to extremely complex   questions and follow-ups
column11: a skill lacking in other assistants.   With Samsung's acquisition
column12: Viv was updated and reemerged as   Bixby
column13: a virtual assistant which will make its debut in the   soon-to-be-released Galaxy S8. Samsung has plans to integrate its   recently acquired assistant into the majority of the native apps   on its upcoming phone.One of the more interesting features is the   camera featuring an optical character recognition system. By   pointing the camera at an object
column14: and engaging the ""Bixby""   button
column15: it seeks to identify said item and launches a native   search engine that circumvents Google search and locates the item   for purchase.There arepersistent rumorsthat Google has tried to prevent Samsung from making Bixby the   default on its phone
column16: and it may find legal standing to do so.   Samsung phones use Google's Android operating system and the pair   have a non-compete as part of their patent-sharing agreement.Google may not want Bixby to bypass its search
column17: though it   would not be the first such occurrence. Those familiar withAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) failed Fire phone will recall a similar feature   -- Firefly -- that allowed users to take a picture of an object   and launch the item listing on Amazon's website. Amazon's phone   never gained any traction
column18: so the fact that it bypassed Google's   search never resulted in any significant threat to Google's   search. The Galaxy S8 is unlikely to meet that same fate
column19: even in   light of the the Galaxy Note 7'srecent difficulties.Consumers begin product searches on Amazon.comMore products searches start on Amazon than Google. Image     source: Amazon.comSpeaking of Amazon
column20: astudyin June 2016 by PowerReviews found that 38% of US consumers   initiated a product search on Amazon versus 35% on Google.This   may be only the beginning. A largerstudyin September 2016 by BloomReach found that 55% of consumers begin   their search for a product on Amazon versus 28% on search   engines. The same report issued a year earlier reported 44% and   34% respectively. Amazon revealed that it is seeking to leverage   this and its massive library of product reviews by expanding paid   search
column21: which will include not only products it sells
column22: but items   not available on the site. This product and paid search will   extend to its virtual personal assistantAlexa and its Echohome systems. Few details have been released by Amazon
column23: but this   will likely compete directly for Google's advertising   dollars. There is not yet any indication of a wider entry   into search
column24: but with some estimates placing Amazon's Prime   membership at nearly half of US households
column25: that might provide a   natural entry into the field.Those little things can add upGoogle is already dealing with lower costs-per-click as a   result of the migration from desktop search to mobile
column26: with rates   falling 15% year over year in its most recent quarter. The   company was able to still grow the top line 22% in the most   recent quarter by making it up with volume
column27: with aggregate paid   clicks up 36% year over year.Alphabet earns nearly 88% of all its revenue from Google's   search
column28: and small challenges like these to its dominant position   could become legitimate threats to the company's cash cow   over time.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A       shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares)       wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10       stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column33: 2017Suzanne Frey
column34: an executive at Alphabet
column35: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors.Danny Venaowns shares of Alphabet (A shares) and Amazon.com.Danny Venahas the following options: long January 2018 $640 calls on     Alphabet (C shares) and short January 2018 $650 calls on     Alphabet (C shares). The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A shares)
column36: Alphabet (C shares)
column37: and     Amazon.com. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: An Amazon-PayPal Partnership Still Doesn't Make Sense;2/8/2017;"WhenPayPal Holdings(NASDAQ: PYPL) split fromeBay(NASDAQ: EBAY) in 2015
column2: it opened the door for the payments   processor to partner with a lot more online merchants.Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) has been at the top of PayPal investors' wish   lists ever since. Partnering with the world's largest online   retailer would provide a huge growth catalyst.PayPal CEO Dan Schulman provided some hope to investors in an   interview withBloombergfollowing the company's fourth-quarter earnings report. ""We have   been in conversations with Amazon
column3: he said.Image source: PayPalmakeArticleAd();The benefits would be huge for PayPal
column4: but it's still not   clear what Amazon could get out of PayPal. Even though PayPal has   shed eBay -- one of Amazon's biggest competitors -- it still   doesn't make sense for the two companies to partner up.""Your margin is my opportunity""Amazon famously operates on extremely thin margins. While   payment processing represents a small portion of the online   retailer's operating costs (falling under its fulfillment   expenses)
column5: every penny counts. Through the first nine months of   2016
column6: the operating margin for Amazon's retail operations was   just 0.7%.While Amazon uses third-party services to process credit   cards
column7: PayPal's take rate is significantly higher than the   standard processing fees of traditional back-end payment   processors. PayPal's standard fee is 2.9% plus $0.30 for U.S.   transactions
column8: and 3.9% plus a fixed fee for international   payments. Amazon would surely get a deal from PayPal
column9: but the   latter is still in business to make a profit.Amazon would be sacrificing some profit in a partnership with   PayPal. The question then is
column10: would it receive benefits that   offset the opportunity cost of sticking exclusively with its   existing payment processors?What does PayPal bring to the table?PayPal's biggest use is for onboarding new customers. It   allows them to skip the step of entering payment information
column11: and   it provides an added layer of fraud protection. The only problem   is
column12: Amazon already has so many customers.PayPal has nearly 200 million active accounts
column13: which sounds   like a lot until you consider that Amazon surpassed 300 million   active customers over a year ago. There aren't many incremental   customers for Amazon to gain from the partnership.In addition
column14: PayPal's strength in recent years has been its   mobile-checkout system
column15: which is a place many online retailers   struggle. Amazon
column16: however
column17: has significantly outperformed the   rest of the industry on mobile.PayPal does bring valuable data to the table. It holds data   from years of partnering with eBay
column18: which is one of Amazon's   biggest competitors. It also has data pertaining to many smaller   online retailers
column19: which could provide Amazon with new verticals   or products to invest in. Whether the retail giant will have   access to that data is unclear
column20: and how valuable it really is to   Amazon is equally vague.A lopsided dealA partnership with PayPal doesn't provide much meaningful   value to Amazon
column21: whereas PayPal gets several benefits: access to   the largest online retailer
column22: the third-party merchants that use   Amazon's marketplace
column23: and at least some of its shopper data.   While Amazon wouldn't be feeding valuable data directly to its   competitor now that PayPal has split ties with eBay

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt seems unlikely that from a fundamental standpoint
column3: there will be a lot of news in thePandora Media Inc(NYSE:P) earnings report on Thursday.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockPandora already announced last month that fourth-quarter results would come in ahead of guidance for both revenue and adjusted Ebitda. That disclosure sent P stock up 6%
column4: and would seem to limit the possibility that the numbers in the Pandora earnings report will boost the stock further.That doesn't mean there will be no news coming out of Pandora earnings. The company has set itself up for a busy 2017. The replacement of Pandora One with Pandora Plus appears to have had some success in the fourth quarter. Commentary on that initiative will be closely watched on the Q4 conference call.Meanwhile
column5: in December
column6: Pandora announced a new ""Premium"" service to compete with offerings fromSpotify
column7: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) and others.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenThat product should roll out shortly
column8: potentially boosting growth in 2017. And Pandora has said it is aiming to return to Ebitda profitability in 2017. The Q4 report should give some color as to whether investors in P stock should believe the company.A Busy 2017 for Pandora StockPandora stock actually is up about 65% over the past year
column9: after coming close to all-time lows in early 2016. Those gains have come despite mixed performance in the business. Revenue is up 14% through the first nine months
column10: and likely rose a similar figure in Q4. But about half the year-to-date growth came from the acquisition of TicketFly last October. Advertising revenue also increased 14% through the first three quarters - but came solely from higher pricing. Active users were actually down year-over-year at the end of Q3
column11: and subscription revenue declined in the quarter as well.The user and subscription figures are a major problem for Pandora stock. The market simply doesn't trust that Pandora can create consistent profits based on advertising revenue alone. That's particularly true given thehigher royalty ratesthat took effect at the beginning of last year. So the move by Pandora to upgrade One to Plus - adding features like song replays - and to develop Premium are a clear step toward a subscription-based model.The plan from Pandora
column12: as detailed after the third quarter
column13: is for that type of model to provide a more stable revenue base. Moving customers to subscription-based services both helps margins and improves retention. If Pandora is successful
column14: Pandora stock likely will rise. But that remains a relatively big ""if.""What to Watch for in Pandora EarningsIn the Pandora earnings report
column15: then
column16: the most important numbers likely will come from the company's guidance. That guidance will give some color as to how successful management thinks Plus has been so far - and what kind of opportunity Premium has to boost Pandora earnings this year.But the Pandora earnings conference call also seems like it might move P stock. Management will have another opportunity to detail its strategy for 2017 and beyond. The company laid out its ""three-legged stool"" strategy - Plus
column17: Premium and Ticketfly - after the third quarter
column18: but investors weren't terribly impressed. Pandora stock fell about 14% over the next seven sessionsThe issue with P stock is that there's a real fear that Pandora's model simply doesn't quite work. The product itself is attractive
column19: as evidenced by the nearly 80 million active users. But it's not clear that Pandora can pay higher royalty rates through ad revenue alone. The company did announce layoffs ofabout 7%of its employees in a bid to improve 2017 profits. That simply raised additional concerns about Pandora stock. The most notable is: Can Pandora really compete with Apple
column20: Spotify andAmazon.com
column21: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)?After all

column23: yet the company has burned about $127 million in cash just in the first three quarters of 2016. Full-year Ebitda loss is likely to be huge as well
column24: and that's not counting depreciation or the additional $139 million in Pandora stock awards.Make Free Profits From Tesla Inc (TSLA) StockFor Pandora stock to appreciate in the near term

column26: investors also will be looking for more information on the plan going forward here.Can Pandora find a niche in the music industry? Is Pandora Premium ""too little
column27: too late"" against the offerings from Spotify
column28: Amazon and Apple? And is there really a profitable business model here
column29: or are royalty rates simply too difficult to manage?Those questions can't be answered quite yet

column1: Why Coca-Cola Co (KO) Stock Is a Great Contrarian Opportunity;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe Coca-Cola Co(NYSE:KO) stock provides a play for contrarians heading into its fourth-quarter earnings report. Earnings and sales have declined year-over-year in each of the lastsixquarters
column3: which should keep expectations low. Meanwhile
column4: Wall Street analysts appear to be exiting KO stock en masse.makeArticleAd();Source:Leo Hidalgo via Flickr (Modified)Morgan Stanley cut Coca-Cola stock to 'Equal Weight' in December; Goldman Sachs downgraded KO to 'Sell' last month and Wells Fargofollowed with its own re-rating to Neutral barely a week later. For investors who like to buy at the point of maximum pessimism
column5: the Coca-Cola earnings report looks like an opportunity.Of course
column6: KO stock isn't likely to make a huge gain off of the Coca-Cola earnings report; the stock generally doesn't move all that much. In fact
column7: the relatively quiet movement in Coca-Cola stock actually has been one reason analysts have turned bearish. Those analysts argue that in a more optimistic market
column8: with broad indexes at all-time highs
column9: KO stock's ""defensive"" nature seems less attractive. Thus
column10: investors are ""rotating"" away from safe
column11: solid names like Coca-Cola andProcter & Gamble Co(NYSE:PG) into higher-risk
column12: higher-reward issues.Perhaps this is true
column13: but that argument only works as long as broad markets remain at or near their highs. And for Q4
column14: that pessimism seems to leave KO stock well-positioned for gains coming out of its report.When expectations are low
column15: after all
column16: it's difficult to disappoint. But the Q4 report also has long-term implications. It will be the first earnings release after the appointment of new CEO James Quincey. Quincey isn't new to Coca-Cola; he has worked at the company for twenty years. And outgoing CEO Muhtar Kent doesn't leave until May.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryBut the Q4 earnings call might give Quincey a chance to detail the company's plans to deal with consumer shifts away from soda. Those plans may be of more interest to investors in KO stock than the Q4 numbers.The KO Stock NumbersAnalyst consensus projects KO stock will generate fourth-quarter earnings of $0.38
column17: down a penny year-over-year. Revenue is expected to decline sharply
column18: falling 8.7% year-over-year.Those estimates aren't quite as bad as they sound
column19: however. The strong dollar is affecting revenue: it reduced Q3 revenue by 2%
column20: for instance. Coca-Cola also has refranchised bottling operations
column21: which has affected revenue. In the third quarter
column22: for instance
column23: reported revenue was down 7%. But the company's figure of 'organic' revenue - growth excluding divested operations and currency effects - rose 3%.KO is still targeting over $600 million in productivity savings this year. And KO also has brought in nearly three-quarters of a billion dollars in proceeds from the refranchising proceeds. The cost savings and cash inflow are being used in part to fund new marketing
column24: but also are improving margins.And if Coca-Cola earnings show further margin improvements
column25: and a surprise earnings beat that shows some bottom-line growth
column26: the narrative here could change. With analysts pricing in a declining business
column27: any sort of growth in Q4 could provide a nice boost to KO stock.The Coca-Cola Earnings Release: The StoryNumbers aside
column28: investors no doubt are more interested in the company's long-term strategy. It's highly unlikely that Coca-Cola will disclose some massive change in its operations
column29: to be sure. The current focus on cost control
column30: and the refranchising efforts
column31: seem likely to persist.But KO does have some options in terms of strategy. Unlike its chief rivalPepsiCo
column32: Inc.(NYSE:PEP)
column33: which owns Frito-Lay
column34: Coca-Cola notably no longer has a food business. Coke reportedly considered making an offer for yogurt manufacturer Chobani
column35: and a move to diversify away from beverages could provide a more stable revenue base. The company also owns nearly 17% ofMonster Beverage Corporation(NASDAQ:MNST)
column36: and could decide to make a play for the rest of that company.3 Reasons Amazon.com
column37: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the KingAnd the mega-merger still sits on the horizon. Many analysts are convinced thatAnheuser Busch Inbev NV (ADR)(NYSE:BUD) will eventually make a play for KO stock. The departure of Warren Buffett's son Howard from the KO board has either fueled or dampened that speculation
column38: depending on the analyst. Howard Buffett's exit could meanBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column39: NYSE:BRK.B) is looking to sell its stake in KO stock. Or it could mean that Warren Buffett and Berkshire are interested in being part of a takeover - and don't want to face the conflict implied by having a seat on Coca-Cola's board.So while there's reason to see some contrarian optimism toward the report from a fundamental standpoint
column40: the real story out of the KO earnings report will be the story management tells to investors. With a strong balance sheet
column41: a new CEO and a number of M&A options
column42: Coca-Cola has a lot of paths to take. Investors will be listening closely to see if KO management gives any hint as to its direction.As of this writing
column43: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great7 Dividend Growth Stocks on Sale TodayThe postWhy Coca-Cola Co (KO) Stock Is a Great Contrarian Opportunityappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Here's What Amazon Actually Plans for Physical Stores;2/8/2017;"AsAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) has dipped its toes into the water of building   physical retail locations
column2: rumors of its eventual plans have   included all sorts of things that the company has not actually   done. When a retail chain struggles
column3: there are speculative   stories about the online retailer buying it. In addition
column4: there   have been stories like a recent one inThe New York Postthat claimed Amazon had plans for an automated
column5: two-story grocery   store that required as few as three workers to operate.Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos took toTwitterto vehemently deny that any such plan existed. Hetweetedin part ""whoever your anonymous sources are on this story ...   they've mixed up their meds!"" The CEO followed that up with   another tweet rebutting the idea that his company had figured out   how to use robot-run stores to dramatically improve typical   grocery store margins: ""... if anybody knows how to get 20%   margins in groceries
column6: call me! :)""It was a very strong denial by Bezos
column7: but just because this   story is not true (or at least the company claims it isn't) does   not mean Amazon does not have brick-and-mortar plans. The   retailer does
column8: and CFO Brian Olsavsky laid them out during   the company's Q4 earnings call on Feb. 2
column9: which was transcribed   bySeeking Alpha(registration required).makeArticleAd();Amazon may not be prepping robot-run stores
column10: but it does       use them in its warehouses. Image source: Amazon.What are Amazon's retail plans?While the media and the public seem to expect Amazon to make a   grand entrance into physical retail
column11: its near-term plans remain   modest. The company currently has one Amazon Go store -- a   convenience store with automated checkout -- and while Olsavsky   called the Seattle store ""very interesting
column12: he also noted ""it's   only one store at this time."" He called the single store a ""beta""   and acknowledged that ""we like the promise of that
column13: but stopped   short of announcing plans for expansion.The CFO did say to expect more brick-and-mortar Amazon   bookstore locations. Even there
column14: though
column15: the company's plans   remain modest. ""We have three physical stores; Seattle
column16: San   Diego
column17: and Portland right now. We see adding five more this   year
column18: he said. ""So we're still in that phase where we're testing   and learning and getting better
column19: even on the bookstore.""Olsavsky also acknowledged that Amazon has tested pop-up   stores
column20: where you can learn about and buy Amazon devices and   services
column21: and ""college pickup points
column22: where online orders   can be picked up. He implied that there would be expansion of the   campus format saying it ""creates a great value
column23: but did not   commit to adding a specific amount. The CFO did not entirely shut   down the idea of launching other formats
column24: but he made it clear   that experiments would continue.""So not much projection beyond where we are today except for   the fact that we will be adding more bookstores
column25: he said. ""But   we test
column26: we innovate
column27: we think the bookstores for instance are a   really great way for customers to engage with our devices and see   them
column28: touch them
column29: play with them and become fans. So we see a lot   of value in that as well.""Amazon is taking it slowIt's easy to see why Amazon customers would love the company   to put stores around the country. On the other hand
column30: it's also   easy to see why the online retailer has taken it very slowly.   Amazon's chief advantage has long been that it does not have the   overhead associated with traditional physical retailers. Adding   stores means adding expense and that's something the company has   correctly been very cautious about.There may someday be thousands of Amazon bookstores
column31: convenience stores
column32: and maybe even robot-run grocery stores. That   day
column33: however
column34: is not imminent. The online retailer is still   testing the waters and while it's growing its physical portfolio
column35: it's doing so slowly

column1: Apple Inc. Taps Head of Amazon Fire to Run Apple TV (AAPL);2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) reported its Q1 financials in January
column3: there was little said about Apple TV sales. The poor performance of AAPL's Other Products division - despiterecord setting Apple Watch sales- said it all. However
column4: it looks as though AAPL is turning its focus once again to its often neglected set-top streamer.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThere's no word of new Apple TV hardware
column5: but the company has made a big move. News just broke that the company hired the former head of rivalAmazon.com
column6: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Fire TV to take over as marketing vice president for Apple TV.New Apple TV Hire Sends SignalsBloombergreported last night that AAPL has hired Timothy D. Twerdahl as thenew marketing VP for Apple TV. Any new hire for the position would be worth noting
column7: but in this case the company's choice is very interesting.According toBloomberg
column8: Twerdahl came to Apple by way of Amazon
column9: where he headed up the very successful Fire TV unit. Snagging one of your primary competitors is always a bit of a coup
column10: but in this case
column11: Apple's hire has an even more compelling background. Prior to his work with the Fire TV
column12: Twerdahl was an executive withNetflix
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) and a vice president overseeing consumer devices atRoku.In other words
column14: the new Apple TV boss previously headed up the top two competing video streamers and had a senior position with the world's number one video streaming service. That's a pretty good hire and not one the company would make unless it's serious about goosing those sliding Apple TV sales.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialBloombergnotes that the previous head of Apple TV marketing is being moved to a role helping to lead AAPL's efforts in securing streaming content deals.Apple TV Needs the PushWhile AAPL's set-top streamer got a sales push with the release of the new fourth-generation Apple TV in 2015
column15: it wasn't able to maintain that momentum. The Apple TV may have games and its own App Store
column16: but unlike the competition
column17: there's no 4K video support and AAPL's box carries a hefty price premium.Even though AAPL doubled its Apple TV sales compared to the previous year when it introduced the new Apple TV in 2015
column18: it still fell short of Roku
column19: Amazon Fire TV andAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column20: NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google Chromecast in market share.AAPL lumps the Apple TV into its Other Products division and doesn't spike out sales numbers. However
column21: in the company's Q1 earnings report
column22: revenue for Other Products declined by 8% year-over-year. Considering that it had a record-setting quarter for Apple Watch sales - the other major product in that division - the numbers point toward poor holiday sales for the Apple TV.No New Apple TV Hardware
column23: YetOf course
column24: even poaching the competition's top guy and someone with the breadth of experience that APPL's new hire appears to have can only go so far without revamping the product.Xiaomi Was Going to Rival Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock -- What Happened?The current
column25: nearly year and a half old
column26: Apple TV carries a huge price premium. AAPL charges a minimum of $149 for its box - double the going rate for competing hardware from Amazon
column27: Google and Roku - and despite the big dollars the Apple TV lacks 4K video support.AAPL was able to shrug that off in 2015 when 4K video was more bleeding edge
column28: but consumers now expect the feature. New content to populate thatTV app hubApple has been showing off won't hurt
column29: but job one for Twerdahl will be dealing with the hardware gap.There's no word on new Apple TV hardware
column30: yet. But with a new VP in place
column31: his predecessor focusing on acquiring additional content and sales continuing to slide
column32: the pressure is on for AAPL to either cut prices or introduce a new
column33: fifth-generation box. Or both.As of this writing

column1: 3 Reasons Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is STILL the King;2/8/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsLast week
column4: e-commerce giantAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) released disappointing holiday sales figures that caused investors to question the firm and send AMZN stock down roughly 3%. While the company produced fourth-quarter earnings that surpassed expectations
column6: the firm's revenue and future guidance figures came in below estimates.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAmazon's lacklusterearnings resultsmay have shocked the broader market
column7: but investors would be wise to use AMZN stock's loss as a buying opportunity because shares of the company very rarely go on sale.Amazon has a lot of potential and its willingness to invest in the future makes it a great long-term bet. While AMZN stock is still expensive at just over $810 per share and a price-to-earnings ratio of 186
column8: the firm's share price could make its way above $900 by the end of the year.AMZN Stock: Three Reasons to Keep the Miss in PerspectiveIt's never a good thing when a company misses revenue expectations and issues worse-than-expected forward guidance. However
column9: it's important to take a look at why AMZN's fourth-quarter earnings shook out the way they did and whether it's a deal breaker for investors considering picking up Amazon stock.Some of the reason for the revenue miss can be explained by currency fluctuations
column10: whichhurtthe retailer's revenue figures by around $558 million. Amazon is also adjusting to its fast-growing marketplace and the number of merchants that have joined the firm's ""fulfilled by Amazon"" program.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThis has in-turn increased shipping costs
column11: but the long-term benefits of the growing number of ""fulfilled by Amazon"" merchants outweigh the short-term negatives. It allows Amazon to offer its Prime members a greater selection of items and will likely help AMZN grab an even larger marketshare.Speaking of Amazon Prime
column12: the loyalty program is another good reason for investors to get behind Amazon stock. Not only do Prime's subscription fees provide AMZN with a passive revenue stream
column13: but the program helps bind people to its ecosystem.Prime has expanded to include benefits like dash-buttons
column14: which allow people to reorder certain products at the click of a button
column15: and movie and music streaming. Prime members who use all of Amazon's services are not only more likely to buy additional Amazon products like the firm's virtual assistant Alexa
column16: but they will also shop at its website before considering rivals - even if it doesn't offer the lowest prices.AMZN is doing with retail whatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) did with technology: building a brand that people will continue to buy into because it is convenient and connected.Here's How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Hit $200However
column17: while the company's dominance in retail is a big reason to buy AMZN stock
column18: one of the most compelling elements of the firm's business is Amazon Web Services - the firm's cloud computing arm. The cloud computing space represents a huge area for growth as the industry is relatively new
column19: but AWS has already become one of the largest players.AWS has been slowly making up a larger and larger percentage of Amazon's total sales
column20: and the fourth quarter was no exception. The firm's cloud computing arm has been growing rapidly over the last year and as the industry continues to expand
column21: investors can expect AWS to add to Amazon's bottom line in a larger and larger capacity.Bottom Line on Amazon StockAMZN stock's stumble last week has given investors an opening to add shares to their portfolios. While there was some weakness in the company's fourth-quarter results
column22: the firm is on track to continue growing and Amazon stock will likely deliver outstanding gains in the year ahead.As of this writing
column23: Laura Hoy was long AAPL and AMZN.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Gold Stocks That Will Shine Under TrumpThe post3 Reasons Amazon.com

column1: Better Buy: Microsoft Corporation vs. Amazon.com
column2: Inc.;2/7/2017;"They are two of the strongest companies in the world. Before   you go to bed each night
column3: you've likely spent time using bothMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) suite of technology products
column4: and bought
column5: received
column6: or streamed content viaAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .An investment of $1
column7: 000 in Microsoft or Amazon back in 1997   would now be worth $8
column10: respectively! While   there's a big gap between the two
column11: both are impressive   returns.But which is the better buy today? To be honest
column12: you can't go   wrong buying either one of these companies. If forced to choose
column13: however
column14: here are three different lenses through which you can   evaluate the question and decide for yourself.makeArticleAd();Image source: Getty ImagesSustainable competitive advantagesIf you're going to choose to forgo the safe route of buying   index funds and try your hand at investing in individual stocks
column15: there's no variable you should spend more time focusing on than a   company's sustainable competitive advantage. Often called a   ""moat"" in investing circles
column16: a company's sustainable competitive   advantages are what keep customers coming back
column17: year after year   and decade after decade.For Microsoft
column18: the moat is pretty easy to define. The company   owns some of the most widely used applications in the world
column19: including the Microsoft Office Suite and Windows. While the   company also has hardware products available and its Azure cloud   competing service is growing rapidly
column20: the moats provided by these   offerings are much narrower.Amazon
column21: on the other hand
column22: has a host of moats. First
column23: the   company's impressive network of fulfillment centers allows it to   deliver packages quicker than anyone else. And it would costbillionsin upfront investments for any company to come close to touching   this. Second
column24: the company's membership rolls in Amazon Prime --   while not publicly disclosed -- are likely over fifty   million.But perhaps most importantly
column25: the company has begun to benefit   from the network effect: as Prime membership grows
column26: the number of   third-party vendors using Amazon's fulfillment services is   swelling. With each new Prime member
column27: a vendor is incentivized to   use Amazon's platform. And with each new vendor
column28: a potential   customer is incentivized to shop on Amazon. That creates averypowerful moat.While I hardly think Microsoft is in trouble
column29: I'm giving the   edge here to Amazon.Winner = AmazonFinancial FortitudeIt's great to see money returned to you every quarter in the   form of dividends. It's even better to see cash being reinvested   for exciting growth opportunities in the future. But at the end   of the day
column30: there's no substitute for boring old cash sitting in   the bank.That's because every company
column31: at some time
column32: will face economic   difficulties. Those that face such times with cash in the bank   have options: they can outspend rivals into oblivion
column33: buy back   shares on the cheap
column34: or even make acquisitions.Debt-heavy companies are in the opposite boat
column35: forced to   narrow their focus just to meet the demands of their   creditors.Here's how Amazon and Microsoft stack up in terms of financial   fortitude.CompanyCashDebtNet IncomeFree Cash FlowMicrosoft$132 billion$59 billion$16.8 billion$27.5 billionAmazon$26 billion$8 billion$2.4 billion$9.7 billionData source: Yahoo! FinanceAs I said at the outset
column36: these are two of the strongest   companies in the world. That is reflected in their balance   sheets. If I were forced to choose a winner here
column37: however
column38: Microsoft would take the crown. The company creates massive free   cash flow from its core Windows and Office platforms
column39: and it is   one of only two companies left that have AAA credit ratings from   Standard & Poor's.Amazon's no slouch either. But CEO/Founder Jeff Bezos is   (in)famous for playing the uber-long game -- reinvesting revenue   into the business to further build an impenetrable moat around   the company.Winner = Microsoft.ValuationFinally
column40: we have valuation. While this isn't an exact science
column41: there are some straightforward metrics we can consult to give us   an idea of how expensive each stock is.CompanyP/EP/FCFPEG RatioDividendFCF PayoutMicrosoft22182.32.4%42%Amazon176402.9N/AN/AData source: Yahoo! Finance
column42: E*Trade. P/E represents figures   from non-GAAP earnings.Given Bezos' aforementioned penchant for trading a dollar   today for the potential of earning ten dollars tomorrow
column43: Amazon   looks very expensive. This has almost always been the case. And   investors that have passed on Amazon because of it have paid the   price in missed returns the whole time.That being said
column44: it's hard not to give the valuation edge to   Microsoft. The company trades for a reasonable valuation
column45: and it   offers a solid and sustainable dividend.Winner = MicrosoftAnd the winner is...MicrosoftSo there you have it: While Amazon has a more impressive moat
column46: Microsoft has both a better balance sheet and a more reasonable   valuation. That being said
column47: it would be disingenuous of me not to   mention that Amazon is by far my largest personal holding
column48: accounting for a whopping 19% of my family's real-life   holdings.That's not necessarily because we've invested a lot in the   stock. Rather
column49: it's because shares have appreciated by so much   since we first bought shares back in 2010. That being said
column50: this   type of review encourages me to look further at making a purchase   of Microsoft
column51: which has a lot going for it as well.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column52: it can pay to listen. After all
column53: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column54: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column55: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column56: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Brian Stoffelowns shares of Amazon. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Amazon. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Tech Stock Roundup: Industry Comments on Visa Ban;2/7/2017;"The technology sector has grown increasingly dependent on foreign talent over the years such that today it can't function without it. On the face of things
column2: this has been really good for innovation helping the U.S. maintain its technological lead over others. But digging down a bit deeper
column3: what this means is that the U.S. is increasingly incapable of producing this talent itself. This is not a good situation to be in
column4: particularly when you consider that countries like China are doing all they can to develop indigenous intellectual property.That's probably the reason President Trump's draft proposal according to Bloomberg reads as follows: ""Our country's immigration policies should be designed and implemented to serve
column5: first and foremost
column6: the U.S. national interest… Visa programs for foreign workers... should be administered in a manner that protects the civil rights of American workers and current lawful residents
column7: and that prioritizes the protection of American workers - our forgotten working people - and the jobs they hold.""There are many conflicting views and opinions about H-1B visas that companies use to employ people from other countries when adequate resources in the fields of science
column8: technology
column9: engineering and math aren't available locally. But since foreign labor is usually cheaper
column10: critics say that companies tend to employ foreigners even when the skills are available thus depressing wages for the industry as a whole.Ron Hira
column11: an associate professor at Howard University
column12: has done extensive research on the topic. Supporters say there isn't room to control wage inflation since the program is highly regulated and technology companies like AmazonAMZN
column13: AppleAAPL
column14: FacebookFB
column15: AlphabetGOOGLand MicrosoftMSFT
column16: in fact
column17: pay handsomely.Whatever the opinion on the wage rate
column18: there's no denying that the jobs go to foreigners. If the trend continues
column19: high tech American employees will have a harder time finding jobs
column20: thus gradually closing down the institutions producing them. The per capita GDP attributable to such jobs will also go down as tech employees from abroad obtain American citizenship.It's also true that a country is in a position of absorbing others
column21: giving them a home
column22: a job
column23: etc. when it is itself in a position of strength. But when it can't find local tech workers
column24: it's definitely not in that position and may need some temporary measures to rejuvenate.There's also another side to the story. If tech companies are unsuccessful in their letters of appeal
column25: lawsuits and other measures they're taking against the President and the proposal is enforced
column26: they may decide to employ the same talent in international facilities. A company's main motivation and objective is to generate profit
column27: and there could be initial costs of setting up such international operations.The visa issue has been clubbed with another important one involving terrorism because the President has blocked all refugees from entering the U.S. for 120 days (the ban is indefinite for Syrian refugees possibly because of their acts of vandalism across Europe). Citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries like Sudan
column28: Iran
column29: Iraq
column30: Libya
column31: Somalia
column32: Syria and Yemen were also banned from entering the U.S. for 90 days. This seems like a relatively short period of time and what will be achieved in the interim remains unclear.In the meantime
column33: Attorney General Bob Ferguson
column34: a Democrat
column35: filed a complaint saying Trump's order is ""undermining the state's sovereign interests"" in violation of equal protection laws under the Fifth Amendment. Washington State also sued the President with support from Amazon and Microsoft.But don't imagine that the so-called refugees are helpless victims because they have plenty of powerful lobbies working for them. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) are getting ready to file lawsuits. What's more
column36: Google has created a ""crisis fund"" with $2 million and its employees have contributed a like amount that they are gifting the ACLU. Other funds are also on the way.But tech companies have plenty to say about both issues:Apple: CEO Tim Cook told employees that the company had communicated with the White House. ""I've heard from many of you who are deeply concerned about the executive order issued (Friday) restricting immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries. I share your concerns. It is not a policy we support…Apple would not exist without immigration
column37: let alone thrive and innovate the way we do
column38: he wrote in an email.Google: CEO Sundar Pichai wrote in a memo to employees: ""It's painful to see the personal cost of this executive order on our colleagues…We've always made our view on immigration issues known publicly and will continue to do so."" He also said that at least 187 Google staff were affected by the ban.Founder Sergey Brin: ""It's a debate about fundamental values and thoughtful policymaking and many of the other things
column39: I think
column40: that are apparently not universally adored but I think the vast majority of our country and legislators support."" Google has a problem with the orders
column41: including ""extreme vetting"" of immigrants. After planning their move for some days 2K+ Google employees from at least eight Google offices walked out on Monday afternoon.Facebook: Founder Mark Zuckerberg wrote on his Facebook page: ""Expanding the focus of law enforcement beyond people who are real threats would make all Americans less safe by diverting resources

column45: and ""First
column46: as the grandson of immigrants and the CEO of a company that was co-founded by an immigrant

He also said: ""At Intel we believe that immigration is an important part of our diversity and inclusion efforts"" and ""Inclusion is about making everyone feel welcome and part of our community.""Its official statement says

We will continue to provide any impacted employees with Intel's full support.""A statement on the company website says that it supports ""legislative or administrative action to improve the immigration system for highly skilled employees."" Half its 106K employees work in other countries and its U.S. workers include roughly 3K foreigners on work visas for those with specialized skills. But the number of employees from the seven banned nations is not known. Intel explained its contribution to Trump's inaugural committee by saying that it gave Intel a seat at the table on issues important to the company.Microsoft: Microsoft's president and chief legal officer Brad Smith wrote in a letter to the Secretary of State Rex Tillerson that there are currently 76 U.S. visa holders within the tech firm and 41 dependents who are citizens of the seven countries mentioned in the order. ""These are not situations that law-abiding individuals should be forced to confront when there is no evidence that they pose a security or safety threat to the United States

The tech community is powerful. Large tech companies in particular have enormous power and are held in high regard. We need to hear from the CEOs clearly and unequivocally. Although there is some business risk in doing so

column78: we will all make each other stronger.""CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+5.85%+20.10%FB-0.98%+5.29%GOOGL-2.95%+2.39%MSFT-3.22%+12.51%INTC-3.83%+4.79%CSCO+1.10%+1.92%AMZN-3.06%+5.53%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateApple in India: Apple will be assembling some iPhones in Bengaluru

column1: Amazon's Next Major Growth Driver Takes Another Step Forward;2/7/2017;"It's anchors aweigh forAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column2: and investors should be cheering the e-commerce   giant's latest move.Amazon recently passed a major milestone in its continued   effort to disrupt the global shipping and logistics industry
column3: long dominated by partners includingFedEx(NYSE: FDX)
column4: UPS(NYSE: UPS)
column5: and numerous others. Equally important
column6: this   achievement illustrates why many
column7: myself included

column9: despite a lofty market   capitalization already in the hundreds of billions of   dollars.Amazon launches a logistics serviceAccording to a number of credible reports
column10: Amazon recently   began operating as a ""global freight forwarder and logistics   provider
column11: pushing the e-commerce giant into a new line of   business. This doesn't mean Amazon owns or rents any seagoing   vessels (yet). Rather
column12: it acts as the liaison that helps   manufacturers book space on freight ships and move products   between ports and warehouses.makeArticleAd();Source: Getty Images.The e-commerce giant is currently doing so under the name of   one of its Chinese subsidiaries
column13: and Amazon has reportedly   provided this service for at least 150 cargo containers thus far.   This small figure is too small to be viewed even as a rounding   error for the global shipping industry -- the Port of Los Angeles   alone processed about 800
column14: 000 containers in December 2016 alone
column15: for example -- but the move represents an important symbolic   achievement for Amazon. It marks just the latest step in Amazon's   apparent long-term ambition to create some type of global   logistics and delivery platform.Recall that early last year
column16: Amazon signed adeal to lease20Boeing767s as part of its partnership withAir Transport Services Group
column17: an agreement that also saw Amazon make a minority investment in   the company as well. This move served as the opening salvo in a   new chapter that pits Amazon directly against many longtime   partners
column18: such as UPS and FedEx
column19: to name a few. Such a seemingly   far-flung tactic might seem like something of a distraction to   outside observers
column20: but investors should love this latest news --   and the broader storyline -- for a number of reasons.Turning water into profitsIt's quite likely that the financial opportunity alone makes   this service an attractive idea for Amazon. All told
column21: the global   shipping and logistics business could be worth $400   billion
column22: according to one research analyst. At the same   time
column23: though
column24: this story is also worth noting because it reflects   Amazon's unique ability to transform parts of its cost structure   into new revenue streams.Retail is an infamously low-margin business
column25: and consumers   typically favor the company that offers the lowest prices for   undifferentiated goods -- people don't care from whom they buy   their batteries. To gain market share
column26: then
column27: Amazon has been   forced to find ways to continually charge less than its   competition for the goods it sells. Thisconstant searchfor ways to lower prices
column28: in turn
column29: has forced Amazon to find ways   to lower its own cost structure to make its business model   sustainable.To so do
column30: Amazon has been remarkably aggressive in creating   new services from the core competencies it has gained. Among some   noteworthy examples are its Amazon Web Services cloud-computing   platform and its Fulfillment by Amazon service. Each of these   services allows Amazon to generate additional revenue by using   its own infrastructure and intellectual capital to help solve   similar problems at other companies.By turning its attention to global logistics and related   services
column31: Amazon seemingly hopes to shave even more from its own   burgeoning shipping and fulfillment bills. According to its most   recent annual report (2015)
column32: fulfillment costs were Amazon's   largest operating cost
column33: accounting for 12.5% of total revenue.   Fulfillment costs as a percentage of sales had also increased in   each of the past two years. Scaling this new service could lead   to billions in cost savings for Amazon
column34: which would allow it to   lower prices in its e-commerce business in a virtuous cycle that   benefits customers and shareholders alike over the long term.Of course
column35: disrupting a global industry as large as logistics   and fulfillment will take years
column36: and there are any number of   reasons Amazon's vision might not come to fruition. As a   potential boon to its sales growth strategy and as an interesting   case study in terms of its broader business philosophy

column1: Is Advertising Amazon's Next Big Growth Product?;2/7/2017;"In digital advertising there areFacebook(NASDAQ: FB) and Google
column2: and then there's everyone else. But one   company is starting to emerge as a potential contender to the two   ad behemoths:Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) is starting to spread its wings as an   advertiser.Amazon certainly has the user data to compete with Facebook or   the bigAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary. Although it has only   300 million active customers as of its last update
column3: the shopping   data it has on those users is invaluable. In fact
column4: Amazon may be   able to target advertisements better than Facebook or Google   despite their huge troves of user data. After all
column5: nothing speaks   louder than how people spend their money.Image source: Amazon.com.makeArticleAd();What's this other revenue line item
column6: and why's it growing so   quickly?During Amazon's fourth-quarter earnings call
column7: UBS analyst Eric   Sheridan asked about the ""other"" line item on Amazon's income   statement. He pointed out that it's exhibited a lot of momentum   over the past few years and wondered if that was due to growth in   advertising.The other category includes ""certain advertising services and   our co-branded credit card agreements
column8: according to Amazon's   quarterly report. While Amazon did just revamp its credit card   offering
column9: it's been around in some form in the U.S. since 2002   and in Canada since 2012. The vast majority of growth in the   category is probably coming from advertising.And it's been growing. Last year
column10: other revenue in North   America increased 60%. That accelerated to 81% growth in the   fourth quarter. That makes it Amazon's fastest growing source of   revenue
column11: growing even faster than its cloud-computing service
column12: Amazon Web Services.Granted
column13: the other revenue Amazon brings in accounted for just   1.7% of its total North American sales -- $1.3 billion. So it's   still working on a very small revenue base.Expanding its ad productsMost of the ads Amazon sells are on its own websites. Search   results on Amazon have an increasing number of sponsored   products
column14: with which third-party merchants pay to show up at the   top of the page
column15: not unlike Google's search advertising.   Management described sponsored products as ""off to a great   start
column16: indicating they see a lot of room for expansion.A report from BloomReach last fall found that 55% of online   shoppers begin their product search on Amazon.com. As more and   more people search Amazon for products
column17: the more ads it can show.   In fact
column18: sponsored products could start stealing ad budgets away   from Google
column19: which is whyEric Schmidt said it's Google's biggest   competitorin 2014.But Amazon's advertising is starting to extend beyond its own   websites
column20: wading deep into Google's territory. Last year it   developed a header-bidding solution. Header bidding allows   publishers to take more offers for their ad inventory instead of   wading through each offer one by one and taking the first decent   one they find. (This is all done extremely quickly by computer   algorithms.)Amazon's advantage in the space is that it can perform the   complex algorithmic ad bidding process in its AWS servers
column21: enabling publishers' websites to load faster than other   header-bidding systems allow. Google has historically dominated   the space that header bidding threatens.As mentioned
column22: Amazon is one of the few companies with user   data that can compete with the targeting capabilities of Facebook   or Google. So if it continues to build out its advertising   products on third-party websites
column23: it could start to take a   significant share of revenue from Google and Facebook. Google   generated $15.6 billion in revenue from its network members'   websites last year. Facebook's Audience Network reached a $1   billion run rate in the fourth quarter last year
column24: but the company   hasn't provided any updates since then.The digital ad market is huge. Advertisers spent $195 billion   worldwide on online ads last year
column25: according to eMarketer. That   number is expected to grow to $335 billion by 2020. If Amazon can   grab just a slice of the market producing high-margin revenue

column8: but   this is just one example of how e-commerce leader Amazon.com   defies convention. Amazon's profit growth is in many ways a   result of the company's well-worn tactic of running its business   as close to breakeven as possible. A small profit base makes this   kind of performance far easier. The company produced only $252   million in net income from sales of $22.3 billion in revenue in   its most recently reported quarter
column9: as the most recent   example.At the same time
column10: its impressive profit growth speaks to the   compelling nature of Amazon's long-term growth opportunity
column11: even   for a company well into its third decade of existence. As one of   the many data points to support this thesis
column12: researcher eMarketer   predicts that worldwide retail e-commerce sales will increase   from $1.9 trillion in $4.1 trillion by 2020. As arguably themost innovative companyin the space
column13: Amazon.com is well positioned to ride the   generational trend to continued growth for years to come.NetflixThe streaming-video giant has produced consistent
column14: albeit   highly variable
column15: GAAP profits in recent years. That figures to   change over the coming 12 months. Netflix has invested heavily to   launch its international streaming business
column16: and the results thus   far have been impressive
column17: to say the least. Better still
column18: the   inherent operating leverage in Netflix's streaming business model   should truly shine through in the coming quarters
column19: as its   international segment begins producing positive contribution   profits
column20: a proxy for operating profit. Specifically
column21: Netflix   expects to add 3.7 million net international subscribers in its   current quarter (Q1 2017)
column22: which should help bump its   international segment's contribution profit from a $67 million   loss in Q4 2016 to $16 million on the plus side in its current   quarter.The maturation of its international business appears largely   responsible for the company's EPS uptick this year; Netflix's   more mature U.S. operation is already highly profitable. This   trend also figures to continue into next year
column23: when analysts see   Netflix's EPS growing a further 82% year over year. That being   said
