column1: Fretting over Trump's Policies? 5 Safe Value Bets;2/7/2017;"Though the earnings season is at its peak
column2: President Donald Trump has been keeping investors busy elsewhere. Investors keenly await clarification on the timing and scope of Trump's business-friendly policies and how the administration will balance tax cuts and infrastructure outlays with protectionist trade policies. The President has also acted promptly on executive orders ranging from a temporary immigration ban to the withdrawal from landmark trade pacts.Investors
column3: in the meantime
column4: also assign greater risk premiums to European countries where anti-establishment movements are gaining traction ahead of elections. Amid such apprehensions
column5: it will be wise to invest in value stocks. Value investors look for times of uncertainty to pick stocks at a discount
column6: which are fundamentally stable.Travel Ban Triggers UncertaintyTrump banned immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries
column7: including legal residents and visa holders. This decision has drawn congressional criticism and widespread protests. These protectionist measures may also cloud the path for pro-business initiatives as several world and corporate leaders condemn the ban. German chancellor Angela Merkel said that it is ""not justified to put people from a specific background or faith under general suspicion""
column8: while French president Francois Hollande said that ""withdrawal into oneself is a dead-end response"".Airlines bore the brunt as well as several airports across the country saw violent protests
column9: disrupting operations to a great extent. Such an executive order on immigration
column10: widely known as the ""Muslim Ban""
column11: is being met with resistance by an increasing number of major tech firms.Tech giants Microsoft CorporationMSFTand Amazon.com
column12: Inc.AMZNhave taken legal action against the executive order as they face obstacles in sourcing labor from foreign lands. Tim Cook
column13: Apple Inc.'sAAPLCEO in an email sent to staff said that Trump's order ""is not a policy we support"". He added that ""diversity makes our team stronger"". In fact
column14: 97 tech giants including Alphabet IncGOOGL
column15: Facebook IncFBand Netflix
column16: Inc.NFLXfiled a joint legal brief in protest of Trump's immigration ban.Alphabet
column17: promptly
column18: created a $2 million crisis fund for four campaigning organizations such as American Civil Liberties Union
column19: Immigrant Legal Resource Center
column20: International Rescue Committee and UNHCR
column21: while Sundar Pichai its CEO said that ""it's painful to see the personal cost of this executive order on our colleagues"".Trade War Could Hit EconomyInvestors
column22: in the meanwhile
column23: may ignore Trump's trade rhetoric at their own peril. The administration's pledge to protect U.S. industries and redefine currency relationships could lead to a trade war with dire consequences
column24: eventually sparking a sell-off. In order to put ""America First""
column25: Trump may retreat from global trade sending exporter's currency plummeting
column26: curbing corporate revenues and destroying consumption.Trump has withdrawn the U.S. from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and is mulling over the imposition of a border tax on imports. The administration had accused China
column27: Mexico
column28: Germany and Japan of keeping their currencies weak to gain trade advantages
column29: which is irking even those who were bullish after the election.Caution Spreads Amid Geopolitical RisksWhile a highly polarized political environment and Trump's confrontational approach are expected to fuel volatility in the market
column30: investors are also preparing for political upheavals across Europe including French and German elections later this year.French Socialist Member of Parliament and supporters have started to break ranks with their party after the primary election win of leftwing presidential nominee Benoît Hamon
column31: offering support to independent candidate Emmanuel Macron. In Germany
column32: Martin Schulz is to run as the Social Democrat candidate for chancellor after Sigmar Gabriel turned down the chance to oppose Angela Merkel in parliamentary election.5 Top Value Stocks to Buy NowIn a sign of how large the President's policies loom over the market
column33: an analysis of FactSet data shows that one out of four companies were anxious about Trump's policies during their most recent earnings conference calls. Add to this more political disorder across Europe and we all know why investing in value stocks is judicious.Value investors look at uncertain times as opportunities to pick up financial sound stocks at a discount.  Such companies are well-established to do business even in the worst of times and are protected against market vagaries.Successful investors like Warren Buffett also recommend choosing stocks that are momentarily underpriced compared to the underlying value of the company

column1: Which Commercial Won the Super Bowl?;2/7/2017;"During last night's Super Bowl
column2: Netflix
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ: NFLX) released a 30-second teaser trailer for the highly   anticipated second season of its surprise summer hitStranger Things. With an estimated average cost of $5 million dollars for a   30-second commercial
column4: this was a big gamble for Netflix.   Advertisers tend to bring their A game
column5: but not everyone gets   their money's worth. Consumer reactions can be hard to   anticipate.Stranger Things season 2 trailer created the most buzz among     Super Bowl ads. Image source: Netflix
column6: Inc.makeArticleAd();And the winner is...It looks like Netflix strategy paid off. Based on data   obtained from marketing technology company Amobee
column7: Business   Insider is reporting that theStranger Thingsseason 2 trailer created the most buzz of any Super Bowl   commercial. The ad generated 307
column8: 000 tweets between 6:30 p.m. and   11:00 p.m. eastern time
column9: which corresponds with the time the game   aired. That was three times more tweets than the next company
column10: and the total was more than the next three combined. Its success   is being corroborated by Media Life Magazine
column11: which is reporting   that the trailer created 479.9 million social impressions
column12: the   most for of any ad.PlaceT-Mobile US
column13: Inc.(NASDAQ: TMUS)
column14: took the second spot
column15: with 91
column16: 700 tweets. This   was a much more expensive proposition for the company
column17: as it   bought more than three full minutes of ad time.Its advertisements   featured a variety of celebrities including Justin Bieber
column18: rapper   Snoop Dogg with home-making maven Martha Stewart
column19: and comedienne   Kristen Schaal
column20: all promoting its unlimited data plan. As the   number three carrier
column21: T-Mobile is keen to gain ground against   competitorsVerizonandAT&T.And showThe Procter & Gamble Company(NYSE: PG) made a surprise appearance in third place with 80

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Still Finding Growth;2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMicrosoft Corporation(NYSE:MSFT) used to be a one-trick
column3: maybe two-trick pony less than 10 years ago. My how things have changed.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Under founder Bill Gates
column4: DOS and then Windows operating systems were on virtually every computer that wasn't anApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) machine. And that dominance continued unabated until the dotcom bubble burst.It wasn't the ensuing crash that hurt
column5: it was the fact that tech had reached a point of inflection.From then on
column6: it wasn't just about owning a fiber-optic switching company with a triple-digit price-to-earnings ratio. One of the sayings from those heady times was
column7: if it doesn't have a triple digit P/E
column8: it's not worth buying.The crash meant the internet and tech itself was growing up. There was plenty of consolidation that happened after the dotcom crash. Some worked out
column9: some didn't. But it was necessary for companies that were going to survive to find a way to pivot into the new marketplace.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99It was also around that time that Microsoft was embroiled in a major antitrust case with the U.S. Government. This meant that MSFT had to change on many levels
column10: just to survive. It was crucial to find a way out of this
column11: because most of the government computers were running Windows
column12: and if Microsoft couldn't find a bright path through the case
column13: it may well lose a very lucrative long-term contract.By 2006
column14: Gates was out of day-to-day operations and his No. 2
column15: Steve Ballmer
column16: took over. While he started strong
column17: it wasn't long until it was apparent that doing the same thing a little differently was not going to cut it as technology was expanding rapidly and interconnections were popping among different tech fields.In 2014
column18: the current CEO
column19: Satya Nadella
column20: took the helm and began to completely reorganize the company
column21: shedding unprofitable and unwieldy divisions and focusing on the future of the company. That meant cleaning up the mess created by the acquisition of the mobile phone business ofNokiaand building a robust cloud-based business for both operating systems and for client storage.It certainly helped that he was previously head of MSFT R&D. But some were still skeptical of his approach
column22: especially in the early days
column23: when the new divisions weren't getting much traction and the established businesses were left wanting - remember Windows 8?Now three years into his role
column24: Nadella has gone from potential goat to real hero. And the most recent earnings number prove out his strategy. He has remained focused and disciplined
column25: and it has paid off.Microsoft has committed $1 billion into cybersecurity investment for its services as well as R&D. The company is reporting 600
column27: 000 attacks a week
column28: up from about 20
column29: 000 just three years ago. But it's not as much the threat as the opportunity. According to tech sitetechemergence.com
column30: there's an artificial intelligence-based cybersecurity market that will be worth $8.3 trillion market by 2035 in the U.S. alone.And given the fact that the U.S. government is one of MSFT stock's biggest clients
column31: security is crucial.Why GoPro Inc (GPRO) Stock Deserves More PatienceGoing hand in hand with this is the impressive growth of Azure
column32: Microsoft's cloud-based operating and storage system. Revenue growth year over year is running around 93% and Azure is getting big enough to compete with Amazon Web Services
column33: the cloud division ofAmazon.com
column34: Inc(NASDAQ:AMZN).Recent earnings were solid overall and there's no reason to think MSFT stock has seen its best days already. And while its 30 P/E may look expensive
column35: AMZN is trading at a P/E of 185. And MSFT also delivers a solid 2.4% dividend as well.Richard Band'sProfitable Investingadvisory service helps retirement savers outperform the market without losing a minute of sleep along the way. column1: Can Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Pass This Turing Test?;2/7/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFinancially and technically

column8: compared with 2015

column12: increasingly
column13: FB is winning.So why is Facebook stock sitting below its 2017 high? Why did it rise only 2% on those incredible earnings? Why does FB stock seem stuck in first gear?Call it the perils of leadership.Facebook Stock and Political OppositionFacebook has become a mirror on the human condition
column14: and civilization's ills have come calling on it.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialGangs are now waging theirturf warson the service. Its human decision-making is opaque
column15: and people are being destroyed by thatwithout recourse.Worse
column16: despite FB's insistence that it's not a media company
column17: and that it is not political in any way
column18: people are treating it as both.Many conservatives tied to the Trump Administrationnow count Facebook as an enemyandsuspect all those who work alongside it.This is happening even while FB goes to unprecedented lengths to fight terrorist propaganda
column19: working alongside law enforcement and security agencies.The truth or falsehood of the political charges should be irrelevant to an investor. What matters is that Facebook is seen to be a media company
column20: and seen to be a political actor
column21: that it's being treated as such
column22: and that responding to all this is expected to cost money
column23: reducing margins and net income.Fortunately
column24: FB stock has a way to fight back.FB Stock: A Turing TestFacebook stock is in a race against billions of people who want its network to pass a Turing Test. Its network must pretend to be human
column25: and to act humanely
column26: without using people to do it.Here are just some examples of what I'm talking about.FB must act againstfake news
column27: phishing profilescreated by criminals
column28: charges of political favoritism
column29: plus millions of individual complaints about the actions of third parties
column30: largeandsmall
column31: in an automated fashion.This is because software scales in ways people cannot. If Facebook mustgo to court constantlyin order to protect itself
column32: it can't continue to grow. It must automate its own self-policing
column33: as with a recent patent application aimed atfighting a photo-tag spambot.3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Is Much More Than Its Main PlatformAt the same time
column34: FB stock must fight charges that its software is becoming bloated
column35: denseand difficult to use.It must accept the increased complexity of video rights managementin this regard.It also must accept the fact thatmistakes will be made by softwareacting in human ways
column36: just as people make mistakes.Fortunately
column37: all I'm describing is a need for more artificial intelligence
column38: and that happens to be the area in software where Facebook is putting a lot of its money right now.The company's recent delivery of a system for identifying the content of photos
column39: andallowing them to be searched as text is searched
column40: is just the tip of the iceberg for what's ahead for Facebook stock.By fighting for its own survival with artificial intelligence
column41: FB stock is pointing the way to a futuredefined by artificial intelligence. This is less about creating an ""artificial assistant
column42: like Amazon's Alexa or Google Home
column43: both advertised during last week's Super Bowl
column44: and more about creating intelligence within the network so questions are answered before they are asked.If Facebook stock can succeed here
column45: it can overcome both its own problems and a lot of yours
column46: to mutual profit.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column2: Tiffany & Co. Needs a Comeback for the Ages;2/6/2017;"Shares of luxury jewelerTiffany & Co.TIFslumped all day Monday
column3: and closed the day down 2.45% to $78.49 per share after announcing that its CEO
column4: Frederic Cumenal
column5: was leaving the company
column6: effective immediately.Tiffany said Chairman and former CEO Michael Kowalski will serve as interim CEO
column7: and that the company's board of directors will begin the search for a successor with an executive search firm.""I am proud of what we have accomplished at Tiffany and would like to thank the management team and our many talented employees around the world with whom I have had the pleasure to work
column8: said Cumenal. ""I have great confidence in Tiffany's brand
column9: strategic direction and people
column10: and I believe the company will have many exciting opportunities in the future.""Cumenal had been with Tiffany since 2011
column11: moving quickly up the ranks at the jeweler and played a pivotal role in hiring design director Francesca Amfitheatrof
column12: who was responsible for Tiffany's modern
column13: popular ""T"" Collection. He was at French luxury conglomerate LVMH for 15 years before that
column14: holding many roles in the company's wine and spirits divisionSlowing SalesDespite its icon status
column15: Tiffany has been hard-pressed in recent years to remain an industry leader. You can place the blame on many things-changing markets in the U.S. and China
column16: the strengthening of the dollar
column17: the tightening of Chinese anti-corruption laws
column18: and the overall slowdown of the ""hard-luxury"" market
column19: i.e. diamonds-and each have contributed to slowing sales.The company's recent holiday quarter was particularly rough. For November and December combined
column20: worldwide net revenues were $966 million
column21: coming in above the $961 million reported a year ago. Worldwide comparable sales
column22: however
column23: declined 2%.In particular
column24: sales at Tiffany's Flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York declined a whopping 14% year-over-year. The store sits right next to Trump Tower
column25: and has been blocked in some way or form
column26: with large numbers of protesters gathered outside
column27: since the election of President Trump.A Carat-Sized ComebackA CEO departure never has the best timing for a company
column28: and Cumenal's abrupt leave casts a long shadow on not just its Super Bowl ad
column29: featuring none other than Lady Gaga
column30: but also one of its key holiday sales periods
column31: Valentine's Day. The ad introduces a new jewelry line that looks to be more edgy than Tiffany's typically classic pieces of jewelry.What Tiffany needs to do is to take a leap of faith like its new ad star did
column32: whose new albumJoanneand acclaimed Super Bowl Halftimeperformancehelped jumpstart a stagnating music career. Maybe that means embracing new types of customers like the LBGTQ community and single women
column33: who are
column34: more and more
column35: buying luxury jewelry for themselves. There's also huge demand for men's jewelry
column36: watches
column37: and accessories
column38: and while Tiffany does have a large selection of men's items
column39: the company could certainly offer more luxurious every day options.Tiffany would also see no harm in boosting its e-commerce presence
column40: since online sales as a percentage of overall revenue haven't grown in three years
column41: notesBloomberg. Maybe this means partnering with AmazonAMZNwith special deals on delivery during key holiday seasons like Thanksgiving-New Year's
column42: Valentine's Day
column43: Memorial Day
column44: Labor Day
column45: etc.If Tiffany continues to post little growth going forward
column46: investors shouldn't be surprised if more management turnover at the company comes as a result. But if they committ to some change

column1: Starbucks Says Its Biggest Problem Is Too Much Demand;2/6/2017;"Image source: Starbucks.A lot of people prefer to avoid any and all human contact   before getting their morning coffee
column2: and that's a problem forStarbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX) .makeArticleAd();Too many people are opting to use its mobile order and pay   system
column3: which allows customers to order ahead on their app and   pick up their coffee in store -- no need to talk to anyone.   Management says the influx of mobile orders resulted in too much   congestion in stores
column4: leading some walk-in customers to leave   before ordering. As a result
column5: same-store sales grew a   disappointing 3%. That's its lowest level since 2009.Well
column6: that escalated quicklyStarbucks just launched mobile order and pay during the first   fiscal quarter of 2015. It was seen as a way to relieve long   morning lines in stores. After rolling it out to every store in   the U.S. a year later
column7: soon-to-be-CEO Kevin Johnson boasted
column8: ""In   many of our busiest stores where morning peak demand is high
column9: mobile order and pay exceeds 10% of total transactions."" Just 13   stores saw 20% of orders during peak hours come from mobile order   and pay a year ago.By the fourth quarter of last year
column10: mobile order and pay   accounted for 20% of orders during peak times at 600 stores. That   doubled to 1
column11: 200 stores in the first quarter.Starbucks wasn't prepared for the sudden surge in mobile   ordering. Without best practices in place
column12: baristas were slowed   down by mobile orders while walk-ins lined up out the doors.   Meanwhile
column13: mobile orderers struggled to pick up their own orders   because of congestion at the handoff plane. ""This congestion   resulted in some number of customers who either entered the store   or considered visiting a Starbucks store and then did not   complete a transaction
column14: according to Johnson.Can Starbucks fix this?Management sounded very upbeat about the progress it's already   making tackling this issue during the earnings call. It's   implementing new tools and practices in the 1
column15: 000 stores with the   highest volume of mobile orders
column16: including new roles and   resources specifically for mobile order & pay and text   message alerts for when orders are ready.But Starbucks' fiscal 2017 guidance may give some investors   pause. Management lowered revenue growth guidance to 8-10% from   the 10% growth guidance it provided a quarter earlier. It   still expects same-store sales growth to pick up in the second   half of the year
column17: resulting in full-year same-store sales growth   in the mid-single-digits.If things don't start clearing up in the second quarter
column18: with   a path to completely fixing the problem by the third quarter
column19: investors may get worried.A good problem to haveWhen it comes down to it
column20: there are worse problems to have   than too many people wanting to order your product. Other   companies have experienced similar problems and managed to make   the most of them.For example
column21: Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) experienced a huge increase in the number of   businesses utilizing its Fulfilled by Amazon program in the   fourth quarter of 2015. That resulted in significant pressure on   operating margin expansion as Amazon's warehouses were filled to   the gills and fulfillment costs ballooned.Amazon prepared for a similar surge this year by asking   merchants to hold back inventory they didn't expect to sell until   the first quarter while continuing to build out its fulfillment   center network. The stock price and the company's margin growth   continued to improve throughout 2016.Indeed
column22: the decline in Starbucks' stock price could present a   buying opportunity for investors who believe in management's   ability to solve problems like it's experiencing. They were all   keen to point out they've solved similar problems before
column23: and   there's no reason to doubt they can solve another high-quality   problem yet again.Find out why Starbucksis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more     than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column1: 3 Signs Netflix Inc.'s Best Days Are Ahead;2/6/2017;"Netflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) just closed the books on a record fiscal year that   added 19 million streaming members to its rolls. Yet with growth   slowing in its core U.S. market
column2: and with no new geographies left   to conquer (except for China)
column3: some investors are concerned that   there's little room to add to its near 100 million subscribers --   and $61 billion market capitalization.Below
column4: I'll highlight a few of the biggest factors that   suggest those worries are overblown.Pricing powerNetflix's fourth-quarter subscriber growth figuresblew away expectationsas 7 million people signed up for it service compared to the 5   million that CEO Reed Hastings and his team had forecast. That   outperformance allowed the company to post another year of   accelerating global gains: Net additions were 19 million in 2016
column5: up from 17.3 million in the prior year.makeArticleAd();Annual subscriber gains. Chart by author.The raw growth story would be impressive enough on its own
column6: but Netflix also demonstrated strong pricing power in this   report. A big chunk of the U.S. member base was pushed onto   higher-priced plans last quarter
column7: which prompted users with a   good reason to cancel. Instead
column8: not only did most members stick   around
column9: but there's evidence that many customers who recently   bolted over the price increases decided to come back.In other words
column10: TV fans are finding that Netflix's value   proposition is compelling
column11: even at the higher pricing point that   has pushed average monthly spending up 15% and allowed   profitability to jump to almost 40% of sales in the core U.S.   market.International growthIn early 2016
column12: the company sped up its global expansion plan   by simultaneously launching in nearly all the markets it wanted   to enter. There's nothing approaching that type of event in the   future
column13: and so international subscriber growth is likely to trend   lower over the short term. Next quarter
column14: for example
column15: Netflix is   forecasting 3.7 million new users
column16: compared to 4.5 million   additions in the prior-year period.Image source: Netflix.The global growth story stretches out far longer than just a   single year
column17: though. Almost 20 quarters after launching in Latin   America
column18: Netflix is finally getting up to speed in that market
column19: and there's every reason to expect a comparable learning curve in   other areas as it tweaks the service and builds brand   strength.The company sees a huge long-term opportunity in Japan
column20: too
column21: but the biggest payoff there will come once the company is more   established and has compiled a deep enough portfolio of local   content. It won't be as dramatic asgoing live in 130 countries at once
column22: but Netflix has a huge runway for international growth   ahead.Scale advantagesHastings and his team have been prioritizing subscriber growth   over earnings for the last several years. The thinking behind   that strategy was that Netflix first needed to establish global   scale to block out rivals. Only then would it use its dominant   position to extract meaningful profits for investors.We're finally entering the second part of that master plan --   and investors must be pleased. Netflix is finding that original   shows and movies travel well across borders
column23: which is giving it a   key advantage in the bidding war for content against streaming   studios that have to piece together rights on a region-by-region   basis. The efficiencies are a key reason why it plans to scale   back on marketing spending while doubling operating profitability   this year.Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) is no longer in that regional category
column24: having   recently matched Netflix in global availability. But few other   streaming specialists can hope to even approach the$8 billion in spending($6 billion on content alone) that Netflix will shell out on its   service this year. And at some point
column25: the online retailing titan   might even balk at the expense of keeping pace with the streaming   specialist.A full decade has passed since Netflix tiptoed into streaming   video in what Hastings predicted would be the company's second   act after dominating DVD rental. Yet its surging growth over the   last 12 months looks more like the beginning of that new chapter   than its conclusion.Find out why Netflixis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. column1: Charles Schwab To Cut Mutual Fund Expenses
column2: Fuels Discount Brokerage Pricing War;2/6/2017;"Charles SchwabSCHWis slicing prices on their mutual fund expenses. Although great for persons who invest with them
column3: stockholders are wary with the new move on speculation of reduced revenue. The company is trading down 1.34% to $39.62
column4: intraday.On February 2nd
column5: Charles Schwab announced they will be lowering expenses on their market-cap weighted index mutual funds. This is to equate them with their respective Schwab ETFs
column6: which already offer some of the lowest expenses in the industry. Expenses will be as follows: 0.03% on Schwab S&P 500 Index FundSWPPX
column7: 0.06% on Schwab Small-Cap Index FundSWSSX
column8: and 0.04% on Schwab U.S. Aggregate Bond Index Fund.Additionally
column9: the company is taking away investment minimums to be in these funds; a single share class will be utilized to make this move. Their top competitors such as Vanguard and Fidelity charge up to 4 times more in expenses and require a $5
column10: 000 minimum to invest in their funds.In addition to cutting expenses on mutual funds
column11: trading commissions on stock and ETFs will also be reduced. Standard online stock and ETF trade commissions will drop by $2 to $6.95 per trade. This makes them lowest to their competitorsTD AmeritradeAMTDand E-TradeETFCwho charge $9.99.Along with the move
column12: Charles Schwab is adopting a satisfaction guarantee policy. If a client is not satisfied with their services then the company will refund any transaction fees
column13: advisory program fees
column14: and commissions fees that were charged.The company announced that they estimate a loss of $15 million a month in revenue due to the new fee structure; less than 11% of their revenue comes from trading. It is important to note that Charles Schwab does not rely as heavily on trade commissions and expenses as its competitors.A Discount Brokerage Price WarCharles Schwab is shaking the discount brokerage industry by cutting their expenses. On the event of the news
column15: TD Ameritrade and E-Trade took a hit of about 10%. Price cutting wars are nothing new in the discount brokerage industry. Brokerages for years now have been slashing prices in hopes of acquiring new investors.On the other hand
column16: Kim Hillyer of TD Ameritrade seems to think that price points are not the only competitive advantage a brokerage can have. On event of Charles Schwab's news she wrote
column17: ""…what you're seeing today is one company's interpretation of what 'value' looks like"". She went on to say TD Ameritrade's focus is on what their customers want which is
column18: ""outstanding trading platforms

column21: education

column24: straightforward price point"".Charles Schwab is adapting a pricing model which parallels that of Amazon'sAMZNAmazon Prime. Low prices

column1: Does Netflix Need Innovative Tools To Increase Viewership?;2/6/2017;"Netflix (NFLX) has had a spectacular Q4 2016 with its international subscriber base increasing rapidly and margins from this segment showing strong signs of improvement. In the domestic segment
column2: despite competition from several existing and new players
column3: Netflix was able to add 1.93 million members in Q4 2016
column4: exceeding its forecast of 1.45 million. While this growth is likely to slow down in the future as the market matures
column5: we expect Netflix to continue to add subscribers in the domestic market over our forecast period.Netflix's focus on original programming is likely to be the key driving factor for domestic subscriber retention and growth. Also contributing is its strong content library
column6: which increases binge watching. The company is investing heavily in original programming  In fact
column7: it has a $6 billion content budget for 2017
column8: which makes it one of the biggest media spenders on content.  It is also looking at innovative ways to make binge watching easier. At one of its recent ""hack day"" events
column9: Netflix engineers devised a way by which viewers can scroll and playvideos through a headband. Using a modified Muse device - a headband that is intended to help with meditation - users can nod to select shows or movies and think ""play"" in order to get the title to start. The device
column10: called MindFlix
column11: works by reading brain activity and using the readings to perform predetermined functions. While this device is not currently available for consumers and the company has not confirmed any launch date
column12: it indicates that Netflix is looking at innovative tools which will make binge watching easier. Last year the company came up with innovative socks which switch off Netflix if the viewer falls asleep during a binge watching session.  While these tools can intrigue viewers
column13: high quality original content will be the key for Netflix's subscriber growth. The company is investing in technology initiatives to identify areas which can make the customer experience better. Still
column14: the two key areas of focus for Netflix should be content creation and the optimization of bandwidth usage. Conveniences such as scrolling and playing videos without using any device or auto switch off are not likely to drive significant subscriber growth.makeArticleAd();Netflix is investing heavily on original programming and this is showing results in terms of subscriber growth. While its international expansion continues at a rapid pace the company is likely to face challenges as it expands into various geographies
column15: such as low internet speeds and consumers' preference for local content. In the U.S.
column16: as the threat of limiting data usage by broadband players looms
column17: Netflix can be impacted if consumers need to pay more to view its content with better streaming quality. We believe innovation to provide high quality streaming at lower bandwidth consumption will be critical for Netflix's growth in the long term. While its ""hack days"" might come up with interesting innovative tools to promote binge watching
column18: we believe focus on content and optimization of bandwidth usage are the two key areas for Netflix's long term growth.View Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis Research"

column1: Wal-Mart Tried to Take on Amazon Prime and Failed;2/6/2017;"Image source: Wal-Mart.Wal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) doesn't think it makes sense to charge its online   customers for two-day shipping anymore. The retailer is shutting   down its year-and-a-half old ShippingPass program
column2: a $50-per-year   two-day shipping service similar toAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) Prime. ""In today's world of e-commerce
column3: two-day   free shipping is table stakes
column4: Marc Lore
column5: head of Wal-Mart U.S.   e-commerce wrote in an announcement.makeArticleAd();Wal-Mart is trying to spin the move as a positive
column6: but it's   simply masking the fact that it tried to take on Amazon Prime and   failed. Prime is one of the three pillars of Amazon
column7: and its   membership drives astounding loyalty. Wal-Mart was looking for a   similar effect with ShippingPass. Instead
column8: it's moving down   market
column9: reducing the threshold for free shipping to $35 from $49
column10: and promising to get some 2 million items to customers in just a   couple days.Wal-Mart can't competeBoth Amazon and Wal-Mart boast huge marketplaces that bring   together thousands of merchants on their online platforms. But   where Wal-Mart falls short is that it's heavily reliant on its   third-party merchants to fulfill online orders themselves. In   fact
column11: just 2 million items qualify for two-day shipping.By comparison
column12: Amazon's marketplace has over 50 million   Prime-eligible items. That's thanks to its Fulfilled by Amazon   service where merchants send inventory to Amazon's warehouses
column13: and Amazon handles shipping individual items to customers.In other words
column14: Wal-Mart's two-day shipping service was   half-baked compared to Amazon's. Customers who signed up for the   free trial were likely disappointed at the lack of product   selection
column15: and didn't pay up for the service.Wal-Mart won't tear customers away from PrimeBy offering free two-day shipping to everyone
column16: Wal-Mart isn't   trying to get Prime members to ditch Amazon (at least it   shouldn't be). Instead
column17: its strategy seems to be to prevent   customers from ever signing up for it in the first place. Prime   members are extremely loyal and have an extremely lowchurn rate
column18: so that's about the best Wal-Mart can hope for.It's a bit late to the game
column19: however
column20: considering Amazon has   already signed up around half of the households in the U.S. In   the last year alone
column21: Amazon added ""tens of millions"" of new   members.If Wal-Mart stands any chance of competing with Amazon
column22: it   needs toleverage its physical stores. That's exactly what its new shipping program does. Items   qualifying for two-day shipping are usually available in local   stores already
column23: meaning Wal-Mart only needs to ship it the last   mile to a shoppers home.While free two-day shipping for everyone may win Wal-Mart a   few one-off purchases
column24: it won't cut into the loyal and growing   Amazon Prime customer base. The best it can hope for is to   establish its online portals as top of mind for online shoppers.   That's one of the biggest hurdles for Wal-Mart or any online   retailer to overcome.Amazon currently dominates mindshare. Fifty-five percent of   online product searches start on its website
column25: according to a   survey from BloomReach last Fall. If Wal-Mart's new shipping   policy can help it grab some of those product searches
column26: it ought   to be considered a win even if its attempt to take on Amazon   Prime failed.10 stocks we like better than Wal-Mart StoresWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column27: it can pay to listen. After all
column28: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column29: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column30: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Wal-Mart Stores wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column5: IL - February 06
column6: 2017 -Zacks Equity ResearchhighlightsAlibaba Group Holdings(NYSE:BABA-Free Report) as the Bull of the Day andAmazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) as the Bear of the Day. In addition
column7: Zacks Equity Research provides analysis onRaymond James(NYSE:RJF-Free Report)
column8: Sandvik AB(OTCMKTS:SDVKY-Free Report) andStora Enso Oyi(OTCMKTS:SEOAY-Free Report).Here is a synopsis of all five stocks:Bull of the Day:Alibaba Group Holdings(NYSE:BABA-Free Report)reported strong December quarter numbers on January 24 with top and bottom line beats and a whopping 54% year-over-year growth in sales.Wall Street analysts liked that growth and the outlook going forward enough to raise estimates 23% for the current fiscal year (ending in March) from $2.15 to $2.65. And the next fiscal year also moves up 23% from $2.56 to $3.16.Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang highlighted ""We are driving the age of 'New Retail
column9: ' which leverages big data and innovation to provide a seamless online and offline experience for nearly half a billion mobile monthly active users. This retail transformation will make it even easier and more efficient for brands and retailers to engage with these consumers anywhere
column10: anytime.""After the conference call
column11: my colleague Ryan McQueeney explained ""Alibaba further detailed its 'New Retail' concept
column12: saying that it will help the company tap into the entirety of China's $4.8 trillion retail sector by breaking down the distinction between online and offline commerce. To that end
column13: Alibaba has started partnering with several different brick-and-mortar retailers.Bear of the Day:The good news in theAmazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)quarterly report was a 10% earnings beat and year-over-year revenue growth that was still very enviable with +24% overall and +47% for AWS (Amazon Web Services).The bad news in the report was that even these terrific sales numbers were below Wall Street expectations.And the guidance for the current quarter doesn't get any more optimistic. That's why the stock was down 3.5% on Friday -- on more than 2.5X the normal volume -- and why it will probably trade under $800 as many analysts lower their earnings estimates and price targets.Zacks Rank Strikes AgainBut the stock was already in the cellar of the Zacks Rank going into the report because analysts were busy lowering estimates in the past few weeks.30 days ago
column14: the full year EPS projection for 2017 was $9.19. By late last week
column15: even before we heard from the company on February 2
column16: that profit picture had dropped to $8.88.You can expect that consensus to drop further as all the estimates filter in this week to the Zacks Rank.And 2018 estimates had already taken a bigger hit in the last month prior to Thursday's report
column17: dropping roughly a dollar from the $14.98 consensus a few weeks ago.Expect those projections to probably get reeled in a little further too.Additional content:Animal Spirits or… a Bubble?Note: This is an excerpt from Zacks Chief Strategist John   Blank's fullMarket Strategy report. column1: Zacks Investment Ideas feature highlights: Amazon
column2: Charles Schwab
column3: Schwab S&P 500 Index Fund
column4: Schwab Small-Cap Index Fund and Schwab U.S. TIPS;2/6/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - February 06
column6: 2017 - Today
column7: Zacks Investment Ideas feature highlights Features:Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column8: Charles Schwab(NYSE:SCHW-Free Report)
column9: Schwab S&P 500 Index Fund(MUTF:SWPPX-Free Report)
column10: Schwab Small-Cap Index Fund(MUTF:SWSSX-Free Report) andSchwab U.S. TIPS ETF(NYSEARCA:SCHP-Free Report).How Charles Schwab Is Becoming the Amazon of InvestingAmazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report) has become a behemoth in the retail world.Sure
column11: the company's most recent earnings report may have left a bit to be desired
column12: but there is no denying how far Amazon has come in a few short years. The company easily dominates the consumer world
column13: and it has left a variety of big-box retailers in its wake in the process.While we can point to a number of reasons for Amazon's ascent
column14: a key to their rise is clearly Amazon Prime. This subscription service-which costs $99/year-gives users free two day shipping
column15: video content
column16: music
column17: and a number of other features as well. The deal is so good that some estimateclose to half of the country's households have a Prime account
column18: with plenty of new subscribers now being added in foreign nations too.What is the point of this? Well
column19: Prime members (at least in the U.S.)spend roughly twice as muchas non-Prime users on Amazon
column20: while the service has an insane renewal rate in the United States
column21: over 90% accordingto the Consumer Intelligence Research Partners
column22: so people are clearly seeing the value.But with so many services and offerings in the Prime package
column23: how does Amazon make any money? Well
column24: the idea is clearly to suck people in to the Amazon ecosystem via Prime
column25: and then keep them there for years. And with such a high renewal rate and spending that is double non-Prime users
column26: it is clearly paying off. One only needs to look at the demise of other retailers in a number of areas to understand just how much Amazon is dominating the consumer world these days.So
column27: the strategy is to give people an offer that is too good to refuse in order to get them in the door and looking at higher margin products later on. AsJeff Bezos said
column28: Prime is 'such a good value
column29: you'd be irresponsible not to be a member'.The Amazon of Investing?We can see how Amazon has changed the world of retail and the consumer market
column30: but is anyone doing the same thing for investing?I'd argue that Charles Schwab (NYSE:SCHW-Free Report) is adopting this 'Amazon model' in the world of investing
column31: and this is especially evident after their recent move.Their latest announcementbrought fees down to $6.95/trade from their previous spot at $8.95/trade
column32: while Schwab also announced a fee cut on some of its broad market mutual funds
column33: and that mutual fund costs would match their ETF counterparts too.The company will now charge 0.03% for its Schwab S&P 500 Index Fund (MUTF:SWPPX-Free Report)
column34: while the Schwab Small-Cap Index Fund (MUTF:SWSSX-Free Report) will cost 0.06% per year. Additionally
column35: the company also reduced fees for its Schwab U.S. Aggregate Bond Index Fund down to 0.04% (which comes out later in February) to become an ultra-cheap choice in that market too. They also discussed the idea of reducing fees for the Schwab U.S. TIPS ETF (NYSEARCA:SCHP-Free Report) and their fundamental index ETFs
column36: but those changes will take place on March first.These cuts put Schwab's fees down to levels below its major competitors
column37: Fidelity
column38: E*Trade andTD Ameritrade
column39: and it sent shockwaves throughout the industry. Share prices of ETFC and AMTD were down nearly 10% immediately following the announcement
column40: while SCHW took a hit as well.I understand why the group was hit in the markets following the press release
column41: as it definitely kicks off worries over a price war. And as for Charles Schwab
column42: charging such rock bottom levels all but guarantees that Charles Schwab will lose money on its fund business
column43: and it will probably see less revenues from its commissions in the process too.So Why Is This Like Amazon?To me
column44: this is very reminiscent of the Amazon Prime service. You give people a ton of low cost options that are bound to please a wide range of people. So
column45: instead of two day shipping and free video content
column46: if you are in the investing world
column47: you offer up fees that are less than major peers and nearly-free ETFs and mutual funds.The move gets plenty of people in the door
column48: and it keeps them inside the ecosystem. Once you switch to Schwab for the low fees and start putting money in their ETFs and mutual funds
column49: it becomes difficult to justify switching back. This is exactly like how you get used to the two-day shipping
column50: music
column51: Pantry
column52: and other features from Amazon
column53: keeping you stuck in the system. Charles Schwab
column54: much like Amazon
column55: realizes that winning over new customers is a vital part of this business
column56: and that providing them low cost products is essential to keeping customers happy and away from the competition over the long-term.And once you have enough customers that you sucked in through the low price options
column57: you now have the ability to earn money off them in different ways. Amazon does this with a variety of their media products and retail options in general (such as Pantry)
column58: though there are obviously some key differences between the retail and investing worlds.Schwab can do something similar to Amazon's approach nonetheless though. Bring people in for low cost index products and cheap trades
column59: and then make the real profits off high margin activities that Amazon can only dream of. These include
column60: investment management
column61: servicing fees
column62: and most importantly
column63: investing the float.This last item will prove to be key for Schwab and other brokers
column64: and especially if rates rise as most are expecting. For 2016
column65: interest income accounted for roughly 44% of Schwab's net revenues
column66: and that was in a year with mostly low-rates. Considering that trading revenue makes up about 11% of the total revenue (looking at 2016)
column67: and it is pretty reasonable to think that Schwab will be alright in the long term with a modest fee cut.I think that Schwab sees the same thing with the writing on the wall for a low rate environment. They are willing to sacrifice a bit in trading revenue now in order to get new users on the platform and get access to their potential asset base and the investable float that comes along with it. And if rates rise as most are expecting
column68: this could prove to pay off
column69: and especially considering that interest makes up a plurality of revenue already
column70: and that is with rates at ultra-low levels.So
column71: while Schwab might be down on this news now
column72: it is a brilliant strategy in order to get more clients and capital in the door over the long haul. It is this type of forward thinking that has propelled Amazon to greatness in the consumer market
column73: and it is about time someone tried this in the investing world as well.Want key ETF info delivered straight to your   inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis
column74: as well as top-performing ETFs
column75: each week.Get it free >>FollowBrian Bolanon Twitter@BBolan1Want more articles from this author? column2: Apple Inc. (AAPL) and Visa Inc (V);2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsU.S. stock futures are mixed this morning
column4: as last week's earnings and jobs euphoria has failed to carry over into premarket action this morning. Furthermore
column5: Wall Street is wary ahead of key economic data from the White House
column6: as President Trump is s required to submit a preliminary budget proposal to Congress on the first Monday of February. Investors are waiting to see just how Trump's campaign promises for massive infrastructure spending and tax cuts will take shape.makeArticleAd();Against this backdrop
column7: futures on theDow Jones Industrial Averageare down 0.21%
column8: whileS&P 500futures are off 0.23% and theNasdaq-100futures are down 0.22%.On the options front
column9: 3 Feb. options expiration drove heavy volume on Friday
column10: as a wealth of earnings speculation finally came to a head. On the day
column11: some 18.6 million calls and 14.7 million puts changed hands. Over on the CBOE
column12: the single-session equity put/call volume ratio ticked higher to 0.68 while the 10-day moving average held at a three-month high of 0.69.Turning to Friday's volume leaders
column13: Bank of America Corp(NYSE:BAC) attracted a surge in call activity ahead of President Donald Trump's executive order aimed at rolling back financial regulations - setting the stage for the repeal of the Dodd-Frank Act. Elsewhere
column14: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) calls were also wildly popular after new broke that the company would begin assembling iPhones in India by the end of April. Finally
column15: Visa Inc(NYSE:V) jumped more than 4.5% after posting better-than-expected quarterly earnings.Bank of America Corp (BAC)Months of speculation came to an end on Friday
column16: whenPresident Trump took steps to roll back regulationson the financial industry - setting the stage for banks like Bank of America to begin unrestricted share buybacks and dividend increases. What's more
column17: financial industry analysts believe that if regulation rollbacks are on the table for banks
column18: then corporate tax cuts can't be far behind
column19: as they were also among Trump's campaign promises.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99BAC stock has been itching for such news for weeks now
column20: with investors banking on deregulation and the possibility of increased dividends given BofA's strong performance in 2016. As a result
column21: BAC options traders flooded the stock with calls on Friday
column22: with these typically bullish bets making up 77% of the 1.3 million contracts traded.Taking a broader look at short-term BAC speculation
column23: the February/March put/call open interest ratio has plunged in recent weeks to a perch at 0.50
column24: with calls doubling puts among contracts set to expire within the next two months. Currently
column25: the most popular strike is the March $25 call
column26: where more than 174
column27: 000 contracts reside. This strike rests about 7.3% out of the money and last traded at an ask price of 20 cents
column28: or $20 per contract.Apple Inc. (AAPL)According to news on Friday
column29: Apple has finally broken through into India's massive mobile market. Apple will startmaking iPhones in India by the end of April
column30: with Taiwan'sWistron Corp.assembling the phones in Bangalore
column31: said Priyank Kharge
column32: the state's information technology minister. Apple had requested a contentious 15-year tax holiday to import components and equipment
column33: but ministry officials refused to comment on any incentives in the deal.Call option volume on AAPL stock surged to well above normal levels following the news. Overall
column34: some 1.03 million contracts traded on Apple
column35: with calls gobbling up 71% of the day's take.That said
column36: there is still plenty of room for additional call activity on AAPL
column37: with the stock's February/March put/call OI ratio arriving at 0.85
column38: with the March $125 arriving as the most popular calls strike with more than 81
column39: 000 calls in residence. This reading has begun to drift lower during the past week
column40: and Friday's India news should help spur additional call activity this week.Visa Inc (V)Visa is ""everywhere investors should want to be
column41: Cowen and Company told investorsafter the former's strong quarterly earnings report. After the close on Thursday
column42: Visa posted first-quarter earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $4.5 billion
column43: easily topping estimates for 78 cents per share on sales of $4.3 billion. Visa also lifted its 2017 earnings outlook.Bank of America Corp (BAC) Stock Will Test Your PatienceFollowing the report
column44: V stock jumped roughly 4.6% to trade at a fresh all-time high just shy of $86 per share. Options traders signaled they expected additional gains from V stock
column45: as volume rose to 223
column46: 000 contracts with calls snapping up 77% of the day's take. Calls have begun to add up for V stock
column47: with the February/March put/call OI ratio falling to a reading of 0.66 on Friday.That said

column49: where peak call OI of 13
column50: 000 contracts rests at the in-the-money $80 strike. Look for V options traders to roll these calls higher if the stock can maintain Friday's momentum.As of this writing

column1: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Prime Air Drones Surprise in Super Bowl Ad;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you were one of the estimated 100 million+ viewers of Super Bowl 51
column4: you saw some drones. There were the 200 quadcopters fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) that were part of Lady Gaga's halftime show. Those we were expecting
column5: but another drone that showed up was a surprise.Amazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) chose the Super Bowl to tease Amazon Prime Air - packages delivered to your home by AMZN drones.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonA big part of the Super Bowl experience is the advertising. This is the one time of year when viewers actuallywantto see commercials. And with those viewersestimated at over 100 million
column7: companies that forked out over $5 million for a 30-second spot make a big splash.Heck
column8: even in Canada
column9: the networks wereforced to run American adsinstead of substituting local commercials.And those 100 million-plus viewers saw a very short teaser commercial with anAmazon drone hoveringoutside the window of a woman who had just ordered some snacks: Amazon Prime Air.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAccording to the voice of Alexa
column10: AMZN's personal digital assistant
column11: we can ""Look for delivery soon.""History of Amazon Prime AirHow can you talk about the history of a service that doesn't yet exist? In the case of Amazon Prime Air and its use of Amazon drones
column12: there's already a big backstory to talk about. AMZNhas a websitewhere it describes the services
column13: shows off a number of Amazon drone videos and even has an FAQ section that spikes out many of the details about Amazon Prime Air.""We're excited about Prime Air - a delivery system from Amazon designed to safely get packages to customers in 30 minutes or less using unmanned aerial vehicles
column14: also called drones. Prime Air has great potential to enhance the services we already provide to millions of customers by providing rapid parcel delivery that will also increase the overall safety and efficiency of the transportation system.""The Amazon Prime Air storykicked off in 2013
column15: when AMZN CEO Jeff Bezos took the wraps off a top secret project with Amazon drones on60 Minutes. Delivery of items under five pounds that would fit in the quadcopter's bucket would take place in under 30 minutes. At the time
column16: Bezos told viewers to expect Amazon Prime Air within four to five years.Last December
column17: a milestone was reached when AMZN claimedthe first Amazon drone delivery- an Amazon Fire TV and a bag of popcorn. As part of an Amazon Prime Air trial in the U.K.
column18: the company's drones had begun autonomously delivering packages to a very small group of consumers.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!At the end of the year
column19: the company hit the news again when it was discovered it hadfiled a patent for a flying warehousethat would serve as an airborne base for Amazon drone deliveries.When Can You Expect an Amazon Drone atYourWindow?Despite the Super Bowl ad and Alexa's promise that Amazon Prime Air is coming soon
column20: it's a little early to get excited yet. In particular
column21: there are regulatory hurdles to overcome. FAA restrictions on drones that aren't flying in line-of-site operation were the primary reason why the Amazon drone trial is taking place in the U.K. instead of here. AMZN even put up a small disclaimer on its ad:""Prime Air is not available in some states (or any really). Yet.""But the fact that it spent the big Super Bowl ad bucks and showed off that Amazon drone to millions of viewers shows AMZN is serious about this. Amazon Prime Air may not be launching tomorrow
column22: but the company is determined to get people excited about drone delivery. The campaign to turn Amazon drone delivery into the next big thing has officially begun.As of this writing
column23: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceIs Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) Ending the Age of Intel (INTC)?Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postAmazon.com

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Still Relies on Office and Windows;2/6/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere is a newfound sense of optimism towardMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column3: and MSFT stock. Microsoft stock touched an all-time high over $65 last week after the company's fiscal second-quarter earnings report. Yet
column4: earnings haven't really budged the last five years
column5: as lower PC sales have pressured Microsoft revenue from its legacy Windows and Office products.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart Via FlickrOf late
column6: however
column7: Microsoft has shown growth in newer products. The Surface product line and cloud computing
column8: led by the Azure platform
column9: are posting impressive growth rates. And
column10: Surface and Azure are driving much of the optimism that has led MSFT stock to increase nearly 150% in a little over four years.But
column11: lost in that optimism toward MSFT seems to be the fact that most of Microsoft's business is relatively unchanged from what it was three to four years ago - if not worse. Windows is a declining platform. There are multiple competitors trying to take down Office
column12: and the cloud shift is cannibalizing some of Microsoft's SQL Server business.So
column13: while there's a reason to see growth coming from Microsoft's new opportunities
column14: investors in Microsoft stock need to remember that most of the business isn't nearly as attractive.Azure and Surface Are Driving Microsoft Stock HigherThere is reason for optimism toward Azure and Surface. The Surface line garners rave reviews
column15: and sales have been strong. Microsoft has an impressive opportunity to drive commercial sales
column16: with the company calling out a major contract with the U.K. Customs Service on its Q2 conference call.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryGrowth in Azure has been even more impressive. Revenue increased 93% in the second quarter and 104% in the first half of FY17. Microsoft remains well behindAmazon.com
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) and its Amazon Web Services business. But
column18: it has a clear opportunity to get to at least second place in what should be a large
column19: fast-growing end market. That portends years of growth in Azure
column20: a potential driver for MSFT stock.At the same time
column21: however
column22: Microsoft is a huge company
column23: with trailing twelve-month revenue over $85 billion. And
column24: neither Azure nor Surface represents a significant portion of those overall sales. Microsoft still doesn't break out Azure sales
column25: but estimates suggest roughly $3 billion in fiscal 2017 - less than 4% of overall revenue.Per the MSFT 10-K
column26: Surface sales were about $4.2 billion in fiscal 2016
column27: and those sales actually declined 2% year over year in the second quarter. Some of that weakness came from the company's phasing out of Surface 3
column28: and gross margins have improved. But
column29: Azure and Surface combined are still less than 10% of total revenue. Even adding cloud computing as a whole
column30: the figure barely gets to one-quarter next year
column31: as MSFT is targeting a $20 billion run rate for commercial cloud.Simple math shows that it's tough for Microsoft to grow as a whole if only a small portion of revenue is driving that growth. Indeed
column32: that's been the case this year. Overall revenue grew just 1.2% in the second quarter
column33: and 0.8% for the first half. Excluding phone sales - where Microsoft has all but has exited the business - top-line growth was still under 5% in Q2 and Q1.Yet MSFT stock now is priced as a growth stock. That might be aggressive.MSFT Earnings Still Rely on Office and WindowsThe problem for MSFT stock is that so much of Microsoft's business still comes from its better-known products. The More Personal Computing segment generated nearly 50% of first half sales. That includes Windows revenue - which was almost 20% of FY16 sales - along with Xbox
column34: Search
column35: and devices (including Surface).Surface aside
column36: that's not a particularly attractive group. Windows revenue seems likely to decline over the long term and has declined in each of the last two fiscal years. Bing has performed well of late
column37: but in part because Microsoft has spent up to attract traffic. The Productivity and Business Processes segment is almost one-third of sales. Prior to Microsoft's acquisition ofLinkedIn Corp
column38: it consisted primarily of Office and Dynamics
column39: MSFT's CRM solution.First-half growth has been impressive
column40: growing about 7%
column41: excluding the contribution from LinkedIn. But
column42: that comes after revenue in the segment declined between FY14 and FY16. While Office 365 sales growth looks solid
column43: much of that growth is simply coming from a shift to ""on-premise"" Office licenses.Bottom Line on Microsoft StockThere are two concerns about the long-term growth prospects of Microsoft stock. The first is that some of the recent headline growth in categories such as cloud and office is simply coming from existing products. Some Azure sales are coming from customers switching away from Microsoft SQL Server. Office 365 sales aren't going to new customers who didn't have word processing software; rather
column44: most subscribers are former users of disk-based Office products.A Trade War With China Puts These Stocks at RiskThe second concern is that so much of the business is stagnant (though bulls might say ""stable"" instead). That makes overall growth tough: if 20% of the business grows 20%
column45: and the rest is flat or declining
column46: overall growth rates stay in the 4% range.With MSFT stock steadily appreciated due almost solely to multiple appreciation
column47: rather than earnings growth
column48: investors are clearly expecting sales to pick up. But
column49: it's important to remember that Azure and Surface won't be able to drive that acceleration on their own.As of this writing
column50: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the Market5 Safe Dividend Stocks to Buy for RetirementThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Still Relies on Office and Windowsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Will Facebook Challenge Netflix and Amazon Via Set Top Boxes?;2/5/2017;"Facebook(NASDAQ: FB) is reportedly developing a dedicated video app for   set top boxes to  expand its social networking ecosystem   into living rooms
column2: according to theWall Street Journal. The app will be different from its existing app for set top   boxes
column3: which is basically just a widescreen version of its mobile   app.Image source: Facebook.makeArticleAd();Instead
column4: the new app will mainly deliver videos from Facebook
column5: potentially turning it into a streaming rival toNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) andAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) . This supports previous reports that Facebook was   looking to license original content
column6: and suggests that its users   could deliver live broadcasts to TVs via Facebook Live.Will this move pay off? Or are Netflix
column7: Amazon
column8: andAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) YouTube already too far ahead in   the video streaming wars?Understanding Facebook's video effortsYouTube is the biggest video streaming site in the world
column9: but   Facebook's video ecosystem has been growing quickly. Last   January
column10: Facebook revealed that  its users watched 100   million hours of videos per day. At the time
column11: Business Insiderestimated that YouTube users were watching about 650 million   hours of video every day.During last quarter's conference call
column12: Facebook CEO  Mark   Zuckerberg called video ""a megatrend on the same order as   mobile""
column13: and highlighted the ways that video ecosystem was   expanding. It recently added a new tab in the Facebook app for   top videos and recommendations in the U.S.
column14: tested a version of   Live 360 videos for slower connections
column15: and added live face masks   and camera effects. It also plans to invest more in original   video content to ""seed that ecosystem"" throughout 2017.Facebook's interest in videos makes sense
column16: since video ads   cost much more than traditional display ads. As Facebook's active   user growth slows down
column17: video ads can bolster its top line by   milking more ad revenue from existing users. Since nearly 94% of   Facebook's 1.86 billion monthly active users already access the    site from mobile devices
column18: it also needs to look toward   other platforms -- like set top boxes -- to continue growing its   ad ecosystem.Carving out a niche between Netflix and AmazonAt first glance
column19: it seems like Facebook could collide with   Netflix and Amazon's streaming video ecosystems. But Facebook   doesn't plan to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on big   budget shows likeHouse of CardsandMan in the High Castle.Instead
column20: Zuckerberg plans to focus on ""shorter-form content to   start
column21: noting that the videos will generally be split into   content people produce socially for friends
column22: promotional content   from businesses and celebrities
column23: and a class of Facebook-financed   ""premium"" content to differentiate it from other platforms. CFO   David Wehner was vague about what that premium content would   actually be
column24: merely stating that the company was ""looking at a   wide range of content"" and ""working toward a revenue share model   with creators.""Those statements indicate that Facebook wants to carve out a   niche on set top boxes
column25: instead of trading costly blows with   Netflix and Amazon. Since Facebook's video platform is all about   delivering ads
column26: the platform should also be free -- so it won't   be competing for Netflix or Amazon's subscription-based   revenues.Is Facebook actually making a play for smart     homes?Facebook's new set top box app could also help it gain a   foothold in smart home ecosystems. Amazon has already established   a major presence in homes with its Kindle tablets
column27: Fire TV set   top boxes
column28: and Echo speakers. Google is trying to catch up with   Home
column29: andAppletethers devices to its HomeKit platform for iOS.Facebook doesn't have an official horse in that race yet
column30: but   Zuckerberg recently showcased Jarvis
column31: a smart  home AI   platform he developed for his own home. The platform
column32: which uses   voice commands to control devices
column33: is controlled via a Messenger   bot.Image source: Facebook.By expanding Facebook's ecosystem to set top boxes like Apple   TV
column34: Fire TV
column35: and Roku
column36: the social network couldpotentiallypiggyback off that hardware to sync with smart home devices. If   Facebook links Messenger to those ""hubs""
column37: it could take control   of users' homes
column38: gather even more data from those users
column39: and   widen its moat against Amazon
column40: Google
column41: Apple
column42: and other   challengers.The key takeawayFacebook's plans to expand its video ecosystem aren't   surprising
column43: and a dedicated video app for set top boxes would be   the logical next step. It won't challenge heavyweights like   Netflix and Amazon
column44: but it could capture a niche market of users   who want to view Facebook video content on a streaming platform   optimized for TVs. If the effort is successful
column45: it could make its   video ads more valuable and give it a firm foundation for   eventually challenging other smart home players.Find out why Facebookis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column1: What Investors Missed in the Market Last Week;2/5/2017;"The U.S. economy was trying to cooperate and end the week on a   high note after the Labor Department announced that the U.S.   added 227

column1: These 2 Tech Companies Have Made the Most AI Acquisitions;2/4/2017;"Market-intelligence firm CB Insights has compiled alistof the major acquirers of private artificial-intelligence (AI)   companies over the last five years. This list reveals well-known   tech giants making large investments to increase their   capabilities in AI. It also provides insight into the evolution   of the technology
column2: and its direct uses.Google and Intel are in the race for artificial     intelligence. Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();Google's been on a buying spreeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google is well known for itsaspirations in artificial intelligence; it heads the list with 11 acquisitions. A number of these   companies specialized in areas that led directly to recent   improvements in the Google Assistant. They also tie to the launch   of Google Home and its plans to take onAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN)Alexa virtual assistantand the Echo smart-speaker home system.The acquisition of Emu provided an assistant that used voice   commands to schedule appointments
column3: set reminders
column4: and make   reservations. Api.ai added tools for building conversational   bots
column5: while Dark Blue Labs contributed natural-language   improvements. Two companies helped personalize recommendations:   Clever Sense learned about nearby coffee shops
column6: restaurants and   bars; Jetpac searched for visual cues in photos to improve   recommendations. Timeful used priorities to add items to a   calendar using smart scheduling.Three companies specialized in image recognition: DNNResearch   focused on image search and facial recognition; Moodstocks   technology improved image recognition for smartphones; Vision   Factory worked to enhance accuracy and speed in object   recognition. Each of the aforementioned technologies serves to   improve specific functions in Google Home's ecosystem
column7: and   specifically within Assistant. This will compete directly in the   virtual personal assistant market currently led by Amazon's   Alexa.London-based DeepMind was one of the largest acquisitions
column8: with a price tag estimated at $660 million. Google already   boasted a significant investment in the area with its development   of the Google Brain
column9: a neural network developed in-house. Gains   in AI research have been used to improve many areas of its   current business. DeepMind is focused on improvements in general   AI research
column10: without any specific business objectives. That said
column11: Google will use every opportunity to apply research gains to   business uses.Is Intel's acquisition of Nervana a threat to NVIDIA? Image     source: Intel.Intel will take the fight to NVIDIAIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) has made a number of acquisitions as well. Saffron   specialized in cognitive computing
column12: combining data analytics with   deep learning; this relates directly to Intel's efforts in the   same area. Indisys provided natural-language recognition
column13: gesture   recognition
column14: and virtual-assistant technologies
column15: but also created   user interfaces for unmanned drones. Itseez focused on software   for the Internet of Things (IoT)
column16: cameras
column17: drones
column18: and autonomous   driving. Movidius brought computer-vision hardware for drones and   cameras; it also provided system-on-a-chip (SoC) technology for   accelerating computer vision
column19: as well as deep-learning   capability. These companies integrate directly into Intel's   RealSense brand for drones and virtual reality
column20: and bolster its   IoT business.The most significant of Intel's acquisitions
column21: however
column22: may be   that of deep-learning start-up Nervana Systems. With a reported   price of $408 million
column23: this company is attempting to reduce   machine learning to the size of a computer chip. Intel competitorNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) has seen its stock price triple in 2016
column24: as its   graphics processing units (GPUs) become the chip of choice for   companiestraining AI systems. If Intel can succeed at reducing machine learning to a level   that could reside on a processor
column25: that would be a significant   boost to its business and a potentially troubling development for   NVIDIA.As the battle for AI supremacy continues
column26: we will likely see   more consolidation in the industry
column27: as tech giants try to gain an   edge in this nascent technology. Success in the field will likely   depend on successful integration of these acquisitions into   existing business lines. Alphabet and Intel are on the right   track.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Will 2017 Be American Outdoor Brand Corp's Best Year Yet?;2/4/2017;"The past year was anawesome oneforAmerican Outdoor Brands(NASDAQ: AOBC) . Handgun sales jumped 40%
column2: rifle sales were up   70%
column3: and its new outdoors market increased 50%
column4: albeit from a   bunch of acquisitions. Yet when you look at its stock
column5: investors   found it lacking
column6: remaining largely unchanged from where it   started.AOBCdata byYChartsmakeArticleAd();That's because after the election of Donald Trump as   president
column7: the urgency to buy a gun before new
column8: stricter laws   were enacted evaporated. At the recent industry SHOT Show trade   show
column9: American Outdoor Brands said that adjusted firearms data in   December tumbled more than 17% from the year-ago period
column10: with   handguns plunging 30%. Considering that firearms account for 88%   of its revenues
column11: can 2017 really be American Outdoor Brands best   year ever?You betcha!Guns aren't going awayAlthough it's true that gun sales were lower in December than   they had been the previous year
column12: breaking a19-month streakof ever higher monthly numbers
column13: sales were still higher than any   other December without an incident of domestic terrorism. The   month was only bested by December 2012 and December 2015
column14: months   notable for the tragic shootings in Sandy Hook and San   Bernardino
column15: California
column16: respectively. It indicates there's still   plenty of latent demand for firearms
column17: and the likely reason is   that personal safety has become a paramount issue for gun   buyers.Image source: Getty Images.The most popular guns being bought today are thosedesigned for concealed carry
column18: small
column19: lightweight weapons that still pack a wallop in   firepower. And if the continuing series of protests and unrest   are any indication
column20: concerns for defense of self
column21: family
column22: and   property will remain uppermost on people's minds. Gun sales may   not run at the blistering pace they've been at
column23: but it's likely   they'll stay at elevated levels.The great outdoorsBeyond just guns
column24: though
column25: American Outdoor Brands is   transforming itself into a broader
column26: more diversified manufacturer   of products for the outdoor recreational industry. With a much   larger target market -- some $30 billion to $35 billion
column27: according to AOB's management
column28: compared to $14 billion for   firearms -- there's much more opportunity for growth.While there are a few
column29: big-name retailers focused on servicing   the market
