column31: Cabela's
column32: andDick's Sporting Goods
column33: not to mention mass merchandisers likeWal-Martor online retailers such asAmazon.com
column34: it remains a very fragmented industry with some 12
column35: 000   independent retailers. Yet it's also an industry that is very   complementary to its existing customer base and the new   opportunities should give American Outdoor Brands a chance to   cross-sell to them.Sights set on the futureVery much in the same vein
column36: and underscoring exactly what it's   trying to achieve
column37: acquisitions like its purchase of Crimson   Trace create completely new lines of business
column38: yet ones that   don't diverge too far from the path it was originally on.Image source: Crimson Trace.With its buyout of the laser sight manufacturer
column39: AOB created a   new business segment: electro-optics. Crimson Trace has a   decade-long record of growing revenues at a compounded rate of   more than 10% annually
column40: a key reason why it was purchased
column41: but   it's a natural extension of its firearms business. Laser sighting   and tactical lighting are already items gun buyers are looking   for (and Crimson Trace was already a long-term supplier of laser   sighting systems for Smith & Wesson)
column42: but it also opens up   new products for it such as various sights
column43: aiming and ranging   devices
column44: magnifiers
column45: and scopes for a variety of   applications.A bright futureA lot of these potential growth markets are long term in   nature
column46: and American Outdoor Brands admits as much. Yet they   indicate a greater diversity of revenue streams
column47: much less stock   volatility
column48: and a chance to move away from being just about   guns.In a year that's supposedly going to see fewer gun purchases
column49: a business model that de-emphasizes that segment of its   operations while channeling more energy into a niche that is   larger and still growing in popularity suggests 2017 will be   American Outdoor Brands' best year yet.10 stocks we like better than American Outdoor Brands   CorporationWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Advance Auto Parts to announce earnings;2/4/2017;"What's HappeningAuto-parts retailer Advance Auto Parts (AAP) is expected to post its quarterly resultsafter the market closeson February 9. Analysts forecast fourth-quarter earnings of $1.09 per share
column2: down from $1.32 during the same period last year. The stock has been trending lower over the last two months
column3: and shares are currently down 4.4% on the year.Technical AnalysisAAP was recently trading at $163.09
column4: down $14.74 from its 12-month high and $31.50 above its 12-month low. Technical indicators for AAP are bearish and the stock is a weak downward trend. The stock has recent support above $159.70
column5: and has resistance below $168.50. Of the 18 analysts who cover the stock
column6: six rate it a ""strong buy""
column7: two rate it a ""buy""
column8: eight rate it a ""hold""
column9: and two rate it a ""strong sell"". The stock receives S&P Capital IQ's 2 STARS ""Sell"" ranking.Analyst's ThoughtsAAP has been trending lower over the last month
column10: and the stock could use a solid earnings report to bring back investor enthusiasm. The company's third-quarter report was solid
column11: with results topping estimates on both the top and bottom lines
column12: but the stock rose too sharply on the news
column13: and has recently been giving back some of those gains. If AAP is able to follow up last quarter's report with another solid set of numbers
column14: I would expect to see the stock quickly erase a large portion of its recent losses. Analysts remain upbeat
column15: setting a price target of $177.69 on the stock
column16: which is 8.9% above its current trading price. Despite the bullish price target
column17: the stock's recent weakness suggests that Wall Street will drive the stock even lower if the company's quarterly numbers disappoint.The biggest concern right now for both Advance Auto and its biggest competitor AutoZone (AZO) is that Amazon (AMZN) is trying to aggressively move into the market. Amazon has recently made deals with some of the largest auto parts makers
column18: and the news of these contracts hurt shares of all the major auto parts retailers. The good news for the sector is that a lot of parts are purchased in stores only after some assistance has been made by a sales rep
column19: and a lot of the parts are very time sensitive and needed to keep cars on the road. Amazon is a concern
column20: but it is not an immediate threat
column21: and investors will come back into AAP as long as the quarterly numbers are not weaker than expected.Stock Only TradeIf you're looking to establish a long stock position in AAP
column22: consider buying the stock under $163.00. Sell if it falls below $146.50 or take profits if it gets to $187.50.Bullish TradeIf you want a bullish hedged trade on the stock
column23: consider a March 140/145 bull-put credit spread for a 60-cent credit. That's a potential 13.6% return (118.5% annualized*) and the stock would have to fall 10.7% to cause a problem.Bearish TradeIf you want to take a bearish stance on the stock at this time
column24: consider a March 175/180 bear-call credit spread for a $0.35 credit. That's a potential 7.5% return (65.4% annualized*) and the stock would have to rise 7.5% to cause a problem.Covered Call TradeIf you like the stock
column25: but wish to lower your cost basis on a new position
column26: you may want to consider a March $160.00 covered call. Buy AAP shares (typically 100 shares
column27: scale as appropriate)
column28: while selling the March $160.00 call for a debit of $154.80 per share. The trade has a target assigned return of 3.4%
column29: and a target annualized return of 30.0% (for comparison purposes only)."

column1: Stocks Surge as Trump Rolls Back Dodd-Frank;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsU.S. equities surged on Friday back to all-time highs
column3: enjoying the best one-day gain of the year so far. The catalyst was executive action by President Trump to roll back some of the new Wall Street regulations put in place following the financial crisis
column4: including the ""fiduciary"" rule that would've increased the compliance risk for financial advisors.makeArticleAd();Investors were also encouraged by a ""Goldilocks"" jobs report that featured better-than-expected payroll gains along with a slight increase in the unemployment rate and weaker wage gains - a perfect combination of strong job growth along with a diminished inflation that likely removes the threat of a March rate hike from the Federal Reserve.In the end
column5: theDow Jones Industrial Averagegained 0.9%
column6: theS&P 500added 0.7%
column7: theNasdaq Compositewafted up 0.5% and theRussell 2000gained 1.5%. Treasury bonds gave up early strength to finish little changed
column8: the dollar weakened
column9: gold lost 0.1% and oil gained 0.4%.Financial stocks - no surprise - led the way with a 2% gain followed by energy
column10: up 0.9%. Consumer discretionary and utility stocks were the laggards.9 Best Cheap Stocks to Buy Now Under $9.99Amazon.com
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) fell 3.5% after revenue growth came in light and guidance disappointed.Visa Inc(NYSE:V) rose 4.6% on an earnings beat with the Street positive on cross border volume growth and market share gains. A big revenue miss fromGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO) on a 12% decline in shipments - hurt by the Karma drone recall and a lack of marketing support - hammered shares for a 12.7% loss.Overall
column12: the fourth-quarter earnings season is now a little more than half over: With 55% of S&P 500 companies reporting results
column13: earnings growth is set to rise 4.6% from last year. That will mark the first back-to-back quarter of earnings growth since the beginning of 2015.For now
column14: the drop in rate hikes and the shift in the Trump narrative back to pro-business - after a recent diversion into possible negatives like an immigration clampdown and possible trade war - sets the stage for a resumption of the post-election uptrend. The nearest potential headwind is Fed Board Chair Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress later this month.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialFor now
column15: the ""Trump-flation"" trade is back on with financial stocks ready to retake the lead.Anthony Mirhaydari is founder of theEdgeandEdge Proinvestment advisory newsletters. A two-week and four-week free trial offer has been extended to InvestorPlace readers.More From InvestorPlace3 Big Buyout Deals That Could Crush Investors10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe postStocks Surge as Trump Rolls Back Dodd-Frankappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Should You Buy Whole Foods Market
column2: Inc. (WFM) Stock? 3 Pros
column3: 3 Cons;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhole Foods Market
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:WFM) used to be the unparalleled natural foods leader. It used to be the only real option
column6: in much of America anyway
column7: to find natural
column8: organic and healthier foods. The company rode its first-mover position to dominance and WFM stock soared.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)But as so often happens in capitalist economies
column9: the competition arrived soon after.Earlier this decade
column10: WFM stock seemed unstoppable. Now shares of the organic grocer have fallen by half from their prior peak
column11: as investors fret over Whole Foods' slowing growth rate and mounting competitive problems.A downturn in food prices hasn't helped either. Are the 365 stores and WFM stock's dividend enough to support the share price here
column12: or will it continue to fall?WFM Stock ConsGrocery Deflation Cycle:There has been a big problem for grocery stores as a sector: deflation in food prices. Many common staples have dropped and then dropped some more in price. Eggs
column13: various meats
column14: cereals and even produce have been under heavy pressure. In theory
column15: you'd think this would cause higher margins for grocery stores. Generally cheaper input prices are good for business. However
column16: it hasn't worked that way for grocery stores.This is because grocery stores are profoundly competitive. There's very little moat around them - most stores compete tooth and nail against various other grocery stores
column17: not to mentionWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT). Customers generally have limited loyalty to individual stores
column18: and are intensely cost-sensitive. Think gas stations as a comparable business.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryAs such
column19: when food prices decline
column20: grocery stores pass this along to customers. Otherwise
column21: the store across the street does
column22: and you lose your shoppers. Thus
column23: when grocery prices fall
column24: stores are forced to push through virtually all the potential cost savings. However
column25: stores are stuck with fixed overhead. Lease costs
column26: wages and other costs don't diminish when food prices fall. When total revenues fall then it ends up eating a fair chunk of the company's overall profitability. Whole Foods finds protection
column27: to some degree
column28: in its stronger brand
column29: but it is not immune.Too Much Competition:There is a related issue; the sector now finds itself with too much competition. Grocery stores had a good period
column30: particularly ones riding the organic trend. That caused management teams to expand heavily.Trader Joe's
column31: for example
column32: had just 300 stores in 2013. It's up to 460 now. And according to a recent Deutsche Bankcomparison
column33: a basket of 77 similar products was priced 21% cheaper at Trader Joe's as compared with Whole Foods. Trader Joe's is hardly the only threat.Sprouts Farmers Market Inc(NASDAQ:SFM) has grown revenues 22% a year compounded over the past five years
column34: and notched a 20% increase over the past 12 months.After this rapid expansion in the upscale grocery department
column35: a period of store closings - or at minimum reduced growth - and retrenchment is needed to reduce the overall competition level and let profit margins tick up a few basis points.Expensive WFM Stock:Yes
column36: I know WFM stock has lost roughly half its value since its 2013 peak. But that doesn't automatically make it cheap. In fact
column37: WFM stock continues to trade at above a price-earnings ratio of 20. Sprouts
column38: with its robust growth rate
column39: trades at 20 times earnings as well. When given the option of a company growing at 20%/year such as Sprouts or Whole Foods with its shrinking earnings
column40: you should generally pick the former.Grocery stores
column41: due to their low margins
column42: tend to trade at modest P/E ratios. Walmart is far more than just a grocery store
column43: but it is a similar low-margin business and sells plenty of food. WMT stock is at just 14 times earnings. Pureplay grocer competitorKroger Co(NYSE:KR) trades at 16 times earnings. It's hard to argue for paying a premium on WFM stock given its recent operational issues.WFM Stock ProsFood Prices to Rise:I suspect the deflationary food price trend will reverse soon. To start with
column44: there's an inflationary upturn in commodity prices generally. There's not necessarily any direct correlation between grains or meats prices and the hard commodities
column45: however given the importance of input costs and also general investor sentiment across the asset class
column46: one should expect firmer agricultural prices if the commodity rally continues.Trump is a plus for food prices if he generates more inflation generally. More specifically
column47: cereals prices have been down for a long period of time. Corn prices
column48: for example
column49: have plunged since 2012. That benefits consumers directly. Americans eat tons of corn in various forms
column50: and it also translates to lower feed prices
column51: which has helped promote low meat and egg pricing. When corn goes up
column52: it will boost food prices across the spectrum.365 Stores:Whole Foods is rolling out a new smaller store format. Named 365
column53: after its private label branded products
column54: these space-conscious 28
column55: 000 square foot stores are up to 50% cheaper to open and operate than the mainline Whole Foods locations.These smaller stores seem designed to compete more directly with Trader Joe's. And so far
column56: it is working
column57: at least according to management. The company claims it has seen many Trader Joe's bags turning up in the new 365 stores. In any case
column58: Whole Foods plans to have several dozen of these stores up and running shortly.Decent Dividend:WFM stock used to be a classic growth play. Up above $50/share
column59: most people involved held with high hopes of grocery market domination. The collapse in the growth story sent investors heading for the exits. At today's more conservative price
column60: a lot less needs to go right to make WFM stock pay off.That's in part due to the increasingly attractive dividend. WFM stock yields 56 cents/share
column61: amounting to a 1.9% yield. Not bad for a top brand
column62: which
column63: if things go right
column64: may become a growth story again.VerdictIf you're looking for a trade in WFM stock
column65: this is a decent place to consider. The margin pressures caused by falling food prices should begin to ease up soon.How Options Traders Nailed Amazon.com
column66: Inc. (AMZN) EarningsWFM stock took a beating
column67: and now looks oversold. As an investment
column68: however
column69: the valuation still looks iffy. And competition continues to mount an increasing threat to Whole Foods' margins in the long term.At the time of this writing
column70: Ian Bezek owned WMT stock. He had no position in WFM stock. You can reach him on Twitter at @irbezek.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketThe 3 Best CEFs for Growth and DividendsThe postShould You Buy Whole Foods Market

column1: How Charles Schwab Is Becoming the Amazon of Investing;2/3/2017;"Amazon ( AMZN) has become a behemoth in the retail world.Sure
column2: the company's most recent earnings report may have left a bit to be desired
column3: but there is no denying how far Amazon has come in a few short years. The company easily dominates the consumer world
column4: and it has left a variety of big box retailers in its wake in the process.While we can point to a number of reasons for Amazon's ascent
column5: a key to their rise is clearly Amazon Prime. This subscription service-which costs $99/year-gives users free two day shipping
column6: video content
column7: music
column8: and a number of other features as well. The deal is so good that some estimateclose to half of the country's households have a Prime account
column9: with plenty of new subscribers now being added in foreign nations too.What is the point of this? Well
column10: Prime members (at least in the U.S.)spend roughly twice as muchas non-Prime users on Amazon
column11: while the service has an insane renewal rate in the United States
column12: over 90% accordingto the Consumer Intelligence Research Partners
column13: so people are clearly seeing the value.But with so many services and offerings in the Prime package
column14: how does Amazon make any money? Well
column15: the idea is clearly to suck people in to the Amazon ecosystem via Prime
column16: and then keep them there for years. And with such a high renewal rate and spending that is double non-Prime users
column17: it is clearly paying off. One only needs to look at the demise of other retailers in a number of areas to understand just how much Amazon is dominating the consumer world these days.So
column18: the strategy is to give people an offer that is too good to refuse in order to get them in the door and looking at higher margin products later on. AsJeff Bezos said
column19: Prime is 'such a good value
column20: you'd be irresponsible not to be a member'.The Amazon of Investing?We can see how Amazon has changed the world of retail and the consumer market
column21: but is anyone doing the same thing for investing?I'd argue thatCharles Schwab( SCHW) is adopting this 'Amazon model' in the world of investing
column22: and this is especially evident after their recent move.Their latest announcementbrought fees down to $6.95/trade from their previous spot at $8.95/trade
column23: while Schwab also announced a fee cut on some of its broad market mutual funds
column24: and that mutual fund costs would match their ETF counterparts too.The company will now charge 0.03% for its Schwab S&P 500 Index Fund ( SWPPX)
column25: while the Schwab Small-Cap Index Fund ( SWSSX) will cost 0.06% per year. Additionally
column26: the company also reduced fees for its Schwab U.S. Aggregate Bond Index Fund down to 0.04% (which comes out later in February) to become an ultra-cheap choice in that market too. They also discussed the idea of reducing fees for the Schwab U.S. TIPS ETF ( SCHP) and their fundamental index ETFs
column27: but those changes will take place on March first.These cuts put Schwab's fees down to levels below its major competitors
column28: Fidelity
column29: E*Trade ( ETFC) andTD Ameritrade( AMTD)
column30: and it sent shockwaves throughout the industry. Share prices of ETFC and AMTD were down nearly 10% immediately following the announcement
column31: while SCHW took a hit as well.I understand why the group was hit in the markets following the press release
column32: as it definitely kicks off worries over a price war. And as for Charles Schwab
column33: charging such rock bottom levels all but guarantees that Charles Schwab will lose money on its fund business
column34: and it will probably see less revenues from its commissions in the process too.So Why Is This Like Amazon?To me
column35: this is very reminiscent of the Amazon Prime service. You give people a ton of low cost options that are bound to please a wide range of people. So
column36: instead of two day shipping and free video content
column37: if you are in the investing world
column38: you offer up fees that are less than major peers and nearly-free ETFs and mutual funds.The move gets plenty of people in the door
column39: and it keeps them inside the ecosystem. Once you switch to Schwab for the low fees and start putting money in their ETFs and mutual funds
column40: it becomes difficult to justify switching back. This is exactly like how you get used to the two-day shipping
column41: music
column42: Pantry
column43: and other features from Amazon
column44: keeping you stuck in the system. Charles Schwab
column45: much like Amazon
column46: realizes that winning over new customers is a vital part of this business
column47: and that providing them low cost products is essential to keeping customers happy and away from the competition over the long-term.And once you have enough customers that you sucked in through the low price options
column48: you now have the ability to earn money off them in different ways. Amazon does this with a variety of their media products and retail options in general (such as Pantry)
column49: though there are obviously some key differences between the retail and investing worlds.Schwab can do something similar to Amazon's approach nonetheless though. Bring people in for low cost index products and cheap trades
column50: and then make the real profits off high margin activities that Amazon can only dream of. These include
column51: investment management
column52: servicing fees
column53: and most importantly
column54: investing the float.This last item will prove to be key for Schwab and other brokers
column55: and especially if rates rise as most are expecting. For 2016
column56: interest income accounted for roughly 44% of Schwab's net revenues
column57: and that was in a year with mostly low-rates. Considering that trading revenue makes up about 11% of the total revenue (looking at 2016)
column58: and it is pretty reasonable to think that Schwab will be alright in the long term with a modest fee cut.I think that Schwab sees the same thing with the writing on the wall for a low rate environment. They are willing to sacrifice a bit in trading revenue now in order to get new users on the platform and get access to their potential asset base and the investable float that comes along with it. And if rates rise as most are expecting
column59: this could prove to pay off
column60: and especially considering that interest makes up a plurality of revenue already
column61: and that is with rates at ultra-low levels.So
column62: while Schwab might be down on this news now
column63: it is a brilliant strategy in order to get more clients and capital in the door over the long haul. It is this type of forward thinking that has propelled Amazon to greatness in the consumer market
column64: and it is about time someone tried this in the investing world as well.Want key ETF info delivered straight to your   inbox?Zacks' free Fund Newsletter will brief you on top news and analysis
column65: as well as top-performing ETFs
column66: each week.Get it free >>Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? Today
column67: you can download 7 Best Stocks for the Next 30 Days.Click to get this free reportmakeArticleAd();The Charles Schwab Corporation (SCHW): Free Stock Analysis ReportSCHWAB-US TIPS (SCHP): ETF Research ReportsE*TRADE Financial Corporation (ETFC): Free Stock Analysis ReportAmazon.com
column68: Inc. (AMZN): Free Stock Analysis ReportTD Ameritrade Holding Corporation (AMTD): Free Stock Analysis ReportTo read this article on Zacks.com click here.Zacks Investment Research"

column1: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. Earnings: Profits March Higher... Again;2/3/2017;"Headed intoAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN) fourth quarter
column3: there was lots of uncertainty about what the e-commerce and cloud-computing company would report
column4: particularly as it related to the company's profitability. But net income soared as operating income exceeded the high end of the company's guidance range.Here's a closer look at Amazon's soaring profits and its overall fourth-quarter results.makeArticleAd();Image source: Amazon.com.Amazon.com results: The raw numbersMetricQ4 2016Q4 2015Year-Over-Year ChangeRevenue$43.7 billion$35.7 billion22%Operating income$1.3 billion$1.1 billion13%Net income$749 million$482 million55%EPS$1.54$1.0054%Data source: Amazon fourth-quarter earningspress release. Table by author.What happened with Amazon this quarter?Revenue increased 22%
column5: a rate that falls in the middle of management's ownforecastfor fourth-quarter revenue growth between 17% and 27%.For its seventh quarter in a row
column6: Amazon was profitable. Net income was $749 million
column7: up 55% form the year-ago quarter.Amazon's operating income was $1.3 billion
column8: easily exceeding the company's forecast for fourth-quarter operating profits to be between $0 to $1.25 billion.Amazon's North America e-commerce business saw its operating income rise from $636 million in the year-ago quarter to $816 million in the fourth quarter of 2016.But the loss in Amazon's international e-commerce business widened from $108 million in the year-ago quarter to $487 million in the fourth quarter of 2016.Amazon's cloud-computing business
column9: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column10: outperformed the company's North America e-commerce business when it comes to profitability. AWS' operating income increased from $580 million in the year-ago quarter to $926 million in the fourth quarter of 2016
column11: accounting for 74% of the company's overall operating income.What management had to sayAmazon continued to make progress on its flywheel strategy of delivering value for Prime members across a growing suite of membership benefits. Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos explained Prime's success in the company's fourth-quarter earnings press release:Our Prime team's customer obsession kept them busy in 2016. Prime members can now choose from over 50 million items with free two-day shipping -- up 73% since 2015. Prime Video is now available in more than 200 countries and territories. Prime Now added 18 new cities
column12: which means millions more members now get one and two hour delivery. New benefits were also added to the list
column13: like Prime Reading
column14: Audible Channels for Prime
column15: Twitch Prime and more. And customers noticed -- tens of millions of new paid members joined the program in just this past year.AWS
column16: which Amazon prides itself on its rate of innovation
column17: released ""308 significant new services and features in the fourth quarter
column18: bringing the total number of launches in 2016 to 1
column20: management said. This is up from 722 significant new services and features in 2015.Management continues to expect 2017 to be marked by a big step-up in investments. Amazon CFO Brian Olsavsky discussed these expected investments' impact on the company's first-quarter guidance during Amazon's fourth-quarter earnings call (via a Reuterstranscript):[W]hat you are seeing ... is the continuation of the step-up investment that we saw in the second half of last year. I talked about in prior calls about the fulfillment center step up.We had 26 warehouses we added last year
column21: 23 of them were in the second half of the year. Digital content
column22: digital video content
column23: end marketing stepped up quite a bit in the second half of the year.We continue to invest heavily in those two areas. We also have investments in other Prime benefits from Prime Now to Amazon Fresh
column24: and of course we're continuing to invest in Alexa in our Echo devices. And finally I'd point out India which continues to be a rather large investment for us.For Amazon's first quarter of 2017
column25: management said it expected revenue to be between $33.25 billion and $36.75 billion
column26: up 14% to 23% compared to the first quarter of 2016. This guidance range
column27: management emphasized
column28: ""anticipates an unfavorable impact of approximately $730 million or 250 basis points from foreign exchange rates."" In anticipation of an aggressive investment year
column29: management expects operating income to be between $250 million and $900 million
column30: down from $1.1 billion in the first quarter of 2016.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsProgressive Corp(NYSE:PGR) is the nation's No. 4 property & casualty (P&C) insurance company. And of the three ahead of it

column1: Earnings Make Long Term Case For Visa (V) And MasterCard (MA);2/3/2017;"Back at the end of November last year
column2: I wrotean articlesuggesting that those bullish on the prospects for “Cyber Monday” should consider playing their belief in a way less obvious than simply buying stock in Amazon (AMZN). The argument then was that the expectations for
column3: and indeed the valuation of
column4: Amazon were such that even a decent holiday period for the online retailer could provoke only a so-so reaction
column5: whereas any hint of weakness could see the stock punished.My suggestion then was that investors should consider the major credit card companies MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V) instead. Now that Q4 earnings for all of the companies concerned are out that seems to have played out pretty well
column6: and the case for V and MA remains strong.To recap the card companies’ earnings
column7: MasterCard
column8: who released on Monday
column9: reported numbers that were essentially in line
column10: with a small beat of EPS and a small miss in revenue terms
column11: but highlighted by sales growth of nearly ten percent on an annual basis. Visa reported last night and beat on both the top and bottom lines
column12: while also reporting noticeable growth.makeArticleAd();Some are quoting the fact that transactions processed by Visa increased by 39% over last year
column13: but that is not a direct comparison as the latest number includes transactions from Visa Europe
column14: while last year’s did not. A more reliable indicator of growth is U.S. transactions
column15: which increased by a not too shabby 12%.What makes both V and MA such good long term plays for investors
column16: though
column17: is the big picture circumstances that seem to be inexorably moving in their favor.Online shopping continues to increase exponentially
column18: not just here in the U.S.
column19: but around the world
column20: and
column21: despite the best efforts of PayPal (PYPL) and others
column22: credit and debit cards remain the go to payment method for online shoppers. Visa and MasterCard combined account forover 85%of global payment volume in general
column23: so even if online shopping growth stalls for some unforeseeable reason
column24: both companies look set to continue growing.At some point it is possible that Bitcoin or some other virtual currency will gain ground and do damage to that dominance
column25: but at the moment that looks far enough away to not present a realistic problem to investors.As I pointed out in the above referenced article
column26: one of the strongest features of the earnings for both Visa and MasterCard is that they have spectacular margins
column27: nudging 40% in both cases. The wider implementation of new technology such as microchip based transactions will possibly hold those margins back for a while
column28: but in the long run will increase profitability by reducing the incidence of fraud.Of course
column29: if the entire global economy slows then card payments will suffer along with everything else
column30: but the cyclical nature of economics can’t be avoided. The simple fact is that
column31: as these recent earnings releases have demonstrated
column32: as long as people continue to buy things
column33: and especially as those purchases continue to shift towards e-commerce
column34: both Visa and MasterCard will continue to grow. On that basis they are stocks that should be a part of everyone’s long term portfolio."

column1: Stronger Jobs at 227K
column2: Unemployment Ticks Up to 4.8%;2/3/2017;"Friday
column3: February 3
column4: 2017makeArticleAd();Ahead of the opening bell this Friday
column5: new non-farm payroll jobs numbers were released from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)
column6: with 227K new jobs created in the month of January
column7: up from the consensus 174K expected from analysts. The unemployment rate rose a tenth of a percentage point to 4.8%
column8: due to an increase in labor force participation.Average hourly earnings did rise again
column9: but only by 0.1%. This figure year over year is +2.5%. Is it keeping up with inflation? Just barely. Look for this metric to continually increase in importance as these monthly jobs numbers become more clearly representative of the Trump administration.Revisions to the past two months were rather considerable: +1000 jobs in December to 157K
column10: but down 40K in November to 164K
column11: an overall revision of -39K new jobs over the past quarter year.Industry by industry
column12: Retail brought in the highest number of new hires at 46K
column13: followed by Construction at 36K. Government hiring was the biggest loser
column15: marking the second straight decline in government employment. The labor force participation rate rose to 62.9%
column16: up 0.2%. The U6 read - sometimes referred to as ""real unemployment"" - rose to 9.4% after several months in a row lower.The Trump administration talks a lot about bringing in lots of news jobs
column17: but we're looking a little tight in the U.S. labor force these days. For sure there are plenty of Uber drivers who'd rather be employed full-time elsewhere (not to pick on Uber
column18: but to use them as a modern example of American labor)
column19: and it is encouraging that more out-of-work citizens have begun to seek out new employment once again. But skill-sets matching job openings looks to be one of the biggest concerns.We've seen a lot of executive orders from Trump so far in the early days of his administration
column20: but nothing yet on his promised infrastructure program (which will presumably include building a big wall on our southern border
column21: but may also include repairing bridges
column22: airports
column23: etc. throughout the country). These jobs ought to be forthcoming
column24: but it's tough for analysts to include in their models at this point. How much money will Congress allot to such ends? No one really knows at this stage.A shortage of skilled labor in the Construction sector is something that the administration and Congress may wish to address in bringing new funds to blue-collar America's workforce. But will it? Another unknown at this point.HersheyHSYand CloroxCLXboth beat earnings ahead of the bell today. This follows Amazon'sAMZNearnings beat after the closing bell Thursday

column1: Is Twilio Inc (TWLO) Stock a Trade or an Investment?;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTwilio Inc(NYSE:TWLO)
column3: which went public in June
column4: is a Henry Higgins for apps. Just as Professor Higgins transformed Eliza Doolittle from a poverty-soaked wretch into a great beauty inPygmalion
column5: orMy Fair Ladyif you prefer the musical
column6: so TWLO transforms Web apps from empty nothings to bright lights and dazzle.  Twilio does this by giving them a voice
column7: video and messaging platform
column8: delivered as a service
column9: through the cloud
column10: offloading these functions asAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) offloads the cloud itself.makeArticleAd();Source:Web Summit Via FlickrThe question for Twilio stock investors is
column12: how many companies need this and how many can use this? Just how many Eliza Doolittle apps are there
column13: and how fast can they be found?When TWLO stock delivers its earnings on Feb. 7
column14: we'll have a clue
column15: and most analysts don't think they will like the answer. They expect revenue of just $73.92 million
column16: and a loss of 5 to 6 cents per share
column17: a narrow loss but no real growth
column18: certainly nothing worth a market cap of $2.63 billion.Twilio Stock Is a BattlegroundThe pessimism is borne out of how quickly the app business is consolidating around a few huge companies which
column19: likeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column20: have the size to deliver these functions on their own
column21: and which don't need to rent them.This has made TWLO stock a battleground stock
column22: subject to wild swings of fortune. After going public in June with a first trade at $21.30
column23: Twilio stock rose to nearly $69 per share by late September before plunging to $26.50 in early January
column24: opening for trade Feb. 3 at around $30.50.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryIt was ""a frumpy New Year"" in the words of InvestorPlace contributor Josh Enomoto. At $28 per share
column25: he saw the downside riskas greaterthan the upside potential. InvestorPlace contributor Chris Tyler agrees
column26: suggesting you don't even nibble until TWLO stock tests its low of $23.66and bounces off it.After all
column27: you don't want to buyanotherFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE).Joseph Hargett is more bullish
column28: saying buyers arelined up to buyonce earnings come out. Facebook itself is at the center of his uncertainty. TWLO is part of Facebook Messenger
column29: but it has no contract with Facebook
column30: which can cancel its deal at any time. Hargett offers two ways to play the volatility with options.Richard Saintvilus
column31: by contrast
column32: is a straight-on bull
column33: saying Twilio stock could hit $40 withjust a little patience.TWLO itself runs in the Amazon cloud
column34: and should be able to access Amazon's cloud customers
column35: he writes
column36: helping them deliver voice notifications and text messages
column37: which enhance security
column38: providing access management features at low cost.TWLO Stock Dances With WolvesMy view is that Twilio stock is dancing with wolves
column39: which makes it both more enticing and more dangerous. Proving your value to the wolf without the wherewithal to attract your own pack
column40: after all
column41: can quickly turn you into wolf food.I suspect analysts are looking too much at TWLO's next earnings report and not enough at its real business model
column42: seeing it as a trade rather than an investment.Twilio is in the business of having programmers find creative solutions for common app problems within the cloud and selling those solutions by subscription. It's possible that Facebook may find another way around the secure sign-in problem
column43: but TWLO CEO Jeff Lawson is building a shop that canfind other problems and other solutions
column44: then deliver them.Why Square Inc (SQ) Stock Is Starting to Pick Up Its GrooveIn other words
column45: if you're bullish on Twilio stock
column46: you don't just believe it can bring in revenue and profit from its current offerings
column47: but that it can use its relationships to find problems and develop solutions that go beyond disaster response and helping users get back their passwords. To return to the beginning of this piece
column48: you believe Eliza will marry Professor Higgins and find a happy ending.TWLO stock is a bet on cloud application development and on the model of selling solutions through the cloud
column49: using the cloud's own self-service model. It's a bet Facebook and Amazon themselves are willing to make
column50: one that has a longer time horizon than just next week.I think a longer-term investor should be willing to play it that way
column51: too. If you're betting on Twilio stock
column52: you're betting on Jeff Lawson's development vision. TWLO stock is about the jockey
column53: not the horse.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column54: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing

column1: GoPro (GPRO) Q4 Results Mixed with Earnings Beat & View Cut;2/3/2017;"After four back-to-back quarters of posting quarterly losses
column2: GoPro
column3: Inc.GPROmanaged to get back in the green as it posted adjusted earnings of 16 cents per share in its fourth-quarter 2016 results. The action camera maker's bottom-line figure beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 12 cents by an impressive 33%.However
column4: the earnings figure was a result of several adjustments made to the huge GAAP loss that GoPro reported (82 cents per share).Shares tumbled almost 14% at one point in late trading in the aftermath of the results
column5: as investors were disillusioned with the company's bleak sales outlook for first-quarter 2017. This was in spite of the fact that this was the second biggest quarter in terms of revenue in GoPro's history. The drab guidance must have spooked investors as 2017 was supposed to be a turnaround time for GoPro and this is a terrible start to the same.In addition
column6: investors were likely upset with the multiple missed opportunities and goof-ups that GoPro had this quarter.The huge GAAP loss of 82 cents for the quarter was much wider than the 25 cents loss generated in the comparable quarter last year.For full-year 2016
column7: the company reported a non-GAAP net loss of $1.44 per share
column8: in stark contrast to net income of 76 cents in 2015.Inside the HeadlinesGoPro's revenues grew 23.8% from the prior-year quarter's tally to $540.6 million. This marked the company's return to revenue growth after four successive quarters of sales declines. The top-line figure still lagged the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $576 million.This was the first quarter that reflected the performance of the recently launched Hero5 camera and its consumer drone Karma
column9: and revenues were far short of the company's earlier guidance of $625 million. The Karma recall hit the top line and manufacturing issues related to Hero5 camera also strained growth.Nevertheless
column10: Hero5 Black was the best-selling digital imaging device in units and dollars in the U.S. and Europe. Also
column11: Hero5 Black sold more units in a single quarter in Europe
column12: in this quarter
column13: than any other GoPro camera ever.For the quarter
column14: non-GAAP gross margins expanded 990 bps year over year to 39.5%. Non-GAAP operating income came in at $31.6 million
column15: as against an operating loss of $21.6 million generated last year.R&D expenses were up almost 40% year over year
column16: driven by investment in HERO5 cameras
column17: Karma
column18: accessories and software. In addition
column19: sales and marketing expenses shot up 36% year over year.The company recently launched GoPro Plus - a cloud-based subscription service - that enables auto-upload of footage from a GoPro camera to a GoPro Plus cloud account for on-the-go access
column20: editing and sharing using a smartphone and the Quik app. Even though it is early days
column21: the GoPro Plus is enjoying high retention rates in the U.S. and its subscriber base seems to be expanding.In the quarter
column22: the rebranded Quik mobile app was downloaded over 4 million times (up almost 30% sequentially)
column23: as its active users and monthly exports tripled in Dec 2016 over the prior year.For full-year 2016
column24: revenues plunged 26.8% year over year to $1.62 billion.Notable DevelopmentsTill date
column25: GoPro's Hero 5 Black cameras and Karma drones have faced production issues and delayed shipments
column26: which restrained the company's ability to meet demand in the quarter. The company's new products also had a rocky start with Amazon.com Inc.AMZN
column27: as GoPro had temporarily stopped selling them on the e-commerce site in mid October due to a pricing dispute.Further
column28: supply constraints made retailers cancel marketing support of GoPro's new products
column29: particularly its new Hero 5 camera
column30: which obviously hurt revenues. Further
column31: the company had to announce a recall of its new Karma drone after a mere fortnight of its commercial launch
column32: as a few of them lost power during flight due to battery issues. This was also a huge setback for the company.However
column33: earlier this week
column34: the company resumed Karma sales and the company plans to ramp production further. Karma is scheduled to be available in international markets this spring. We believe that GoPro is well set to capitalize on the fast-growing consumer drone market.The company also launched several accessories during the quarter
column35: including Karma Grip
column36: a handheld stabilizer; Remo
column37: a waterproof
column38: voice-activated remote and Quik Key
column39: a microSD card reader enabling quick editing and sharing from smartphones.LiquidityExiting the quarter
column40: the company had cash and cash equivalents of $192.1 million
column41: down significantly from $280 million a year back.GuidanceIn light of such unfortunate events and uncertain market reaction
column42: the company gave a very disappointing guidance for first-quarter 2017. It projects revenues for the current quarter in the range of $190-$210 million
column43: which is well below the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $268 million for the quarter. The company expects gross margin in the low 30% range.GoPro refrained from offering specific revenue or margin guidance for full-year 2017.However
column44: GoPro declared plans to limit its adjusted operating expenses in 2017 to $600 million
column45: in an attempt to try to return to full-year profitability next year. This is comparable to a 2016 figure of about $709 million.GoPro should be able to attain these massive cost reductions
column46: in light of its recent business restructuring
column47: which did away with many high-cost operations including its entertainment division.It is likely that GoPro's sales will gradually improve as it ramps production and expands Karma's reach to international markets. This will supplement its cost-reduction initiatives and enable it to achieve sustained
column48: profitable growth.GoPro
column49: Inc. Price
column50: Consensus and EPS SurpriseGoPro
column51: Inc. Price

column54: the company has been grappling to achieve its earlier growth and go beyond its trademark action cameras. GoPro had earlier reduced its inventory of older legacy cameras
column55: in order to prepare for its new products. However
column56: what followed was more operational stumbles and messed-up products launches.The company has also been facing pressure to establish a more mainstream market for its cameras. However
column57: tough competition from smartphone brands such as Apple Inc.AAPLand Samsung Electronics Corp. has been making it difficult for the company.Despite all the problems that GoPro is straining under

column1: KLA-Tencor
column2: Iconix Brand Group and Amazon highlighted as Zacks Bull and Bear of the Day;2/3/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column3: IL - February 03
column4: 2017 -Zacks Equity ResearchhighlightsKLA-Tencor(NASDAQ:KLAC-Free Report) as the Bull of the Day andIconix BrandGroup (NASDAQ:ICON-Free Report) as the Bear of the Day. In addition
column5: Zacks Equity Research provides analysis onAmazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report).Here is a synopsis of all three stocks:Bull of the Day:KLA-Tencor(NASDAQ:KLAC-Free Report) recently beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate and then guided Wall Street higher which has sent estimate higher. This has caused the Zacks Rank to move up to a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) and today it is the Bull of the Day.The last several months have been very good ones to the semiconductor stocks. It looks like there is evidence that the run will continue if not pick up speed. Other high profile names have seen renewed interest from analysts as Artificial Intelligence
column6: Autonomous Driving
column7: and 3-D Virtual Reality concepts begin to move from beta into the mainstream. This is all good news for the chip industry.DescriptionKLAC is a semiconductor capital equipment company
column8: they make the equipment that will help the chip companies make their chips.Recent EarningsKLA Tencor beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.41 by $0.11 in posting earnings of $1.52. That translates into a positive earnings surprise of 7.8% marking the 10th straight beat of the Zacks Consensus Estimate.Guidance called for revenue of between $860M - $920M when the consensus estimate was calling for $849M. As the aggressive growth stock strategist at Zacks
column9: this is what I love to see. Also on the call
column10: management noted that they expect CY17 gross margin to be a ""couple hundred basis points"" better than previously expected.It world of beating and raising this stock has higher revenues and higher margins. Usually
column11: when that happens you see higher multiples. Speaking of multiples
column12: KLAC trades at 15.6x forward estimates and over the last two years the stock has traded between 13.2x and 17.8x. This tells me that the stock could go as high as $109 (17.8*6.17) if it trades at the high end of the range over the last two years.Room for Upgrades for KLACOne thing that I like to see is a stock that has room for future catalysts. KLAC has three brokerages that have ""Hold"" or equivalent ratings on the stock. Instinet is by far the most bearish of the three with a price target of $78 and a neutral rating. Stifel Nicolaus has a hold and a price target of $83. A few days after the most recent report Deutsche Bank reiterated their ""Hold"" on the stock and increased their price target from $78 to $85.Goldman Sachs
column13: Cowen and Company
column14: Credit Suise
column15: B. Riley and Needham all have KLAC at either ""Buy"" or ""Strong Buy"" or the equivalent. Of those
column16: B. Riley is the most bullish with a $106 price target and Needham is just a dollar behind at $105.The Big Tell for KLACOver the years I have picked up on the lingo for chip stocks. At first I learned all about book to bill and after that the focus became backlog. More recently I have picked up an even bigger tell than a stock with records billings or record backlog. The phrase that pays is ""design wins.""During the most recent conference call management spoke the phrase that pays when talking to 3D NAND. If there is anything that is as good as a design win
column17: I have yet to know what it is. This ensures some high margin business over the next 6 to 18 months
column18: and that alone should have the multiple for this stock increasing.Bear of the Day:Iconix BrandGroup (NASDAQ:ICON-Free Report) is a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) and it is the Bear of the Day. Let's take a look at why the stock is the Bear of the Day and if there are some trends that might help investors avoid other stocks that could become a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell).DescriptionICON is a brand management company. column1: Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Stock Is Going to Bounce;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhile the dithering dance continued in theS&P 500this week
column3: the energy sector was quietly raided by sellers. And therein lies opportunity. With heavy hitters likeExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) now resting near critical support levels
column4: the time for a bullish rebound is nigh. Let's take a deep dive into XOM stock and build a high-probability option trade to capitalize on its current setup.makeArticleAd();For starters
column5: the price trend for Exxon Mobil over the past six months has been … well
column6: trendless. Ever since the stock peaked in mid-July last year
column7: it has been mired in a trading range. As illustrated in the accompanying chart
column8: the $82 zone has become a significant support level halting each and every downturn.Click to EnlargeSource: OptionsAnalytixAnd guess what? The dastardly descent gripping XOM this year is now knocking on the door of this support level.Traders waiting for confirmation that buyers would defend their turf need wonder no longer. Yesterday's big hammer candle proved that the bulls are indeed willing to put up a fight. The beautiful thing about stock prices leaning against key support or resistance levels is the ability it provides traders to structure low-risk
column9: high-reward trades.7 Stocks to Sell as Fear Returns to the MarketFor example
column10: if we purchased XOM stock with a stop-loss just below $82
column11: then the risk per share is minimal. And if the mighty oil king travels even halfway to the top of its price range
column12: we're looking at a high-potential reward per share.How to Trade XOM Stock HereWhile equity traders could go with a straight stock purchase
column13: options traders can play XOM stock with a bit more finesse. If you're looking for a bit of an edge in your trade
column14: consider using the bull put strategy.Sell the XOM Mar $80 put for 78 cents while buying the Mar $77.50 put for 37 cents. The net credit received upon trade entry is the 41 cents and represents the maximum reward available. If Exxon stock sits above $80 at March expiration
column15: you will capture the gain.The max risk is limited to the distance between strikes minus the net credit
column16: or $2.09. You will lose this amount if XOM stock sits below $77.50 at expiration. To minimize the damage
column17: you could exit early if the stock falls below $80.As of this writing

column1: 3 Ways Shopify Is Like Amazon and 1 Key Difference;2/3/2017;"Image source: Shopify.commakeArticleAd();Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) has been a tremendous investment for shareholders.   Since the company went public in 1997
column2: its stock has grown over   54
column3: 000% and the company is now one of thetop five most valuable companiesby market capitalization. People are always looking for companies   that are set to succeed as well as Amazon has
column4: and that leads me   to Mark Twain
column5: who is credited with saying that ""history doesn't   repeat itself
column6: but it often rhymes.""Taking a Twain approach to finding the next Amazon-like   investment
column7: Shopify(NYSE: SHOP)  comes to the forefront as sharing three   success factors with Amazon while having one critical difference   that might put it at a disadvantage in terms of growing to   Amazon's size.SimilaritiesDifferenceFounder-led with long-term vision.Obsessed with customers' experience.Investing aggressively for growth.Shopify's total addressable market is much smaller             than Amazon's.Let's compare these three success factors and the one   difference to see how Amazon-like Shopify really is.Founder-led with long-term visionA founder can have a significant impact in shaping the culture   of a company. Jeff Bezos
column8: Amazon's CEO and founder
column9: did this   early in the company's history by emphasizing in his first letter   to shareholders his determination to have his company succeed   over the long term.We believe that a fundamental measure of our success will be     the shareholder value we create over the long term. This     value will be a direct result of our ability to extend     and solidify our current market leadership position. The     stronger our market leadership
column10: the more powerful our     economic model.Tobi Lutke
column11: Shopify's founder and CEO
column12: has a similar mandate.   Lutke's letter to shareholders in the company's 2015 public   filing declared long-term value more important than the short   term.In order to build long-term value
column13: we decided to forgo     short-term revenue opportunities and nurture the people who     were putting their trust in Shopify. ... This is a prime     example of how we approach value and something that potential     investors must understand: we do not chase revenue as the     primary driver of our business. ... we have always prioritized     long-term value over short-term revenue opportunities.Having the long-term view has paid off for Amazon and its   shareholders
column14: and it seems that Shopify has the same mindset.   Lutke boldly ended his letter to shareholders saying
column15: ""I want   Shopify to be a company that sees the next century."" How's that   for the long-term view?Obsessed with the customer experienceAs a longtime customer of Amazon
column16: I have seen the customer   experience get better and better. Enhancements in search
column17: ordering experience
column18: fulfillment
column19: account management
column20: and   surprise extras seem commonplace. This is not by accident. Bezos   used the phrase ""obsess over customers"" in his first shareholder   letter and he has not relented on his passion for pleasing   customers. He includes the original 1997 shareholder letter every   year in Amazon's annual report.Similarly
column21: Shopify understands its success is tied to the   success of its customers. Whereas Amazon's customers are   consumers
column22: Shopify's customers are merchants selling their goods   on Shopify's e-commerce platform. Like Amazon
column23: the idea of   customer focus has been core to Shopify from the beginning. Lutke   has a letter on the Shopify investor home page where he describes   Shopify's focus on the customer. It says in part:Shopify is exactly this: the only platform you need to build     your empire. Shopify is the first thing our merchants log into     in the morning and the last thing they log out of in the     evening. It's at the heart of their business -- a     responsibility that we take very seriously. ... our job is to     make our merchants look their very best in every interaction     they have with consumers.Shopify's success is aligned with the success of its   customers. When Shopify's customers are successful
column24: Shopify makes   more money in subscription and transaction fees. Shopify has   provided significant resources to help its clients run successful   e-commerce businesses
column25: including company-facilitated   customer meet-ups
column26: a user community
column27: video how-to guides
column28: a   podcast
column29: and even a directory of Shopify experts that merchants   can use for almost any aspect of e-commerce   business. Lastly
column30: even if the core Shopify platform doesn't   meet your needs
column31: Shopify hosts an app store with over 1
column32: 500   apps.  Shopify's relentless focus on the customer continues   today. Lutke mentioned in the most recent earnings release: ""Our   accomplishments over the last few months support the strategy we   have made clear from the beginning
column33: which is to do the things   that help merchants succeed""Shopify scores a checkmark in the first two Amazon keys to   success. Let's look at the third success factor and how Shopify   shares a similar aggressive investment strategy with the   e-commerce and could-computing titan.Investing aggressively to growAmazon didn't report a profit until 2003
column34: which was six long   years after going public. The reason Amazon didn't post a profit   was because it was investing heavily to grow its business.Amazon has continued to invest in its business and this   impacted the company's most recent quarter. Amazon cited   investments in fulfillment centers
column35: digital content
column36: international growth
column37: Alexa/Echo
column38: and AWS asreasons for lower profit in Q3.Shopify hasn't posted a profit as long as it's been reporting   results publicly. But
column39: as I noted inthis article
column40: Shopify's core business has healthy gross margins and could be   profitable if it weren't investing heavily in growth   initiatives. In Shopify's filing to go public
column41: Shopify   provided detail about these investments including:Marketing activities.Expanding partner referral programs.Research and development to introduce new products and     services.Maintaining a high level of merchant service and     support.Data center and network infrastructure.In its most recent earnings call Chief Financial Officer Russ   Jones directly linked these investments to Shopify's ability to   continue grow.... we believe the primary reason we will continue to gain     share of this growing pie is ... our strategic focus on     merchant success. This means continually reevaluating the     platform capabilities necessary for merchants to thrive at     every stage of growth and also investing in the partnerships     and projects that we believe will help future-proof their     success.Shopify scores a win on all three of these Amazon success   factors
column42: but there's one important difference between Amazon and   Shopify that investors need to keep in mind.Total addressable marketImage source: Amazon.comAmazon's logo has an arrow starting at the ""a"" in its name and   going to the ""z""
column43: which is a subtle reminder that Amazon wants to   make its website the place consumers go to buy just about   anything.While Shopify is an e-commerce business like Amazon
column44: Shopify   doesn't sell goods to consumers. Shopify provides a suite of   e-commerce tools to enable entrepreneurs and small-business   owners to start and run an e-commerce business quickly and   simply. Shopify makes money from subscription fees from these   business owners and transaction fees when they sell goods over   the Shopify platform.Retail e-commerce is estimated to reach more than $4 trillion   in the next few years
column45: giving Amazon a huge total addressable   market (TAM). Shopify's TAM is more modest. Shopify provided TAM   details about the small and medium business (SMB) market it   serves in the company's filing to go public.... we focus on selling to SMBs. We have merchants in     approximately 150 countries... According to AMI Partners
column47: there were approximately 10 million merchants with less     than 500 employees operating in our key geographies
column48: and     approximately 46 million such merchants worldwide.At the time
column49: Shopify estimated that its annualized revenue per   merchant was about $1
column50: 000. Given that as a baseline
column51: Shopify's   total addressable market in its key geographies would be $10   billion
column52: and worldwide would be $46 billion. Shopify goes on to   say that its market will expand as more entrepreneurs start   businesses and as Shopify gains more revenue per merchant. Given   that Shopify's trailing-12-month revenue is $329 million
column53: Shopify   still has plenty of room to grow.Shopify looks and acts a lot like Amazon
column54: and that's a really   good thing for investors. Despite the difference in the   companies' total addressable markets
column55: investors should be excited   about Shopify's Amazon-like traits in the large and growing   e-commerce marketplace.10 stocks we like better than ShopifyWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column56: it can pay to listen. After all
column57: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column58: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column59: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Shopify wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column60: 2017Brian Withersowns shares of Amazon.com
column61: and Shopify. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Amazon.com and Shopify. The Motley     Fool has adisclosure policy."

column2: Inc. (MRK) Stock: The Long-Awaited Breakout?;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsShares of global pharmaceutical companyMerck & Co.
column4: Inc.(NYSE:MRK) rallied 3.35% on Thursday on the back of its latest quarterly financial results. MRK stock has largely been trotting sideways since August of last year despite two breakout attempts to the upside and a couple of scares of breaking down.makeArticleAd();Hastily chasing stocks higher before they show clear chart breakouts is a sure way to lose money in them markets
column5: but Thursday's price action in Merck stock is worth giving the benefit of the doubt.For its fourth quarter
column6: Merck earned 42 cents per share - a notable improvement over the 35 cents it earned in the same period a year ago. The company's financial guidance for fiscal year 2017 was roughly in line
column7: and I for one couldn't detect any major outstandingly positives nor negatives in the report. However
column8: sales of the company's Keytrude cancer drug looked strong.I often say that when it comes to the stock market
column9: one can learn a lot by just watching. That breakout attempt by MRK stock on Thursday might be telling us more than the financial results did.When Ilast discussed shares of Merck on Jan. 4
column10: I pointed to the previous day's bullish reversal and offered that a next upside target around the $62 could soon come to fruition. A few days later
column11: MRK reached this upside price target.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryUntil yesterday
column12: Feb. 2
column13: the stock then mostly pushed sideways.MRK Stock ChartsLooking at Merck through a long-term lens
column14: we see that the area around $62-$64 has been serving as significant technical resistance for the stock since the early 2000s.Click to EnlargeFrom this perspective
column15: we can see that MRK stock has been consolidating below this area of resistance once again since last summer. This could be a coiling-up before ultimately breaking higher in a more meaningful way.On the daily chart
column16: we see this sideways move since last summer in more detail. Note the two breakout fake-out attempts last October and again in November.Click to EnlargeOn Jan. 3
column17: MRK stock bounced off its 200-day simple moving average (red) after marginally closing below it the previous day. Yesterday's rally served as a second leg higher following the Jan. 3 rally. It also marginally pushed the stock out of the blue box on the chart
column18: but not yet above the two aforementioned breakout fake-out highs from last fall.Buy Amazon.com
column19: Inc. column1: Here’s Why I Still Like Chevron Corporation (CVX) Stock;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsChevron Corporation(NYSE:CVX) made headlines last week as the first major oil company to report fourth-quarter earnings. But while the company swung to profitability thanks to higher revenue and lower costs
column3: 2016's depressed oil prices kept the numbers well below what Wall Street had been steeled to expect.makeArticleAd();Source:swong95765 via Flickr (Modified)Let's take a closer look. On the one hand
column4: earnings of 22 cents a share were a nice improvement from last year's loss of 31 cents a share.On the other
column5: consensus estimates were for 64 cents a share. Revenue grew more than 7.5% to $31.5 billion
column6: but that was still below analysts' expectations of $33.3 billion.The weakness was largely the result of one-time charges CVX incurred in the quarter
column7: which totaled $872 million. However
column8: the company does not adjust its results to account for that.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryCVX lost 27 cents a share in the full year
column9: which CEO John Watson attributed to the low oil and gas prices the industry experienced in 2016. He also said that the company cut costs by $14 billion last year
column10: which has it positioned to improve results this year. Full-year revenue came in at $114.47 billion.Looking ahead
column11: management indicated that they were considering further asset sales as well as cutting their capital budget again should prices remain depressed. Results may have been short when looking at the specific numbers
column12: but everyone was well aware that they would be impacted by the low oil and gas prices in 2016.Why Amazon.com
column13: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Will NEVER Be About P/EWhile the stock closed the day of its report down 2.4% and has continued drifting since
column14: I still like this stock as a longer-term investment on higher oil prices. It's also a great income holding.CVX has dipped below its 50-day moving average
column15: but I like that it remains solidly above the 200-day
column16: which is a level it's held since March 2016. I think the selling is overdone at this point
column17: and the stock's sizable 3.8% dividend yield only adds to its attractiveness in the wait for higher prices.Curious what Wall Street insider Charles Payne really thinks?Get more behind-the-scenes insights
column18: valuable market research and hands-on guidance including live stock recommendations from Fox Business's rising star. column1: Stock Exchange: Navigation Help For The Challenging Trump Waters;2/3/2017;"ByJeff Miller:Our lastStock Exchange(two weeks ago) discussed diverse ideas from our experts
column2: and also explained why I vetoed one of the recommendations. When trading using models
column3: you can link directly to a platform if you do many trades and have a very short time frame. Otherwise
column4: you should not blindly follow the model. A human who understands the factors used by the model can identify when a situation is truly exceptional.The current market environment is all about Trump - perhaps excessively so. Everyone worries about what companies are vulnerable to a tweet (which we will call aT-WOP
column5: HT @corporatecommie). Each day includes more speculation about companies that might benefit from policy changes.How should traders find a sweet spot in this environment?makeArticleAd();This week includes both new ideas and reviews of some past highlights. Everyone can benefit from finding the trading model most relevant for your own style.Let's look at the ideas from our experts. As usual
column6: I will conclude with a brief observation.Getting UpdatesWe have a new (free) service to subscribers to our Felix/Oscar update list. You can suggest three favorite stocks and sectors. We report regularly on the ""favorite fifteen"" in each category - stocks and sectors - as determined by readers. Sign up with email to ""etf at newarc dot com."" Suggestions and comments are welcome. In the tables below

column9: and red a ""sell."" Each category represents about 1/3 of the underlying universe. Please remember that these are responses to reader requests
column10: not necessarily stocks and sectors that we own. Sign up now to vote your favorite stock or sector onto the list!This Week-Finding Your Trading Sweet SpotHolmesThis week I'm buying good ol' U.S.A. Macys (M). This stock probably needs no introduction - Main Street retail store.This chart strikes me as a great money-making opportunity. My major concern is that this stock keeps making lower lows

It's a little comforting to know that there are 18 analyst holds on this stock and their target price is STILL $36. That is consistent with what the charts are telling me.I'm buying here with a tight stop
column14: and looking for a move back into the mid-$30s

column16: but mostly to reaffirm your existing biases.J: I am delighted that our clients caught this at a lower price
column17: but do you realize the stock was up over $1.50 today?H: No. I am enjoying the beach in Mexico. I sent in my pick

column19: and it is still a good buy.J: There is a rumor of a possible takeover. Did you know about that?H: No. I just know a great rebound chart when I see one.J: Are you going to have any trouble returning from Mexico? We do not have the fresh

column23: I seem to remember that you said the pick was OK

That did not do so well. My approach is geared to the long term

column1: 4 Stocks That Are NOT Driven by the Trump Trade;2/3/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAnyone who has been watching the markets for the past two months knows the far-reaching impact President Trump has had on stocks
column3: bonds and currencies. Stock indices soared to all-time highs
column4: bond prices dropped to 52-week lows and the value of the U.S. dollar climbed to highs last seen during the financial crisis.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockIf it seems like all sectors of the market were touched by the election
column5: they were. President Trump's campaign promises
column6: if enacted
column7: have the ability to reach every corner of the stock market.His promised changes to the business tax code would impact every business. His promised changes to the personal income tax code would impact nearly every consumer. His promised infrastructure spending would increase inflation for the entire nation. His promised changes to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) would impact nearly every employee. His promised relaxing of government regulations would affect nearly every employer. The list goes on and on.Looking at the market through this lens
column8: there is not a company or stock that will not be impacted in some way by the Trump presidency. However
column9: not all companies will be impacted to the same extent. Some companies are more vulnerable - for good or bad - to the promised policy changes than others.For instance
column10: large banks and other financial institutions - likeGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS) - have been the unrivaled beneficiaries of a Trump presidency up to this point
column11: because so many of the president's suggested changes benefit the banks' bottom lines. Rising inflation
column12: lower corporate taxes and decreased regulation all benefit the banks.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryConversely
column13: biotech companies - likeBiogen Inc(NASDAQ:BIIB) - have struggled in the aftermath of the presidential election because the uncertainty swirling around what will eventually replace the ACA after the Republican-controlled Congress repeals it
column14: coupled with the pointedTwitter Inc(NYSE:TWTR) and interview criticisms President Trump has issued regarding the high price of pharmaceuticals and other medical treatments
column15: has created a tremendous amount of uncertainty in the healthcare industry.So which companies are less vulnerable to the potential policy changes and political whims of the president?While it's important to note that no company is immune from the potential threat of a targeted Twitter tirade from the president should it happen to draw his ire
column16: there does seem to be a group of stocks that could bullishly go on its merry way during the first half of 2017 without having to look over its shoulder every morning to see if some new policy decision may threaten to derail its progress: the ""FANG"" stocks.The FANG stocks -Facebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column17: Amazon.com
column18: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column19: Netflix(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column20: NASDAQ:GOOGL) [formerly Google
column21: hence the ""G""]  - have been Wall Street darlings for the past few years. The shift consumers have made to living in an online world for everything from their social networking to shopping has pushed the valuation of these companies ever higher as traders bet on this trend continuing
column22: regardless of what else happens in the economy.The FANG stocks took an initial hit after the results of the presidential election were announced in early November
column23: as traders started taking profits on some of their more lucrative positions and rotating that money into the financial sector and other sectors that were poised to rally following President Trump's win. Nobody was doubting the strength of the FANG stocks - they just needed to free up cash to invest in even hotter stocks at the time.Once the initial rotation was complete
column24: investors started coming back to the FANG stocks
column25: which were then trading at much more favorable valuations
column26: and started buying them up. After all
column27: whatever happens to inflation
column28: whatever happens with the tax code
column29: whatever happens with health care
column30: consumers are going to continue connecting with friends on Facebook
column31: buying more stuff on Amazon
column32: watching videos on Netflix and searching for information on Google.Why Amazon.com
column33: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Should Expect Fireworks SoonWe expect the FANG stocks and other tech stocks like them - stocks likeApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) andNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) - to continue to do well during the next few months. We will certainly have to keep watching what the Trump administration does in the future (watching the net neutrality debate is going to be especially important for NFLX)
column34: but the traders on Wall Street aren't going to abandon their perpetual winners just yet.InvestorPlace advisors John Jagerson and S. Wade Hansen
column35: both Chartered Market Technician (CMT) designees
column36: are co-founders of LearningMarkets.com
column37: as well as the co-editors ofSlingShot Trader
column38: a trading service designed to help you make options profits by trading the news. Get in on the next trade and get 1 free month todayby clicking here.More From InvestorPlace5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak February10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThe post4 Stocks That Are NOT Driven by the Trump Tradeappeared first onInvestorPlace."
