Image source: Wal-Mart.What does each company offer?All three major retailers offer some sort of free shipping.   Here's a look at the standard offers from Wal-Mart

column17: though not every item is eligible.Amazon: The online retailer clearly wants people to join     Prime as its free shipping offer for those not in Prime     requires purchases of either $25 in books or $49 of eligible     items that are ""delivered 5-8 business days after all of your     items are available to ship

Wal-Mart simply was not going to get mass buy-in to a $50-a-year   free two-day shipping membership program when Amazon Prime   already has an estimated 65 million U.S. members. column1: Why Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Should Expect Fireworks Soon;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhether you love the company or hate it
column4: there's no denyingAmazon.com
column5: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) is the 800 pound gorilla in the retail room … online
column6: or offline. Although a true market share figure would be impossible to pinpoint
column7: without a doubt
column8: Amazon is the name all other players fear the most
column9: and try to mimic.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe company is slated to remind the market on Thursday exactly why AMZN stock is up more than 2000% over the course of the past ten years.Or
column10: perhaps Thursday's post-close announcement will keep some observers wondering how this minimally profitable (until very recently) organization manages to consistently draw such a bullish crowd.Whatever the case
column11: fireworks Thursday evening will easily carry through into Friday morning.Amazon Earnings OutlookAs of the latest look
column12: Amazon is expected to report a profit of $1.41 per share for its fourth fiscal quarter of last year
column13: on revenue of $44.84 billion. The company earned $1.00 per share of AMZN stock in the same quarter a year earlier
column14: when it reported $35.75 billion worth of revenue.Amazon is headed into its quarterly earnings announcement with its usual impressive revenue-growth momentum. What's relatively new is growing profits per share of Amazon stock. Over the course of the last four quarters
column15: AMZN has earned $4.36 per share. That's the best profitability the company has ever seen
column16: and assuming Amazon has indeed turned a profit in its fourth quarter
column17: 2016 will mark the first year the organization has posted a positive bottom line in every quarter of the year.7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeIt's not Amazon.com's e-commerce business that's pushing the company to such profitability though. While its foreign and domestic e-tailing operations are growing
column18: Amazon Web Services is driving a big chunk of the top line's growth
column19: and the bulk of the company's profit growth.Case in point: During the third quarter
column20: Amazon Web Services turned $3.2 billion in revenue (up 74% yoy) into operating income of $861 million. E-commerce sales were up 27% year-over-year
column21: and lost money on an operating basis when factoring in the international arm's loss.Look for more of the same leadership from AWS going forward.Amazon Stock: Three Things to Chew OnAmazon reliably has several pet projects on its plate
column22: and shifts in its respective markets consistently pose new threats to its growth. At any given time though
column23: there are only three matters that really work for or against AMZN stock. Thursday's top hot buttons are the following:Delivery ServicesAmazon'sentry into the package delivery gamewas largely cheered by owners of Amazon stock. The move puts the company in charge of its own destiny
column24: and may well save on shipping costs. And just this week
column25: AMZN announced it would beestablishing a major air freight hub in Kentucky.Yet
column26: it was also this week thatUnited Parcel Service
column27: Inc.(NYSE:UPS) told us the advent of so many at-home deliveries driven by theongoing rise of e-commerce(Amazon's core business) is a tough way to make a buck. Amazon may not like what it gets when it starts handling more of its delivery work.Real Cash FlowIt has been a point of contention - particularly for accountants - because it somewhat obscures the true health of AMZN's cash flow. Given how big the numbers are getting though
column28: Amazon stock owners may want to get a grip on the idea.Long story made short
column29: the costs associated with purchasing and managing all the servers needed to operate Amazon Web Services are being booked as capital leases rather than capital expenditures. This means payment for these leases isn't deducted before calculating free cash flow … one of the metrics that's enamored so many new investors. It's not ""wrong"" per se
column30: but it's worth understanding.More Competitive CompetitionFinally
column31: this week
column32: rivalWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) announced it was scrapping its membership-based free shipping scheme and insteadsimplified its online-shopping offer to free shipping for any order over $35.00.Can Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Jump Over These Hurdles?One new tactic from Wal-Mart won't rattle Amazon
column33: but Wal-Mart's move is just a microcosm of a bigger theme. Everyone is collectively taking aim at Amazon.com
column34: and sooner or later
column35: enough of those competitors will hit the target.Bottom Line for AMZN StockAMZN shares were up 17% in 2016
column36: and have gained 170% since the end of 2014 primarily because the market saw how potent AWS was going to be. Amazon Web Services can only do the heavy lifting for so long though. Sooner or later
column37: e-commerce has to help out.And the fourth quarter's report could very easily be the one that prods such a change of heart.See
column38: expectations are low - analysts are only a calling a profit of $1.41 per share for AMZN stock. On the surface it seems like an easy target to top
column39: but if traders have reason to see the glass as half-empty rather than half-full after Thursday's close
column40: nothing can be ruled out. Sometimes the market will punish a mere meet of lackluster estimates. (And if nothing else
column41: investors may be ready to take some profits.)On the other hand
column42: most of thepost-earnings responsesAMZN has made in recent quarters were bullish ones. This is one of those names investors love to love.As of this writing
column43: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThe postWhy Amazon.com
column44: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Should Expect Fireworks Soonappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: The 3 Worst-Performing Stocks in January;2/1/2017;"Cold winds may blow in January
column2: but stocks tend to get awfully   hot in the first month of the year. The so-called ""January   effect"" is the phenomenon of stocks jumping higher supposedly in   response to the tax-loss selling that occurs in December as   investors seek to offset realized capital gains during the   year.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();While January this year hasn't exactly been a barn burner --   theS&P 500is only up about 2.5% for the month -- there are actually a few   stocks that haven't enjoyed similar gains. Or any at all
column3: for   that matter. In fact
column4: of the 25 worst-performing stocks in   January
column5: three of them were well-known clothing retailers.Kohl's: Down 19.6%Almost all ofKohl's(NYSE: KSS) losses occurred on one day at the beginning of the   month when the retail sector revealed just how bad the Christmas   shopping season was. As brick-and-mortar retailers continue to   struggle against theAmazoneffect -- a much more powerful force than the January effect
column6: depending upon the business you're in -- Kohl's proved to be theworst of the bunch
column7: plunging 19% all at once.Image source: Flickr via Mike Mozart.The retailer said its comparable sales fell 2.1% in November   and December
column8: leading to a 2.7% drop in total sales
column9: a result   that was exacerbated by its closing down numerous stores. But the   department store operator was forced to cut its full-year   earnings guidance substantially because of the poor showing
column10: and   told investors they could now anticipate its adjusted earnings to   come in between $3.60 and $3.65 per share compared to its   previous guidance of range of $3.80 to $4.00 per share.Although the stock has mostly stabilized after the fall
column11: it   still is trending south
column12: making January a very chilly month for   Kohl's.J.C. Penney: Down 21.2%Like Kohl's
column13: the kickoff to the new year wasn't kind toJ.C. Penney(NYSE: JCP)
column14: either. While the Christmas update wasn't very   flattering for the department store chain
column15: it wasn't hit nearly   as bad as its peer -- the stock only fell about 6% that day --   but that might be because J.C. Penney had been falling since   early December and the market wasn't expecting much good news   from it anyway.Image source: The Motley Fool.Still
column16: even though it survived the early January carnage that   took down rivals likeMacy's(down 14% in one day)
column17: Nordstrom(down 10%)
column18: andL Brands(down 9%)
column19: J.C. Penney has continued to fall throughout the month   as it becomes increasingly doubtful the retailer will be able to   live up to CEO Marvin Ellison's promise to turn a profit for   2016. Comparable sales haven't been nearly as robust as   originally predicted -- even after they were revised down -- and   with comps turning negative during November and December
column20: the   picture is looking bleak.Tailored Brands: Down 23.8%""Easy come

column22: which saw shares get a big boost in December after   it seemed the turnaround at its Jos. A. Bank brand was finally   gaining traction

column24: and while that would normally be considered a   disaster for any other company
column25: it was a big improvement for the   men's suits retailer that had been regularly reporting comps   falling 20% or more for several quarters. The better results led   the retailer to raise earnings guidance for the year.Image source: Getty Images.Although there was no specific news that caused Tailored   Brands to start falling again
column26: the general malaise of the retail   sector coupled with its own internal weaknesses may have led to   the steady decline in its shares. Moreover

column1: 3 Top Big Brand Stocks to Buy Now;1/31/2017;"When it comes to stocks
column2: bigger is not always better.Sometimes name recognition works against a company
column3: in that   some investors happily buy shares in companies they've heard of.   That's the stock market equivalent of when novice horse racing   fans bet aggressively on a contender based solely on the horse's   name. You don't want your investment thesis to be the equivalent   of someone placing $2 to win on a horse named ""Can't Possibly   Lose.""It's not that the horse is a bad horse or that a share of a   popular company always means you shouldn't buy it. Instead
column4: when   making either choice
column5: you want to ignore the name and look at the   fundamentals. Whether you're asking ""Does this horse have what it   takes to win the race?"" or ""Does this company have what it needs   for long-term success?"" -- that's what you need to examine.makeArticleAd();The three companies here are all big brands -- names you most   certainly know. They're also companies with the building blocks   in place to move even higher. While they aren't bargains
column6: they're   long-term buy-and-hold stocks that are poised for steady
column7: strong   growth.Amazon's Alexa-enabled Echo and Dot are creating a new     business for the company. Image source: Amazon.com.Amazon has become something moreThere was a timeAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) was mostly an online bookstore. It then became a   marketplace that eventually started selling pretty much   everything
column8: and then it became that plus a company that dabbled   in devices. Now
column9: with the success of the company's cloud business   and its rapidly growing Echo/Alexa platform
column10: the online retailer   has become a three-headed monster.At the end of Q3
column11: the company had seen its year-to-date   product sales grow by over $10 billion
column12: from $52.65 billion in   the first nine months of 2015 to $64.03 billion during that   period in 2016. In addition
column13: the company has increased its   service revenue -- mostly its Amazon Web Services cloud business   -- from $18.6 billion over three quarters in 2015 to $28.2   billion through nine months of 2016
column14: another nearly $10 billion   improvement.The company doesn't break down numbers for its device sales
column15: but the Echo
column16: powered by the company's Alexa artificial   intelligence
column17: has been a breakout hit that has essentially   created a new category forcing nearly all the major tech players   to launch rival products. CEO Jeff Bezos didn't go into exact   numbers
column18: but he did share some info on Echo/Alexa's success in   theQ3 earnings release.Alexa may be Amazon's most loved invention yet -- literally     -- with over 250
column19: 000 marriage proposals from customers and     counting. And she's just getting better. Because Alexa's brain     is in the cloud
column20: we can easily and continuously add to her     capabilities and make her more useful.Bezos might be using humor to illustrate a point
column21: but Alexa   goes beyond just selling devices for the company. It's an entry   into home automation and a synergistic opportunity for Amazon to   sell more products
column22: music subscriptions
column23: and anything else as it   becomes embedded in consumers' kitchens and living rooms.Starbucks has a new way to grow revenueStarbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX) shares dipped after the company reported its Q1   earnings. Investors reacted to same-store sales in the United   States coming in below expectations. COO and incoming CEO Kevin   Johnson talked about how that happened in part because Mobile   Order & Pay created congestion at the front of stores
column24: where   people wait to pick up their order
column25: causing some people to walk   away without ordering anything.The Starbucks Roastery in Seattle may be the model for a new     business. Image source: Starbucks.That particular problem is a logistical blip the company can   easily solve in coming quarters. It's more important that   Starbucks has trained its customers to use the digital system   that takes people out of line
column26: allowing for more workers behind   the limited counter space to focus on drink production rather   than order-taking. In the long run -- once the logistics get   solved -- that lets stores serve more customers
column27: increasing sales   potential.In addition to having technology that should help the company   grow over the long term
column28: Starbucks also had some strong results   that show it can succeed with its premium Roastery/Reserve brand.   Sales at the Starbucks Roastery in Seattle grew by 24% in 2016   over the previous year and were up another 18% in Q1 2017. CEO   Howard Schultz attributed that to an average ticket that comes in   at four times what a typical customer spends in a regular   store.Our decision to aggressively but thoughtfully and     strategically expand our portfolio of Roasteries is supported     by the one-of-a-kind
column29: ultra-premium Reserve experience our     Roasteries deliver to our customers
column30: and the accelerating     outperformance against plan we are experiencing in our Seattle     Roastery.The company plans to expand on that opportunity by opening   Roasteries in Shanghai in 2017
column31: followed by New York in 2018
column32: Tokyo that same year
column33: and a not-yet-picked European city after   that. The chain also plans to open 1
column34: 000 or more premium Reserve   stores around the world and add Reserve bars to a   not-yet-determined number of stores. These new formats
column35: along   with Starbucks' ability to leverage technology to make its stores   more efficient
column36: should lead to increased growth   opportunities.Netflix has room to grow globallyWhile Starbucks and Amazon's growth potential takes some   explaining
column37: Netflix's(NASDAQ: NFLX) doesn't. The company has shown staggering growth   over the past year
column38: adding 7.05 million global subscribers in Q4
column39: following over 12 million added in the previous three quarters.   Only 4.69 million of those came from the U.S.
column40: which
column41: with 49.43   million of the company's 93.8 million total global membership
column42: has become a mature market.Netflix CEO Reed Hastings explained during the company's   fourth-quarter earnings call that the streaming leader has become   stronger as it has grown its library.Netflix keeps adding to its lineup of original content.     Image source: Netflix.Think of it as it's a cumulative effect. Very few people     will join Netflix just because of a single title. But there's a     tipping point. We have one more title that has great     excitement
column43: you're hearing a lot about
column44: and that triggers you     to finally sign up for Netflix.Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos expanded on what Hastings   said. He explained that as time goes on and new originals are   added
column45: the appeal of the product becomes stronger.We have multiple seasons of our shows
column46: and we see that the     audience continues to build cumulatively and therefore the     excitement for the upcoming season builds as well. So
column47: in Q2 of     this year
column48: we have new seasons of a lot of our very popular     shows
column49: likeOrange Is the New Black
column50: Kimmy Schmidt
column51: Bloodline
column52: Sense8
column53: Master of None
column54: and we think that they should have a pretty nice impact on     our subscriber growth as well.Because Netflix's biggest draw is its own content -- an asset   it owns -- the company's appeal only gets stronger as time goes   on. That means that not only will holdouts eventually have so   much they want to watch they succumb and join
column55: but existing   members also won't be tempted to leave.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column1: Is Voice Search an Opportunity or a Threat to Google?;1/31/2017;"Image source: Google.Consumers are doing more and more web searches just by   talking. And they're not just asking the digital assistants on   their smartphones; they're also buying all-new devices
column2: such as   theAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) Echo and Google Home
column3: to answer random   queries.makeArticleAd();For Google
column4: the subsidiary ofAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOGL) (NASDAQ: GOOG)
column5: the new trend in search is a   double-edged sword. On one hand
column6: it provides another point for   users to interact with its product. On the other
column7: Google doesn't   have a stranglehold on the device market
column8: and it isn't clear how   companies can monetize voice search with ads.Even as Google navigated the shift to mobile
column9: it still   fundamentally followed the same business model -- display ads   within search results. That's not possible with voice   searches.But Google CEO Sundar Pichai isn't concerned. ""I see more   opportunity than challenge
column10: when I think about voice search
column11: he   told analysts on the company's fourth-quarter earnings call. I   wouldn't be so sure he doesn't have that backward.Losing the hardware battleGoogle didn't provide any exact figures on the sales of its   new Google Home device. Pichai did say that ""Google Home was a   very popular present that many people opened on Christmas   morning
column12: but that was as detailed as he got.RBC analyst Mark Mahaney suggests that Google is getting   outsold 10-to-1 by competitors such as Amazon Echo. That presents   a real challenge for Google
column13: because without control over the   hardware
column14: it has no control over the user interface. That means   all those potential voice searches will go to someone else.Pichai points out that it's the very early days for devices   such as Google Home. And Google does have one big advantage over   Amazon and other competitors -- it's much better at search. ""When   I look at what it would take to voice search well
column15: our years of   progress we have done in areas like natural language processing   comes into play
column16: Pichai said on the call. To his credit
column17: Google Home has outperformed Alexain manyhead-to-head searchreviews.But smart-speaker hardware is about more than search
column18: and   Amazon's Echo is capable of integrating with more devices and   services than Google Home is. Google is certainly capable of   overcoming that through more strategic partnerships
column19: though. It   just released a development kit for businesses to integrate with   Google Home last month.One area that will be harder to overcome is how well Amazon   Echo works for Amazon Prime members. With tens of millions of   Prime members around the world
column20: it creates a pretty big moat for   Google Home to cross.But wait -- it gets tougherEven if Google closes the gap in hardware sales
column21: it still has   to find a way to turn voice search into a business. Hardware   sales won't move the needle for Alphabet
column22: which generated over   $90 billion in revenue last year.What's more
column23: Google has to sell the hardware near cost because   its biggest competitor
column24: Amazon
column25: does the same. The margins on a   Google Home device don't even come close to Google's 31%   operating margin in the fourth quarter.If Google is going to make some real money off of voice   search
column26: it needs to go beyond just getting its devices into   people's homes. Google's best idea so far is tofacilitate commerce through voice search. But if there's one company that has Google's number in   e-commerce search
column27: it's Amazon. Google will not win a battle   against Amazon in developing a personal shopping assistant
column28: no   matter how good its search capabilities are.Not just a challenge -- a threatThe growth of voice isn't just a challenge for Google. The   shift to voice represents a threat
column29: as it could result in a   decline in the amount consumers use Google search
column30: the company's   cash cow.Google is working to overcome the head start Amazon got in   smart speakers
column31: which accelerated the voice search trend. It   plans to expand its hardware lineup and invest more in 2017. But   as voice search continues growing and starts taking searches away   from mobile and desktop
column32: it will put pressure on Google to   continue developing new higher-value display and search ads for   its main desktop and mobile products.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A   shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column33: it can pay to listen. After all
column34: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column36: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares) wasn't   one of them! column1: Walmart ShippingPass to Be Replaced by Free Two-Day Shipping;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWal-Mart Stores Inc(NYSE:WMT) is replacing Shipping Pass with free two-day shipping.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrWalmart will now allow customers to select free two-day shipping for items being sent to stores or their homes. Items that are being sent to customers' home must be part of an order that is at least $35. This is a drop from the previous $50 minimum for free home delivery.The free two-day shipping that Walmart of offering to customers ordering online is available without a membership. Items that are eligible for the offer include electronics
column3: food
column4: cleaning supplies and more. It doesn't include freight and marketplace items.With the introduction of free two-day shipping for customers

column1: Amazon Under Attack As Walmart Rolls Out Free Two-Day Shipping For Everyone;1/31/2017;"USA Todayhas some more detail on the move:Upping the ante in the shipping wars
column2: Walmart is scrapping a     subscription program that gave members free two-day delivery in     order to make the service available to all of its customers     starting Tuesday.There's only one catch: shoppers must meet a minimum order   size requirement to qualify for free shipping:makeArticleAd();Walmart customers shopping for items ranging from pet food     to peanut butter will be able to get those items delivered to     their homes within two days at no extra cost for a minimum     purchase of $35. If they have the products delivered to a local     store
column3: customers don't need to meet a spending threshold.Walmart had previously been testing a pilot program called   Shipping Pass
column4: which cost $49 a year for unlimited free two-day   shipping. That service was clearly Walmart's answer to Amazon   Prime
column5: which currently costs $10.99 a month for unlimited two-day   shipping
column6: along with a large host of other benefits including   streaming video
column7: music
column8: and Prime-exclusive products.WMT has decided to do away with the program
column9: however
column10: and   instead roll out free shipping for everyone without a   subscription fee. Customers that signed up for Shipping Pass will   have their membership costs refunded.It'll be interesting to see if and how Amazon responds to the   change. It's unlikely the company will offer free two-day   shipping outside of its Prime model
column11: as the company instead   offers free non-Prime five-day shipping on many of its items.Historically
column12: AMZN prefers to add significant value to the   Prime service rather than compete on price. In that vein
column13: perhaps   we'll see a corresponding announcement from CEO Jeff Bezos soon   about a new Prime account feature
column14: because this announcement from   Walmart is certainly significant enough to warrant a strong   response.Amazon.com

column19: Wal-Mart Stores Inc (NYSE:WMT)was trading at $66.20 per share on Tuesday morning
column20: down $0.22   (-0.33%). Year-to-date
column21: WMT has declined -4.22%."

column1: Will Amazon.com (AMZN) Disappoint this Earnings Season?;1/31/2017;"Amazon.comAMZNwill report fourth-quarter 2016 earnings on Feb 2 after the bell.The company has a Zacks Rank #5 (Strong Sell) and anEarnings ESPof -2.13%. You can uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they're reported with ourEarnings ESP Filter.Per our proven model
column2: a stock needs to have both a positive Earnings ESP and a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)
column3: 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold) to beat estimates. We don't recommend Sell-rated stocks (Zacks Rank #4 or #5) going into the earnings announcement.Amazon's earnings surprise history hasn't been much impressive as the company missed estimates in two of the last four quarters.Over the last one year
column4: the stock has however outperformed the Zacks Electronic Commerce industry. It has gained 44.46% compared with the industry's gain of 41.77%.What Happened in the Last Reported QuarterInternational/North America/AWS Mix:The North America segment accounted for around 58% of sales
column5: representing a sequential and year-over-year increase of 6.8% and 25.8%
column6: respectively. The International segment accounted for 32%
column7: up 7.8% sequentially and 28.3% year over year.  The AWS segment was up 12% sequentially and a massive 55% year over year with revenue share at nearly 10%.Prime:Amazon continued adding new features and benefits for Prime members.The company rolled out Prime exclusive original TV shows
column8: movies and music streaming services. It introduced Twitch Prime (Prime benefits for gamers)
column9: Prime Reading (Prime exclusive free reading service)
column10: Audible Channels (free
column11: unlimited short-form digital audio service) and added new features to Prime Photo service.Heavy investments:Amazon's third quarter earnings miss was primarily due to a spike in operating expenses mainly
column12: which increased as a result of buildout of fulfillment centers in preparation for the holiday season. Costs also escalated due to the company's increased spending on original TV shows and movies. Amazon Web Services (AWS) and India expansion-related expenses also resulted in higher spending.Guidance:Fourth quarter revenues are expected to include a 60 bps positive FX impact and come in around $42-45.5 billion. Operating income is expected to be between $0 and $1.25 billion.What We Are WatchingRetail: Amazon's retail business remains very hard to beat on price
column13: choice
column14: convenience
column15: you name it. The company has a solid loyalty system in Prime and its Fulfillment by Amazon (FBA) strategy. Content addition continues to add selection to Prime memberships. If Amazon is able to replicate its domestic success internationally
column16: investors could see far more growth. At the moment
column17: international contributes a third of revenue but generates just a fraction of profits.AWS:Amazon Web Services is the cash cow for Amazon. The business generates much higher margins than retail
column18: so it has a positive impact on Amazon's profitability. We are optimistic about the functionality
column19: partner ecosystem and the experience AWS offers and believe this to have added to its customer base.IoT:One area of potential growth is devices and IoT. It's probably not right to ignore the growing capabilities of Echo and Alexa in this regard and how they are being received by hardware partners.IoT devices/technologies are unlikely to have a very big impact on results right now (revenue contribution won't be material near term)
column20: but it could very well supplement the rest of the business by making it easier to buy from Amazon.Amazon.com

column1: 15 Best Short-Term Stock Investments;1/31/2017;"As any stock trader can tell you
column2: the market can be volatile. That's why investment professionals typically recommend investors take a long-term approach to investing to reduce the risk of losing principal. If you invest at the wrong time
column3: you could lose a significant amount of your money overnight
column4: so keep in mind that stocks are not always the best short-term investments.That said
column5: stock prices work both ways. A prudent — or lucky — investor could make a great deal of money just as rapidly as he could lose it. If you have a tolerance for risk and are willing to do the research
column6: short-term trading might be a solution for at least part of your portfolio.If you decide to go this route
column7: don't hesitate to contact a financial professional if you need assistance. Most important
column8: if you're looking for stocks to buy now
column9: do your homework to find good ones in which to invest. You can begin here with this list of 15 stocks to buy that might be thebest short-term investments for your portfolio.makeArticleAd();1. Apple:AAPLApple is one of the best-known companies in America
column10: thanks in no small part to the iPhone. It's also the largest U.S. company in terms of market capitalization — the value of a company that's traded on the stock market — a number you can calculate by multiplying a company's stock price by the number of its outstanding shares. In the case of Apple
column11: this number topped $618 billion as of late December 2016
column12: coming in ahead of competitors Alphabet at $548 billion
column13: Microsoft at $494.6 billion
column14: Amazon at $366 billion and Facebook at $343.1 billion.Apple stock is positioned to move even higher in 2017. The company is aggressively buying back stock
column15: which reduces the number of outstanding shares and increases earnings per share. Its latest iPhones
column16: the 7 and 7 Plus
column17: are the best-selling phones in its history. Apple also holds roughly $200 billion in overseas cash
column18: which might move home this year if corporate taxes on repatriation are lowered. To top it all off
column19: the stock is trading at just about 10 times earnings.2. Gilead Sciences:GILDIf you're looking for a short-term stock that had a rough go of it in 2016
column20: Gilead Sciences might be your pick. The biotechnology company's sales of its hepatitis C drug declined and the stock fell 29 percent in 2016.Gilead could turn out to be one of the best stocks for 2017
column21: however. The company trades at the compelling valuation of 6.99 times estimated earnings over the next year. It's bought back 14 percent of its stock over the past three years
column22: and with its $32 billion cash hoard
column23: the company might continue to buy more or make strategic acquisitions. Gilead also uses its cash to pay out a 2.5 percent dividend to shareholders. The stock could very well hit $101 in 2017
column24: according to analysts at JP Morgan.3. Alphabet:GOOGAlphabet
column25: formerly known as Google
column26: is one of the world's great businesses
column27: according to Barron's. The company owns numerous products and services including Google Maps and Google Play
column28: YouTube
column29: Nest
column30: Chrome
column31: Android
column32: and Gmail. Analysts project 2017 revenues for the company in excess of $103 billion
column33: which would represent a growth rate of more than 18 percent.Given the current political climate
column34: Alphabet might see a short-term boost in the form of repatriated cash. The company currently holds about $80 billion in cash overseas
column35: which translates to around $115 per share. Additionally
column36: it has a lot of room for cost cutting because it spends freely on noncore businesses. Some analysts are estimating $41 per share in earnings this year
column37: which would be huge since the company currently trades at just 18 times earnings.4. Facebook:FBEven if you don't use Facebook at home or on your smartphone
column38: it's hard to avoid its presence in store windows or on advertising asking you to ""like"" something. The key to Facebook's financial success is its monetization of its enormous customer base. It has 1.79 billion monthly active users — and that number continues to rise. Lately
column39: Facebook's stock price has gone up and exceeded analyst earnings estimates by an average of 21.11 percent.Facebook is still investing in ways to grow its earnings even more
column40: with mobile ads and video revenues currently doing the heavy lifting. The company is also expecting big things out of its virtual reality investments. With a long-term growth rate of 27.6 percent
column41: the company is expected to continue its rise.5. Citigroup:CCitigroup could benefit from a number of factors in 2017
column42: including rising interest rates. TheFederal Reserve raised interest ratesfor just the second time in a decade in 2016. The Fed indicated that it expects to hike rates an additional three times in 2017. In response
column43: the two-year Treasury note hit its highest rate since 2009. When interest rates rise
column44: banks can charge more money on loans and credit cards
column45: potentially increasing their profitability.Citigroup's stock has lagged compared with its peers' so far in 2017
column46: which gives it room to catch up. The stock trades at just about 11 times its expected earnings for next year — and it trades at the widest discount-to-book value of the major banks. This means the stock is discounted more than 25 percent compared with the price-earnings ratios of its peers
column47: making it a possible value play.6. IBM:IBMIBM is another turnaround candidate for 2017. The company used to dominate the computer hardware and services business sector but has been surpassed in recent years by its competitors. However
column48: its slow turn toward the more modern businesses of artificial intelligence
column49: cloud computing
column50: mobility and security is showing signs of bearing fruit.The company spent more than $5 billion in acquisitions in 2016 alone
column51: and its new product lines now account for more than 40 percent of firm revenues. Its analytics division showed revenue growth of 16 percent
column52: and its cloud business jumped by 42 percent — both hopeful signs for future growth. IBM's artificial intelligence business has generated positive buzz thanks to its Watson cognitive system
column53: which is known for beating two human ""Jeopardy!"" contestants. The stock trades at a 12.19 price-earnings ratio based on expected 2017 earnings.7. Norwegian Cruise Line:NCLHNorwegian Cruise Line is poised to benefit from the rapidly growing cruise segment and could be one of the best stocks to buy now. With the core demographic of aging baby boomers on the rise
column54: cruise lines are a growing market. The company doesn't pay dividends to shareholders but reinvests its cash flow into building more ships and expanding its routes. Norwegian has already won approval to sail to Cuba
column55: and it has repositioned its calendar to deploy ships into the fast-growing Asian market for the first time in 15 years.Norwegian boasts the newest fleet among its major North American competitors
column56: making it attractive to customers looking for the latest and greatest offerings. The company owns a diversified portfolio of maritime brands including Oceania and Regent Seven Seas. Analysts estimate the stock will grow earnings by more than 18 percent in 2017 — the stock trades at just 14 times 2017 estimates.8. Amazon:AMZNAmazon has grown from an online bookseller to the eighth-largest retailer in the world
column57: and it hasn't shown any signs of slowing down. Amazon will become the largest apparel seller in the U.S. by 2021
column58: when it will be selling $62 billion in apparel annually — more than TJ Maxx and Macy's combined — according to analysts at Cowen Group.Amazon is firing on multiple fronts: It's poised to capitalize on streaming media's popularity via its Amazon Prime subscription service. Additionally
column59: its Web Services business is more advanced than competitors Microsoft and Alphabet's cloud offerings
column60: thanks to it being first to market. Analysts at Evercore ISI Institutional Equities cite Amazon as the best internet stock for 2017. Excitement is also brewing over Amazon's latest foray into the grocery business
column61: Amazon Go. In true disruptor fashion
column62: Amazon's take on the grocery store is to use sensors rather than grocery clerks.9. Restoration Hardware:RHRestoration Hardware is a well-known
column63: luxury home furnishings brand that suffered through 2016. Its earnings fell and triggered a stock sell-off in which shares lost more than half their value. However
column64: the company has shown some signs of being a possible candidate for short-term traders. In its most recent quarter
column65: revenue actually rose 3 percent and beat analysts' estimates by more than $20 million. Earnings also beat Wall Street expectations by 4 cents per share.In addition to rebounding sales and earnings
column66: Restoration Hardware conducted an image makeover. Going forward
column67: the company will be called simply ""RH."" Additionally
column68: the company has launched a new
column69: RH Modern line. In an attempt to capitalize on a more current type of revenue stream
column70: RH is now offering annual memberships. As a result
column71: analysts peg the company's five-year earnings growth rate at 20.33 percent
column72: with earnings for the upcoming year jumping 61.27 percent.10. Toll Brothers:TOLToll Brothers is a leading luxury home builder
column73: a business that's been hit hard on many fronts. Although risks remain
column74: the fear of rising interest rates dampening homebuying activity has sent Toll Brothers stock to a bargain price. The company now trades at less than 10 times its anticipated 2017 earnings
column75: which are expected by some to rise 20 percent.Some concerns over the luxury condo market in New York City also hang over the stock
column76: but company reps indicate that earnings will hold up. With the stock seemingly priced for a worst-case scenario
column77: its valuation of about 1.2 times book value is compelling. If housing markets hold firm or interest rates don't rise dramatically
column78: Toll Brothers stock could prove surprising to those anticipating the worst.11. Deutsche Telekom:DTEGYDeutsche Telekom is a German stock that many investors might recognize as the former parent of U.S. T-Mobile. The company still owns a 65 percent stake in the independently traded T-Mobile — and that stock has been skyrocketing. Deutsche's core European telecom business trades at a discount compared with its peers — it fell by 13 percent in 2016 — even though it's the leading wired and wireless operator in Germany. Sporting a nearly 4 percent yield
column79: some analysts describe the stock as undervalued.A takeover play might happen in 2017: Comcast has had its eye on T-Mobile as a potential purchase. T-Mobile might also make another attempt to merge with Sprint
column80: which could end up being a catalyst for Deutsche's stock. If everything falls into place
column81: a share price of $20 isn't inconceivable.12. Sprouts Farmers Market:SFMSprouts Farmers Market flies under the radar of many investors because it's not really a headline-making stock. This lack of publicity might work to its advantage
column82: however
column83: as more investors become aware of its potential. Sprouts is drawing customers from the growing natural and organic food segment — and it prices its goods below that of its notable peer
column84: Whole Foods Market. As a result
column85: some analysts see the company generating mid-teens earnings and revenue growth in the foreseeable future.The company is growing out of its base in the American Southwest and moving east
column86: growing 14 percent in square footage every year. Coupled with its favorable market segments
column87: Sprouts is generating positive cash flow and returning cash to shareholders via a stock buyback program. At 20.5 times estimated 2017 earnings
column88: the stock could be ready to move.13. Delta Air Lines:DALDelta Air Lines has greatly improved its financial performance but still trades at a typical airline multiple of about nine times estimated 2017 earnings. Since 2009
column89: Delta has worked to cut its debt in half. As a result
column90: it now has an investment grade rating from independent ratings service Moody's. To further entice shareholders
column91: Delta pays a 1.7 percent dividend and has aggressively repurchased stock.Delta management feels the stock should be valued more like a diversified industrial company
column92: which would dramatically raise its multiple
column95: its share price. If you need another short-term catalyst
column96: look at the company's free cash flow. Delta is a cash-flow machine — it generated $4.1 billion in cash flow in the last 12 months alone and put just 9.8 percent of that into dividend payments
column97: according to Forbes.14. Novartis:NVTSAnother value play for 2017 could be Novartis
column98: a Swiss diversified drug company and the world's biggest prescription drugmaker. The company's share price had a difficult 2016 but now trades at about 15 times next year's earnings. With a yield of about 3.75 percent
column99: Novartis has an analyst consensus price target of $87
column100: some $15 north of its current price.Part of what held Novartis back in 2016 was fear over the slow start of Entresto
column102: but some analysts think sales will soon accelerate and could go as high as $3 billion. Novartis also gets 25 percent of its sales from high-growth
column104: which makes it less dependent on the more mature U.S. drug market. The company's recent purchase of Encore Vision should also shore up its vision sales and further enable it to diversify its holdings.15. General Motors:GMGeneral Motors has been an integral part of the global auto industry for more than 100 years and has recently faced headwinds. Some market participants feel that global auto sales have peaked
column105: and concerns over themovement to electric vehicleshave held back GM stock. Whatever the reasons are
column106: General Motors currently trades at a low price-to-earnings ratio of 4.3. Even industry competitors — like Ford
column107: which trades at a ratio of 6.6
column109: which trades at 9.7 times — trade at higher multiples
column110: and GM's average price-earnings ratio over the past five years is 12.2.GM could move higher as the market appreciates its emerging electric and hybrid portfolio. Some analysts feel GM has the bankroll and technology to undersell rivals such as Tesla and perhaps even compete on quality at some point. GM stock began rallying at the end of 2016
column111: which leads some analysts to predict it could double in price over the next one or two years.Data is accurate as of Jan. 25

column1: 3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earnings;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsEven ifApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) weren't the biggest company in the world (as measured by market cap)
column3: its quarterly earnings reports would still arguably be the most-watched reports for any given earnings seasons. Not only are a wide swath of many other companies linked to Apple's success
column4: but AAPL stock itself is something of a barometer for the broad market.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleYet
column5: the last few quarterly earnings announcements have also raised questions
column6: not the least of which is whether or not iPhone-mania has run its course. The growth pace has been undeniably tapering off.That's going to be the hot button on Tuesday
column7: after the close
column8: when the Apple earnings report for its fiscal first quarter is due.Apple Earnings PreviewAs of the most recent look
column9: Apple isexpected to post earnings of $3.22 per shareon revenue of $77.42 billion for the quarter ending in December. The company itself had guided for Q1 revenue of between $77 and $78 billion. That bottom line would be a tad lower than the $3.28 per share of AAPL stock reported for the same quarter a year earlier
column10: though the top line would be up just a bit from the prior year's first fiscal quarter tally of $75.87 billion.Apple needs a strong showing on Tuesday. Although it has been a strong growth machine since unveiling the first iPhone a little over a decade ago
column11: per-share profits have been lower on a year-over-year basis in each of the prior three quarters. Ditto for revenue.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatAAPL stock investors have been patient thus far
column12: giving CEO Tim Cook time to adjust to a maturing market. A shortfall and/or another quarter of shrinking numbers
column13: however
column14: may push those traders' patience over the edge.3 Things to Watch for AAPLNot that Apple doesn't have a myriad of things going on at any given time
column15: but for the most part
column16: investors tend to focus on what they perceive as the biggest three. The three items that will be doing most of the driving for AAPL stock after Tuesday's report are (in no particular order)…iPhone 7 salesIt's the 800-pound gorilla in the room. Strong sales of the company's flagship device can cure all other ills
column17: but if sales of the company's most recent iteration of the iPhone fall short
column18: little else matters.Expectations are widely varied on this front too. Cowen & Co.thinks Apple sold 58.5 million units of the iPhone 7 last quarter
column19: while Drexel Hamilton believes Applesold 76 million iPhones- not just the iPhone 7 - during its fiscal Q1. The overall consensus
column20: though
column21: isan average of 77.3 million units. Presumably most of those are the 7 and 7 Plus models.Apps and Digital ContentWhile Apple used to be a hardware company that also happened to facilitate the purchase of smartphone apps
column22: music and video media
column23: digital content is increasingly becomingan important part of the revenue mixas saturation becomes a real issue.The company doesn't offer much in the way of expectations for how its revenue breaks down
column24: but we do know that in the previous quarter
column25: Apple enjoyed revenue of $6.3 billion for its ""Services"" division
column26: which is mostly made up of its video
column27: audio and apps arms. That was a 24% year-over-year improvement. That makes it thesecond-biggest category of product for Apple
column28: though it's still well behind the biggest - the iPhone.Facebook Inc (FB) Stock: New All-Time Highs or New Problems?AAPL is even mulling the creation ofits own original television shows and movies
column29: following in the footsteps of on-demand video rivalsNetflix
column30: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) andAmazon.com
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN).Donald Trump AgendaIt remains to be seen to what extent
column32: if any
column33: it will be discussed within the Apple earnings report and conference call. Maybe it won't come up at all
column34: but there's no denying AAPL is one of the more vulnerable companies to President Donald Trump's policy plans.Not only might a strict foreign worker and immigration policy limit Apple's access to technical talent
column35: but much-discussed tariffs on Chinese-made imports could start a trade war that leaves Apple right in the middle of it. Not only does Apple sell products to Chinese consumers
column36: it relies on China to make many of the iPhone's key components.Bottom Line for AAPL StockWith a trailing P/E of 14.5
column37: Apple shares are priced fairly … maybe even undervalued. That's apt to be a large part of the reason the pros are collectively rating AAPL a bit better than a ""Buy"" right now (leaning toward a ""Strong buy."") That optimism
column38: though
column39: is a bit suspicious in light of the lackluster results we've seen for the prior three quarters. Apple is going to have to outperform most expectations if the stock's to build any further on the 34% gain it has mustered since May of last year.As of this writing
column40: James Brumley did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeThe post3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Owners Must Watch in Q1 Earningsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Reasons Amazon.com Is Taking Over the World;1/30/2017;"If you're wondering what the best stock of the past 20 years   is
column2: there's a far-and-away winner.Image source: The Motley FoolmakeArticleAd();According to data from YCharts
column3: Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) stock has increased more than 42
column4: 000% since its   IPO 20 years ago
column5: in May 1997.AMZNdata byYChartsIn other words
column7: 000 invested at that time would today be   worth more than $420
column8: 000. Amazon's market value at the time of   the IPO
column9: which was $300 million
column10: has grown by more than 1
column11: 000   times as the company is now worth nearly $400 billion. Share   dilution has made the increase in the individual share value   less.What's amazing about Amazon is that even as it's become one of   the five most valuable companies in the country
column12: the company   continues to grow at a breakneck rate. Analysts are expecting   revenue to have increased 28% in 2016 when the company reports   full-year earnings on Feb. 2
column13: and for earnings per share to have   grown nearly fourfold from a year ago
column14: thanks to blockbuster   growth at its cloud computing division.With that kind of momentum and the popularity of programs like   its Prime membership service
column15: it seems likely that Amazon will   become the most valuable company in the world in the next decade.   Here are three reasons for that outlook.Invent
column16: invent
column17: inventNo company has put a greater emphasis on invention in the past   two decades. Founder and CEO Jeff Bezos has credited the company'   success on the three big ideas: Put the customer first. Invent.   And be patient.Amazon has been at the forefront of a vast range of emerging   industries since its inception
column18: including e-commerce
column19: e-readers   and e-books
column20: cloud computing
column21: video streaming
column22: digital technology   such as Alexa
column23: and even drone delivery.Amazon's culture encourages invention
column24: risk-taking and   failure
column25: and that culture seems to be the biggest driver of its   success. The company's recent opening of its Amazon Go store   offers a perfect example. Using a network of cameras and other   advanced technologies similar to self-driving cars
column26: the   convenience allows customers to select items and simply walk out   of the store with them. There is no checkout process. Amazon just   charges customers automatically through a smartphone app. The   company spent four years working on the technology
column27: and its   willingness to make those kinds of sacrifices have enabled it to   gain such market power. The company's emphasis on making things   easier for the customer and developing new technologies is what's   made it such a powerful disruptor across so many industries.Cutthroat competitivenessA more-hidden aspect of Amazon's unique culture may be the   company's extreme competitiveness. Bezos has repeatedly issued   broadsides to rivals such as ""Your margin is my opportunity"" and   operated with breakeven margins for 20 years as the company built   out scale. While most businesses seek out profits to satisfy   shareholders
column28: Bezos has always been content to play the long   game
column29: promising investors from day one that he was building a   company for the long term
column30: and it's paid off.A much-read 2015New York Timesexpose described Amazon as a brutal workplace where much is   demanded of employees whose ideas are sternly challenged and even   belittled. But even the harsh workplace environment may   contribute to the company's strength.The company has often elbowed out smaller competitors by using   monopolistic tactics. When Quidsi's Diapers.com began taking   significant market share from Amazon
column31: the e-commerce leader   responded by lowering diaper prices by a third
column32: bleeding Quidsi   until it sold itself to Amazon.In book publishing
column33: Amazon got involved in a lawsuit when it   refused to abide by a publisher's prices
column34: with the publisher   insisting the prices were necessary to give authors adequate   incentive and keep the industry alive and profitable. Amazon   wanted to charge $10 for most e-books and went as far as   essentially refusing to sell 5
column35: 000 titles from Hachette
column36: delaying   shipments by weeks for no reason other than to punish the   publisher for not cooperating. Amazon eventually caved in to the   publishing houses
column37: agreeing to their pricing model
column38: but it still   maintains monopoly-like control over the bookselling   industry.Competitive advantagesComplementing Amazon's inventiveness and its   ultra-competitveness is the company's network of competitive   advantages. Amazon has a built a reputation as a low-cost   provider
column39: although recent studies have shown that the company is   most competitive on price on only the most popular products.Regardless
column40: Amazon has gained the trust of many of its   customers
column41: especially Prime members who go directly to Amazon   when they need to order something online. Prime has encouraged   Amazon shoppers to spend double what they used to on the website   and encouraged members to participate in other parts of Amazon's   ecosystem
column42: such as video streaming and Kindle books.But not all of Amazon's competitive advantages are   customer-facing. The company's Marketplace and Fulfillment by   Amazon have made the website the most popular home for   third-party vendors. That adds another revenue stream for Amazon   and in turn makes it the more appealing for customers as it   increases its product range.Finally
column43: Amazon's reputation with customers allows it to   easily enter new industries as it did when it launched Home   Services
column44: offering services such as house cleaning or furniture   assembly through third-party vendors.As Amazon continues to build out new fulfillment centers and   unveil technologies like Amazon Go and Alexa
column45: its competitive   advantages are likely to increase. Considering the vast majority   of retail spending still takes place off line
column46: Amazon has a long   growth path ahead.Expect the company to keep disrupting industries far and wide   over the next decade as it continues its quest to take over the   world.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent more   than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column47: the newsletter they   run
column48: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column49: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for   investors to buy right now. Amazon.comis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full list!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: New Technologies
column2: Automation And The Future;1/30/2017;"ByElliott R. Morss:New Technologies
column3: Automation and the FutureElliott R. Morss© All Rights ReservedIntroductionmakeArticleAd();In recent postings
column4: I havejoinedmany others in speculating on what effects the information revolution will have. Already
column5: its impact has been tremendous. Its effects include:The elimination of a huge number of jobs lost in both service and production industries;Social media has completely transformed the manner in which we interact/communicate;Online shopping is growing rapidly
column6: andDigital communication has resulted in an acceleration of technological discoveries.So what is coming? Since 2002
column7: the McKinsey Global Institute ((MGI)) has been tracking changes resulting from the information revolution. This is needed because many politicians have little idea of what is happening. For example
column8: Trump says he will bring back jobs by taxing imports. This will hardly solve the problem. A recentMGI studyconcluded:""Trade and outsourcing explain only about 20 percent of the 5.8 million manufacturing jobs lost during the 2000-10 period; more than two-thirds of job losses can be attributed to continued productivity growth
column9: which has been outpacing demand growth for the past decade.""In itsmost recent study
column10: MGI attempted to determine the labor force implications of technological developments. In what follows
column11: I summarize its methodology and conclusions along with my own commentary.MethodologyMGI used the state of technology in respect to 18 performance capabilities to estimate the technical automation potential of more than 2
column12: 000 work activities from more than 800 occupations across the US economy
column13: and then broadened our analysis across the global economy.ResultsMGI started by developing seven categories of ""automatable"" human activities. Table 1 provides its estimates of automatable shares for each category. While 81% of ""predictable physical"" can be automated by adapting currently available technologies
column14: MGI estimates that only 9% of ""managing"" is automatable. The third column is the category's share of the US automatable total. MGI has concluded that the categories most susceptible for automation are ""predictable physical"" and the ""collecting and processing of data."" Together
column15: these three activities constitute 51% of total employment and $2.7 trillion in wages.Table 1 - US: Time Spent on Automatable ActivitiesSource: McKinsey Global Institute
column16: A Future That Works: Automation
column17: Employment
column18: and ProductivityMGI then looked at the automation potential for more than 2
column19: 000 work activities. It reduced this down to 19 industrial sectors for the US economy. It then broadened the analysis to the global economy. The results from this exercise are summarized in Table 2.Table 2 - Automation Potential for 19 SectorsSource: McKinsey Global Institute
column20: A Future That Works: Automation
column21: Employment
column22: and ProductivityOf course
column23: it is easy to second-guess MGI's estimates. For example
column24: I believe a far greater share of educational activities than 27% can be automated. Why? Because a good deal of education occurs via lectures
column25: and definitely there are better and worse lecturers. In light of this
column26: why not get the best lectures on all topics and provide them digitally to classrooms? Classroom teachers would then only have to discuss and answer questions on the lectures. Of course
column27: such an action would be vigorously resisted by the teachers' unions.And to that point
column28: MGI argues there are five key factors that will influence the pace and extent of automation:Technical feasibility
column29: since the technology has to be invented
column30: integrated and adapted;The cost of developing and deploying solutions
column31: which affects the business case for adoption;Labor market dynamics
column32: including the supply
column33: demand
column34: and costs of human labor as an alternative to automation (see education discussion above);The economic benefits
column35: which could include higher throughput and increased quality
column36: as well as labor cost savings.Regulatory and social acceptance will affect the rate of adoption even when deployment makes business sense.MGI believes that when all of these factors into account
column37: it will take decades for automation's effect on current work activities to play out fully.Demographics
column38: Productivity Growth and Labor Force AdjustmentsOver the last four decades
column39: productivity gains have been labor-saving. In fact
column40: these gains have wiped out a huge number of middle class jobs. However
column41: if we look out over a longer time frame
column42: the picture is somewhat different. Economic growth is constrained by the labor supply and its productivity. We know that for most developed countries
column43: populations and as a consequence
column44: labor supplies are falling. That means that economic growth depends exclusively on productivity growth. For most developing countries
column45: economic growth will benefit from both rising population and growing productivity. MGI points out:""…peak employment will occur in most countries within 50 years. The expected decline in the share of the working-age population will open an economic growth gap: roughly half of the sources of economic growth from the past half century (employment growth) will evaporate as populations age. Even at historical rates of productivity growth
column46: economic growth could be nearly halved. Automation could compensate for at least some of these demographic trends. We estimate the productivity injection it could give to the global economy as being between 0.8 and 1.4 percent of global GDP annually
column47: assuming that human labor replaced by automation would rejoin the workforce and be as productive as it was in 2014. Considering the labor substitution effect alone
column48: we calculate that
column50: automation could potentially add productivity growth in the largest economies in the world (G19 plus Nigeria) that is the equivalent of an additional 1.1 billion to 2.3 billion full-time workers.""Table 3 provides MGI's estimates of the full-time equivalent (FTE) GDP gap in 2065 of assuming today's productivity and current population projections and today's GDP/FTE. So
column51: for example
column52: the US GDP/FTE would be 4% less than it is now because of the labor force decline. MGI concludes for developed nations:""Automation can provide the productivity boost required to meet economic growth projections that they otherwise would struggle to attain without other significant productivity growth accelerators. These economies thus have a major interest in pursuing rapid automation adoption.""Table 3 - FTE Gap Between FTE Projections and Number of FTEs Needed to Maintain GDP per Capita as Percent FTEs in 2014Source: McKinsey Global Institute
column53: A Future That Works: Automation
column54: Employment
column55: and ProductivityWhile this is an interesting exercise
column56: I remain far more concerned about labor supply surpluses
column57: resulting from accelerating labor-saving automation than slower economic growth resulting from labor supply shortages.Investing - Who Produces Automation Equipment?Automation is clearly accelerating so it is reasonable to ask who the producers are. A list is provided in Table 4. Many of the companies have been around for a long time and getting into automation is an evolution from their main focus. Examples include Amazon (AMZN)
column58: Boeing (BA)
column59: Honda (HMC)
column60: Hyundai (HYMLF)
column61: Kawasaki (KWHIY)
column62: Lockheed (LMT)
column63: Samsung (SSNNF) and Toyota (TM). ""Purer"" automation plays include ABB Robotics (ABB)
column64: AeroVironment (AVAV)
column65: Fanuc (FANUY)
column66: iRobot (IRBT)
column67: Intuitive Surgical (ISRG)
column68: Swisslog (SLHGF) and Titan (TITXF). A relatively large number of these firms are Japanese.Table 4 - Leading Automation ""Producers""Source:Robotics Business ReviewI answer this with a quote from Peter Lynch. Peter Lynch's track record was truly remarkable. As I havenoted elsewhere
column69: he beat the S&P 500 (^GSPC) in 12 of the 14 years he ran Fidelity's Magellan Fund (FMAGX). And on average
column70: if the S&P gained 5%
column71: Magellan gained 22.5%! Even in the two years the S&P outperformed Lynch
column72: the spread was very small. Lynch argues you should:""Use your specialized knowledge to home in on stocks you can analyze
column73: study them and then decide if they're worth owning. The best way to invest is to look at companies competing in the field where you work.""With rapid technological change
column74: the automation business is inherently risky. And I don't work in the industry.ConclusionsIt is hard to keep in mind just how rapidly technologies are changing. And that
column75: coupled with how long it takes people to adapt
column76: makes the future very uncertain. Most people are quite slow in adapting to the new technologies - just look at how long it has taken buying online to become significant. There are reasons to be tremendously optimistic in the fields of health and energy. But dealing with jobs lost to automation remains a real problem.See alsoIf You Don't Understand This
column77: You Don't Understand Macroon seekingalpha.com"

column1: Is the Bar Higher for the Q4 Earnings Season?;1/30/2017;"Even as Earnings growth appears to have improved notably relative to the last couple of years

Comparing the most recent share price to the 200 day moving average can also be a useful technical analysis technique --learn more about the 200 day moving average ».makeArticleAd();Exchange traded funds (ETFs) trade just like stocks
column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column19: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column21: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had   notable inflows »"

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Microsoft
column2: Apple
column3: Amazon
column4: Alphabet and Intel;1/30/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - January 30
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column7: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column8: Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column9: Alphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) andIntel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This QuarterAnalysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column11: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column12: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column13: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column14: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column15: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column16: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) for one has strongly resisted government demands as have Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report). Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report); networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. column23: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. column24: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. column1: Here’s How Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can Reclaim Its Throne;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) has its day of reckoning fast approaching. Tim Cook has turned out to be a game manager for AAPL stock. That's not a slight against him
column3: but a game manager comes in when your first-string QB is out for a quarter or two. The problem is that Apple needs a visionary. There's no replacing Steve Jobs
column4: and being a game manager in a sector that moves like lightning is not what the company needs.makeArticleAd();Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrAAPL stock generates almost 70% of revenue from the iPhone
column5: and that product is seeing increasing competition.The good news is that Apple has well over $200 billion in cash and investments. It can literally do anything it wants. The problem is that most of that cash is stuck overseas - although that may change under Trump - and what Cook might do with that cash is a mystery.Without a vision
column6: Apple would probably have to make acquisitions in rapidly growing companies. However
column7: there is one other area that AAPL stock can venture into
column8: one that I've been saying it must get into: original content.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018News has surfaced that AAPL is finally looking seriously at creating original TV and film content. For years
column9: Apple has begged off of this direction. It seemed content to play around with music streaming
column10: and licensing content from other providers for iTunes.TheWSJreported:""The technology giant has been in talks with veteran producers in recent months about buying rights to scripted television programs. It also has approached experienced marketing executives at studios and networks to discuss hiring them to promote its content
column11: said people with knowledge of the discussions. In addition to TV
column12: Apple indicated to these people that it is considering offering original movies
column13: though those plans are more preliminary. Executives at Apple have told people in Hollywood they hope to start offering original scripted content by the end of 2017.""The apple is ripe for AAPL to get involved
column14: and in a very big way. We've seen thatNetflix
column15: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) has shifted its model toward original programming and is producing really great stuff. So isAmazon.com
column16: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). YouTube Red
column17: though
column18: is kind of floundering right now.One thing people want is not only more content
column19: but good content. Because Apple is so flush with cash
column20: it can literally do anything in this arena. There is a ton of talent out there
column21: and so many models to play with for AAPL stock.Obviously
column22: Apple would want to create high quality TV and film
column23: and could do so across all genres. It wouldn't even have to be an issue of streaming content alone. If Apple wanted
column24: it could produce feature films
column25: and buy out any of the existing movie theatre chains and rebrand it as an Apple Theatre experience
column26: and drop in all manner of synergies like this.The concept of the ""long tail"" is still very much in play
column27: so creating independent work for a price
column28: or returning to a version of the old studio system might also yield rewards. Yet there are other models
column29: such as mining new talent from film schools and user-generated genius that's all over the place.The emerging technology of VR is another place to stretch. The ability to curate fully engaging experiences via VR
column30: and developing technology that allows players to wear bodysuits permitting them to actually experience touch in these games is the next frontier.Can Apple Inc. (AAPL) Afford a War With Qualcomm
column31: Inc. (QCOM)?And Apple has the money for it. It could become a multi-platform creator of content
column32: and be able to engage people from all over the world.Is this is a blockbuster revenue generator for Apple stock? It's way too early to tell. However
column33: having a vision that extends the concept of ""content"" to things like VR and more ""experiential"" content
column34: could mean becoming the first mover in a whole new generation of entertainment. That is priceless.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital

column1: How to Trade Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN) Stock After Earnings;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) is scheduled to report its latest batch of earnings on Thursday
column5: Feb. 2
column6: after the close of trading. Looked at through a multimonth lens
column7: AMZN stock has largely done nothing since last October
column8: though it has seen some gyrations within this time frame.makeArticleAd();To be better prepared for Amazon earnings
column9: and for perspective
column10: here is my battle plan for AMZN following the report.Like I always say
column11: ""gambling"" on a stock through its earnings announcement in hopes of a certain outcome (a rally or a selloff) is on average a low-probability bet. Even in the best-case scenario
column12: this has a 50/50 chance of success.Regardless of how good or bad a company's outlook
column13: earnings
column14: sales or other metric is
column15: the immediate- to near-term direction of any given stock following earnings ultimately depends on what large investors want to do with shares after the report. This might sound oversimplistic
column16: but I find that many active investors often lose sight of the fact that above all
column17: it's supply and demand that dictates price direction. And supply and demand don't always correlate rationally with news flow.AMZN Stock ChartsLooking at the multiyear weekly chart of Amazon
column18: we see that the latest steep rally since early 2015 has largely taken place within a well-defined up-trending channel similar to what we see in in other large-cap technology growth stocks such asFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB).Click to EnlargeNote how well the yellow 50-week simple moving average has held as support over the past couple of years and how this has coincided with the lower end of the up-trending channel.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatFrom this perspective
column19: considering that AMZN stock tends to make big moves following its earnings reports
column20: shares this week might either gravitate toward the upper end of the up-trending channel (toward $900) or retest the lower end of the channel around the low to mid-$700s.That might not sound like much insight. However
column21: it gives us a very well-defined trading range between $750 and $900.All else being equal
column22: a rally to the upper end of the range would be a better opportunity to sell or short the stock. A move to the lower end may provide better buying opportunities
column23: following a bullish reversal.Lastly
column24: note the negative divergence between price and momentum over the past 12 months. The price of AMZN stock has continued to rise
column25: yet momentum - as represented by the MACD oscillator at the bottom of the chart - is still pointing lower and making lower highs. This does not bode well for much further upside in the stock
column26: and even a post-earnings rally may be better sold than chased higher.Here's Why Netflix
column27: Inc. Stock (NFLX) Will Trade At $270 By 2020On the daily chart
column28: we see that the latest multiweek rally in AMZN
column29: after bouncing off the 200-day moving average (red) in early January
column30: once again has the stock back at its October 2016 highs near $840.Click to EnlargeActive traders could look to buy/chase AMZN stock higher if and when the stock can break and hold above $850 on a daily closing basis following the earnings report. From there
