column1: Here’s Why Netflix
column2: Inc. Stock (NFLX) Will Trade At $270 By 2020;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsNetflix
column4: Inc.(NFLX) stock continued its steady ride upward on Friday following another price target increase. The streaming giant has certainly had its share of target increases since itslast earnings reportand huge subscriber add surprise.makeArticleAd();But will it continue to soar? Analysts aren't ready to say no just yet.Netflix Stock Target: $175 Per Share…For NowIn a research note dated Jan. 27
column5: MKM Partnersanalyst Rob Sanderson bumped up his price target for Netflix stock by $10 to $175 per share. While he hasn't changed his view of the domestic opportunity for the company
column6: he does feel that the opportunity in international markets is bigger than he had thought before. Now he's looking for higher subscriber numbers and positive contributions from overseas markets.The analyst doesn't believe that Netflix stock is fully valued yet. In fact
column7: he sees more than $12 per share in earnings power potential by 2021 and believes that the streaming company will remain in ""rapid growth mode for subscribers.""He also expects Netflix stock to trade at $270 per share by 2020
column8: marking a multiple of 20 to 25 times forward earnings per share.Netflix's Content TravelsOne of the factors in Sanderson's view is that the content Netflix has been buying seems to travel outside the U.S. He notes that the company is no longer sending Hollywood-produced content overseas but rather regional content. The company's original shows are proving to be big draws for subscribers
column9: especially as the company expands into new regions.He's now expecting Netflix's international subscribers to rise to 115 million over the next five years. This would mark a 22% penetration rate for broadband homes
column10: including 28% of broadband homes in developed economies and 14% in developing markets. Previous international markets reached that level around five years after Netflix launched in them
column11: he said.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksHe pegs Wave-1 developed economies' aggregate penetration for Netflix at about 30% of broadband homes and Latin America's penetration at greater than 14%.Is NFLX a Cult or Growth Stock?With analysts from most firms so massively bullish on Netflix stock
column12: it's no wonder investors have been carrying it onward and upward. CNBC's Jim Cramer called the stock a cult stock in 2015
column13: but is that the case anymore? In a post forThe Motley Foolearlier this week
column14: Leo Sun argued against that label's accuracy
column15: saying that he now believes Netflix stock to be a growth stock.He says that while the stock does look rather expensive compared to the company's trailing 12-month earnings
column16: its bottom line growth is stabilizing and suggests that it's not all that expensive relative to the company's future earnings growth potential. And this is the basis of most analysts' arguments.The rapid growth of Netflix's subscriber base suggests that it does have a bright future and may indeed still be in growth mode…http://investorplace.com/2017/01/netflix-inc-stock-will-trade-at-270-by-2020-analyst/2/Bearsare convinced that the company has no future and is burning cash too rapidly on content that won't keep subscribers paying their monthly fees. The company's history of producing content that travels bodes well for its future
column17: but at some point
column18: it will have to stop burning so much cash
column19: or investors will get tired of waiting.Just look atAmazon.com
column20: Inc.(AMZN)
column21: which had to take a breather from all the cash burn to get investors back on board. At the end of the day
column22: Netflix's future probably hangs less on its ability to produce content that travels well and more on producing content that will stick around.Are series likeThe CrownandOrange is the New Blackshows that people will still be paying to watch in ten years
column23: or will they have passed their expiration dates
column24: requiring the company to keep feeding the monster more than it can afford to?Netflix stock rose by as much as 2.04% to $141.79 during regular trading hours on Friday.The postNetflix
column25: Inc. Stock Will Trade At $270 By 2020: Analystappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column26: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" column1: Alexa
column2: How Big Is Amazon's Echo?;1/30/2017;"WhenAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) first introduced the Echo
column3: it was a bit of a   novelty
column4: little more than a voice-controlled music player that   had some very rudimentary digital assistant features. Slowly and   steadily
column5: however
column6: the company has increased what Alexa
column7: the name   used to address the artificial intelligence (AI) voice assistant   in the device
column8: can do.Echo and its sister product
column9: Dot
column10: now can serve as the base   that controls your home. Developers from hundreds
column11: perhaps   thousands
column12: of companies have been rolling out products that   integrate with Echo and countless more have been embedding Alexa   into their devices. In addition
column13: the Amazon devices and their AI   ""brain"" were one of the big topics at January's Consumer   Electronics Show with Alexa-enabled or controllable devices being   very well represented.Amazon has jumped to a lead in the race to control the smart   home of the future
column14: which
column15: for some people
column16: has become the smart   home of the present. What's hard to know
column17: because the online   retailer does not share much
column18: if any
column19: data on devices sold
column20: is   exactly how big the market for Echo has become.makeArticleAd();Amazon's Echo and the smaller Dot have the Alexa AI built in.   Image source: Amazon.How big is Echo?While Amazon does not share sales data
column21: Consumer Intelligence   Research Partners (CIRP) has analyzed the company's user base and   come up with an estimate as to how many Echos have been sold. The   research firm said its analysis indicates that 8.2 million Amazon   customers in the United States have purchased an Echo device   since its late-2014 introduction.CIRP also found that awareness of the Echo has risen   dramatically among the online retailer's customers. The research   company estimates that among U.S. Amazon customers
column22: awareness of   the devices increased to 82% as of Dec. 31
column24: up from 47% a   year before that and 20% on March 31
column25: 2015 (the first quarter   after its introduction).""Amazon efforts to promote the expanded Echo product line   appears to have paid off
column26: said CIRP Partner Josh Lowitz in a   statement. ""With traditional media advertising and prominent   placement at the Amazon.com website
column27: Echo product awareness among   Amazon customers continued its rapid ascent in the fourth quarter   of 2016.""Echo has benefited from Amazon cleverly building the user   base. It did that by first making the device exclusively   available to Prime members
column28: selling to early adopters for $99
column29: half its normal price. It then kept adding features
column30: built word   of mouth
column31: and added the cheaper Dot to further grow the   brand.""The installed base of homes with Amazon Echo devices has   grown dramatically
column32: and close to tripled in the past twelve   months
column33: said CIRP Partner Mike Levin in a statement. ""Amazon   promoted Echo aggressively over the holiday shopping season
column34: with   especially aggressive pricing for the Echo Dot. The new models   account for close to half of sales since Amazon introduced them   earlier in 2016.""Amazon has created a marketAmazon has the lead and it has a customer base that it can   market to
column35: but it will face challenges to its dominance in this   space.Alphabet's Google released an Echo knockoff for the holiday season and   other major players includingMicrosofthave their own speaker plus voice-controlled AI devices either   available or planned.The online retailer does have two big advantages. First
column36: it   has the 8.2 million customers CIRP estimates own an Echo device.   That can (and should) be a word-of-mouth army taking some of the   fear out of buying a product that many people may be aware of
column37: but not quite understand. Second
column38: Amazon has hundreds of millions   of customers in its database that it can market to. Those are   people whose shopping habits the retailer knows well
column39: which   should allow it to customize offers to get people to buy an   Echo.Other competitors will certainly succeed in this space
column40: but   Amazon has made the category viable. The retail giant has built a   smart
column41: useful product that has gotten better literally every week   since its introduction. That should make Echo/Alexa a growth   business for Amazon
column42: giving it a valuable beachhead in millions
column43: eventually tens of millions of homes.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column44: the newsletter     they run
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for     investors to buy right now. Amazon.comis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full       list!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Baby Boomers Love These 5 Brands;1/29/2017;"It would seem common sense that a company that has a closer   relationship with its customers would perform better. The Brand   Intimacy report frommarket research firm MBLMconfirms this. The report reveals that if consumers feel a   strong emotional attachment to a brand -- what it terms ""brand   intimacy"" -- that company enjoys better financial results than   those that don't. MBLM reports that the most intimate brands   produce higher revenues and earnings and better stock price   performance than non-intimate brands. The report identifies the   top companies that have most successfully created and sustained   that connection with their customers.Image source: Getty ImagesmakeArticleAd();Baby boomers represent a disproportionate amount of the wealth   and spending among the population. Some estimate that baby   boomers control as much as 70% of the disposable income in the   country. Areport[opens in PDF] issued by Synchrony Financial indicates that as   consumers
column2: the group is fiercely brand loyal
column3: wants seamless   customer service
column4: and is very comfortable shopping using mobile   devices. In preparing its Brand Intimacy Report
column5: MBLM   surveyed 6
column6: 000 consumers between 18 and 64 years old. Those aged   55 to 64 were the oldest subset and are likely representative of   the full baby boomer generation
column7: which most people define as   those between 53 and 71 years old. Let's look at the most adored   brands among this demographic from No. 5 to No. 1
column8: according to   the MBLM survey.Image source: Samsung.5.Samsung(NASDAQOTH: SSNLF) : Samsung was bound to make an appearance on   this list
column9: with its No. 1 position in worldwide smartphone   market. Even in the face of theGalaxy Note 7 fiasco
column10: boomers are brand loyal
column11: and as many as 41% of the owners   surveyed indicated they couldn't live without their device and   nearly 82% say they use their device daily. Samsung is also known   for other home electronics such as TVs
column12: which may play into its   popularity.Baby boomers still love their Coke. Image source: Coca-Cola
column13: Inc.4. Coca-Cola(NYSE: KO) : Coca-Cola helped keep soldiers supplied with its   soda pop during World War II
column14: distributing over 5 billion bottles    to U.S. service personnel
column15: for whom the company pledged a   price of 5 cents per bottle. It became a staple in the homes that   boomers grew up in. Coke is legendary for heartstring-tugging   advertising campaigns. ""I'd like to buy the world a Coke"" (1971) and ""Thanks
column16: Mean Joe!"" (1979) were iconic ads of their era
column17: and it's no wonder that   baby boomers feel a connection to this brand. It has continued to   use nostalgia in its message
column18: which taps into the brand loyalty.   Food industry activist Marion Nestle toldThe Washington Postin 2015: ""The advertisements are designed to sell happiness.   They're not selling a drink. But on an emotional level you attach   to it.""Image source: Toyota Motor Corporation.3.Toyota(NYSE: TM) : Baby boomers were out to prove that they were not   their parents and were not bound by the ""Buy American"" mindset.   They were concerned with gathering information when making   purchases and having options. They were also part of the 20th   century trend that viewed a car as freedom and an extension of   themselves.  When the US energy crisis arrived in 1973   and caused gas shortages and long lines at the pumps
column19: boomers   embraced Toyotas as fuel-efficient alternatives to their   gas-guzzling American counterparts.  Toyota has also built   its brand on reliability.Image source: Pixabay.2. Levi Strauss & Company: Levi saw its blue jeans gain popularity in the late 1950s and   early 1960s through such movie icons as Marlon Brando and James   Dean. This development led to a boom in popularity among   then-teen baby boomers. Levi's bell bottoms were a staple of the   counter-culture revolution. This loyalty carried into their   adult lives: Fashions changed
column20: but Levi's remained the same. Baby   boomers are known for their steadfast brand loyalty
column21: and Levi's   have been with them every step of the way.Image source: Amazon.com.1. Amazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) : Are you surprised that this e-commerce behemoth   is the most beloved by baby boomers? Consider these statistics   from Synchrony Financial: they spend more time online than their   millennial counterparts
column22: with 51% spending 15 hours per week   online
column23: compared with only 41% of millennials. A more telling   statistic is that 70% of boomers report using Amazon at least   once per month. With more money and more time
column24: this demographic   is embracing e-commerce
column25: and nobody is bigger than Amazon.   Boomers want a variety of products and want to be able to find   them. Sounds like a description of Amazon in a nutshell.If this list reveals one thing
column26: it is that there are many ways   to connect with consumers on a visceral level: nostalgia
column27: utility
column28: or just being where they are. There is no one method   that works across the board. Equally
column29: there is no silver bullet   or single metric one can use when looking to find a winning   investment. There are many data points that should be considered
column30: and the concept of brand intimacy is merely one additional tool   in an investor's toolkit.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock   tip
column31: it can pay to listen. After all
column32: the newsletter   they have run for over a decade
column33: the Motley Fool Stock   Advisor
column34: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are theten best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Wal-Mart wasn't one   of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even   better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12
column35: 2016The author(s) may have a position in any stocks mentioned.Danny Venaowns shares of Amazon.com and is himself a baby boomer. The     Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Amazon.com. The     Motley Fool recommends Coca-Cola. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Microsoft Goes From Window(s) Cleaning to Cloud-Gazing;1/29/2017;"After nearly two years
column2: Microsoft(MSFT) finally reported quarterly revenue growth during the second quarter of 2017. In many ways
column3: Microsoft's performance during the second quarter is a peek into what the future holds for the company. Revenue from the Productivity and Business Process segment and the Intelligent Cloud segment was up10%during the quarter
column4: while More Personal Computing declined by 5% due to lower phone revenues.Microsoft raced past analyst estimates
column5: posting adjusted EPS of83cents on the back of $26.07 billion in revenues
column6: while the market was expecting 79 cents in earnings and $25.3 billion in revenues.The above-average results were made possible by stellar performance from Microsoft's cloud business
column7: whose annualized commercial cloud revenue run rate has now exceeded $14 billion. Microsoft takes the revenue earned from cloud products (Office 365
column8: Microsoft Azure
column9: Dynamics 365) in the final month of the quarter
column10: and multiplies it by 12 to get to its annual cloud run rate. During the first quarter
column11: Microsoft said that its cloud run rate exceeded $13 billion
column12: and in the second quarter it has gone past $14 billion. This means Microsoft's cloud properties brought nearly $1.08 billion in September 2017 and $1.16 billion December 2017.makeArticleAd();Microsoft's cloud-based businesses are still growing sequentially
column13: which is great news for the company as it transitions from being Windows-dependent to being cloud-reliant. Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% during the quarter
column14: while Office consumer products and cloud services revenue increased by 22%.Office and related products
column15: especially the cloud-delivered lineup
column16: has been growing in a very strong way for the company. Microsoft has steadily built its lead in this segment
column17: and if the above-47% growth of the last six quarters continues
column18: it will be very difficult for the competition to catch up.Microsoft Azure has been clocking triple-digit growth rates for the past several quarters
column19: and in the second quarter it came very close
column20: posting 93% growth over the prior period. Microsoft noted that Azure compute usage has more than doubled during the quarter.Productivity and Business Processes and Intelligent Cloud
column21: the two forward-looking business streams that are based on cloud delivery
column22: made $14.283 billion during the second quarter

Online   sales could be used to extend both of those propositions while   also adding convenience as an added benefit. Costco doesn't   appear to see that value
column35: and rather than viewing digital as a   way to take sales from competitors

column38: not a defensive standpoint

column46: it should be viewing any online sales it can make as a way to win   business that's going to Amazon and other online retailers.The warehouse club has done a good job of protecting its   in-store business

column1: 10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America Great;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmidst the bombast
column3: braggadocio and fact-free claims of the 2016 presidential campaign
column4: perhaps the most effective was the subtext contained in President Trump's incessantly cited mantra
column5: ""Make America Great Again.""makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThe implication of this successful sonnet of sloganism is that America is not great
column6: at least not in its current iteration. And while certainly an effectual rhetorical rallying point for the most disaffected voters
column7: the claim fails to hold up to scrutiny when one takes a more lucid view of the corporate and investing landscape.Indeed
column8: there are scores of companies
column9: and scores of stocks to own
column10: that already make America great. These are the companies that make the products and services that Americans organize their lives around. Creators of communication devices
column11: social media networks and information retrieval services are just a few of the brilliant achievements of entrepreneurial Americans that have made the country great through the genius of their ideas.7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018They're also among the top companies
column12: and the top stocks
column13: that make our nation great for investors. If you want to feel good about the country
column14: and about the prospects for long-term portfolio performance
column15: here are 10 stocks to own thatalreadymake America great.Stocks to Buy: Boeing (BA)Source:Phillip Capper via FlickrPremier American aircraft manufacturerBoeing Co(NYSE:BA) also is one of the largest defense contractors in the U.S. The company supplies Western military forces with the F-15 and F-18 fighter jets
column16: which also are capable of precision strategic bombing runs crucial to defeating enemies such as the Islamic State.Just check out this footage of an F-18 delivering ISIS fighters a dead-on strike with a500-lb laser guided bomb[Graphic content warning] and you'll be convinced of the efficacy of its fighter jets in the effort against a determined
column17: well-funded and ideologically inspired army.Yet Boeing is far more than just a builder of military hardware. The company's iconic ""7 Series"" passenger jets - the 747
column19: 777 and 787 - have allowed not just Americans
column20: but travelers worldwide to speed off to their destinations safely
column21: and in style. If you want evidence of American corporate greatness
column22: just look to the sky near any major metropolitan airport. You're sure to spot the greatness of Boeing in flight.Stocks to Buy:Amazon.com (AMZN)Source: ShutterstockOnline seller of everythingAmazon.com(NASDAQ:AMZN) has been making America great for nearly 23 years. The brainchild of CEO Jeff Bezos began life as a hub where avid readers could get the latest novels

column24: but for everything from music
column25: film

column27: electronics
column28: clothing
column29: toys
column30: toothpaste … and just about anything else one can require or desire.Amazon.com's relatively recent foray into the cloud computing business has been an unequivocal success

Amazon's web services business proves that not only does the company make America great by delivering the products we want right to our door
column32: it also makes possible many of the e-commerce sites the American - and global - economy relies on to function smoothly.Stocks to Buy:Apple (AAPL)Source:Yuanbin Du Via FlickrPersonal technology giantApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is not only one of the most profitable companies in history
column33: it's alsothe most admired. And why shouldn't it be?The ubiquity
column34: efficacy
column35: ease of operation
column36: quality
column37: sophisticated industrial design and just outright aesthetic beauty of the company's products is a feat of entrepreneurial genius that on its own can be cited as a ""drop-the-mic"" reason why America already deserves the greatness title.The company's iconic products - the Mac
column38: iPod
column39: iPad and iPhone - all have transformed the way not only Americans live
column40: but also the way most of the developed and developing nations live. AAPL stock ran into a slowdown for much of 2016
column41: but since Election Day
column42: Wall Street has made Apple shares great again
column43: with a surge of more than 10%.Investors are clearly betting on the continued upside likely to come with the release of the company's 10th-anniversary iPhone. If you want proof America is already great
column44: just check your iMessages.Stocks to Buy:Facebook (FB)Source: ShutterstockSocial media pioneerFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) is a relatively recent entry into the ranks of companies making America great
column45: and it's done so by the sheer disruptive power of its product.The creation of CEO Mark Zuckerberg is the kind of game-changing invention that comes along infrequently
column46: but when it does it's hard to see how we ever got along without it.From connecting with old friends to staying in contact with relatives; and from discovering new interests
column47: nurturing hobbies and networking with others who share similar worldviews
column48: Facebook has become an essential part of the American (and global) experience.Ironically
column49: Facebook's flap with ""fake news"" and its ranking of certain news stories was an issue in the presidential campaign. Yet Facebook also was cited by President Trump as a key to his victory
column50: as he told CBS'60 Minutesthat thepower of his following on the social media gianthelped him win key races where he was outspent by his opponent.The 3 Best Sector ETFs to Buy for a Profitable 2017So
column51: Facebook not only already makes America great
column52: it also made President Trump's campaign a winner.Stocks to Buy:Goldman Sachs (GS)Source:Erik DrostIf you were asked to compile a list of the ""Big Banks"" that have financed America's growth
column53: as well as her ascension to greatness
column54: it's hard not to start withGoldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS).The premier investment bank has been at the center of the financial world since the reparative
column55: post-Civil War years
column56: when it helped finance America's rebirth beginning in 1869.Since then the company has had a storied history of providing the capital
column57: as well as the financial framework

column63: better known as Google
column64: is its ghastly choice of new moniker. Yet despite its ill-fitting name

column66: the tech entrepreneurs leveraged the PC and internet explosion and created the go-to source for information on just about anything imaginable.Its corporate mission
column67: to organize the world's information and make it universally accessible and useful
column68: has long been accomplished. And though Google has only been in existence for less than 20 years
column69: like Facebook
column70: it also has become an essential part of the American and the international experience.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsJust try to go more than a few days without using Google. It's nearly impossible
column71: especially if you are someone who loves knowing things.Stocks to Buy:Disney (DIS)Source: ShutterstockAnyone who has grown up in America since the 1940s

column79: and that it will remain great long after President Trump has completed his tenure in the Oval Office.Stocks to Buy:American Express (AXP)Source:Marcus Quigmire Via FlickrWhen ""American"" is part of your name

column82: andDow Jonescomponent

column88: American Express shares may be the biggest beneficiary. The reason why is because higher income and higher net worth consumers tend to use American Express more than rival credit cards.3 Dividend Aristocrats to Buy for Income and GrowthAs such

column90: a feat that on its own qualifiesCaterpillar Inc.(NYSE:CAT) for a spot on the 10 stocks that already make America great.The unmistakable CAT brand is responsible for helping more builders erect more homes
column92: office buildings
column94: bridges and dams than any government infrastructure project could ever do.In fact
column95: any effort to make America's infrastructure great again would likely start with a whole lot of equipment from Caterpillar
column96: as its heavy machinery is an integral part of massive build outs here at home
column97: and worldwide.The CAT brand also is seen as a sort of badge of honor in the developing world

column1: The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This Quarter;1/27/2017;"Analysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column2: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column3: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column4: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column5: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column6: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column7: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. MicrosoftMSFTfor one has strongly resisted government demands as have AppleAAPLand AmazonAMZN. Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like IntelINTC
column8: NVIDIANVDA
column9: Qualcomm and Advanced Micro DevicesAMD; networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column10: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column11: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column12: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column13: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column14: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column15: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column16: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column17: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column18: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column19: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column20: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter

column1: eBay's Stock Gains As Q4 Earnings Beat Market Expectations;1/27/2017;"eBay (EBAY) released its Q4 2016 results recently and they were in line with market expectations. The company's revenue grew 3% year over year to $2.4 billion during the quarter driven by consistent low single digit growth in both the marketplace and advertising businesses. The company's adjusted earnings of $0.54 per share were up 8% year over year
column2: just beating analyst consensus estimates of $0.53.Top line growth was driven by an 18% increase in StubHub sales and a 3% increase in Marketing & Advertising revenue over the prior year quarter. This was the fourth consecutive quarter of sales growth for eBay and was driven by:  1) structuring data into catalogs (for search engine optimization); 2) diversifying traffic sources; 3) enhancing the seller experience; and
column3: 4) trimming down the asset portfolio. However
column4: this increase was offset by a 9% increase in cost of revenues
column5: which led to a 4% decline in operating income to $638 million in the quarter. Another cause for concern was the decline in free cash flows due to declining cash flows from operations.eBay repurchased $1 billion worth of its own shares in the quarter
column6: bringing last year's total to $3 billion. The company stated that it plans to buyback about $1 billion worth of its shares this year. Owing to the company's market beat and in-line guidance
column7: eBay's stock rose 9% in after-hours trading on Wednesday and is currently about 5% above its pre-earnings price. In the first quarter this year
column8: the company expects revenue between $2.17 billion and $2.21 billion
column9: against consensus estimates of $2.20 billion. It also expects non-GAAP EPS of $0.46 to $0.48 per share
column10: against consensus estimates of $0.50.Average Spend Per Users DecliningmakeArticleAd();Although the number of active users continue to rise for eBay
column11: the average spend per user declined in 2016. Compared to an average spend per user of around $129 per quarter in 2015
column12: the figure was $127 per user per quarter in 2016. The consistent decline in every quarter of 2016 is a cause for concern for eBay
column13: especially considering rising competition in e-commerce from Amazon
column14: Walmart
column15: Target and even Groupon. eBay managment stated that it intended to ramp up TV advertisements to attract more millenials and work towards improving product search features on its website for buyers.Have more questions about Ebay? Please refer toour complete analysis for EbayInteractive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap|U.S. Mid & Small Cap|European Large & Mid Cap|More Trefis Research"

column1: How Risky Is The Procter & Gamble Company?;1/27/2017;"As a 179-year-old diversified producer of household products
column2: Procter & Gamble(NYSE: PG) is often regarded as one of the most risk-free stocks   on the market.It's a Dividend Aristocrat to boot
column3: having raised its   quarterly payout for 60 consecutive years
column4: and now offers a   healthy dividend yield. Selling product like soap
column5: laundry   detergent
column6: and razors that are as timeless now as they were a   century ago
column7: the company seems to have a business built to   last.Image source: The Motley Fool.makeArticleAd();P&G may
column8: therefore
column9: look bulletproof -- but looks can be   deceiving.Longevity is no guarantee of future success
column10: as we were   reminded earlier this month when Ringling Bros. and Barnum &   Bailey circus said it would fold up its tent after 146 years in   business. Pressure from animal rights groups forced the   entertainer to cut out elephants from its performances
column11: and   attendance sunk without them. Digital entertainment options that   existed a generation ago like iPads andNetflixalso likely hastened the circus' demise.The Tide-maker may not be facing such an existential threat
column12: but the competitive landscape is changing in its industry. Here   are a few of the risks investors should be on the lookout   for.E-commerceThe internet has upset the traditional order in retail. It's   created opportunities for upstart brands such as eyewear-maker   Warby Parker to challenge entrenched brick-and-mortar chains
column13: and   Procter & Gamble's biggest brands have also been   affected.Razor-maker Gillette has seen heady competition from online   brands like Dollar Shave Club and Harry's. Dollar Shave Club's   success led Gillette to roll out its own subscription-based   membership program
column14: and Gillette even sued Dollar Shave Club for   patent infringement in 2015. Launched in 2012
column15: Dollar Shave Club   helped cut Gillette's North American market share from 71% to 59%   in the intervening yearsas the start-up built up a membership base of 3.2 million   and was bought byUnilever(NYSE: UL) for $1 billion last year.An even bigger threat to P&G may come fromAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column16: the great disrupter of this era. Reports emerged   last year that the e-commerce giant would begin making its own   private-label goods
column17: including diapers and laundry detergent.   With tens of millions of Prime members in its ecosystem
column18: Amazon   has a ready-made legion of trusting customers that it could   likely cut off from P&G if it chooses to make quality   products and undercut it on price.A lack of innovationProcter & Gamble was once a hallmark of American   innovation
column19: as it was a pioneer of products like laundry   detergent
column20: fluoride-based toothpaste
column21: and disposable diapers
column22: but   its innovation pipeline has dried out in recent years as the   company has spent a smaller proportion of its revenue on R&D.   Its latest major invention was the Swiffer
column23: the floor-cleaning   system with disposable pads
column24: which it launched in 1999.The company's response to Dollar Shave Club may best   illustrate its attitude toward innovation these days. In 2014
column25: Gillette released the ProGlide FlexBall razor with a retail price   starting at $11.49
column26: though its only enhancement was a track ball   to guide the razor
column27: and planned to spend $200 million marketing   the new product.In other words
column28: the bulk of the product's budget seemed to go to   marketing
column29: rather than innovation. Gillette later created its own   shave club
column30: but its response to the start-ups has been generally   weak. It could have just bought Dollar Shave Club
column31: but the   company has been so focused on shedding brands that it may be   missing opportunities.Slowing growthPerhaps as a consequence of e-commerce threats
column32: a lack of   innovation and a stronger dollar
column33: Procter & Gamble has seen   its growth slow significantly in recent years. In its most recent   report
column34: organic sales increased 2%
column35: though investors sent the   stock up as it raised its full-year organic sales guidance from   2% to 2-3%.The stock's performance has also been underwhelming in recent   years
column36: as the chart below shows.PGdata byYChartsAs a defensive stock
column37: it's worth noting that P&G may be   more likely to outperform the broader market during a sell-off.   Perhaps more importantly for dividend investors
column38: the company's   dividend growth has slowed dramatically.Procter & Gamble Dividend HistoryCreate line chartsIn the last two years
column39: it hiked its dividend by 3% and then   just 1%. With a payout ratio of 73%
column40: the company has some room to   raise its dividend faster than that
column41: but without significant   increases in earnings growth it will be hard for the company to   beat low-single digit increases.Ultimately
column42: what defines risk for an investor is the chance of   losing money on a given investment. With its solid dividend   payout and stable of diversified brands
column43: investors can probably   count on a modest return from P&G in the coming years
column44: but   its recent underperformance against theS&P 500is a lesson. Even for investors looking for low-risk stocks
column45: there are probably better places to put your money.10 stocks we like better than Procter and     GambleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column47: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column48: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column49: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Procter and Gamble wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Has a History of Winning;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMay I be frank with you?General Electric Company(NYSE:GE) is a bit of a bore
column3: and that's putting it mildly. In fact
column4: of the thousands of investments available
column5: GE stock is the one I dread analyzing.Amazon.com
column6: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN) has the sexy industry
column7: Tesla Motors Inc(NASDAQ:TSLA) has the sexy CEO - or so I've been told - andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column8: NASDAQ:GOOGL) basicallyowns sex. General Electric? It has a 3.23% dividend yield - I think you're getting my drift.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's not to say that GE stock is irrelevant in the current markets. This week
column9: theDow Jones Industrial Averagehit20
column10: 000 pointsfor the first time in history.Not only is General Electric a component of the Dow 30
column11: it was a strong contributor to the record. GE stock turned in a 1.23% performance against its prior session. The average gains for the Dow-listed companies on the record-breaking day was only 0.6%
column12: which is surprisingly low.In fact
column13: there were only six companies that posted better numbers than GE
column14: and these were the usual suspects. In increasing order

column16: Goldman Sachs Group Inc(NYSE:GS)
column17: JPMorgan Chase & Co. (NYSE:JPM)
column18: Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) and standoutBoeing Co(NYSE:BA)
column19: which ringed up an impressive 4% move.Besides the obvious point that these companies are proudly red
column20: white and blue
column21: it's easy to see why they performed so well over the others. President Donald Trump has promised fewer regulations stymieing business
column22: more support for the military industrial complex and keeping jobs stateside. General Electric belongs among the titans of American industry; hence
column23: yesterday's robust gains.10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsBut is the recent surge of GE stock based on optimism for President Trump
column24: or a reaction from pronounced volatility? The answer to that question is critical for investors.GE Stock Is Exciting
column25: and That's Bad!GE has shed its boring image
column26: but for all the wrong reasons.Click to EnlargeWhile it's very early into the new year
column27: nevertheless
column28: it's worth pointing out that shares are down 4%. I should also mention that at this price point
column29: GE stock is firmly below its 50-day moving average
column30: and only a hair above its 200-DMA.I don't think the volatility should be ignored as a bunch of technical mumbo jumbo. Just a few days ago
column31: General Electric shares were down 6%.More worryingly
column32: traders haven't pushed the needle that far since GE faltered under the weight of an uninspiring and anemic fourth quarter of fiscal year 2016 earnings results.Rightfully
column33: people are concerned. True
column34: GE stock is a reliable investment
column35: making steady gains through all sorts of economic cycles. At the same time
column36: its stable nature can work against the investor if there's a sharp downfall. It may take an inordinate amount of time for General Electric to gain 10%
column37: but it could be gone in a flash. As an example
column38: GE returned 6% last year - and we've basically burned through two-thirds of that profit.I don't care how high the dividend yields are for General Electric. No one can afford to lose that much capital and justify the losses due to the passive income. Unless GE stock was offering double digits
column39: it's a bad deal. Of course
column40: the question would then become
column41: why are they offering double digits?Just Stay the Course With General ElectricSo should potential buyers heed the warning? Absolutely
column42: they should! GE stock has formed an ""inside day"" pattern against the losses incurred by the feeble earnings report. Unless shares can quickly fill the technical gap
column43: momentum definitely leans bearishly. Attempting to catch a falling knife here would not be the greatest idea.Asia Will Take Over the World
column44: and Facebook Inc (FB) Wants InThat said
column45: the month of January is GE stock'skryptonite. The last three Januarys produced a shockingly bad loss of 6%. Since 1962
column46: General Electric has averaged only 0.8% returns for the opening month of the calendar. In nominal terms
column47: there were only 28 positive Januarys over that time frame. That means that GE stock is as useful as a coin toss during the NFL playoffs.However
column48: the industrial titan is a consistent winner over the long run. By the end of the year
column49: GE stock is good for an average 13% return. Nominally
column50: 39 years ended sunny side up. This current decade has been particularly robust
column51: averaging over 15%.I've made this argument before
column52: but it really comes down to your end goal. If you're looking for a hot growth stock
column53: look elsewhere
column54: please! If you want to bide your time and not rock your portfolio with risk
column55: GE stock is a prudent choice.But even reliable names have their off seasons. Watch General Electric closely
column56: and wait for a baseline of technical support before going in too rich.As of this writing
column57: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy"" 20177 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeThe postWhy General Electric Company (GE) Stock Has a History of Winningappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What We Learned From the 2016 Retail Sales Numbers;1/27/2017;"makeArticleAd();The U.S. Census Bureau recently released its Retail Trade   Report for 2016. Despite negative news around the globe
column2: a hotly   contested U.S. presidential election
column3: and numerous threats to the   economy
column4: consumers upped their spending compared to the previous   year. Here are the details you need to know.Image source: Getty Images.The numbers and why they matterOn the year
column5: total retail and food services spending increased   3.3% over 2015 to $5.5 trillion. During the all-important holiday   shopping season
column6: lasting October through December
column7: sales were up   4.1% from the same period in 2015. Additionally
column8: consumer   spending increased sequentially each month from October through   the end of the year
column9: on consumers' rising comfort with opening up   their wallets for non-essential items.Why should investors care about the report? Well
column10: it means   more than sales for retailers. The monthly and annual retail   sales updates are an important metric for measuring the health of   the overall economy. Spending at the household level makes up   about two-thirds of U.S. gross domestic product
column11: a measure of all   goods and services produced in the country.Retail sales specifically are an important indicator because   they show the amount of money families are willing to spend after   basic necessities are paid for. The report includes money spent   on items including furniture
column12: auto parts
column13: groceries
column14: clothing
column15: and electronics. A slow and steady increase in total retail sales   shows that the average person has more extra money to spend each   month.While the monthly figures bounce around
column16: the average   consumer's willingness to spend an increasing amount would   indicate the economy is still in an upswing.Data source: U.S. Census Bureau's Retail Trade   Report. Chart by author.The report is valuable in gaining insights on the economy
column17: but   is also of interest to investors looking to capitalize on   business trends. The Census Bureau breaks down sales categories   and shows specifically where families are spending their extra   cash. Several industries posted handsome gains in 2016 and look   like they are set to have another strong year in 2017.The picture the numbers paintThe big winners on the year were internet retailers
column18: health   and personal care stores
column19: and restaurants and bars. The biggest   losers were gas stations
column20: department stores
column21: and electronics and   appliance stores. Here is a breakdown of how retail did on the   year by major category.Data source: U.S. Census Bureau's Retail Trade Report. Chart   by author.It might be easy for investors to try and chase stocks in the   categories that are faring the best
column22: but that could be dangerous.   Last year's winners could end up lagging behind going   forward.Looking for longer-term themes in the numbers is a better   strategy. One such theme has been the continuing rise of online   shopping. For years now
column23: internet retail has been growing by   double digits. Sales at nonstore retail
column24: digital retail in the   chart above
column25: grew 11.4% from 2015 to 2016. The obvious play   here would beAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column26: which got the party started. That party hasn't   ended yet
column27: as Amazon reported a 29% year-over-year increase in   product sales during its third quarter.An Amazon drone gets ready for liftoff. Image source:     Amazon.Traditional brick-and-mortar stores
column28: while late to pick   up on the shift in consumer shopping to online
column29: have   been busy playing catch-up. Last year retail kingWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT)
column30: fighting back against declining foot traffic
column31: announced the closing of 154 stores in the U.S.
column32: mostly smaller   formats. The company followed that announcement up with its   acquisition of e-commerce player jet.com over the summer. The   hope is that the move will kick-start Wal-Mart's sales and help   the company return to growth.The move to digital hasn't been limited to just general   merchandise
column33: either. For example
column34: many restaurants and grocery   stores have been rolling out online and mobile ordering   features. An early adopter of this format has beenBuffalo Wild Wings(NASDAQ: BWLD)
column35: which allows customers to order online and   pickup to-go. B-Dubs paired that with a ""Fast Break"" lunch   promotion promising quick turnaround for time-strapped diners.   The company has also begun experimenting with delivery in select   locations
column36: which also feeds into the company's online strategy of   making buying its food more convenient.A 2017 game planWith shoppers indicating their overall comfort in spending   money and 2016 finishing strong
column37: it looks like retail and food   services could have another good year in 2017. column1: Is Netflix Inc. a Growth Stock or a Cult Stock?;1/25/2017;"I personally like to invest in growth stocks
column2: butNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) has always seemed too hot to handle. The stock's   valuations never seem justified by its earnings
column3: yet it's rallied   almost 900% over the past five years.The bulls usually call Netflix a ""growth"" stock
column4: while many   bears call it a ""cult"" stock supported by brand awareness instead   of fundamental growth. Let's take a closer look at the streaming   giant's growth figures to see which label is better suited for   the streaming video leader.makeArticleAd();Image source: Netflix.How fast is Netflix growing?Between fiscal 2011 and 2016
column5: Netflix's annual revenues rose   175% from  $3.2 billion to $8.8 billion. During those five   years
column6: its total streaming subscribers worldwide climbed from   23.5 million to 93.8 million as it pivoted away from DVD-by-mail   subscriptions and expanded to overseas markets.Last quarter
column7: Netflix's total subscriber base grew  25%   annually
column8: fueled by 10% growth in the U.S. and 48% growth   overseas. That growth silenced critics who claimed that Netflix's   gradual increases in fees would cause its subscriber growth to   peter out. The bulls will likely claim that Netflix's robust   revenue and subscriber growth supports its price-to-sales ratio   of 6.8 -- which is more than double the industry average of    3.3 for broadcast media companies.Those numbers clearly indicate that Netflix's ecosystem is   growing
column9: and explain why it's become synonymous with streaming   video in many markets. That's why analysts expect Netflix's   revenue to rise 27% this year and  another 20% next year.   Meanwhile
column10: Netflix's growing portfolio of acclaimed original   shows -- likeHouse of Cards
column11: Daredevil
column12: andStranger Things-- are locking in subscribers and reducing its dependence on   pricey third-party content.But what about the bottom line?Netflix's revenue and subscriber growth look solid
column13: but its   bottom line growth doesn't. Between 2011 and 2016
column14: Netflix's net   income actually fell 17% from $226.1 million to $186.7 million   due to the rising costs of licensing third-party content
column15: the   development of its own multi-million dollar programs
column16: and its   aggressive expansion into overseas markets with localized   content.Image source: Netflix.But on the bright side
column17: Netflix's operating margin has   improved over the past few quarters
column18: rising from 3.3% to 6.2%   between the fourth quarters of 2015 and 2016. Netflix sees higher   revenue growth and reduced expenses boosting that figure to 9.1%   for the current quarter. Based on these bottom line improvements
column19: Netflix's net earnings are expected to grow 158% this year and   82% next year.Those figures sound impressive
column20: but they don't really justify   the stock's trailing P/E of 379. Its forward P/E of 69 looks less   frothy
column21: but it still indicates that quite a bit of its future   growth is already priced in. Investors should also note that   Netflix's heavy spending dropped its free cash flow to negative   $639 million at the end of the fourth quarter
column22: compared to   negative $276 million in the year ago quarter.Mind the disruptive headwindsNetflix has been a disruptive force over the past decade
column23: first crushing movie rental giants like Blockbuster and then   skewering traditional media
column24: cable
column25: and advertising companies by   convincing their subscribers to ""cut their cords.""But looking ahead
column26: Netflix is headed for head-on collisions   withTime Warner's(NYSE: TWX) HBO
column27: Amazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) Prime Video
column28: and numerous other stand-alone   over-the-top (OTT) platforms. IfAT&T(NYSE: T) is cleared to buy Time Warner
column29: the telecom giant could   exclude HBO Now and other streaming content fromdata chargesacross its networks -- which could force Netflix to subsidize its   users' data costs or pay AT&T for ""zero-rated"" content.Meanwhile
column30: Amazon has aggressively expanded Prime Video with   original content to counter Netflix
column31: bundled the platform into   its prisoner-taking Prime memberships
column32: and even offered   stand-alone video subscriptions at lower prices than    Netflix. Amazon Video has already become the third largest   streaming video service in  North America after Netflix and   YouTube according to research firm Sandvine -- so it's certainly   well-poised to hurt the streaming leader.So is Netflix a growth stock or a cult stock?I used to consider Netflix a cult stock
column33: but I don't think the   label is accurate anymore considering the stability of its   subscriber and revenue growth and its improving margins. Netflix   still looks pricey relative to its trailing 12 month earnings
column34: but its stabilizing bottom line growth indicates that it's not   that expensive relative to its future earnings growth   potential.Netflix is certainly a risky stock
column35: and competitive moves by Time Warner
column36: AT&T
column37: and   Amazon could sink it. But it's still a growth play which could   rally even higher as it locks in even more users worldwide with   well-received original shows and movies.Find out why Netflixis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column38: the newsletter     they run
column39: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column40: has tripled the market!*)Tom and David just revealed their ten top stock picks for     investors to buy right now. Netflixis on the list-- but there are nine others you may be overlooking.Click here to get access to the full       list!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Why My Visit to Amazon Books was Eye-Opening;1/25/2017;"When my wife said she wanted to take a long-awaited pilgrimage   to a bookstore
column2: I thought it would be a perfect opportunity to   check outAmazon.com's(NASDAQ: AMZN)  recently opened Amazon Books concept in   San Diego. Based on my previous bookstore experiences
column3: I expected   a sprawling big-box bookstore packed with tens of thousands of   books crammed into every available shelf space
column4: like sardines.   What I found was a small
column5: unassuming location with only a few   thousand titles
column6: with space for every book. I also found   opportunities to join the Amazon ecosystem at every turn.makeArticleAd();The Amazon Books at the Westfield UTC Mall in La Jolla. Image   source: Author.A bookstoreIt's been quite some time since my last visit to a bookstore.   Years back
column7: my family and I would go to the Borders near our home   every few months. We would browse the seemingly endless supply of   books that lined its shelves from floor to ceiling
column8: as well as   other sections containing a variety of newspapers
column9: music
column10: and   movies.Customers are encouraged to join Amazon Prime. Image source:     Author.Amazon Books was quite different. There were no movies or   music. There were wide aisles without crowding
column11: and while there   were plenty of books
column12: there were far fewer than I had   imagined.Only the most popular titles could be found. They were   arranged with the covers facing up so that you could see each   one. Though not the most efficient use of space
column13: it made browsing   a much less complicated experience. If a specific title was not   available
column14: customers were reminded that it could likely be   purchased on Amazon's website.And so much moreWhat was most surprising was the wide variety of Amazon   devices in the store. These included Fire Tablets
column15: Kindle   e-readers
column16: and Fire TV Stick. The Echo and Echo Dot
column17: Amazon's   interactive speaker systems with theAlexa virtual assistant
column18: were featured prominently. Placards illustrating people using   numerous Alexa commands hung between them: ""Alexa
column19: shuffle my   workout playlist"" and ""Alexa
column20: find me a Chinese restaurant"" were   two such examples.Several of each of the devices were mounted on stands for   hands-on customer interaction. Amazon Basics electronic   accessories
column21: as well as partner products that integrate with   Alexa
column22: were available. This area covered approximately 25% of the   store.Kindle and Echo displays. Image source: Author.One employee that I spoke to indicated that this was the   store's ""discovery center."" Many customers need the experience of   touching the products
column23: listening to them
column24: and interacting with   them before making a purchase. This provided a safe place for   experimenting and discovery of the features
column25: capabilities
column26: and   benefits of the products. Kindle e-readers could also be found on   shelves among the books
column27: displaying a nearby title
column28: with customer   testimonials regarding their love of the product.Signs advised customers that Amazon Prime members would pay   the same prices found on the website for both books and devices.   For non-members
column29: devices cost the same as for members
column30: but they   paid the list price for books. Staff would helpfully suggest that   they would save on their purchases by becoming Amazon Prime   members and detailed the many additional benefits of   membership.Investor takeawayThe one thread running through the entire visit wasn't so much   that this was a bookstore
column31: though by all outward appearances it   was. Amazon Books provided all the familiar trappings and is a   delightful bookstore in its own right -- wide aisles
column32: top   sellers
column33: and easy to see books make it an ideal place to while   away an afternoon. The undercurrent
column34: though
column35: revealed a rather   ingenious way of familiarizing customers with Amazon products and   services.This is an important
column36: when considering the following   statistics.  Amazon estimates that Prime members spend twice   the amount of non-members
column37: though some estimates put that number   as high as 4.6 times.  Current Prime membership is estimated   at 63 million -- more than half of US households.  The Echo   and Echo Dot have an installed base of approximately 5 million
column38: which also permit ease of ordering.  Customers with a   current Amazon store credit card spend 16% more than the average   Prime member.  Finally
column39: Amazon recently introduced its new   Prime Rewards Visa card
column40: which offers 5% back on Amazon   purchases.  Each of these is part of a coordinated   strategy aimed at increasing the number of Prime members
column41: as   these customers are the company's most lucrative.As an investor
column42: I think this is a brilliant strategy. The   prominent displays of its devices
column43: the demonstrations of product   capabilities
column44: and the regular reminders of the benefits of Prime   membership are a clever way to introduce the uninitiated to the   Amazon ecosystem.Find out why Amazon.comis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column1: Tech Stock Roundup: AAPL-QCOM Deal
column2: FB's Zuckerberg Testifies;1/25/2017;"With the 45thPresident of the United States vowing to bring back jobs to the country
column3: teach China a lesson and institute large-scale tax reform
column4: there has been a great deal of uncertainty surrounding technology stocks. To make matters worse
column5: President Trump has an axe to grind with AmazonAMZNand AppleAAPLwhile most AlphabetGOOGLexecutives have openly supported the democrats going into the elections.So companies are now making nice with the President like Tesla's Elon Musk
column6: who has changed tunes and is now tweeting his support. It's been reported that Google's Schmidt has also found reasons to visit the President. Executives that have supported Trump from the start are better off: some speculate that Zuckerberg is considering politics while ex-MicrosoftMSFTand GM employee Chris Liddell is moving to the White House as assistant to the President and director of strategic initiatives. Oracle CEO Safra Catz joined the executive committee of Trump's presidential transition team in December.Then there's Cramer
column7: promising us that the post inauguration sell-off won't last and that it's actually an opportunity to buy stocks.Amidst all the excitement surrounding the swearing in
column8: the FTC sued QualcommQCOMfor anti-competitive practices while Mark Zuckerberg took the stand to defend Facebook'sFBpurchase of Oculus. So let's dig in.Apple Forced to Use Qualcomm ChipsFollowing similar lawsuits
column9: huge fines ($1 billion in China and $890 million in Korea) and anticompetitive investigations in Taiwan and the EU
column10: the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has sued Qualcomm for ""de facto exclusive deals that were as effective as express purchase requirements and that effectively foreclosed Qualcomm's competitors from gaining processor business at Apple.""The FTC alleges that Qualcomm allowed Apple billions in discounts for exclusively using its chips and not using the competing 4G Wi-Max standard that Intel was pushing. This agreement
column11: running from 2011 to 2016
column12: ultimately killed WiMax. Apple wasted no time in sourcing from Intel after the expiry of the agreement in Sep 2016.Another point in contention is Qualcomm's practice of limiting access to its cellular chips and then hiking royalty payments
column13: amounting to ""a tax on the manufacturers' use of baseband processors manufactured by Qualcomm's competitors."" The FTC filed the lawsuit after a 2-1 vote. Qualcomm has of course denied the charges while Apple chose not to comment.Following the FTC lawsuit
column14: Apple filed one of its own against Qualcomm for a billion dollars. The amount is what Apple alleges that Qualcomm is witholding for rebates. Like the FTC says
column15: the deal was to keep Qualcomm chips in Apple products and is a fair indication that Qualcomm finally has some real competition.Mark Zuckerberg TestifiesFacebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg took the stand last week to deny charges that Facebook was aware of the violation of any employee agreement between Occulus head John Carmack and its former employer id Software
column16: a unit of ZeniMax
column17: the plaintiff in this case. He also denied that the technology developed by the startup Occulus and its founder Palmer Luckey was based on copyrighted technology belonging to ZeniMax.Carmack previously testified that he copied files from ZeniMax before moving to Occulus but did not use the information in Occulus and the terms of his employment allowed him to get involved with Occulus even while in ZeniMax employ. But the thing that could cost Facebook at this point is ZeniMax lawyer Toni Sammi's question: ""So your plan for a $2-point-something billion deal was to begin legal diligence on Friday
column18: and sign the deal on Monday
column19: over a weekend
column20: right?"" to which Zuckerberg said
column21: ""Yeah.""CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+2.09%+21.62%FB+0.33%+6.42%YHOO-0.14%+10.80%GOOGL-0.16%+9.94%MSFT+0.21%+16.26%INTC+0.63%+5.38%CSCO+0.20%+0.64%AMZN-0.65%+9.82%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateIndia Considering Apple Case: It's hard to tell just how badly India wants Apple to manufacture in the country. But if government officials agree to Apple's demands
column22: it would indicate that they want it bad. Because Apple has asked for just about every concession possible
column23: ranging from reduction in import duties on smartphones
column24: customs duty exemption on manufacturing equipment and raw materials
column25: a ""less-intrusive"" customs procedure to be completed in 30 minutes
column26: the right to import and refurbish iPhones that are more than 3 years old so they can be exported
column27: and so forth.Apple is trying to convince government officials that Indian made iPhones won't be competitive unless they give in to these demands even as its manufacturing costs in China are on the rise. But Asian phone makers are already manufacturing in the country with no such concessions
column28: so the regulations themselves may need to be altered and relaxed to accommodate not just Apple but also other manufacturers. This could take time.On a positive note
column29: Reuters reports that Information Technology Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has mentioned the setting up of a government panel headed by the cabinet secretary that would now clear investment proposals in the electronics sector above $1 billion
column30: instead of them going through multiple government departments.Microsoft Executive Joins Baidu: Baidu has appointed Qi Lu as its Chief Operating Officer and Group Head as it turns focus to artificial intelligence as the next growth driver. The company was mixed up in a scandal involving medical ads that led to stricter government regulations and consequently hit its revenues.Lu left Microsoft last year on health concerns but was in charge of its search business and also part of the team involved in architecting its artificial intelligence and bots technology. He holds more than 40 U.S. patents.Google Ad Auctions Are Suspect: The Wall Street Journal has independently confirmed that ads for Google products and the products of its sister companies usually find the top spot on the search engine results page. On checking 25K search results
column31: it found that Google products occupied the top spot 91% of the time and the top two spots 43% of the time.Google has said that this is because it is also a buyer of ads
column32: so its position comes from paying a higher price. It also says that this doesn't raise prices because when others bid for the price
column33: it's as if Google isn't bidding. Bottom line: other advertisers lose the top spot no matter what they bid for it. Google reportedly removed its ads in a number of cases when confronted with the data last December.Amazon
column34: Apple End Audiobook Exclusivity Deal: Apple and Amazon have decided to end the deal initiated back in 2008
column35: according to which Amazon subsidiary Audible became the exclusive supplier of audiobooks to Apple and was barred from selling to any other party. The agreement was actually serving no one because the market for audiobooks has advanced since then and it's now in the interest of both parties to be able to source from others and in Audible's case
column36: to also be able to sell on other platforms. Nonetheless
column37: it was preceded by regulatory scrutiny of the deal by German and EU competition authorities that felt it was inflating prices.Pandora Shares Gain: Pandora preannounced fourth-quarter results that it said exceeded its revenue and EBITDA targets. This came as a relief because it has been lowering expectations the last two quarters indicating continuing bad news. Moreover
column38: Pandora also said that the $5-a-month Pandora Plus garnered 365K new subscribers in the quarter and the Pandora Premium service remained on track to launch later this quarter. It also expects to lay off around 7% of the U.S. workforce
column39: which will further boost margins.Legal/RegulatoryCisco-Arista Developments: The U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agency has expressed concern that its earlier decision to lift the ban on Arista switches may have been incorrect. Following conversations with CiscoCSCO
column40: the CBP therefore intends to reinstate the ban. Arista has said that it will respond to Cisco points and re-engage with the CBP.In the meantime
column41: U.S.-manufactured switches will have to make do
column42: which can result in supply glitches and pressure on its gross margin. On Dec 2
column43: the ITC judge ruled that Arista patents infringe on Cisco's and Arista has subsequently produced workaround while denying the charges. A full commission review of the judge's decision will be completed by Apr 9.New Technology/ProductsGoogle to Launch Android One Phones In U.S.: Google's high-end Pixel phones are mostly unavailable
column44: but it's already gearing up to launch the low-end ($200-$300) Android One devices in the country by the middle of the year. The goal seems to be to build brand value and familiarize people with the Android ecosystem.Android One was first launched in India and later in other countries including Japan and then Europe. It is a system under which Google agrees beforehand with handset manufacturers to push out Android updates as soon as they are available so the experience is true to the latest iteration of the software.M&A and CollaborationsHPE Buying Simplivity: Hewlett Packard Enterprise is dishing out $650 million to buy SimpliVity
column45: the second largest provider of hyperconvergence software (after Nutanix which has over 50% market share). The company describes a hyperconverged system as one that integrates compute
column46: storage and networking into a pre-configured system
column47: managed by a user-friendly software platform that doesn't require extensive IT staff for set up and management.Within a couple of months after the deal closes
column48: HPE will offer a range of integrated HPE SimpliVity hyperconverged systems based on HPE ProLiant Servers. The acquisition significantly strengthens its position in the space where competitors like Cisco and Dell/EMC base their hyperconvergence solutions on market leader Nutanix or Simplivity software. HPE will initially support current SimpliVity customers.Cisco
column49: Ericsson Join Forces in Australia: The collaboration between Ericsson and Cisco on telecom cloud infrastructure has yielded a major customer in Vodafone Hutchison Australia (VHA). The companies will virtualize Vodafone's infrastructure
column50: enabling it to improve customer service and user experience while increasing network agility
column51: reducing opex and capex
column52: and speeding up the deployment of services. The partnership has reportedly generated 60 new deals and is expected to generate revenue of a billion dollars to each partner by 2018.Microsoft Acquires Simplygon: Microsoft has acquired 3D data optimization specialist Simplygon of Sweden for an undisclosed sum. This is intended to play an important role in developing its 3D For Everyone strategy
column53: which is part of the Windows 10 Creators Update. 3D optimization is used by game developers and others to facilitate 3D content creation.Simplygon also does more than this: it has already started optimizing content for AR and VR technology
column54: including for Microsoft's Hololens. Microsoft believes that by making the technology a part of its creators update
column55: users will be empowered to capture
column56: create and share 3D content thus augmenting their productivity
column57: collaboration and creativity.Google Buys Twitter Developers Platform: Google has acquired Fabric
column58: which is based on Crashlytics technology (crash analytics
column59: app feedback and real-time analytics) that Twitter acquired back in 2013. Google hasn't said how much it's paying for Fabric
column60: but has said that it will be a part of its cloud based mobile software effort called Firebase that was itself acquired in 2014. Firebase offers mobile app developers tools to build and monitor their apps
column61: so any attempt to build its capabilities should help the company attract developers.Alibaba Has Long-term Digital Deal: Alibaba and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) signed a deal
column62: according to which Alibaba will be responsible for the IOC's digital presence through its cloud platform. The deal makes Alibaba the digital sponsor of the Olympics in cloud services
column63: e-commerce and television for a period running through 2028. While immediate returns may not there
column64: this lends credibility to the service and should help Alibaba win big customer accounts.WDC Considering Toshiba Stake: Nikkei Asian Review has reported that Toshiba is looking to spin off or sell off a 20% stake in its chip business in which case Western Digital might be the one picking it up. Toshiba is in trouble right now as it has to deal with an unprofitable nuclear business and accounting scandal that requires it to cough up some cash. Selling off a share to its longtime partner Western Digital (the two operate a flash memory fab in Japan) might be just the answer it needs.Some NumbersUK App Store Prices Up: As a result of the pound's continued declines
column65: Apple has been compelled to raise App store prices by as much as 25%.Intel Invests in Retail Tech: At the National Retail Federation's annual conference in New York
column66: Intel said that it intended to invest $100 million in retail technology over the next five years. It also announced the Intel Responsive Retail Platform
column67: which uses a combination of sensors
column68: software kits and other hardware solutions to provide ""in-the-moment information about what customers are buying
column69: what they want and how to manage inventory so it arrives just in time for customers to take it home"".Companies That Reported Results Last Week: CHKP
