column1: Alibaba Earnings Takeaways: Strong Growth Across Segments;1/25/2017;"Alibaba(BABA) announced its fiscal Q3 earnings on January 24
column2: reporting a 54% year-over-year increase in revenues to RMB 53.2 billion. The massive revenue growth was similar to results from the March
column3: June and September quarters
column4: with new acquisitions driving much of the top line growth. Alibaba acquired online video streaming platform Youku Tudou in November 2015 and Singaporean e-commerce giant Lazada in April 2016
column5: which drove Digital Media and International Retail Commerce revenues
column6: respectively. Additionally
column7: Alibaba's core commerce and cloud business continued to grow at a strong pace through the December quarter - similar to the trend observed all year.We have a revised$99 price estimate for Alibaba's stock
column8: which is roughly in line with the current market price. Alibaba's stock price rose from $88 at the end of last year to around $101 currently.makeArticleAd();See our complete analysis for AlibabaStrong Revenue Growth Across DivisionsIn addition to inorganic growth in Digital Media and International Retail segments
column9: Alibaba reported a massive 115% annual increase in Cloud Computing revenues to RMB 1.8 billion for the December quarter. As a result
column10: full year Alibaba Cloud revenues were up almost 140% y-o-y to RMB 5.6 billion. The growth in revenues was largely due to a more than 100% increase in the total number of paying customers for cloud computing and internet infrastructure offerings from 313
column11: 000 customers in September quarter last year to 765
column12: 000 this year. This number is expected to increase given the huge demand for internet infrastructure across China and other Asian markets. As a result
column13: we expect strong growth in Cloud Computing revenues for Alibaba in the coming years. (Read more: Amazon Vs. Alibaba: Cloud Services In Focus)Alibaba's core e-commerce business includes websites Taobao
column14: Tmall and Juhuasua
column15: and has provided consistent growth for the company over the last few years
column16: with revenues growing from RMB 24 billion in 2012 to RMB 75 billion in 2015. This segment witnessed a sustained period of growth
column17: with Q3 FY'17 revenues rising by 42% y-o-y to RMB 42.6 billion. Similarly
column18: full year revenues were up 43% to RMB 112.3 billion (or around $16.5 billion at current exchange rates).In the December quarter
column19: Alibaba's online retail segment in China was boosted by an 9% increase in annual active buyers and a 25% increase in mobile monthly active users (MAUs) to 443 million and 493 million
column20: respectively. Additionally
column21: the revenue per buyer (particularly for mobile users) has also surged on a year-over-year basis as shown below.In terms of operating profits
column22: Alibaba's adjusted EBITDA grew by 43% year-over-year to RMB 70.1 billion for the year. The rate of growth of operating profit was slightly lower than revenue growth since the company invested heavily in its smaller non-commerce segments. For instance
column23: Alibaba is spending a lot on developing platforms for cloud computing
column24: acquiring traffic for the online video and music segments
column25: and investing in content and production with a longer term view. As a result
column26: the smaller divisions operate at a loss
column27: as shown in the table. While the margins of the loss-making divisions have improved
column28: it could take a year or two for these divisions to become profitable. As a result
column29: the company-wide margins can improve in the long run given the relatively low variable costs
column30: due to which its operating leverage will remain high.View Interactive Institutional Research (Powered by Trefis):Global Large Cap | U.S. Mid & Small Cap | European Large & Mid CapMore Trefis Research"

column1: Which Streaming Service Has the Most-Satisfied Customers?;1/25/2017;"Americans remain somewhat divided on their favorite streaming   service
column2: but they have a clear pick when it comes to which one   they like the least. A newreportfrom Strategy Analytics measured customer satisfaction in 14   categories across three key areas: the number and availability of   TV shows/films
column3: how easy it is to find them
column4: and the overall   value of the service.Time Warner's(NYSE: TWX) HBO Now won the most categories
column5: taking 11 out of   14
column6: butNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) received the highest score when it came to overall   satisfaction.Both Netflix and HBO Now can stake a claim as having the top   service
column7: and Hulu made a strong case for third place
column8: beating   Netflix in six of 14 categories and scoring top marks in   children's programming. Amazon Prime
column9: however
column10: consistently   brought up the rear
column11: ranking last in all 14 categories among the   four services rated.""HBO Now has successfully positioned itself as a go-to-service   for quality programs
column12: especially movies
column13: said Strategy Analytics   analyst Zhaowen Wu in the press release. ""Though HBO Now has a   much smaller library than other SVOD [subscription video on   demand] services
column14: it has more blockbuster movies and hit series   such as Game of Thrones and Westworld.""makeArticleAd();Image source: Strategy Analytics.HBO is the big winnerHBO's stand-alone streaming service was a late entry to the   field
column15: first launching in April 2015. The company was late to the   party because it did not want to upset its cable partners
column16: which   had long sold the channel as a premium service. That legacy as a   cable product may be the only reason Netflix scored a victory in   overall customer satisfaction
column17: according to Strategy Analytics   Digital Media Strategies Director Michael Goodman.""When considering the bigger picture
column18: Netflix clearly benefits   from its brand 'halo' while HBO Now suffers from a negative   association with cable's legacy issues
column19: he said. ""However
column20: once   one gets into the weeds
column21: the reality is that HBO subscribers are   the most satisfied with nearly all elements that make up a strong   SVOD service.""Goodman did point out that the overall difference in scores is   relatively small. He also explained that while Amazon was the   clear loser in the report
column22: the fact that the video service is   just one element of the company's Prime membership means its   members ""may actually be the least likely to churn
column23: particularly   as they're the most likely to have household incomes above   $100
column24: 000.""Netflix ranked highest for overall satisfaction. Image source:   Netflix.Which services will people get?HBO Now costs more than any of its rivals at $14.99 a month.   Hulu costs $7.99 with commercials or $11.99 without while Netflix   charges $9.99 a month
column25: and Prime costs $99 a year (or it can be   purchased for $10.99 a month) and includes other perks like free   two-day shipping. Goodman acknowledged that many consumers will   buy more than one streaming subscription
column26: but he sees HBO as   potentially emerging as the top choice.""People have been talking about it being a Netflix vs. Amazon   battle in terms of which service viewers choose
column27: with the others   left to pick up the scraps
column28: he said. ""However
column29: if HBO continues   on this vein
column30: we're more likely to see a situation where people   will have one 'blockbuster' service like HBO or HBO Now and   either a Netflix or Amazon in support.""That interpretation would ring more true if Netflix did not   already have 47.91 million U.S. subscribers
column31: a gain of nearly 2   million paying customers in Q4. Time Warner does not report HBO   Now subscribers
column32: but the number was estimated at about 1 million   in March 2016. That's not a representative picture of how many   people are watching because HBO still has tens of millions of   traditional cable subscribers.There will be more than one winnerWhat's clear from this report is that both HBO and Netflix are   considered top-tier streaming services by consumers while Prime   and Hulu sit at least a slight tick below. In a market where   people are dropping cable subscriptions that cost more than $100   a month on average
column33: it seems likely that both HBO and Netflix can   be winners.In fact
column34: given how closely these scores are grouped and the   fact that the key driver for many Prime customers is free   shipping
column35: it's possible that all four of these services will   continue to grow. Paying for all four would cost $45.22 a month   (prorated for paying $99 for Prime all at once) and it can be   argued that just getting all four costs well less than cable   while offering a comparable
column36: if not a better
column37: array of   entertainment is a big win.Find out why Netflixis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact
column38: the newsletter     they run

column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFor three of the last four quarters
column4: the market reaction to earnings fromAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) has been a disappointment. After last year's Christmas earnings were released
column6: Amazon stock dropped below $500 per share. After the March earnings came out
column7: you could get it for about $600. September's numbers took it off its all-time high of $835 to a low below $720.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockNow AMZN shares are on the march again; as InvestorPlace contributor Richard Saintvilus predicts
column8: it will zoom to $1
column9: 000and Street Authority writes that it isstill a winner.Yet earnings estimates for the quarter that ended in December are not extreme. Beating the consensus earnings estimate of$1.46 per sharewould not be a record - earnings were $1.77 per share in June. It's the top-line that should stand out - $44.77 billion would top last Christmas' record of $35.7 billion in revenue by 25%. The estimated yearly handle of $136.7 billion would top last year's figure by more than 25%.That's what you're buying with Amazon stock: big growth in big numbers.AMZN: Killing It on ChristmasBy all accounts
column10: Amazon killed it over Christmas.Almost before the tinsel came down
column11: Macy's Inc(NYSE:M) said it wouldclose 68 stores and lay-off more than 10
column12: 000 workers.Kohl's Corporation(NYSE:KSS) cut its earnings forecast andother retailers were ""slaughtered.""10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsSlice Intelligence estimatesAMZN got half the last-minute Christmas trafficand Morgan Stanley estimates Amazon has sold over 11 million of its Echo voice-command devicesbefore December.The $50 Fire tablet sold out.The good news may have just started. Fire tablets are going to sell more Prime memberships
column13: and those memberships are even-more valuable with a new credit card offering 5% cash back on Amazon purchases.I know that in my house
column14: I don't have time to see all the new Amazon shows that come with Prime. The $99 per year Prime Unlimited book offer keeps the family occupied. An Amazon ""shopping cart"" that used to be prime for abandonment is now a placeholder. I go offline and come back when I want to add enough for free shipping instead. The company's ad of a priest and imam buying each otherlime green kneepadswent viral.Oh
column15: and did you see the Oscar nominations this week?Manchester by the Seadrew six nominations
column16: including Best Picture. The studio?Amazon.com.Amazon Stock: No Bears LeftThe worst thing I can say about AMZN stock today is that it has nearly extinguished the bearish analysts who used to moan that it made no money and that it was a Ponzi scheme.The worst thing you can say was said by Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak. Amazon is startinganother investment cycle.This will cut into profits.I remember debating those people
column17: loud and long
column18: until I finally listened to my own arguments and bought some Amazon shares
column19: at about $330 each. Now
column20: at nearly $830
column21: they represent a huge portion of my retirement portfolio. Jeff Bezos is literally paying for my old age.Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) Q4 Earnings PreviewWere it not forInvestorPlace Contributor Chris Tyler
column22: I would be worried. Chris is a technical analyst and
column23: since he made his call on Jan. 3
column24: the shares are up nearly 10%. As Scooby-Doo would say
column25: ""ruh-roh.""It's when everyone is bullish that it's time to be bearish. The Dot-Com bubble of 2000 happened because there were no more buyers left - everyone was in the market.For those of us who have ridden this bull for several years
column26: then
column27: it might be time to take some profits on Amazon stock. Don't wait for earnings. Someone will find a reason to sell AMZN stock after earnings and
column28: even if they don't
column29: I didn't say sell out your position.Just take a little something off the table. Enjoy your profit. Buy something from Amazon - Valentine's Day is coming.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud

column1: Apple Earnings Strategy: When To Buy AAPL Shares;1/25/2017;"Apple will release earnings soon (Shutterstock photo)Apple (AAPL) will release their earnings for the fourth quarter of 2017 next Tuesday
column2: and the guessing game has begun. It used to be that analysts would wait until they had seen the numbers before opining or changing any rating on Apple stock. In part that was because up until last year
column3: the company continually made those analysts look foolish by beating every quarter’s estimates by huge margins.That meant that investors who bought the stock in the run up to earnings invariably benefited
column4: and analysts would rush to upgrade forecasts once the extent of the beat was known. However
column5: the recent slowdown in growth has changed the dynamic somewhat.makeArticleAd();Now it seems that the competition among those that cover AAPL is to see who can come out with the gloomiest earnings prediction
column6: and who can downgrade the earliest. Over the past week two big names
column7: Barclays and Stifel have downgraded AAPL in front of earnings
column8: both citing worries about i-Phone 7 sales.This kind of focus on potential and actual negatives surrounding Apple’s earnings has changed the way retail investors should approach the release too. With such negativity abounding the stock is likely to lose ground as earnings approach
column9: and/or to react to anything but a spectacular report in a negative
column10: or at best muted
column11: manner.Far from buying in front of the release
column12: then
column13: waiting until afterwards makes sense this time around. That assumes that buying AAPL at all would be a good idea; an assumption not everybody will be comfortable with. The negative slant to coverage that makes it likely that you will be able to pick up AAPL cheap next week will also put off some people
column14: but a look at the facts and prospects should reassure you.First
column15: let’s look at the stock’s actual performance. If you listen to the naysayers they would have you believe that AAPL has underperformed recently. The reality
column16: though
column17: as demonstrated by the chart below comparing AAPL to the Nasdaq tracking ETF
column18: QQQover the last six months
column19: is completely different. During that time AAPL has outperformed its benchmark by a factor of 3
column20: gaining 24% compared to the index’s 8%.Appreciation in AAPL though
column21: as with any stock
column22: is about what will happen in the future rather than what has happened in the past
column23: but there are a few reasons to be optimistic on that front too. As I wrotea few weeks ago
column24: my personal experience suggests that demand for the Apple Watch series 2 is greater than anybody expected
column25: with a fair amount of pent up demand resulting from widespread shortages of the product in the holiday buying season.In addition
column26: even those anticipating lower than expected iPhone sales have noted that the higher priced 7 Plus has proven more popular than expected
column27: which should benefit the bottom line.All of that is positive
column28: but what investors are really looking for is for Apple to do something spectacular again in order to re-invigorate the whole ecosystem. Their recent decision to start commissioning original content for Apple TV offers the possibility of that. Content production is
column29: of course
column30: a very crowded field right now
column31: and a difficult business at the best of times
column32: but Apple has a huge advantage over others that might try to break into the market: over $200 billion in cash.As Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) have shown
column33: it only takes one or two hits to be successful in this area and with the ability to absorb a few failures
column34: betting against Apple succeeding would seem to be foolish.Add in a decent and growing dividend and buying or adding to holdings of AAPL is a good idea. With that said
column35: though
column36: the fact that the conventional wisdom seems to be that this will be a disappointing earnings release for the company makes patience in this case a virtue
column37: and waiting until after next Tuesday’s report is a risk that should pay off."

column1: If I Could Buy Only 1 Stock
column2: This Would Be It;1/25/2017;"Image source: Apple.makeArticleAd();If I could only buy one stock right now
column3: then there are a few   boxes that stock needs to check. I'd like the holding to be   relatively safe in a tumultuous time but still look likely to   generate modest short-term growth
column4: while having the potential for   exceptional long-term growth. I also want the stock to have a   robust balance sheet and be relatively cheap in this expensive   market -- and is a little dividend too much to ask?For all of that
column5: look no further thanApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) .Short-term growth prospects look goodApple's finances are massive in almost every way
column6: with sales   in the fiscal Q4 ended Sept. 24 of $47 billion. Sales and   earnings actually slowed during the during quarter
column7: down 9% and   19%
column8: respectively
column9: but the company has guided for a return to   sales growth in fiscal Q1.Some Apple bears have pointed to the company's reliance on its   iPhone -- which made up about two-thirds of sales in the most   recent quarter -- and that those sales are starting to slow as   the phone seems to be saturating the addressable market. The   average selling price (ASP) of the iPhone segment has fallen   slightly year over year.However
column10: the iPhone could have plenty of growth left. The new   iPhone 7 launched in late 2016 seems to be performing very well   already and should help to boost ASP once again. Additionally
column11: the issues with the explodingSamsungGalaxy Note 7
column12: which has even been banned on all U.S.   aircraft
column13: could help to make 2017 iPhone sales the highest   yet.Image source: Apple.The bears also point to nascent growth in most of Apple's   other products
column14: such as its personal computers
column15: iPads
column16: and the   Apple Watch. One other area that's growing impressively is the   services segment
column17: which includes revenue from services such as   iTunes
column18: iCloud
column19: and Apple Pay. This segment's revenue grew 24%   year over year to $6.3 billion in the fiscal year
column20: making up 13%   of total revenue as Apple's second largest segment by sales   behind the iPhone segment. Services are increasingly important
column21: as the total number of Apple products in use continues to grow   each quarter
column22: meaning more devices that are likely linked to an   Apple account and could help services revenue to continue growing   nicely.Apple's robust financial positionWhile Apple's sales and earnings have come under pressure
column23: its   cash growth has not. Apple's operating cash flow in the most   recent quarter surged to $16 billion
column24: a new company record for   that time period. With so much excess cash flow
column25: the company   has grown its total cash and investments to $238 billion
column26: more   than a third of its market cap
column27: and aboutdouble the next wealthiest company in the United   States.Unfortunately for Apple's capital expenditure advocates
column28: about   90% of that money is stored out of the U.S.
column29: as the company has   resisted paying heavy repatriation taxes to bring it back home.   However
column30: President Trump has signaled that he'd like to offer a   much lower tax rate
column31: maybe as low as 10%
column32: for companies in   Apple's position that are seeking to send huge chunks of money   home. There are certainly other risks for Apple in some of   Trump's proposed tax ideas
column33: such as potential import tariffs on   goods manufactured overseas
column34: but this one point is important for   what it could mean for Apple's cash available for immediate   use.Long-term growth potentialApple's new wireless headphones
column35: called ""air pods."" Image     source: Apple.Apple's modest short-term growth on continued incremental   innovations and execution is encouraging
column36: but it's much more fun   to consider Apple's moonshot long-term growth possibilities.   Apple increased its research and development spend by about 25%   to $10 billion in fiscal 2016.Speaking of the company's huge cash position
column37: there are a few   fun reckless predictions we can make about what the company might   spend that money on developing. Self-driving cars
column38: virtual   and augmented reality
column39: and more recently original content for   iTunes are all areas of growth that tech industry analysts are   looking for from Apple.My favorite reckless prediction is that Apple will begin   competing more heavily in artificial intelligence. Apple's Siri   was one of the first voice-based search tools beforeAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) andGoogle(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) entered the space with their smart   home voice-activated devices.Amazon and Google beat Apple to market with their home   assistant devices
column40: but Apple isn't known for being an early   market mover -- rather
column41: Apple has a knack for swooping in with   amazing products that in turn dominate the market that's already   there. Let's not forget that Amazon and Google have ventured into   Apple's world with their consumer electronics much more than   Apple would be venturing into theirs with its own artificial   intelligence assistant.WhyApple stockstill looks like a great buyFinally
column42: in terms of valuation
column43: Apple still looks cheap. Even   though the stock is up 20% over the past six months
column44: it's still   trading at just 14 times earnings. Compare that with around 25   times earnings on average for the S&P 500
column45: Google at 30
column46: and   Amazon at 185. Also
column47: Apple stock has run up quickly lately
column48: but   it's still down from its high of around $135 in mid-2015
column49: so its   recent run doesn't look unreasonable.Add to that a relatively cheap valuation
column50: as well as all of   the points covered here
column51: that Apple stock also pays a 2% dividend   yield
column52: which could very well rise as Apple deploys more of its   huge cash load in 2017. The best investment strategy is one   that's well diversified
column53: but for all of those points -- if I   could only buy one stock
column54: Apple continues to look like a great   stock to buy and hold as a core long-term position.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: What's Behind Netflix's Massive Subscriber Additions;1/24/2017;"Image Source: NetflixIt's been 10 years sinceNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) launched its video-streaming service
column2: and it just   added the most new subscribers ever in a quarter. The   streaming-video leader added 7.05 million total new subscribers   -- 1.93 million in the U.S.
column3: 5.12 million internationally --   bringing its total to almost 94 million.Not only did those numbers exceed Netflix's and analysts'   expectations
column4: they represented a significant recovery from poor   net addition numbers in the second and third quarters. In fact
column5: Netflix added more subscribers in the fourth quarter than the   second and third quarters combined. So
column6: what factors led to   Netflix's massive subscriber additions?makeArticleAd();The end of the great un-grandfatheringDuring the second and third quarters
column7: longtime Netflix   subscribers saw their monthly rates increase from $8 or $9 per   month to $10 per month. Netflix had un-grandfathered 75% of   subscribers by the end of the third quarter. Importantly
column8: those   un-grandfathered in the fourth quarter saw just a $1 increase
column9: while most of the earlier price increases were $2.Netflix noted that subscriber churn increased more than   expected in the second quarter
column10: and it clearly remained elevated   in the third quarter. However
column11: management also told investors   that gross additions remained in line with expectations. In the   fourth quarter
column12: it seems churn rates returned to normal   levels.What's most telling is the amount Netflix spent on marketing
column13: particularly in the U.S. Marketing expenses actually declined   compared to the third quarter
column14: but Netflix managed to add five   times as many subscribers. Unless Netflix made some drastic   changes in marketing last quarter (it didn't)
column15: its gross adds   have likely remained relatively stable (with adjustments for   seasonality).It's also worth noting that some customers who left over the   Summer may have rejoined last quarter. Netflix's constant stream   of new releases makes it difficult to stay away from it once   you've gotten used to it.Pulling forward some subscribersNetflix's outlook for the first quarter is about in line with   analysts' expectations
column16: but it expects a little less from the   U.S. and a little more from the rest of the world. In its letter   to shareholders
column17: management wrote
column18: ""We believe our strong Q4   results likely pulled forward some net adds from Q1'17 to   Q4'16.""To be clear
column19: that's not a bad thing. The sooner people sign   up
column20: the sooner Netflix starts making money off of them. But   it does mean investors should temper their expectations for the   first quarter
column21: especially with the new season ofHouse of Cardsbeing pushed back into the second quarter.A new high-revenue subscriber baseNow that Netflix customers are all paying higher rates
column22: the   company should continue to add subscribers at a more steady pace.   Netflix said its average sales price per U.S. subscriber was up   15% last quarter thanks to its price increase. As a result
column23: domestic revenue increased 27%
column24: while the subscriber base   increased just 10%.Netflix will face more pressure on international growth this   year now that Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) launched Prime Instant Video   globally. What's more
column25: Amazon is undercutting Netflix's pricingin most countries
column26: which could constrain Netflix's ability to   keep increasing its prices.Netflix may respond by shifting some of its marketing budget   from the U.S. to its International division. Of course
column27: it will   also continue investing in new originals and licensed content for   its international audience. But Amazon has the marketing and   content budget to keep up with Netflix.Whether that impacts Netflix's ability to continue growing its   subscriber base or raise prices remains to be seen. It certainly   hasn't had a huge impact in the United States
column28: where Amazon also   undercuts Netflix's pricing.Last quarter's results show that Netflix might experience a   few hiccups as it raises prices
column29: but it's capable of getting back   on track quickly.Find out why Netflixis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. (In fact

column1: The Problem With Apple's TV Ambitions;1/24/2017;"Image Source: Motley Fool.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL) has toyed with the idea of entering the television   industry for what seems like ages now. Since it unveiled the   original Apple TV in 2007
column2: the company has considered   manufacturing its own television set
column3: putting together a ""skinny   bundle
column4: and even
column5: according to pundits
column6: making an offer for a   company likeNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) .makeArticleAd();Apple has long had a foothold in music ever since it launched   iTunes
column7: and television could bring the same complementary   benefits to its ecosystem. Apple already sells many of the   devices used to consume streaming video
column8: and technology has   tipped the entertainment scales toward tech companies rather than   traditional media players. After Netflix
column9: e-commerce giantAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) has made the biggest splash in streaming.Now Apple wants to join the herd
column10: producing its own original   shows. According toTheWall Street Journal
column11: the company has been in talks with producers to make its own   programming
column12: which would be available to subscribers of its   $10/month music-streaming service. The company hopes to launch   such programming by the end of 2017.However
column13: while it seems natural for Apple to have ambitions in   TV
column14: diving straight into original programming could present a   number of challenges for the company.1. Profits are thinAfter years of breakneck international expansion
column15: Netflix is   finally set to deliver its first year of ""material profits"" since   2011
column16: when it split its streaming service from its DVD-by-mail   business after years of operating at breakeven. Amazon
column17: meanwhile
column18: doesn't break out figures for its streaming service
column19: and essentially gives it away to its Prime members
column20: using its   content as a carrot to entice more people to shop on its   website.The point is that video streaming is no one's idea of a cash   cow at this point. The services are so cheap
column21: at about $10/month
column22: that a company needs to generate a substantial base before hoping   to make a profit. Netflix
column23: for example
column24: is set to top 100 million   subscribers this year
column25: but it took the company years to get to   that point. Apple could operate the service at a loss
column26: but that   seems contrary to the company's high-margin business model. With   more than $45 billion in net income in its last fiscal year
column27: it's   going to take more than a small video streaming service to move   the needle.2. Where's the expertise?Apple is a device-maker. Its brand and its profits come from   making hardware like the iPhone
column28: iPad
column29: and the Mac. Developing   and shopping for TV shows is outside of its core competencies
column30: and because iTunes has languished over the years
column31: it lacks the   detailed data that competitors like Netflix have on customer   preferences.Analysts dismissed Netflix's initial ambitions in original   programming
column32: but the company's vast database guided it when it   chose to remake the British seriesHouse of Cards
column33: as it recognized that its subscribers had a penchant for   political dramas and actor Kevin Spacey. That show would be the   first of several hit series for Netflix.Amazon may have had to start more from scratch
column34: though it had   its own a la carte streaming service before getting into   originals. That company's culture also prizes innovation
column35: risk-taking
column36: and failure
column37: and it launched its original   programming in 2013
column38: giving it a significant head start over   Apple. Thanks to its Prime subscriber base
column39: the company quickly   found an audience for its shows. In comparison
column40: Apple under Tim   Cook seems more content to leverage its current assets and   products into new revenue streams rather than build fresh   ones.If Apple wishes to give away original programming to its Apple   Music subscribers
column41: it may be able to build viewership like Amazon   did. But Apple doesn't have the same interest in adding perks to   Apple Music the way Amazon does with Prime. Ultimately
column42: the   company needs to find a way to grow profits
column43: and original TV   seems unlikely to do that either directly or indirectly as its   impact on hardware sales would probably be limited.Apple's track record in television so far also bodes poorly   for its ambitions
column44: as the company seems unclear of its ultimate   goal and is unable to successfully negotiate with media partners.   With its hardware sales stalling
column45: Apple has increasingly turned   to services like Apple Music or Apple Pay
column46: but the relationship   between its devices and TV seems tenuous at best. Rather than   entering the increasingly competitive media environment
column47: the   company would be better off leading with its strength
column48: directly   investing in research and development that would advance hardware   sales or develop its next blockbuster product..10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: The Top 5 Brands Millennials Love to Love;1/24/2017;"Market research firmMBLMhas released its latest Brand Intimacy Report
column2: which measures the   emotional attachment consumers have to various brands. The study   reveals that a strong connection is a key ingredient to a better   relationship with customers. This translates to better results   for the company over the long term
column3: and likely will have a   positive effect on its stock price.There's additional evidence that these customers are willing   to pay a premium for those preferred brands. Let's look at the   brands that have the strongest attachments for millennials and   why.makeArticleAd();Total Return Pricedata byYCharts.Nintendo enjoys a resurgence. Image source:Pixabay.5. Nintendo(NASDAQOTH: NTDOY) . Having grown up with Nintendo

column6: Final Fantasy
column7: Tetris
column8: andPokemon. Nintendo acknowledged those ties last year in a Father's Day   press release

Most millennials would have just been entering   their earning years with the release of the iPhone in 2007. The   introduction of the iPod six years earlier and it's 80% market   share provided a perfect transition.Research shows that

column21: and 87% report that their phones never leave their   sides.Millennials have grown up with technology and expect it to   work
column22: so dependability is important to them.Reader's Digestcalled iPhones the most trusted mobile phone brand for 2016. That   level of familiarity
column23: coupled with reliability
column24: breeds a certain   attachment.Netflix and chill. Image source: Netflix.3. Netflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) . Netflix is becoming the new normal

column26: this   demographic was born in the information age and is more tech   savvy than previous generations

column33: or on a mobile app

column35: as   well. It applies as an escapist play in the same manner as   Netflix
column36: via its Prime streaming service.Millennials' social networking proclivities play a part

column38: and solicit the views of   others. This plays directly to Amazon's DNA of customer reviews.   As consumers

column40: and according to studies

column43: while remaining a part of   their present. From the young stars on the Disney channel to some   of millenials' comic book favorites coming to life on the big   screen

column1: Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) Q4 Earnings Preview: Pixel & Home Could Fuel Growth;1/24/2017;"As per usual
column2: all eyes will be on the company formerly known as Google
column3: Alphabet Inc.GOOGL
column4: as the tech giant prepares to release its fourth-quarter earnings report on Thursday. The company rolled out its new Google Pixel phone and ushered in a new era of hardware-software interaction during the quarter
column5: making this week's announcement even more important than usual.In fact
column6: the Google Pixel will most likely be the most compelling aspect of Alphabet's latest report
column7: and investors will be clamoring to know how the device sold. It will also be interesting to see what the company says about its Google Home Controller
column8: which also launched in the U.S. this quarter.The Google Pixel is important because it is Alphabet's first high-end smartphone entirely produced in-house and represents a significant challenge to Apple'sAAPLiPhone line. The Google Home tells another story of competition; the ""Internet of Things"" in-home hub is one of the only competitors to Amazon'sAMZNEcho speaker.More importantly

column11: Google Assistant is the backbone of the Pixel and Home devices and promises to be the foundation for all of Google's original products heading forward.Also

column16: ""Google Wifi
column17: and a Chromecast update
column18: ""Chromecast Ultra.""All of these products are important pieces of Google's effort to create a complete line of products that work together and with the new Google Assistant software. This is just the first quarter of sales
column19: but it is also the holiday quarter and should give us a good idea of whether or not these products are resonating with shoppers.Heading into the report

column10: however

column17: represented in the category by Siri

Apple argues   that it isn't necessary to upload all of your data to the cloud   in order for Siri to improve. It uses a technique called   differential privacy
column23: which keeps individual information at the   local phone level and protects user privacy.  Though it   currently doesn't have a

It was found to rival and in many cases surpass its   nearest competitors. Assistant's greatest strength may be the   ability to answer follow-up questions
column27: a feature many of its   rivals lack. Integration with Google Home smart speaker puts it   squarely in competition with Amazon's Echo. Its strengths include   entire home synchronized audio and grouping of smart-home   commands.Some researchersbelieve that Alexa will cede its early lead in the category to   Google Assistant by 2020.Microsoft Cortana. column28: tablets and PC's. It has many competing   features

column1: Amazon Echo’s Alexa Gets a New Wake Word;1/24/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAmazon.com
column3: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa voice assistant has been a revelation
column4: which continues to grow in terms of the features it offers.Source: AmazonAdditionally
column5: the assistant that once existed as an add-on of the company's Echo speakerscan now be woken up
column6: or turned on using a new word. Amazon engineers have ensured that you can now turn on your favorite device that is linked up with Alexa by using the word ""Computer.""makeArticleAd();That's right
column7: you can turn on the robot assistant by calling it a computer
column8: which will work on Amazon
column9: with Echo speakers and other Alexa-related gadgets. The move is inspired byStar Trek
column10: where a machine would be turned on in the same manner.CEO Jeff Bezos is a big Trekkie

column13: the e-commerce retaileroffered some updateson the voice-activated assistant that may excite you even more.At CES 2017 earlier in January

column15: including household appliances such as your fridge
column16: your shopping and even your toaster.It can already hook up to your phone.AMZN shares grew 0.4% by Tuesday afternoon.More From InvestorPlaceThe 10 Best Contrarian Stocks to Buy in the New     YearThe 7 Best High-Yield Investments for     Retirement10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy""     2017The postAmazon Echo's Alexa Gets a New Wake Wordappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alibaba's "New Retail" Concept Threatens Amazon's Global Dominance;1/24/2017;"Alibaba GroupBABAimpressed investors with the release of its financial results for the December quarter on Tuesday. The Chinese e-commerce giant posted revenue growth of 54% year-over-year
column2: and while its traditional business performed well on the back of a solid Singles' Day
column3: the real story was the growth of Alibaba's newer segments.Financial ResultsAlibaba posted earnings of $1.09 per share and revenues of $7.669 billion
column4: which surpassed our consensus estimates of $0.85 per share and $7.483 billion. Revenues from core commerce increased 45% year-over-year to $6.708 billion
column5: while revenues from Alibaba's cloud computing and digital media and entertainment units grew 115% and 273%
column6: respectively.(Also Read:Here's Why Alibaba Stock Popped After   Earnings)Alibaba's biggest competitor in the world is clearly AmazonAMZN
column7: which holds a uniquely different share of the e-commerce market; nevertheless
column8: the actual head-to-head battle between Amazon and Alibaba will continue to heat up as both companies look to grow internationally.For Alibaba
column9: this solid growth in cloud computing and digital media is a good sign for its ongoing war with Amazon. It goes without saying that these segments are answers to Amazon Web Services and Amazon Prime Video
column10: so it must be encouraging for Alibaba investors to see the Chinese giant also succeeding in these endeavors.However
column11: Alibaba's biggest threat to Amazon could be something mentioned further down the report.""New Retail""The fight between Alibaba and Amazon may actually come down to Alibaba's ""New Retail"" concept. According to Alibaba's earnings report
column12: New Retail is a strategy that will allow the company to ""tap into the entire US$4.8 trillion retail sector in China by eliminating the distinction between online and offline commerce.""To execute this plan
column13: Alibaba is partnering with several brick-and-mortar retailers. The company detailed its new relationships with a pair of retailers in the report
column14: and it looks like Alibaba is really putting some serious cash into the idea.Alibaba's first partnership was with Sanjiang Shopping Club
column15: a leading neighborhood grocery chain in the Zhejiang Province. In November
column16: Alibaba scooped up a 35% stake in the chain for $302 million
column17: and now Sanjiang will pilot a new shopping format powered by Alibaba's technology.Alibaba also detailed its $2.6 billion offer for a controlling stake in Intime Retail Group
column18: an operator of department stores and shopping malls throughout China.Of course
column19: Amazon has also been busy with its new brick-and-mortar concepts. The company has recently opened bookstores in California
column20: Oregon
column21: and Washington
column22: with locations in Illinois
column23: Massachusetts
column24: New Jersey
column25: and New York coming soon. Some reports have indicated that Amazon has plans to open hundreds of bookstores throughout the country.(Also Read:Amazon to Open Brick & Mortar Bookstore in   New York City)Beyond these bookstores
column26: Amazon is also exploring a revolutionary new retail concept known as ""Amazon Go."" The company recently soft-launched the first Amazon Go convenience store in Seattle
column27: and it will be open to the public early this year.Amazon Go operates with a ""Just Walk Out"" shopping format that is devoid of cashiers and check outs and thus will not have long customer queues. As customers shop
column28: a mobile app adds items to their virtual cart
column29: generates a digital receipt
column30: and charges customers from their Amazon account.(Also Read:Will Amazon's Convenience Stores Transform   Retail?)According to a report fromThe Wall Street Journal
column31: Amazon has a broader plan to open over 2000 brick-and-mortar stores in three different formats depending on the success of the concepts.What Does It Mean?Both companies have not been shy about their plans for global dominance
column32: and Alibaba commented on the success of its international expansion in its latest report. These two brands are massive e-commerce players
column33: but their entrances into cloud computing and digital media underscore their desires to become global factors in several industries.With that said
column34: it looks like Alibaba and Amazon's biggest impact will continue to be in the world of retail. These companies have been integral in the worldwide shift to online shopping; now they want to take over what is left of traditional retail.From our domestic perspective
column35: it might seem like Amazon has a big head start in the battle to rule the world. Today's report tells us Alibaba is not that far behind.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Is Building an AI Monster;1/24/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsWhen investors think of artificial intelligence stocks
column3: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) isn't usually the first name that comes to mind. Many consumers   viewAmazon.com
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) as the leader in at-home AI
column5: due to the success of the   company's Echo device
column6: while ""Watson"" fromInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) is arguably the top turn-key artificial intelligence solution   for enterprise-level entities.Those investors who believe AI is the future
column7: however
column8: may want   to put MSFT stock back on their radar as a way to play the   movement.makeArticleAd();The software giant's recent acquisition of Maluuba speaks   volumes about its artificial intelligence ambitions and what it   actually wants to ""do"" with it.What's Maluuba?Maluuba isn't a household name
column9: but within artificial   intelligence circles (and these are VP of AI Research Harry Shum's   words)
column10: ""Maluuba's vision is to advance toward a more general   artificial intelligence by creating literate machines that can   think
column11: reason and communicate like humans - a vision exactly in   line with ours.""In simpler terms
column12: the AI agent doesn't just serve up a   canned response to the most likely question it thinks it's being   asked based on keywords. Rather
column13: Maluuba understands the words   being used
column14: their context
column15: and what information is desired. The utility of such a tool   could vary from finding a specific qualification or experience   from within a company's ranks to a chatbot that actually works   without talking in circles.Those are just small examples of how a   next-generation artificial intelligence - called artificial   general intelligence
column16: in this case - could be used and monetized.   In September
column17: when Microsoft assembled 5
column18: 000 engineers to work on   AI
column19: Shum specifically pointed out that such a technology could   not only make Cortana and Skype more potent
column20: butcould be incorporated into Microsoft's popular   cloud-based apps such as Office 365 and Azureto enhance the ease-of-use factor for those platforms.7 Blue-Chip Dividend Stocks That Are Dead       Weight Right NowYou Ain't Seen Nothin' YetIt's difficult to see
column21: or sense
column22: but Microsoft is developing   its AGI know-how with as much of a philosophical bent as it is a   technical one.Just in time
column23: too. AsCIO's Matt Kapko observed in December
column24: ""While machine learning has generated tremendous interest   throughout the enterprise
column25: a wide gap still exists between   research and beneficial use cases in the real world.""The ramped-up focus on AI (and this happened well before   Maluuba) couldn't have come at a better time for Microsoft
column26: either
column27: and by extension
column28: for owners of MSFT stock.Calling a spade a spade
column29: Microsoft largely missed out on the   early phase of artificial intelligence; now it's play catch up.   It's playing it well
column30: though
column31: particularly focusing on ""bots"" -   or chatbots that can intelligently text-chat with a user - as the   organization believes that's the interface that makes the most   sense of such a platform. This kind of AI could potentially   replace many of the touch-based apps found on your smartphone   withone voice-based conversational tool that actually   does everythingthe way you want it done.President and principal analyst of Moor Insights &   Strategy
column32: Patrick Moorhead
column33: has taken notice
column34: too
column35: commenting   last month that ""Microsoft surprised everyone in 2016 and I'm   expecting more surprises in 2017."" Specifically
column36: Moorhead   believes Microsoft will unveil an artificial intelligence that   will not only be more powerful to individual consumers than   Amazon's Echo
column37: but will also serve a specific business (read   ""revenue-bearing"") function. Incorporating Maluuba's know-how   will only move the company closer to that end zone.At stake is a piece of a market thatcould be worth $16.6 billion by 2022. Tractica thinks the artificial intelligence market willbe worth $36.8 billion by 2025. Both are a far cry from 2016's estimated global AI revenue of   $644 million.Now
column38: all of a sudden
column39: Microsoft's intense interest makes   sense.Bottom Line for MSFT StockNone of this is to suggest that that MSFT stock should be   viewed first and foremost as an artificial intelligence stock
column40: now or later. It's still a productivity-solutions stock
column41: and AI   simply helps the organization provide better solutions.7 Stocks to Buy to Double Your Money in       2017Nevertheless
column42: Microsoft may well be working on one of the most   marketable uses of artificial intelligence
column43: serving enterprises   in a very real way - beyond the home-utility that the Echo   provides
column44: while not imposing overkill with something   like IBM's Watson. MSFT owners may soon find Microsoft quietly   winning the AI war with an elegant
column45: customizable solution to real   challenges.Even if few have come to fully appreciate just how potent this   artificial intelligence product is.As of this writing
column46: James Brumley did not hold a position     in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top Dividend Stocks to Buy for Safety in       201710 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print       Money7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Is Building an AI   Monsterappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Berkshire Hathaway Sold $2 Billion of Wal-Mart Stock: Time for You to Sell
column2: Too?;1/24/2017;"Warren Buffett. Image source: The Motley Fool.Warren Buffett'sBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE: BRK-A) (NYSE: BRK-B) has been unloading its position inWal-Mart(NYSE: WMT) for more than a year. But in the third quarter of   2016
column3: its selling accelerated as it dumped 70% of its remaining   stake
column4: or about $2 billion.makeArticleAd();Though Buffett has pooh-poohed technology through his career
column5: the Oracle of Omaha conceded at Berkshire's shareholder meeting   last year that brick-and-mortar retailers would have trouble   keeping up withAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) .At the conference
column6: Buffett called Amazon founder Jeff Bezos a   ""genius
column7: saying
column8: ""We haven't seen many businessmen like him.   ""Overwhelmingly
column9: he's taken things you and I've been buying and   he's figured out a way to make us happier buying those products
column10: either by fast delivery or prices or whatever it may be
column11: and   that's remarkable.""That conclusion has likely led Berkshire to shed its stake in   Wal-Mart in recent quarters as it is squarely in Amazon's path.   Berkshire may have dumped more Wal-Mart shares in the fourth   quarter of 2016.Wal-Mart at a crossroadsIt's never good when Buffett
column12: probably the most respected   investor of all time
column13: is selling your stock. A look at Wal-Mart's   performance also may explain why he sold
column14: especially compared to   Amazon
column15: which has been the best-performing stock in the last 20   years.WMTdata byYCharts.But as savvy investors know
column16: past performance is not a   guarantee of future returns.Wal-Mart today is at a crossroads. CEO Doug McMillon has taken   several steps to revamp the company since taking the helm three   years ago. He's raised the base wage to $10 per hour
column17: streamlined   the promotion process
column18: and made cleaning up stores and customer   service a priority. The company has also invested billions in   e-commerce
column19: opening hundreds of grocery pick-up kiosks
column20: and   acquiring start-up Jet.com for $3.3 billion.Brick-and-mortar retailers got hammered over the holiday   season
column21: but Wal-Mart has not reported holiday sales. The retail   giant is also coming off eight straight quarters of comparable   sales growth
column22: a sign it's outperforming the broader retail   industry.Because of its investments in higher wages and e-commerce
column23: the   company is expecting profits to fall in fiscal 2017
column24: which ends   this month
column25: then be flat during fiscal 2018
column26: and return to growth   in fiscal 2019. In other words
column27: investors will need to be patient   as the company continues to invest.What's a shareholder to doWal-Mart investors should know what to expect from such a   stock. It's a defensive dividend payer that has steadily   increased its dividends for 43 years in a row
column28: making it a   Dividend Aristocrat. Unlike a volatile stock like Amazon
column29: which   has the potential to blockbuster returns but also put up   significant losses
column30: Wal-Mart will be a stable slow-growth   investment. The stock is unlikely to significantly outperform the   market
column31: especially given the challenges in retail and the   investments it's making. The nature of the company's business as   a low-cost provider means that the stock is essentially   recession-proof
column32: and investors often flock to it when it looks   like tough times are ahead.So the decision to sell Wal-Mart should probably be determined   by your investing style. If you're a risk-averse investor looking   for modest growth and a solid dividend yield at 3%
column33: then Wal-Mart   looks a like a good choice. If you're looking for higher   potential growth
column34: perhaps follow Buffett and dump Wal-Mart for a   company whose profits are actually increasing.10 stocks we like better than Wal-Mart StoresWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why Alphabet Inc (GOOG) Stock Is Unstoppable Despite Any Pitfalls;1/24/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading Tips""What happened?"" It's a question often posed to celebrity crushes that are now decades past their prime. And it seems like an appropriate inquiry forAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column3: NASDAQ:GOOGL). GOOG stock is the anchor among the so-called ""FANG"" stocks
column4: which includeFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column5: Amazon.com
column6: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN)
column7: and the hot-runningNetflix
column8: Inc. (NASDAQ:NFLX). Arguably
column9: GOOG is the most culturally significant of the bunch
column10: yet its recent performance has left a lot to be desired.Source: ShutterstockFor 2016
column11: GOOG stock returned a whopping 4% even. To put that underperformance into perspective
column12: Alphabet Inc gave shareholders 48% returns on average during the 2000s decade when it was first introduced to the markets.makeArticleAd();Inclusive of last year
column13: its lifetime average is now a little bit above 30%. In fact
column14: compared to the other FANGs
column15: GOOG stock is the absolute worst. And while it's almost identical to Facebook's overall performance
column16: both Amazon and Netflix put Alphabet Inc to shame.That's the kind of post-mortem talk you hear on CNBC when reality finally catches up to a speculative company. Certainly
column17: it's not the kind of metric you expect from a bigger-than-life-itself organization like GOOGL. I mean
column18: this is a company that was thecenterpieceof a Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson movie - and they totally agreed to it!But just like the movie's plot
column19: outside appearances can be deceiving. Here are a few reasons why you should still give GOOG stock a chance.GOOG Is More Than a Search EngineFirst off
column20: Alphabet Inc isn't just a search engine. Yes
column21: I completely understand the argument that the vast
column22: overwhelming majority of its multi-billion dollar business derives from advertisements. However
column23: there are unmistakable signs of diversity.10 Stocks to Buy to Survive a ""Trumpsy-Turvy""     2017As InvestorPlace contributorWill Ashworth points out
column24: in the third quarter of fiscal year 2016
column25: ""GOOGL generated $2.4 billion in other revenues
column26: 39% higher year-over-year and 12% sequentially. This represented 10.9% of the Google segment's overall revenue of $22.3 billion. For the first nine months of the year
column27: Google's other revenues came to $6.7 billion
column28: 31% higher than a year earlier."" Essentially
column29: Alphabet Inc can spin off a brand new business separate from advertisements
column30: and it would do just fine.Indeed
column31: GOOG stock is backed by coverage of over157 products
column32: according to another InvestorPlace colleague
column33: Aaron Levitt. While a good chunk of the offerings are web-based applications
column34: such as Gmail
column35: Maps and Chrome
column36: ""the firm has continued to plow some big-time dollars onto the physical device market."" As we move forward
column37: GOOG stock may be less recognized as an app investment
column38: and more as a consumer electronics investment similar toApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) orSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE).As both Ashworth and Levitt note
column39: diversification towards physical devices and non-core businesses don't necessarily endear folks to GOOG stock. Many of these divisions are money losers. The Motorola venture was a particularly rotten deal.However
column40: I wholeheartedly agree with Ashworth's thesis: ""As painful as it is for investors to see Alphabet pour good money after bad into its Other Bets
column41: GOOGL stock depends on it. Because its legacy business likely won't be this profitable 10 years from now.""Alphabet Inc Has the Ultimate Trump CardPerhaps most analysts bullish towards GOOG stock have laid out similar arguments - Alphabet Inc is more than just a one trick pony. Considering all the evidence
column42: it would be foolish to attempt to counter it. But allow me to shamelessly grab the ultra-low hanging fruit. Just what the heck is wrong with being a one trick pony?3 Reasons Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Will Keep     Delivering in 2017We're not talking aboutPolaroidhere.Click to EnlargeBy investing in GOOG stock
column43: you are taking ownership in not only a massive company
column44: but a cultural phenomenon.Consider that among the mostpopular search engineson the internet
column45: Google beats out second-best competitor Bing by a margin of 300%! Startlingly
column46: the gap between first and fifth place is nearly 1
column47: 200%. Against the bottom run of the top ten
column48: the gap is nearly 12
column49: 000%.In other words
column50: if you think that Google will ever be upended by anyone else
column51: think again. No other investment besides GOOG stock has such dominance over their industries that people refer to it by the company name. WeGooglethings on the web. And until the day I hear ""I'lliPhoneyou
column52: people can rest assured in their GOOG position.Put in the simplest of terms
column53: unless there are Russian ICBMs raining down on us
column54: I would never short GOOG stock. The only caveat would be to point out instances of potential technical weakness. Even then
column55: the volatility would likely be on a short-term basis. As I stated above
column56: Alphabet Inc has too much of a powerful brand to ever fail.As of this writing
column57: Josh Enomoto was long SNE.More From InvestorPlace10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You     Back10 Dividend Growth Stocks That Simply Print     MoneyThe postWhy Alphabet Inc (GOOG) Stock Is Unstoppable Despite Any Pitfallsappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Stock Faceoff: Wal-Mart Stores Inc vs Target Corporation (WMT
column2: TGT);1/24/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn the back of astrong holiday season
column4: retailers are back in the spotlight.makeArticleAd();To start out the new year
column5: we want to take the time to circle back to two of our previous long ideas on some of the giants in the retail industry:Wal-MartStores Inc(WMT) andTargetCorporation(TGT).We recommended both of these companies to investors in 2015. So far
column6: both picks have underperformed. WMT is up 1% since our call
column7: vs. 14% for theS&P 500. TGT has dropped by 11% while the S&P is up 6%.Both stocks still look sound
column8: while earning our Attractive rating.Since these are two of the largest retailers in America
column9: and direct competitors
column10: it seems fair to ask: which is the better stock for investors in 2017?In this article
column11: we will judge Wal-Mart and Target on five key categories:ProfitabilityValuationCash Flow YieldCorporate GovernanceGrowth OpportunitiesTwo stocks enter. One stock leaves. Who will emerge the champion in this faceoff of retail giants?Wal-Mart vs Target  - ProfitabilityFrom 1998 to 2015
column12: Wal-Mart dominated this category. The company earned a superior return on invested capital (ROIC) in every single year over that time frame. Per Figure 1
column13: however
column14: that dominance evaporated last year.Figure 1: Wal-Mart Vs. Target ROIC: 1998-CurrentSources: New Constructs
column15: LLC and company filings.Target's ROIC has surged in the past few years as it hassold off unprofitable business linesand refocused on its core competencies. Wal-Mart's ROIC has gone in the opposite direction as it hasoverpaid for acquisitionsand seen its already thin margins further squeezed byrising labor costs.The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksThough Wal-Mart's profitability dominated Target for most of the last twenty years
column16: we've seen Target make some big improvements while Wal-Mart has faltered. Right now
column17: Target is the more profitable company
column18: and we expect that edge to last.Scoreboard: Target 1
column19: Wal-Mart 0WMT and TGT Stock ValuationsBoth of these stocks are cheap. A variety of factors
column20: from low growth potential
column21: to theevergreen fears overAmazon.com
column22: Inc.(AMZN)
column23: have weighed on their stock prices.WMT was up 13% in 2016
column24: while TGT was flat
column25: but both stocks are still quite cheap based on their current profits. Both stocks have a price to economic book value ratio (PEBV) of just 0.6. This ratio means the market expects a permanent 40% decline in after-tax operating profit (NOPAT) for both companies.While it's certainly fair to be wary of the risks facing traditional retailers
column26: such a pessimistic outlook seems unwarranted. Both Wal-Mart and Target are appealingly cheap
column27: which makes this round a push.Scoreboard: Target 1.5
column28: Wal-Mart 0.5Let's continue to evaluate these two giants…Cash Flow YieldsCash is king. This fact goes double for companies like Wal-Mart and Target that require heavy capital investment and return a large amount of capital to shareholders through dividends and buybacks.Both Target and Wal-Mart generate substantialfree cash flow. Per Figure 2
column29: that cash flow comes in different ways. Wal-Mart provides a steady stream of cash year after year
column30: whereas Target has oscillated between years of great free cash flow and years of low or even negative cash flow.Figure 2: Wal-Mart Vs. Target Free Cash Flow Yield: 1999-CurrentSources: New Constructs
column31: LLC and company filings.While Wal-Mart may have the more consistent stream of cash flow
column32: Target has had a better free cash flow yield in four out of the past six years
column33: and a superior average yield in that timeframe
column34: so Target wins this round.Scoreboard: Target 2.5
column35: Wal-Mart 0.5Growth OpportunitiesNeither of these companies offers investors significant growth potential from their impressive brick-and-mortar footprints. Target's sales have been flat to down recently
column36: and it'sfocusing on small storesthat offer only incremental growth going forward. Wal-Mart has announced that it'sslowing the paceof its new store openings over the next couple years.Online sales have been rosier. Target announced online salesgrew by 26%in the most recent quarter. Wal-Mart acquired therapidly growing Jet.comin a deal that
column37: while richly valued
column38: should provide a significant boost to its e-commerce efforts.Consensus analyst forecasts have Wal-Mart's revenue growing by 1.3% compounded annually over the next two years. That's not a number to generate much excitement
column39: but it's better than their projection for a 1.9% compounded annual decline in Target's sales. Wal-Mart wins this round.Scoreboard: Target 2.5
column40: Wal-Mart 1.5Corporate GovernanceCorporate governance
column41: especially executive compensation
column42: is a critical and underappreciated aspect of investment analysis. High quality executive compensation plans hold executives accountable for capital allocation and align their interests with shareholders. Low quality compensation plans can encourage executives to engage in activities thatdestroy shareholder value.Both Wal-Mart and Target start off great by tying a significant portion of executive's long-term stock grants to ROIC. Even better
column43: they both make an effort to calculate an accurate ROIC and account foroff-balance sheet debtdue to operating leases.Digging deeper though
column44: Target's ROIC methodology is more rigorous. It not only capitalizes operating leases
column45: it also adds back theimplied interest componentof those leases. Meanwhile
column46: Wal-Mart uses pretax operating income rather than NOPAT
column47: which along with some other unorthodox practices makes its ROIC number less reliable.We applaud those firms that make the effort to hold executives accountable to performance metrics that are directly aligned with shareholder value creation. Though ROIC is a simple concept
column48: it is a rathermajor undertaking to get right
column49: especially across multiple companies. Target's efforts here are noteworthy.Wal-Mart does better than most companies we cover at aligning executive incentives with shareholder value
column50: but Target's executive compensation plan is one of the gold standards in corporate America. Target wins this round and the matchScoreboard: Target 3.5
column51: Wal-Mart 1.5Our Conclusion: If You Must Choose One…You can't go wrong with either of these stocks. They both have great track records of profitability and cheap valuations. If you have to choose just one
column52: though
column53: Target's superior ROIC
column54: cash flow
column55: and executive compensation practices make it the better pick in 2017 for investors.7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in 2017This article originally publishedhereon January 3
column56: 2017.Disclosure: David Trainer and Sam McBride receive no compensation to write about any specific stock
column57: sector
column58: style
column59: or theme.Article by Sam McBride

column1: Obama Knows What's Really Killing Jobs. Is Trump Listening?;1/24/2017;"President Donald Trump has made jobs
column2: and bringing them back   to the United States
column3: a key part of his platform. That was a   major theme during his campaign and his first acts in office have   included opting out of trade deals
column4: saluting companies that have   made hiring announcements
column5: and promising hefty tariffs for those   sending work outside the country.It's a message that has played well to his base. That makes   sense because a laid-off auto worker or former factory worker   wants to hear that things can go back to where they were.The problem
column6: and it's one that Barack Obama laid out in his   final interview as president
column7: is that American jobs moving   overseas is not the long-term issue. Instead
column8: America's former   commander in chief said
column9: the issue is robots and automation. And
column10: Obama pointed out
column11: it's not just factories. It's also retail jobs   being lost due to sales moving online to retailers led byAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column12: which employs about 200
column13: 000 people
column14: but well   less than the combined total of the retailers it's   displacing.makeArticleAd();Amazon uses a mix of humans and robots in its warehouse. Image   source: Amazon.Where are all the jobs going?Appearing on thePod Save Americanpodcast hosted by a group of his former aides
column15: Obama told Jon   Favreau
column16: Jon Lovett
column17: Dan Pfeiffer
column18: and Tommy Vietor
column19: that the   robots are coming. It wasn't presented as a rebuff to Trump
column20: just   as a statement of truth
column21: delivered by a man who no longer has to   run for office.""The fact is and the data shows this
column22: the jobs that are going   away are going away primarily due to automation
column23: he said.   ""Automation is relentless and it's going to accelerate.""In the Jan. 19 podcast
column24: Obama cited examples including the   potential for driverless Uber vehicles along with office workers   being displaced when their work becomes automated. He laid out   that this is not just an issue involving factory jobs
column25: but   multiple segments of the employment market.""You saw what happened to retail stores sales this past   Christmas. Amazon and online sales is killing traditional retail
column26: and what's true there is going to be true throughout our   economy
column27: he said. ""We are going to have to start thinking about   where do jobs come from and how much government involvement we   want in the marketplace.""Facts back up ObamaWhat Obama said is supported by numbers from Rice University's   Moshe Vardi. The professor of computational engineering has   written about how manufacturing employment has been falling for   more than 30 years
column28: while U.S. manufacturing output is near   its all-time high.""Job losses due to automation and robotics are often   overlooked in discussions about the unexpected rise of outside   political candidates like Trump and Bernie Sanders
column29: said Vardi   in a July 2016press release. ""U.S. factories are not disappearing; they simply aren't   employing human workers.""What we want to hear vs. what we need to hearA president with just hours left in office has a luxury that   current politicians do not. He doesn't t have another election to   win so he can stop peddling easy answers.Obama acknowledged that tougher negotiations with Mexico or   China might bring some jobs back for the short term
column30: but that's   clearly not the underlying problem. What the current   administration needs to deal with is that automation and robots   have changed the nature of work. That change might be delayed in   some cases because foreign workers are cheaper than automating
column31: but that's really just a question of time.The current administration has a choice when it comes to jobs.   It can focus on short-term victories that won't change the ending   or it can look at the more complicated question of how to evolve   a workforce for the jobs that will exist tomorrow not the ones   from today and yesterday.10 stocks we like better than Wal-MartWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock     tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter     they have run for over a decade
column34: the Motley Fool Stock     Advisor
column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are theten best stocksfor investors to buy right now… and Wal-Mart wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as ofDecember 12
